Popliteal: Of or pertaining to the ham; in the region of the ham, or behind the knee joint; as, the popliteal space.
Pecopteris: An extensive genus of fossil ferns; -- so named from the regular comblike arrangement of the leaflets.
Polycotyledon: A plant that has many, or more than two, cotyledons in the seed.
Pupivorous: Feeding on the pupæ of insects.
Purfled: Ornamented; decorated; esp., embroidered on the edges.
Poetry: The art of apprehending and interpreting ideas by the faculty of imagination; the art of idealizing in thought and in expression.
Pongo: Any large ape; especially, the chimpanzee and the orang-outang.
Prescient: Having knowledge of coming events; foreseeing; conscious beforehand.
Pattinsons process: A process of desilverizing argentiferous lead by repeated meltings and skimmings, which concentrate the silver in the molten bath, the final skimmings being nearly pure lad. The processwas invented in 1833 by Hugh Lee Pattinson, an English metallurgist.
Populous: Abounding in people; full of inhabitants; containing many inhabitants in proportion to the extent of the country.
Plenicorn: A ruminant having solid horns or antlers, as the deer.
Parulidae: A natural family of New World warblers.
payoff: profit or gain from an action; -- used broadly; as, lots of effort with little payoff.
Prophetic: Containing, or pertaining to, prophecy; foretelling events; as, prophetic writings; prophetic dreams; -- used with of before the thing foretold.
parsimoniousness: The quality of being parsimonious; extreme care in spending money; reluctance to spend money unnecessarily.
Picoline: Any one of three isometric bases (C6H7N) related to pyridine, and obtained from bone oil, acrolein ammonia, and coal-tar naphtha, as colorless mobile liquids of strong odor; -- called also methyl pyridine.
Petite: Small, little; of a woman or girl, of small size and trim figure.
Polymerize: To change into another substance having the same atomic proportions, but a higher molecular weight; to undergo polymerization; thus, aldehyde polymerizes in forming paraldehyde.
Puer: The dung of dogs, used as an alkaline steep in tanning.
Pupillary: Of or pertaining to a pupil or ward.
Pluperfect: More than perfect; past perfect; -- said of the tense which denotes that an action or event was completed at or before the time of another past action or event.
Pennaceous: Like or pertaining to a normal feather.
Presumably: In a presumable manner; by, or according to, presumption.
Peribolos: In ancient architecture, an inclosed court, esp., one surrounding a temple.
Planimeter: An instrument for measuring the area of any plane figure, however irregular, by passing a tracer around the bounding line; a platometer.
parenthetic: Of the nature of a parenthesis; pertaining to, or expressed in, or as if in, a parenthesis; as, a parenthetical clause; a parenthetic remark; a parenthetical style.
Pteridology: That department of botany which treats of ferns.
Paul: An Italian silver coin. See Paolo.
Paum: To palm off by fraud; to cheat at cards.
Presumable: Such as may be presumed or supposed to be true; that seems entitled to belief without direct evidence.
Preachment: A religious harangue; a sermon; -- used derogatively.
Puff-leg: Any one of numerous species of beautiful humming birds of the genus Eriocnemis having large tufts of downy feathers on the legs.
Prepollent: An extra first digit, or rudiment of a digit, on the preaxial side of the pollex.
Pathogen: Any microorganism which causes disease; a pathogenic organism; an infectious microorganism; a bacterium, virus, or other agent which can cause disease by infection; -- opposed to zymogene.  The spelling pathogene is now archaic.
Party-colored: Colored with different tints; variegated; as, a party-colored flower.
Pilot flag: The flag hoisted at the fore by a vessel desiring a pilot, in the United States the union jack, in Great Britain the British union jack with a white border.
Prosopulmonata: A division of pulmonate mollusks having the breathing organ situated on the neck, as in the common snail.
Pinfeather: A feather not fully developed; esp., a rudimentary feather just emerging through the skin.
Polyoptron: A glass through which objects appear multiplied, but diminished in size.
Phylum: One of the larger divisions of the animal kingdom; a branch; a grand division.
Parnassia: A genus of herbs growing in wet places, and having white flowers; grass of Parnassus.
Paralipomenon: A title given in the Douay Bible to the Books of Chronicles.
Plenist: One who holds that all space is full of matter.
Preconizate: To proclaim; to publish; also, to summon; to call.
Praisable: Fit to be praised; praise-worthy; laudable; commendable.
Prosiliency: The act of leaping forth or forward; projection.
Preconceit: An opinion or notion formed beforehand; a preconception.
Poorhouse: A dwelling for a number of paupers maintained at public expense; an almshouse; a workhouse.
Precise: Having determinate limitations; exactly or sharply defined or stated; definite; exact; nice; not vague or equivocal; as, precise rules of morality.
Pavan: A stately and formal Spanish dance for which full state costume is worn; -- so called from the resemblance of its movements to those of the peacock.
Phytivorous: Feeding on plants or herbage; phytophagous; as, phytivorous animals.
Posteriorly: Subsequently in time; also, behind in position.
Phosphorescence: The quality or state of being phosphorescent; or the act of phosphorescing.
Prebendate: To invest with the office of prebendary; to present to a prebend.
Peduncular: Of or pertaining to a peduncle; growing from a peduncle; as, a peduncular tendril.
Perturber: One who, or that which, perturbs, or cause perturbation.
Pre\u00ebxistent: Existing previously; preceding existence; as, a preëxistent state.
Pyrogravure: Pyrography; also, a design or picture made by pyrography.
Priorship: The state or office of prior; priorate.
Physique: The natural constitution, or physical structure, of a person.
plains wanderer: A bird of the genus Pedionomus (Pedionomus torquatus) of New South Wales, the only species in the genus.  Pedionomus is the only genus of the family Pedionomidae of the order Passeriformes and the plains wanderer is thus the only species in the family.  The total world population (ca. 2000) is estimated to be 5 to 10 thousand.
Pedatifid: Cleft in a pedate manner, but having the lobes distinctly connected at the base; -- said of a leaf.
Participator: One who participates, or shares with another; a partaker.
Primipara: A woman who bears a child for the first time.
Pleasurable: Capable of affording pleasure or satisfaction; gratifying; abounding in pleasantness or pleasantry.
Parenthood: The state of a parent; the office or character of a parent.
Pediatrics: That branch of medical science which treats of the hygiene and diseases of infants and children.
Plethron: A long measure of 100 Greek, or 101 English, feet; also, a square measure of 10,000 Greek feet.
Pagoda sleeve: A funnel-shaped sleeve arranged to show the sleeve lining and an inner sleeve.
Piscary: The right or privilege of fishing in another man's waters.
Plugging: The act of stopping with a plug.
Penitential: A book formerly used by priests hearing confessions, containing rules for the imposition of penances; -- called also penitential book.
Paviage: A contribution or a tax for paving streets or highways.
Pulpit: Of or pertaining to the pulpit, or preaching; as, a pulpit orator; pulpit eloquence.
Polysepalous: Having the sepals separate from each other.
paperwork: Work that involves handling or writing documents such as forms, letters, reports, sales records, etc.
Purificator: One who, or that which, purifies; a purifier.
Penitent: One who repents of sin; one sorrowful on account of his transgressions.
Preadamite: An inhabitant of the earth before Adam.
Paranthracene: An inert isomeric modification of anthracene.
Perioplic: Of or pertaining to the periople; connected with the periople.
Petromastoid: Of or pertaining to the petrous and mastoid parts of the temporal bone, periotic.
Proprietary: Belonging, or pertaining, to a proprietor; considered as property; owned; as, proprietary medicine.
Pig-sticking: Boar hunting; -- so called by Anglo-Indians.
Poikilocyte: An irregular form of corpuscle found in the blood in cases of profound anæmia, probably a degenerated red blood corpuscle.
Professory: Of or pertaining to a professor; professorial.
packthread: A strong three-ply thread or small twine used to sew or tie packs or packages.
Positive: That which is capable of being affirmed; reality.
Prison: To imprison; to shut up in, or as in, a prison; to confine; to restrain from liberty.
Pluriparous: Producing several young at a birth; as, a pluriparous animal.
Proeguminal: Serving to predispose; predisposing; as, a proeguminal cause of disease.
Presser: One who, or that which, presses.
Polypite: One of the feeding zooids, or polyps, of a coral, hydroid, or siphonophore; a hydranth. See Illust. of Campanularian.
Persistence: The quality or state of being persistent; staying or continuing quality; hence, in an unfavorable sense, doggedness; obstinacy.
Preponderation: The act or state of preponderating; preponderance; as, a preponderation of reasons.
Prudence: The quality or state of being prudent; wisdom in the way of caution and provision; discretion; carefulness; hence, also, economy; frugality.
Polypharmacy: The act or practice of prescribing too many medicines.
Pectose: An amorphous carbohydrate found in the vegetable kingdom, esp. in unripe fruits.  It is associated with cellulose, and is converted into substances of the pectin group.
Proboscis: A hollow organ or tube attached to the head, or connected with the mouth, of various animals, and generally used in taking food or drink; a snout; a trunk.
promotion: The act of promoting, advancing, or encouraging; the act of exalting in rank or honor; also, the condition of being advanced, encouraged, or exalted in honor; preferment.
Postilion: One who rides and guides the first pair of horses of a coach or post chaise; also, one who rides one of the horses when one pair only is used.
Phosphene: A luminous impression produced through excitation of the retina by some cause other than the impingement upon it of rays of light, as by pressure upon the eyeball when the lids are closed.  Cf. After-image.
Pear-shaped: Of the form of a pear.
Phrenograph: An instrument for registering the movements of the diaphragm, or midriff, in respiration.
Postdiluvian: One who lived after the flood.
Postdiluvial: Being or happening after the flood in Noah's days.
Postmeridian: Coming after the sun has passed the meridian; being in, or belonging to, the afternoon. (Abbrev. P. M.)
Protuberant: Prominent, or excessively prominent; bulging beyond the surrounding or adjacent surface; swelling; as, a protuberant joint; a protuberant eye.
Pottle: A liquid measure of four pints.
Prohibiter: One who prohibits or forbids; a forbidder; an interdicter.
Pistareen: An old Spanish silver coin of the value of about twenty cents.
Punkie: A minute biting fly of the genus Ceratopogon or allied genus of the family Chironomidæ, found in swarms in various densely wooded or mountaneous regions.
Palsy: To affect with palsy, or as with palsy; to deprive of action or energy; to paralyze.
Portague: A Portuguese gold coin formerly current, and variously estimated to be worth from three and one half to four and one half pounds sterling.
Parisology: The use of equivocal or ambiguous words.
Pressiroster: One of a tribe of wading birds (Pressirostres) including those which have a compressed beak, as the plovers.
Perigastric: Surrounding the stomach; -- applied to the body cavity of Bryozoa and various other Invertebrata.
Professoriate: The body of professors, or the professorial staff, in a university or college.
Poulaine: A long pointed shoe. See Cracowes.
Poundal: A unit of force based upon the pound, foot, and second, being the force which, acting on a pound avoirdupois for one second, causes it to acquire by the of that time a velocity of one foot per second. It is about equal to the weight of half an ounce, and is 13,825 dynes.
Pousse-caf\u00e9: A drink served after coffee at dinner, usually one of several liqueurs, or cordials, of different specific gravities poured so as to remain separate in layers; hence, such a drink of cordials served at any time.
Pewter: A hard, tough, but easily fusible, alloy, originally consisting of tin with a little lead, but afterwards modified by the addition of copper, antimony, or bismuth.
Plica: A disease of the hair (Plica polonica), in which it becomes twisted and matted together. The disease is of Polish origin, and is hence called also Polish plait.
Plumassary: A plume or collection of ornamental feathers.
Paracelsian: A follower of Paracelsus or his practice or teachings.
paltriness: The state or quality of being paltry.
Plot: To plan; to scheme; to devise; to contrive secretly.
Plow: To labor with, or as with, a plow; to till or turn up the soil with a plow; to prepare the soil or bed for anything.
Plop: Act of plopping; the sound made in plopping.
Ploy: To form a column from a line of troops on some designated subdivision; -- the opposite of deploy.
Poriform: Resembling a pore, or small puncture.
Plod: To walk on slowly or heavily.
Ploc: A mixture of hair and tar for covering the bottom of a ship.
Progenitor: An ancestor in the direct line; a forefather.
Propagator: One who propagates; one who continues or multiplies.
Pillowed: Provided with a pillow or pillows; having the head resting on, or as on, a pillow.
Preponderate: To exceed in weight; hence, to incline or descend, as the scale of a balance; figuratively, to exceed in influence, power, etc.; hence; to incline to one side; as, the affirmative side preponderated.
Potoroo: Any small kangaroo belonging to Hypsiprymnus, Bettongia, and allied genera, native of Australia and Tasmania. Called also kangaroo rat.
Parallel vise: A vise with jaws so guided as to remain parallel.
Paleface: A white person; -- an appellation supposed to have been applied to the whites by the American Indians.
Pudu: A very small deer (Pudua humilis), native of the Chilian Andes. It has simple spikelike antlers, only two or three inches long.
Polygoneutic: Having two or more broods in a season.
Putresce: To become putrescent or putrid; to putrefy.
Palinode: An ode recanting, or retracting, a former one; also, a repetition of an ode.
Pantaloon: A ridiculous character, or an old dotard, in the Italian comedy; also, a buffoon in pantomimes.
Plotter: One who plots or schemes; a contriver; a conspirator; a schemer.
Pension: To grant a pension to; to pay a regular stipend to; in consideration of service already performed; -- sometimes followed by off; as, to pension off a servant.
Peanut butter: A paste made by mixing ground fresh roasted peanuts with a small quantity of water or oil, and used chiefly as a relish on sandwiches, etc.
PAYE: the British system of withholding tax.
Plash: The branch of a tree partly cut or bent, and bound to, or intertwined with, other branches.
Puristic: Of or pertaining to purists or purism.
Plasm: A mold or matrix in which anything is cast or formed to a particular shape.
Presumptively: By presumption, or supposition grounded or probability; presumably.
Principal: A leader, chief, or head; one who takes the lead; one who acts independently, or who has controlling authority or influence; as, the principal of a faction, a school, a firm, etc.; -- distinguished from a subordinate, abettor, auxiliary, or assistant.
Phenolate: A compound of phenol analogous to a salt.
Pacificator: One who, or that which, pacifies; a peacemaker.
Pilgarlic: One who has lost his hair by disease; a sneaking fellow, or one who is hardly used.
patio furniture: Furniture such as chairs, tables, settees or loungers, suited for use on a patio{3}, i.e. such that will not be damaged by exposure to rain, sun or other outdoor elements.
Pennon: A pennant; a flag or streamer.
Pterosaurian: Of or pertaining to the Pterosauria.
Please: To afford or impart pleasure; to excite agreeable emotions.
Perisome: The entire covering of an invertebrate animal, as echinoderm or cœlenterate; the integument.
Plate-gilled: Having flat, or leaflike, gills, as the bivalve mollusks.
Proctor: To act as a proctor toward; to manage as an attorney or agent.
Pr\u00e6cordia: The front part of the thoracic region; the epigastrium.
Padding: The act or process of making a pad or of inserting stuffing.
Prop\u00e6deutic: Of, pertaining to, or conveying, preliminary instruction; introductory to any art or science; instructing beforehand.
Promulge: To promulgate; to publish or teach.
Purposedly: In a purposed manner; according to purpose or design; purposely.
Perspiratory: Of, pertaining to, or producing, perspiration; as, the perspiratory ducts.
Pauldron: A piece of armor covering the shoulder at the junction of the body piece and arm piece.
Parturition: The act of bringing forth, or being delivered of, young; the act of giving birth; delivery; childbirth.
Peridiastole: The almost inappreciable time which elapses between the systole and the diastole of the heart.
Predication: The act of predicating, or of affirming one thing of another; affirmation; assertion.
Picturesque: Forming, or fitted to form, a good or pleasing picture; representing with the clearness or ideal beauty appropriate to a picture; expressing that peculiar kind of beauty which is agreeable in a picture, natural or artificial; graphic; vivid; as, a picturesque scene or attitude; picturesque language.
Preluder: One who, or that which, preludes; one who plays a prelude.
Purkinjes cells: Large ganglion cells forming a layer near the surface of the cerebellum.
peacoat: A thick loose double-breasted woolen jacket, or coat, commonly worn by sailors in cold weather; a pea-jacket.
Pepperidge: A North American tree (Nyssa multiflora) with very tough wood, handsome oval polished leaves, and very acid berries, -- the sour gum, or common tupelo. See Tupelo.
Pegm: A sort of moving machine employed in the old pageants.
Phyllopod: One of the Phyllopoda. [Also used adjectively.]
Pinhold: A place where a pin is fixed.
Pycnodontini: An extinct order of ganoid fishes. They had a compressed body, covered with dermal ribs (pleurolepida) and with enameled rhomboidal scales.
Pursuit: The act of following or going after; esp., a following with haste, either for sport or in hostility; chase; prosecution; as, the pursuit of game; the pursuit of an enemy.
paintbrush: A brush used to apply paint.
Pyelitis: Inflammation of the pelvis of the kidney.
Preconscious: Of or pertaining to a state before consciousness.
Privado: A private friend; a confidential friend; a confidant.
Pepperoni: a hard sausage of beef and pork, highly seasoned.
Pandora: A beautiful woman (all-gifted), whom Jupiter caused Vulcan to make out of clay in order to punish the human race, because Prometheus had stolen the fire from heaven.  Jupiter gave Pandora a box containing all human ills, which, when the box was opened, escaped and spread over the earth.  Hope alone remained in the box.  Another version makes the box contain all the blessings of the gods, which were lost to men when Pandora opened it.
Polarily: In a polary manner; with polarity.
pearly-white: White like a pearl; very white.
Pentacle: A five-pointed star, also called a pentagram or pentalpha.  See illustr. under pentalpha.  Sometimes referring to a similar figure, such as the figure composed of two equilateral triangles intersecting so as to form a six-pointed star.  It was used in early ornamental art, and also with superstitious import by the astrologers and mystics of the Middle Ages.  The six-pointed star is more comonly called a hexagram, or called Solomon's seal; it resembles the star of David (Magen David)
Pastern: The part of the foot of the horse, and allied animals, between the fetlock and the coffin joint. See Illust. of Horse.
Pasteurism: A method of treatment, devised by Pasteur, for preventing certain diseases, as hydrophobia, by successive inoculations with an attenuated virus of gradually increasing strength.
Peeper: A chicken just breaking the shell; a young bird.
Presager: One who, or that which, presages; a foreteller; a foreboder.
Potentate: One who is potent; one who possesses great power or sway; a prince, sovereign, or monarch.
Paragon: To be equal; to hold comparison.
Portrayal: The act or process of portraying; description; delineation.
Phonal: Of or relating to the voice; as, phonal structure.
Paugie: The scup. See Porgy, and Scup.
Prepossessing: Tending to invite favor; attracting confidence, favor, esteem, or love; attractive; as, a prepossessing manner.
Pug: A footprint; a track; as of a boar.
Paradise: To affect or exalt with visions of felicity; to entrance; to bewitch.
Polyandria: A Linnæan class of monoclinous or hermaphrodite plants, having many stamens, or any number above twenty, inserted in the receptacle.
Polyandric: Pertaining to, or characterized by, polyandry; mating with several males.
Priapism: More or less permanent erection and rigidity of the penis, with or without sexual desire.
Poetaster: An inferior rhymer, or writer of verses; a dabbler in poetic art.
Plotinian: Of pertaining to the Plotinists or their doctrines.
Pasilaly: A form of speech adapted to be used by all mankind; universal language.
Peradventure: Chance; hap; hence, doubt; question; as, proved beyond peradventure.
Photoceramics: Art or process of decorating pottery with photographically prepared designs.
Playgoing: Frequenting playhouses; as, the playgoing public.
Placate: To appease; to pacify; to concilate.
Pseudopodial: Of or pertaining to a pseudopod, or to pseudopodia. See Illust. of Heliozoa.
Parnellism: The policy or principles of the Parnellites.
Pagandom: The pagan lands; pagans, collectively; paganism.
Putrilage: That which is undergoing putrefaction; the products of putrefaction.
Perorate: To make a peroration; to harangue.
Piece: To unite by a coalescence of parts; to fit together; to join.
Polyphaser: A machine generating more than one pressure wave; a multiphaser.
Passager: A passenger; a bird or boat of passage.
Plutocracy: A form of government in which the supreme power is lodged in the hands of the wealthy classes; government by the rich; also, a controlling or influential class of rich men.
Petit: Small; little; insignificant; mean; -- Same as Petty.
Purifier: One who, or that which, purifies or cleanses; a cleanser; a refiner.
Phthalide: A lactone obtained by reduction of phthalyl chloride, as a white crystalline substance; hence, by extension, any one of the series of which phthalide proper is the type.
Punishable: Deserving of, or liable to, punishment; capable of being punished by law or right; -- said of person or offenses.
Pasture: To feed on growing grass; to graze.
Peevish: Habitually fretful; easily vexed or fretted; hard to please; apt to complain; querulous; petulant.
Paleotherium: An extinct genus of herbivorous Tertiary mammals, once supposed to have resembled the tapir in form, but now known to have had a more slender form, with a long neck like that of a llama.
Pedicular: Of or pertaining to lice; having the lousy distemper (phthiriasis); lousy.
Proportion: To adjust in a suitable proportion, as one thing or one part to another; as, to proportion the size of a building to its height; to proportion our expenditures to our income.
Profligateness: The quality of being profligate; an abandoned course of life; profligacy.
Pinkness: Quality or state of being pink.
Pencil: To write or mark with a pencil; to paint or to draw.
Pilewort: A plant (Ranunculus Ficaria of Linnæus) whose tuberous roots have been used in poultices as a specific for the piles.
Patella: A small dish, pan, or vase.
Pervasion: The act of pervading, passing, or spreading through the whole extent of a thing.
Pepsin: A proteolytic enzyme (MW 34,500) contained in the secretory glands of the stomach.  In the gastric juice it is united with dilute hydrochloric acid (0.2 per cent, approximately) and the two together constitute the active portion of the digestive fluid.  It degrades proteins to proteoses and peptides, and is notable for having a very low pH optimum for its activity.  It is the active agent in the gastric juice of all animals.
Purim: A Jewish festival, called also the Feast of Lots, instituted to commemorate the deliverance of the Jews from the machinations of Haman.
Pessulus: A delicate bar of cartilage connecting the dorsal and ventral extremities of the first pair of bronchial cartilages in the syrinx of birds.
Pretense: The act of laying claim; the claim laid; assumption; pretension.
Pleuropneumonia: Inflammation of the pleura and lungs; a combination of pleurisy and pneumonia, esp. a kind of contagions and fatal lung plague of cattle.
Promulgate: To make known by open declaration, as laws, decrees, or tidings; to publish; as, to promulgate the secrets of a council.
Pastorate: The office, state, or jurisdiction of a pastor.
Piraya: A large voracious fresh-water fish (Serrasalmo piraya) of South America, having lancet-shaped teeth.
Perigee: That point, in the orbit of the moon or other body orbiting the earth, which is nearest to the earth; -- opposed to apogee. It is sometimes, but rarely, used of the nearest points of bodies not orbiting the earth, such as of a comet, a planet, etc. Called also epigee, epigeum.
Pledge: To deposit, as a chattel, in pledge or pawn; to leave in possession of another as security; as, to pledge one's watch.
pits: The worst possible situation, person, or thing; something extremely bad, boring, or depressing; -- always used with the; as, cleaning the house is the pits.
Playful: Sportive; gamboling; frolicsome; indulging a sportive fancy; humorous; merry; as, a playful child; a playful writer.
Pomewater: A kind of sweet, juicy apple.
Pebble: To grain (leather) so as to produce a surface covered with small rounded prominences.
Pre\u00ebmptive: Of or pertaining to preëmption; having power to preëmpt; preëmpting.
Ph\u00e6acian: Of or pertaining to the Phæacians, a fabulous seafaring people fond of the feast, the lyre, and the dance, mentioned by Homer.
Paternal: Of or pertaining to a father; fatherly; showing the disposition of a father; guiding or instructing as a father; as, paternal care.
Putting green: The green, or plot of smooth turf, surrounding a hole.
Prestidigitator: One skilled in legerdemain or sleight of hand; a juggler.
Pitiless: Destitute of pity; hard-hearted; merciless; as, a pitilessmaster; pitiless elements.
Petiolate: Having a stalk or petiole; as, a petioleate leaf; the petiolated abdomen of certain Hymenoptera.
Perception: The act of perceiving; cognizance by the senses or intellect; apperhension by the bodily organs, or by the mind, of what is presented to them; discernment; apperhension; cognition.
Posthaste: With speed or expedition; as, he traveled posthaste; to send posthaste.
Palustral: Of or pertaining to a bog or marsh; boggy.
Proteinaceous: Of or related to protein; albuminous; proteid.
Politicly: In a politic manner; sagaciously; shrewdly; artfully.
Prefectorial: Of or pertaining to a prefect.
Phospham: An inert amorphous white powder, PN2H, obtained by passing ammonia over heated phosphorus.
Pompadour: A crimson or pink color; also, a style of dress cut low and square in the neck; also, a mode of dressing the hair by drawing it straight back from the forehead over a roll; -- so called after the Marchioness de Pompadour of France. Also much used adjectively.
Paraxial: On either side of the axis of the skeleton.
Paleola: A diminutive or secondary palea; a lodicule.
Pierid: Any butterfly of the genus Pieris and related genera. See Cabbage butterfly, under Cabbage.
participatory: Affording the opportunity for individual participation; as, participatory democracy.
Prolicide: The crime of destroying one's offspring, either in the womb or after birth.
Podagra: Gout in the joints of the foot; -- applied also to gout in other parts of body.
Piked: Furnished with a pike; ending in a point; peaked; pointed.
Pervious: Admitting passage; capable of being penetrated by another body or substance; permeable; as, a pervious soil.
Poncelet: A unit of power, being the power obtained from an expenditure of one hundred kilogram-meters of energy per second. One poncelet equals g watts, when g is the value of the acceleration of gravity in centimeters.
Pauropoda: An order of small myriapods having only nine pairs of legs and destitute of tracheæ.
Parch: To become scorched or superficially burnt; to be very dry.
Periclase: A grayish or dark green mineral, consisting essentially of magnesia (magnesium oxide), occurring in granular forms or in isometric crystals.
Ph\u00e6ospore: A brownish zoöspore, characteristic of an order (Phæosporeæ) of dark green or olive-colored algæ.
patternmaker: Someone who makes patterns (as for sewing or carpentery or metalworking).
Python: Any species of very large snakes of the genus Python, and allied genera, of the family Pythonidæ. They are nearly allied to the boas. Called also rock snake.
Pianissimo: Very soft; -- a direction to execute a passage as softly as possible. (Abbrev. pp.)
Printing out: A method of printing, in which the image is fully brought out by the direct actinic action of light without subsequent development by means of chemicals.
Philippic: Any one of the series of famous orations of Demosthenes, the Grecian orator, denouncing Philip, king of Macedon.
Projecture: A jutting out beyond a surface.
Persis: A kind of coloring matter obtained from lichens.
Pentylic: Pertaining to, derived from, or containing, pentyl; as, pentylic alcohol
Popularize: To make popular; to make suitable or acceptable to the common people; to make generally known; as, to popularize philosophy.
Panspermic: Of or pertaining to panspermy; as, the panspermic hypothesis.
Panspermia: The doctrine of the widespread distribution of germs, from which under favorable circumstances bacteria, vibrios, etc., may develop.
Podo-: A combining form or prefix from Gr. poy`s, podo`s, foot; as, podocarp, podocephalous, podology.
papooseroot: A tall herb (Caulophyllum thalictroides) of eastern North America and Asia having blue berrylike fruit and a thick knotty rootstock formerly used medicinally; the Cohosh.  See also Cohosh.
Pelvic: Of, pertaining to, or in the region of, the pelvis; as, pelvic cellulitis.
Pelvis: The pelvic arch, or the pelvic arch together with the sacrum. See Pelvic arch, under Pelvic, and Sacrum.
Pyrenoid: A transparent body found in the chromatophores of certain Infusoria.
Parosteal: Of or pertaining to parostosis; as, parosteal ossification.
Perisperm: The albumen of a seed, especially that portion which is formed outside of the embryo sac.
Parallelistic: Of the nature of a parallelism; involving parallelism.
Pumpkin: A well-known trailing plant (Cucurbita pepo)  and its fruit, -- used for cooking and for feeding stock; a pompion.
Pomey: A figure supposed to resemble an apple; a roundel, -- always of a green color.
Proxyship: The office or agency of a proxy.
Pecora: An extensive division of ruminants, including the antelopes, deer, and cattle.
pepperwood: A Pacific coast tree (Umbellularia californica) having aromatic foliage and small umbellate flowers followed by olivelike fruit; yields a hard tough wood.
Proto-Doric: Pertaining to, or designating, architecture, in which the beginnings of the Doric style are supposed to be found.
patrikin: one related on the father's side.
Paragonite: A kind of mica related to muscovite, but containing soda instead of potash.  It is characteristic of the paragonite schist of the Alps.
Postremogeniture: The right of the youngest born.
Prothalamion: A song in celebration of a marriage.
Partibility: The quality or state of being partible; divisibility; separability; as, the partibility of an inherttance.
Pheasant: Any one of numerous species of large gallinaceous birds of the genus Phasianus, and many other genera of the family Phasianidæ, found chiefly in Asia.
Precinct: The limit or exterior line encompassing a place; a boundary; a confine; limit of jurisdiction or authority; -- often in the plural; as, the precincts of a state.
Pronucleus: One of the two bodies or nuclei (called male and female pronuclei) which unite to form the first segmentation nucleus of an impregnated ovum.
Philologize: To study, or make critical comments on, language.
Pendragon: A chief leader or a king; a head; a dictator; -- a title assumed by the ancient British chiefs when called to lead other chiefs.
Proportionateness: The quality or state of being proportionate.
Pneumatocyst: A cyst or sac of a siphonophore, containing air, and serving as a float, as in Physalia.
Pandermite: A hydrous borate of lime, near priceite.
Pentagon: A plane figure having five angles, and, consequently, five sides; any figure having five angles.
Panidiomorphic: Having a completely idiomorphic structure; -- said of certain rocks.
Pongee: A fabric of undyed silk from India and China.
Patentable: Suitable to be patented; capable of being patented.
Para-an\u00e6sthesia: Anæsthesia of both sides of the lower half of the body.
Peanut: The fruit of a trailing leguminous plant (Arachis hypogæa); also, the plant itself, which is widely cultivated for its fruit.
Pharmacy: The art or practice of preparing and preserving drugs, and of compounding and dispensing medicines according to prescriptions of physicians; the occupation of an apothecary or a pharmaceutical chemist.
Profiling: In the construction of fieldworks, the erection at proper intervals of wooden profiles, to show to the workmen the sectional form of the parapets at those points.
Plunderage: The embezzlement of goods on shipboard.
Pasigraphy: A system of universal writing, or a manner of writing that may be understood and used by all nations.
Palmy: Bearing palms; abounding in palms; derived from palms; as, a palmy shore.
Piscinal: Belonging to a fishpond or a piscina.
Polypody: Any plant of the genus Polypodium.
Passus: A division or part; a canto; as, the passus of Piers Plowman. See 2d Fit.
Pre\u00ebxistence: Existence in a former state, or previous to something else.
Plebiscitum: A law enacted by the common people, under the superintendence of a tribune or some subordinate plebeian magistrate, without the intervention of the senate.
Practiced: Experienced; expert; skilled; as, a practiced marksman.
Pleuroperitoneum: The pleural and peritoneal membranes, or the membrane lining the body cavity and covering the surface of the inclosed viscera; the peritoneum; -- used especially in the case of those animals in which the body cavity is not divided.
Pertain: To belong; to have connection with, or dependence on, something, as an appurtenance, attribute, etc.; to appertain; as, saltness pertains to the ocean; flowers pertain to plant life.
Peripateticism: The doctrines or philosophical system of the peripatetics. See Peripatetic, n., 2.
Practicer: One who practices, or puts in practice; one who customarily performs certain acts.
Propounder: One who propounds, proposes, or offers for consideration.
Pikelet: A light, thin cake or muffin.
Peract: To go through with; to perform.
Plenipotence: The quality or state of being plenipotent.
Porch: A covered and inclosed entrance to a building, whether taken from the interior, and forming a sort of vestibule within the main wall, or projecting without and with a separate roof. Sometimes the porch is large enough to serve as a covered walk. See also Carriage porch, under Carriage, and Loggia.
Pretendership: The character, right, or claim of a pretender.
Protista: A provisional group in which are placed a number of low microscopic organisms of doubtful nature. Some are probably plants, others animals.
Platonize: To explain by, or accomodate to, the Platonic philosophy.
Patrial: Derived from the name of a country, and designating an inhabitant of the country; gentile; -- said of a noun.
Polyhalite: A mineral usually occurring in fibrous masses, of a brick-red color, being tinged with iron, and consisting chiefly of the sulphates of lime, magnesia, and soda.
Prytany: The period during which the presidency of the senate belonged to the prytanes of the section.
Parentage: Descent from parents or ancestors; parents or ancestors considered with respect to their rank or character; extraction; birth; as, a man of noble parentage.
Protend: To hold out; to stretch forth.
Popery: The religion of the Roman Catholic Church, comprehending doctrines and practices; -- generally used in an opprobrious sense.
Pedimanous: Having feet resembling hands, or with the first toe opposable, as the opossums and monkeys.
Plim: To swell, as grain or wood with water.
Palter: To trifle with; to waste; to squander in paltry ways or on worthless things.
Pulsatilla: A genus of ranunculaceous herbs including the pasque flower. This genus is now merged in Anemone. Some species, as Anemone Pulsatilla, Anemone pratensis, and Anemone patens, are used medicinally.
Prochordal: Situated in front of the notochord; -- applied especially to parts of the cartilaginous rudiments in the base of the skull.
Peristome: The fringe of teeth around the orifice of the capsule of mosses. It consists of 4, 8, 16, 32, or 64 teeth, and may be either single or double.
Puniness: The quality or state of being puny; littleness; pettiness; feebleness.
Phrygian: A native or inhabitant of Phrygia.
Pertinent: Belonging or related to the subject or matter in hand; fit or appropriate in any way; adapted to the end proposed; apposite; material; relevant; as, pertinent illustrations or arguments; pertinent evidence.
Phototype: A plate or block with a printing surface (usually in relief) obtained from a photograph; also, any one of the many methods of processes by which such a printing surface is obtained.
Polarizer: That which polarizes; especially, the part of a polariscope which receives and polarizes the light. It is usually a reflecting plate, or a plate of some crystal, as tourmaline, or a doubly refracting crystal.
Palinurus: An instrument for obtaining directly, without calculation, the true bearing of the sun, and thence the variation of the compass.
Partitive: A word or phrase expressing partition, or denoting a part; as, the phrase “of the team” in “half of the team”.
Pridian: Of or pertaining to the day before, or yesterday.
paneled: Decorated with panels or wainscoting; -- used of walls; as, a paneled family room.
Plutology: The science which treats of wealth.
Porotic: A medicine supposed to promote the formation of callus.
passenger: A passer or passer-by; a wayfarer.
Pulveraceous: Having a finely powdered surface; pulverulent.
partygoer: Someone who is attending a party{4}; as, the hall was crowded with an overflow of partygoers.
Prejudgment: The act of prejudging; decision before sufficient examination.
Polygyny: The state or practice of having several wives at the same time; marriage to several wives.
Planishing: a. & vb. n. from Planish, v. t.
Perfunctoriness: The quality or state of being perfunctory.
Purbeck stone: A limestone from the Isle of Purbeck in England.
Parochially: In a parochial manner; by the parish, or by parishes.
Pugilism: The practice of boxing, or fighting with the fist.
Possible: Capable of existing or occurring, or of being conceived or thought of; able to happen; capable of being done; not contrary to the nature of things; -- sometimes used to express extreme improbability; barely able to be, or to come to pass; as, possibly he is honest, as it is possible that Judas meant no wrong.
Possibly: In a possible manner; by possible means; especially, by extreme, remote, or improbable intervention, change, or exercise of power; by a chance; perhaps; as, possibly he may recover.
Pintado: Any bird of the genus Numida. Several species are found in Africa. The common pintado, or Guinea fowl, the helmeted, and the crested pintados, are the best known. See Guinea fowl, under Guinea.
Protosalt: A salt derived from a protoxide base.
Pinniped: One of the Pinnipedia; a seal.
Pseudotinea: The bee moth, or wax moth (Galleria).
Palilogy: The repetition of a word, or part of a sentence, for the sake of greater emphasis; as, “The living, the living, he shall praise thee.”
Pale\u00ebchinoidea: An extinct order of sea urchins found in the Paleozoic rocks. They had more than twenty vertical rows of plates. Called also Palæechini.
Patriarchdom: The office or jurisdiction of a patriarch; patriarchate.
Person: To represent as a person; to personify; to impersonate.
Pindal: The peanut (Arachis hypogæa); -- so called in the West Indies.
Peroration: The concluding part of an oration; especially, a final summing up and enforcement of an argument.
Pavisor: A soldier who carried a pavise.
Palladian: A follower of the architectural style of Andrea Palladio.
Participate: To partake of; to share in; to receive a part of.
Paleornithology: The branch of paleontology which treats of fossil birds.
Peddler: One who peddles; a traveling trader; one who travels about, retailing small wares; a hawker.
Plume: To pick and adjust the plumes or feathers of; to dress or prink.
Protractor: One who, or that which, protracts, or causes protraction.
Plumb: To adjust by a plumb line; to cause to be perpendicular; as, to plumb a building or a wall.
Plumy: Covered or adorned with plumes, or as with plumes; feathery.
pantywaist: A timid man or boy considered childish or unassertive.
Photogravure: A photoengraving; also, the process by which such a picture is produced.
Peek: To look surreptitiously, or with the eyes half closed, or through a crevice; to peep.
Peen: To draw, bend, or straighten, as metal, by blows with the peen of a hammer or sledge.
Peel: The skin or rind; as, the peel of an orange.
Prostomium: That portion of the head of an annelid situated in front of the mouth.
Photophore: A form of endoscope using an electric light.
Paltock: A kind of doublet; a jacket.
Penetration: The act or process of penetrating, piercing, or entering; also, the act of mentally penetrating into, or comprehending, anything difficult.
parimutuel: A form of betting where winners share the total amount wagered, in proporation to their bets, and less a portion for the management; -- used commonly in betting at horse racing track.  In parimutuel betting, the payoff for a bet does not have fixed odds, but depends on the amount bet on each outcome.
Peep: The cry of a young chicken; a chirp.
Plebicolist: One who flatters, or courts the favor of, the common people; a demagogue.
Philister: A Philistine; -- a cant name given to townsmen by students in German universities.
Paage: A toll for passage over another person's grounds.
Premium: A reward or recompense; a prize to be won by being before another, or others, in a competition; reward or prize to be adjudged; a bounty; as, a premium for good behavior or scholarship, for discoveries, etc.
Peucil: A liquid resembling camphene, obtained by treating turpentine hydrochloride with lime.
Pistache: The anacardiaceous tree Pistacia vera, which yields the pistachio nut; also, the nut itself and the flavoring extract prepared from it.  Called also pistachio.
Petunia: A genus of solanaceous herbs with funnelform or salver-shaped corollas. Two species are common in cultivation, Petunia violacera, with reddish purple flowers, and Petunia nyctaginiflora, with white flowers. There are also many hybrid forms with variegated corollas.
Pyrography: A process of printing, ornamenting, or carving, by burning with heated instruments.  One variant is wood burning.
Predecease: The death of one person or thing before another.
Pacu: A South American fresh-water fish (Myletes pacu), of the family Characinidæ. It is highly esteemed as food.
Palatal: A sound uttered, or a letter pronounced, by the aid of the palate, as the letters k and y.
Proximo: In the next month after the present; -- often contracted to prox.; as, on the 3d proximo.
Profanation: The act of violating sacred things, or of treating them with contempt or irreverence; irreverent or too familiar treatment or use of what is sacred; desecration; as, the profanation of the Sabbath; the profanation of a sanctuary; the profanation of the name of God.
Puddle-ball: The lump of pasty wrought iron as taken from the puddling furnace to be hammered or rolled.
Participation: The act or state of participating, or sharing in common with others; as, a participation in joy or sorrows.
parachuting: The act or process of descending from a high altitude to the ground by means of a parachute.
Punchinello: A punch; a buffoon; originally, in a puppet show, a character represented as fat, short, and humpbacked.
Pennsylvanian: The geological period from 280 million to 310 million years ago; -- it was characterized by a warm climate and abundance of swampy land.
Premise: To make a premise; to set forth something as a premise.
Phacops: A genus of trilobites found in the Silurian and Devonian formations. Phacops bufo is one of the most common species.
Peculiar: That which is peculiar; a sole or exclusive property; a prerogative; a characteristic.
Petit mal: The mildest form of epilepsy, with momentary faintness or unconsciousness, but without convulsions; -- opposed to grand mal.
Placard: To post placards upon or within; as, to placard a wall, to placard the city.
Perambulate: To walk about; to ramble; to stroll; as, he perambulated in the park.
Pluviography: The branch of meteorology treating of the automatic registration of the precipitation of rain, snow, etc.; also, the graphic presentation of precipitation data.
Philosophistic: Of or pertaining to the love or practice of sophistry.
Pyro-: Combining forms designating fire or heat; specifically (Chem.), used to imply an actual or theoretical derivative by the action of heat; as in pyrophosphoric, pyrosulphuric, pyrotartaric, pyrotungstic, etc.
Prostibulous: Of or pertaining to prostitutes or prostitution; meretricious.
Polytungstic: Containing several tungsten atoms or radicals; as, polytungstic acid.
Pandowdy: A deep pie or pudding made of baked apples, or of sliced bread and apples baked together, with no bottom crust.
Plumiliform: Having the of a plume or feather.
Precalculate: To calculate or determine beforehand; to prearrange.
Packet: To ply with a packet or dispatch boat.
Protocol: To make or write protocols, or first draughts; to issue protocols.
Prefatory: Pertaining to, or of the nature of, a preface; introductory to a book, essay, or discourse; as, prefatory remarks.
Periptery: The region surrounding a moving body, such as the wing of a bird or a gliding aëroplane, within which cyclic or vortical motion of the air occur.
Prognosticable: Capable of being prognosticated or foretold.
Pleasurist: A person devoted to worldly pleasure.
Peascod: The legume or pericarp, or the pod, of the pea.
Persimmon: An American tree (Diospyros Virginiana) and its fruit, found from New York southward. The fruit is like a plum in appearance, but is very harsh and astringent until it has been exposed to frost, when it becomes palatable and nutritious.
Presentative: Having the right of presentation, or offering a clergyman to the bishop for institution; as, advowsons are presentative, collative, or donative.
Pureness: The state of being pure (in any sense of the adjective).
Patriarchate: The office, dignity, or jurisdiction of a patriarch.
Paving: The act or process of laying a pavement, or covering some place with a pavement.
Prune: A plum; esp., a dried plum, used in cookery; as, French or Turkish prunes; California prunes.
Passageway: A way for passage; a hall. See Passage, 5.
Pollution: The act of polluting, or the state of being polluted (in any sense of the verb); defilement; uncleanness; impurity.
Pelopium: A supposed new metal found in columbite, afterwards shown to be identical with columbium, or niobium.
Punctuation: The act or art of punctuating or pointing a writing or discourse; the art or mode of dividing literary composition into sentences, and members of a sentence, by means of points, so as to elucidate the author's meaning.
Poetics: The principles and rules of the art of poetry.
Pre\u00ebngage: To engage by previous contract; to bind or attach previously; to preoccupy.
Pilotism: Pilotage; skill in the duties of a pilot.
Pythiad: The period intervening between one celebration of the Pythian games and the next.
Peony: A plant, and its flower, of the ranunculaceous genus Pæonia.  Of the four or five species, one is a shrub; the rest are perennial herbs with showy flowers, often double in cultivation.
Pyral: Of or pertaining to a pyre.
Prompt-book: The book used by a prompter of a theater.
Protococcus: A genus of minute unicellular algæ including the red snow plant (Protococcus nivalis).
Phyllomania: An abnormal or excessive production of leaves.
Phycocyanin: A blue coloring matter found in certain algæ.
Peristerite: A variety of albite, whitish and slightly iridescent like a pigeon's neck.
parachute: TO descend to th ground from an airplane or other high place using a parachute; as, when the plane stalled, he parachuted safely to the ground.
Phenylamine: Any one of certain class of organic bases regarded as formed from ammonia by the substitution of phenyl for hydrogen.
Personalty: The state of being a person; personality.
Prothorax: The first or anterior segment of the thorax in insects. See Illusts. of Butterfly and Coleoptera.
Pudic: Of or pertaining to the external organs of generation.
Preservable: Capable of being preserved; admitting of preservation.
Pedionomus: A genus of birds including the plains wanderer (Pedionomus torquatus) of New South Wales as its only species.  It is the only genus of the family Pedionomidae of the order Passeriformes and the plains wanderer is the only species in the family.  The total world population (ca. 2000) is estimated to be 5 to 10 thousand.
Porcine: Of or pertaining to swine; characteristic of the hog.
Palpus: A feeler; especially, one of the jointed sense organs attached to the mouth organs of insects, arachnids, crustaceans, and annelids; as, the mandibular palpi, maxillary palpi, and labial palpi. The palpi of male spiders serve as sexual organs. Called also palp. See Illust. of Arthrogastra and Orthoptera.
Paretic: Of or pertaining to paresis; affected with paresis.
Patripassian: One of a body of believers in the early church who denied the independent preëxistent personality of Christ, and who, accordingly, held that the Father suffered in the Son; a monarchian.
Probe: An instrument for examining the depth or other circumstances of a wound, ulcer, or cavity, or the direction of a sinus, of for exploring for bullets, for stones in the bladder, etc.
Pro rata: In proportion; proportionately; according to the share, interest, or liability of each.
Punt: To boat or hunt in a punt.
Pansophy: Universal wisdom; esp., a system of universal knowledge proposed by Comenius (1592 -- 1671), a Moravian educator.
Pyrrhonist: A follower of Pyrrho; a skeptic.
Paragoge: The addition of a letter or syllable to the end of a word, as withouten for without.
Pinnule: One of the small divisions of a decompound frond or leaf. See Illust. of Bipinnate leaf, under Bipinnate.
Pyopneumothorax: Accumulation of air, or other gas, and of pus, in the pleural cavity.
Param: A white crystalline nitrogenous substance (C2H4N4); -- called also dicyandiamide.
Painsworthy: Worth the pains or care bestowed.
Pounding: The act of beating, bruising, or breaking up; a beating.
penlight: A small flashlight resembling a fountain pen, often having a clip to permit firm attachment to a pocket.
Polythalamia: A division of Foraminifera including those having a manychambered shell.
Psychanalysis: same as psychoanalysis; -- an older term now obsolete.
Polymathy: The knowledge of many arts and sciences; variety of learning.
Punctated: Pointed; ending in a point or points.
Piste: The track or tread a horseman makes upon the ground he goes over.
Prosiness: The quality or state of being prosy; tediousness; tiresomeness.
parader: One who walks with regular or stately step.
Promissive: Making a promise; implying a promise; promising.
Popularity: The quality or state of being popular; especially, the state of being esteemed by, or of being in favor with, the people at large; good will or favor proceeding from the people; as, the popularity of a law, statesman, or a book.
Palpocil: A minute soft filamentary process springing from the surface of certain hydroids and sponges.
Para-: A prefix signifying alongside of, beside, beyond, against, amiss; as parable, literally, a placing beside; paradox, that which is contrary to opinion; parachronism.
Pantastomata: One of the divisions of Flagellata, including the monads and allied forms.
Paleolithic: Of or pertaining to an era marked by early stone implements.  The Paleolithic era (as proposed by Lubbock) includes the earlier half of the “Stone Age;” the remains belonging to it are for the most part of extinct animals, with relics of human beings.
Polyphemus: A very large American moth (Telea polyphemus) belonging to the Silkworm family (Bombycidæ). Its larva, which is very large, bright green, with silvery tubercles, and with oblique white stripes on the sides, feeds on the oak, chestnut, willow, cherry, apple, and other trees. It produces a large amount of strong silk. Called also American silkworm.
Phlebolite: A small calcareous concretion formed in a vein; a vein stone.
Pterygoid: Like a bird's wing in form; as, a pterygoid bone.
Patriots Day: A legal holiday in the States of Massachusetts and Maine, April 19, the anniversary of the battle of Lexington in 1775. It was first observed in 1894.
Pronouncing: Pertaining to, or indicating, pronunciation; as, a pronouncing dictionary.
Postglacial: Formed or occurring after the last glacial epoch of the Pleistocene period, or at a locality within the area of Pleistocene glaciation after the final disappearance of the glacier from the locality.
Pocan: The poke (Phytolacca decandra); -- called also pocan bush.
Plowman: One who plows, or who holds and guides a plow; hence, a husbandman.
Plumbaginous: Resembling plumbago; consisting of, or containing, plumbago; as, a plumbaginous slate.
parison: An intermediate stage or shape of a glass object which is produced in more than one stage.
Picts: A race of people of uncertain origin, who inhabited Scotland in early times.
Purpuriparous: Producing, or connected with, a purple-colored secretion; as, the purpuriparous gland of certain gastropods.
Panorpian: Like, or pertaining to, the genus Panorpa.
Plication: A folding or fold; a plait.
Pectinibranchiata: A division of Gastropoda, including those that have a comblike gill upon the neck.
Parlance: Conversation; discourse; talk; diction; phrase; as, in legal parlance; in common parlance.
Photosculpture: A process in which, by means of a number of photographs simultaneously taken from different points of view on the same level, rough models of the figure or bust of a person or animal may be made with great expedition.
Placet: A vote of assent, as of the governing body of a university, of an ecclesiastical council, etc.
Placer: A deposit of earth, sand, or gravel, containing valuable mineral in particles, especially by the side of a river, or in the bed of a mountain torrent.
Pythocenic: Producing decomposition, as diseases which are supposed to be accompanied or caused by decomposition.
Prickle: To prick slightly, as with prickles, or fine, sharp points.
Phalansterism: A system of phalansteries proposed by Fourier; Fourierism.
Phorone: A yellow crystalline substance, having a geraniumlike odor, regarded as a complex derivative of acetone, and obtained from certain camphor compounds.
Puberty: The earliest age at which persons are capable of begetting or bearing children, usually considered, in temperate climates, to be about fourteen years in males and twelve in females.
Platinocyanic: Pertaining to, derived from, or designating, an acid compound of platinous cyanide and hydrocyanic acid.  It is obtained as a cinnaber-red crystalline substance.
Propodiale: The bone of either the upper arm or the thing, the propodialia being the humerus and femur.
Privatdocent: In the universities of Germany and some other European countries, a licensed teacher or lecturer having no share in the university government and dependent upon fees for remuneration.
Parchment: The skin of a lamb, sheep, goat, young calf, or other animal, prepared for writing on. See Vellum.
palatinate: The province or seigniory of a palatine; the dignity of a palatine.
Pneumatogarm: A tracing of the respiratory movements, obtained by a pneumatograph or stethograph.
Phototherapy: The application of light for therapeutic purposes, esp. for treating diseases of the skin.
Psychotherapeutics: The treatment of disease by acting on the mind, as by suggestion; mind cure; psychotherapy.
Prithee: A corruption of pray thee; as, I prithee; generally used without I.
Patrolman: One who patrols; a watchman; especially, a policeman who patrols a particular precinct of a town or city.
Phytopathologist: One skilled in diseases of plants.
Procrusteanize: To stretch or contract according to some rule or standard.
Peritomous: Cleaving in more directions than one, parallel to the axis.
Pounder: One who, or that which, pounds, as a stamp in an ore mill.
Pinacoid: A plane parallel to two of the crystalline axes.
Pacify: To make to be at peace; to appease; to calm; to still; to quiet; to allay the agitation, excitement, or resentment of; to tranquillize; as, to pacify a man when angry; to pacify pride, appetite, or importunity.
Pantagruelism: The theory or practice of the medical profession; -- used in burlesque or ridicule.
Puffingly: In a puffing manner; with vehement breathing or shortness of breath; with exaggerated praise.
Prayerless: Not using prayer; habitually neglecting prayer to God; without prayer.
Prophetically: In a prophetical manner; by way of prediction.
Plurifarious: Of many kinds or fashions; multifarious.
Parasol: To shade as with a parasol.
Pleonast: One who is addicted to pleonasm.
Polygamy: The having of a plurality of wives or husbands at the same time; usually, the marriage of a man to more than one woman, or the practice of having several wives, at the same time; -- opposed to monogamy; as, the nations of the East practiced polygamy. See the Note under Bigamy, and cf. Polyandry.
Plebeianize: To render plebeian, common, or vulgar.
Parillin: A glucoside resembling saponin, found in the root of sarsaparilla, smilax, etc., and extracted as a bitter white crystalline substance; -- called also smilacin, sarsaparilla saponin, and sarsaparillin.
Pleonasm: Redundancy of language in speaking or writing; the use of more words than are necessary to express the idea; as, I saw it with my own eyes.
Pantile: A roofing tile, of peculiar form, having a transverse section resembling an elongated S laid on its side (&unr_;).
Phase splitter: A device by which a single-phase current is split into two or more currents differing in phase. It is used in starting single-phase induction motors.
Pleuralgia: Pain in the side or region of the ribs.
Potoo: A large South American goatsucker (Nyctibius grandis).
Pigeon-breasted: Having a breast like a pigeon, -- the sternum being so prominent as to constitute a deformity; chicken-breasted.
pager: A small electronic communication device which signals when a telephone call has been received at a base station.  Each such device receives radio signals from the base station specifically coded for the individual to whom it is registered; the signal given by the device to the registered user may be a beeping sound, indicating that the user should call the base station to receive a message; or it may display a telephone number to which the user may call directly to return the incoming call, or may display a short message.  Such devices are small enough to carry in the pocket or pocketbook, or to clip onto a belt or other part of the clothing.  Also called beeper.
Precociousness: The quality or state of being precocious; untimely ripeness; premature development, especially of the mental powers; forwardness.
Portuguese: Of or pertaining to Portugal, or its inhabitants.
Paymaster: One who pays; one who compensates, rewards, or requites; specifically, an officer or agent of a government, a corporation, or an employer, whose duty it is to pay salaries, wages, etc., and keep account of the same.
Phalanger: Any marsupial belonging to Phalangista, Cuscus, Petaurus, and other genera of the family Phalangistidæ. They are arboreal, and the species of Petaurus are furnished with lateral parachutes. See Flying phalanger, under Flying.
Pavlovian: Of or pertaining to Ivan Pavlov, or the principles of conditioned responses that he investigated; as, a Pavlovian response.
Preparative: Tending to prepare or make ready; having the power of preparing, qualifying, or fitting; preparatory.
Pedagogic: Of or pertaining to a pedagogue; suited to, or characteristic of, a pedagogue.
Polyphony: Multiplicity of sounds, as in the reverberations of an echo.
Presentaneous: Ready; quick; immediate in effect; as, presentaneous poison.
Polyphone: A character or vocal sign representing more than one sound, as read, which is pronounced rēd or r&ebreve_;d.
Pichiciago: A small, burrowing, South American edentate (Chlamyphorus truncatus), allied to the armadillos. The shell is attached only along the back.
Pay streak: The zone, parallel to the walls of a vein, in which the ore is concentrated, or any narrow streak of paying ore in less valuable material.
Pervasive: Tending to pervade, or having power to spread throughout; of a pervading quality.
Pedimental: Of or pertaining to a pediment.
Pinna: A leaflet of a pinnate leaf. See Illust. of Bipinnate leaf, under Bipinnate.
Philoprogenitive: Having the love of offspring; fond of children.
Perviousness: The quality or state of being pervious; as, the perviousness of glass.
Pharyngobranchial: Of or pertaining to the pharynx and the branchiæ; -- applied especially to the dorsal elements in the branchial arches of fishes. See Pharyngeal.
Pettish: Fretful; peevish; moody; capricious; inclined to ill temper.
Phosphoritic: Pertaining to phosphorite; resembling, or of the nature of, phosphorite.
Phakoscope: An instrument for studying the mechanism of accommodation.
Phantasmal: Pertaining to, of the nature of, or resembling, a phantasm; spectral; illusive.
Pig-headed: Having a head like a pig; hence, figuratively: stupidity obstinate; perverse; stubborn.
palatalized: Produced with the front of the tongue near or touching the hard palate as "y"; or with the blade of the tongue near the hard palate as "ch" in "chin" or "j" in "gin".
Piratical: Of or pertaining to a pirate; acquired by, or practicing, piracy; as, a piratical undertaking.
Pampiniform: In the form of tendrils; -- applied especially to the spermatic and ovarian veins.
Pitheci: A division of mammals including the apes and monkeys.  Sometimes used in the sense of Primates.
Papacy: The office and dignity of the pope, or pontiff, of Rome; papal jurisdiction.
Psychism: The doctrine of Quesne, that there is a fluid universally diffused, end equally animating all living beings, the difference in their actions being due to the difference of the individual organizations.
Protomerite: The second segment of one of the Gregarinæ.
peewit: A large crested Old World plover having wattles and spurs; the pewit.
Papulous: Covered with, or characterized by, papulæ; papulose.
Prevail: To overcome; to gain the victory or superiority; to gain the advantage; to have the upper hand, or the mastery; to succeed; -- sometimes with over or against.
Pyrophyllite: A mineral, usually of a white or greenish color and pearly luster, consisting chiefly of the hydrous silicate of alumina.
Pythonic: Prophetic; oracular; pretending to foretell events.
Publish: To make public; to make known to mankind, or to people in general; to divulge, as a private transaction; to promulgate or proclaim, as a law or an edict.
Parapegm: An engraved tablet, usually of brass, set up in a public place.
Parkia: A genus of tropical Old World trees, including the nitta trees.
Plush: A textile fabric with a nap or shag on one side, longer and softer than the nap of velvet.
Pudendal: Of or pertaining to the pudenda, or pudendum.
Pendency: The quality or state of being pendent or suspended.
Prejudical: Of or pertaining to the determination of some matter not previously decided; as, a prejudical inquiry or action at law.
Panoramic: Of, pertaining to, or like, a panorama; exhibiting a very broad view; as, a panoramic view.
Pauperize: To reduce to pauperism; as, to pauperize the peasantry.
Peck: A quick, sharp stroke, as with the beak of a bird or a pointed instrument.
Polycystina: A division of Radiolaria including numerous minute marine species. The skeleton is composed of silica, and is often very elegant in form and sculpture. Many have been found in the fossil state.
Pronominalize: To give the effect of a pronoun to; as, to pronominalize the substantives person, people, etc.
Prismoidal: Having the form of a prismoid; as, prismoidal solids.
Placement: The act of placing, or the state of being placed.
Protestator: One who makes protestation; a protester.
Perithecium: An organ in certain fungi and lichens, surrounding and enveloping the masses of fructification.
palimpsest: A parchment which has been written upon twice, the first writing having been erased to make place for the second.  The erasures of ancient writings were usually carried on in monasteries, to allow the production of ecclesiastical texts, such as copies of church services and lives of the saints.  The difficulty of recovering the original text varied with the process used to prepare the parchment for a fresh writing; the original texts on parchments which had been washed with lime-water and dried were easily recovered by a chemical process, but those erased by scraping the parchment and bleaching are difficult to interpret.  Most of the manuscripts underlying the palimpsests that have been revived are fragmentary, but some are of great historical value.  One Syriac version of the Four Gospels was discovered in 1895 in St. Catherine's Monastery at Mount Sinai by Mrs. Agnes Smith Lewis.  See also the notes below.
p\u00e6onine: An artifical red nitrogenous dyestuff, called also red coralline.
Perisarc: The outer, hardened integument which covers most hydroids.
Perpetuity: The quality or state of being perpetual; as, the perpetuity of laws.
Parrots-bill: The glory pea. See under Glory.
Photolithography: The art or process of producing photolithographs.
Problematic: Having the nature of a problem; not shown in fact; questionable; uncertain; unsettled; doubtful.
Phonautograph: An instrument by means of which a sound can be made to produce a visible trace or record of itself. It consists essentially of a resonant vessel, usually of paraboloidal form, closed at one end by a flexible membrane. A stylus attached to some point of the membrane records the movements of the latter, as it vibrates, upon a moving cylinder or plate.
Prorector: An officer who presides over the academic senate of a German university.
Pantheistic: Of or pertaining to pantheism; founded in, or leading to, pantheism.
Pedrail: A device intended to replace the wheel of a self-propelled vehicle for use on rough roads and to approximate to the smoothness in running of a wheel on a metal track.  The tread consists of a number of rubber shod feet which are connected by ball-and-socket joints to the ends of sliding spokes.  Each spoke has attached to it a small roller which in its turn runs under a short pivoted rail controlled by a powerful set of springs. This arrangement permits the feet to accomodate themselves to obstacles even such as steps or stairs. The pedrail was invented by one B. J. Diplock of London, Eng.
Papillary: Of, pertaining to, or resembling, a papilla or papillæ; bearing, or covered with, papillæ; papillose.
Pallial: Of or pertaining to a mantle, especially to the mantle of mollusks; produced by the mantle; as, the pallial line, or impression, which marks the attachment of the mantle on the inner surface of a bivalve shell. See Illust. of Bivalve.
Passively: In a passive manner; inertly; unresistingly.
pahautea: An evergreen tree (Libocedrus bidwillii) of New Zealand resembling the kawaka.
Polyparous: Producing or bearing a great number; bringing forth many.
Paromology: A concession to an adversary in order to strengthen one's own argument.
Postpositive: Placed after another word; as, a postpositive conjunction; a postpositive letter.
Precipitator: One who precipitates, or urges on with vehemence or rashness.
Pious: Of or pertaining to piety; exhibiting piety; reverential; dutiful; religious; devout; godly.
Pungency: The quality or state of being pungent or piercing; keenness; sharpness; piquancy; as, the pungency of ammonia.
Perchloride: A chloride having a higher proportion of chlorine than any other chloride of the same substance or series.
Plenum: That state in which every part of space is supposed to be full of matter; -- opposed to vacuum.
Paranymph: A friend of the bridegroom who went with him in his chariot to fetch home the bride.
Pranker: One who dresses showily; a prinker.
Punctuative: Of or belonging to points of division; relating to punctuation.
Paleichthyes: A comprehensive division of fishes which includes the elasmobranchs and ganoids.
Pr\u00e6nominical: Of or pertaining to a prænomen.
Pipistrel: A small European bat (Vesperugo pipistrellus); -- called also flittermouse.
Prey: To take booty; to gather spoil; to ravage; to take food by violence.
parsec: A unit of length used in describing astronomical distances, equal to 3.26 light years, or 3.086 x 1013 km.  Abbreviated pc.  The derived units of kiloparsec (kpc, 1000 parsecs) and megaparsec (mpc, one million parsecs) are often found in discussion of astronomical distances.
Profile: to draw the outline of; to draw in profile, as an architectural member.
Phillyrea: A genus of evergreen plants growing along the shores of the Mediterranean, and breading a fruit resembling that of the olive.
Pre-: A prefix denoting priority (of time, place, or rank); as, precede, to go before; precursor, a forerunner; prefix, to fix or place before; preëminent eminent before or above others. Pre- is sometimes used intensively, as in prepotent, very potent.
Parallelable: Capable of being paralleled, or equaled.
Partlet: A covering for the neck, and sometimes for the shoulders and breast; originally worn by both sexes, but later by women alone; a ruff.
Participially: In the sense or manner of a participle.
Pr\u00e6commissure: A transverse commissure in the anterior part of the third ventricle of the brain; the anterior cerebral commissure.
Public-spirited: Having, or exercising, a disposition to advance the interest of the community or public; as, public-spirited men.
Prester: A priest or presbyter; as, Prester John.
Physics: The science of nature, or of natural objects; that branch of science which treats of the laws and properties of matter, and the forces acting upon it; especially, that department of natural science which treats of the causes (as gravitation, heat, light, magnetism, electricity, etc.) that modify the general properties of bodies; natural philosophy.
Pork: The flesh of swine, fresh or salted, used for food.
Pore: To look or gaze steadily in reading or studying; to fix the attention; to be absorbed; -- often with on or upon, and now usually with over.
pacing: the speed at which a composition is to be played.
Polyphyllous: Many-leaved; as, a polyphyllous calyx or perianth.
Portage group: A subdivision of the Chemung period in American geology. See Chart of Geology.
Pot lead: Graphite, or black lead, often used on the bottoms of racing vessels to diminish friction.
Purveyance: The act or process of providing or procuring; providence; foresight; preparation; management.
Propitiatory: The mercy seat; -- so called because a symbol of the propitiated Jehovah.
Plagionite: A sulphide of lead and antimony, of a blackish lead-gray color and metallic luster.
Port: To turn or put to the left or larboard side of a ship; -- said of the helm, and used chiefly in the imperative, as a command; as, port your helm.
Paparchy: Government by a pope; papal rule.
Prehallux: An extra first toe, or rudiment of a toe, on the preaxial side of the hallux.
Platyrhine: Having the nose broad; -- opposed to leptorhine.
Purprise: A close or inclosure; the compass of a manor.
parlay: The act of betting the winnings from a prior bet, plus the original stake, on a subsequent bet; the second or later such bet in a series; also, a series of such bets, with the stakes for later bets coming from the winnings of earlier bets.
pent-: Same as penta-; -- used as a combining form before vowels, as in pentoxide.
Platyrhini: A division of monkeys, including the American species, which have a broad nasal septum, thirty-six teeth, and usually a prehensile tail. See Monkey.
Psalterial: Of or pertaining to the psalterium.
Pernoctalian: One who watches or keeps awake all night.
Pouter: One who, or that which, pouts.
Pleasantness: The state or quality of being pleasant.
Pearlwort: A name given to several species of Sagina, low and inconspicuous herbs of the Chickweed family.
Potato: A plant (Solanum tuberosum) of the Nightshade family, and its esculent farinaceous tuber, of which there are numerous varieties used for food. It is native of South America, but a form of the species is found native as far north as New Mexico.
Perfume: The scent, odor, or odoriferous particles emitted from a sweet-smelling substance; a pleasant odor; fragrance; aroma.
Perfectionist: One pretending to perfection; esp., one pretending to moral perfection; one who believes that persons may and do attain to moral perfection and sinlessness in this life.
Parole: To set at liberty on parole; as, to parole prisoners.
Pachydermata: A group of hoofed mammals distinguished for the thickness of their skins, including the elephant, hippopotamus, rhinoceros, tapir, horse, and hog; the pachyderms.  It is now considered an artificial group.
Palustrine: Of, pertaining to, or living in, a marsh or swamp; marshy.
Pixy: An old English name for a fairy; an elf.
Prebendary: A clergyman attached to a collegiate or cathedral church who enjoys a prebend in consideration of his officiating at stated times in the church. See Note under Benefice, n., 3.
Photomezzotype: A photomechanical process similar to collotype.
Piscatorial: Of or pertaining to fishes or fishing.
Post-: A prefix signifying behind, back, after; as, postcommissure, postdot, postscript.
Professorialism: The character, manners, or habits of a professor.
Polyperythrin: A coloring matter found in many simple Anthozoa and some hydroids.
Pressure wires: Wires leading from various points of an electric system to a central station, where a voltmeter indicates the potential of the system at those points.
Poulard: A pullet from which the ovaries have been removed to produce fattening; hence, a fat pullet.
Premonitory: Giving previous warning or notice; as, premonitory symptoms of disease.
Pituitrin: A substance or extract from the pituitary body.
Pleurocarpic: Side-fruited; -- said of those true mosses in which the pedicels or the capsules are from lateral archegonia; -- opposed to acrocarpous.
Prenasal: Situated in front of the nose, or in front of the nasal chambers.
Pharaoh: A title by which the sovereigns of ancient Egypt were designated.
Prosthetic: Of or pertaining to prosthesis; prefixed, as a letter or letters to a word.
Photochromography: Art or process of printing colored photographs.
Patterer: One who patters, or talks glibly; specifically, a street peddler.
Postorbital: Situated behind the orbit; as, the postorbital scales of some fishes and reptiles.
Pedi-: Combining forms from L. pes, pedis, foot, as pedipalp, pedireme, pedometer.
Prophylactic: Defending or preserving from disease; preventive.
Partition: To divide into parts or shares; to divide and distribute; as, to partition an estate among various heirs.
Plectospondyli: An extensive suborder of fresh-water physostomous fishes having the anterior vertebræ united and much modified; the Eventognathi.
Pooling: The act of uniting, or an agreement to unite, an aggregation of properties belonging to different persons, with a view to common liabilities or profits.
Phrasal: Of the nature of a phrase; consisting of a phrase; as, a phrasal adverb.
Picari\u00e6: An extensive division of birds which includes the woodpeckers, toucans, trogons, hornbills, kingfishers, motmots, rollers, and goatsuckers. By some writers it is made to include also the cuckoos, swifts, and humming birds.
Professed: Openly declared, avowed, acknowledged, or claimed; as, a professed foe; a professed tyrant; a professed Christian.
Pileus: A kind of skull cap of felt.
Phonotypic: Of or pertaining to phonotypy; as, a phonotypic alphabet.
Pleiades: The seven daughters of Atlas and the nymph Pleione, fabled to have been made by Jupiter a constellation in the sky.
Pistillate: Having a pistil or pistils; -- usually said of flowers having pistils but no stamens.
Pains: Labor; toilsome effort; care or trouble taken; -- plural in form, but used with a singular or plural verb, commonly the former.
Pakistani: A native or inhabitant of Pakistan.
Petiolule: A small petiole, or the petiole of a leaflet.
Parabolism: The division of the terms of an equation by a known quantity that is involved in the first term.
Paigle: A species of Primula, either the cowslip or the primrose.
Porphyrogenitism: The principle of succession in royal families, especially among the Eastern Roman emperors, by which a younger son, if born after the accession of his father to the throne, was preferred to an elder son who was not so born.
Petrography: The art of writing on stone.
Polyphonist: A proficient in the art of multiplying sounds; a ventriloquist.
Pulmometry: The determination of the capacity of the lungs.
Palm Sunday: The Sunday next before Easter; -- so called in commemoration of the triumphal entry of Jesus Christ into Jerusalem, when the multitude strewed palm branches in the way.  The event is commemorated in Christian churches by distribution of blessed palm leaves.
Peninsula: A portion of land nearly surrounded by water, and connected with a larger body by a neck, or isthmus.
Prepositure: The office or dignity of a provost; a provostship.
Pleximeter: A small, hard, elastic plate, as of ivory, bone, or rubber, placed in contact with body to receive the blow, in examination by mediate percussion.
Paralogism: A reasoning which is false in point of form, that is, which is contrary to logical rules or formulæ; a formal fallacy, or pseudo-syllogism, in which the conclusion does not follow from the premises.
Puritanize: To agree with, or teach, the doctrines of Puritans; to conform to the practice of Puritans.
parkleaves: A European species of Saint John's-wort; the tutsan. See Tutsan.
Peziza: A genus of fungi embracing a great number of species, some of which are remarkable for their regular cuplike form and deep colors.
Proembryo: The series of cells formed in the ovule of a flowering plant after fertilization, but before the formation of the embryo.
Pocketbook: A small book or case for carrying papers, money, etc., in the pocket; also, a notebook for the pocket.
