Podotheca: The scaly covering of the foot of a bird or reptile.
Proffer: An offer made; something proposed for acceptance by another; a tender; as, proffers of peace or friendship.
Prowling: Accustomed to prowl, or engaged in roving stealthily, as for prey.
Puppyism: Extreme meanness, affectation, conceit, or impudence.
Penetrative: Tending to penetrate; of a penetrating quality; piercing; as, the penetrative sun.
Perishable: Liable to perish; subject to decay, destruction, or death; as, perishable goods; our perishable bodies.
Pr\u00e6nomen: The first name of a person, by which individuals of the same family were distinguished, answering to our Christian name, as Caius, Lucius, Marcus, etc.
Perishably: In a perishable degree or manner.
Phthalin: A colorless crystalline substance obtained by reduction from phthaleïn, into which it is easily converted by oxidation; hence, any one of the series of which phthalin proper is the type.
Profectitious: Proceeding from, as from a parent; derived, as from an ancestor.
Phthalic: Pertaining to, or designating, a dibasic acid obtained by the oxidation of naphthalene and allied substances.
Potamography: An account or description of rivers; potamology.
passerby: One who passes by, especially casually or by chance; one not directly involved in some action; a passer.
Preter-: A prefix signifying past, by, beyond, more than; as, preter- mission, a permitting to go by; preternatural, beyond or more than is natural.
Premonstratensian: One of a religious order of regular canons founded by St. Norbert at Prémontré, in France, in 1119. The members of the order are called also White Canons, Norbertines, and Premonstrants.
Practical: Of or pertaining to practice or action.
Pearl-eyed: Having a pearly speck in the eye; afflicted with a cataract or cataracts.
Polymastism: The condition of having more than two mammæ, or breasts.
Postlude: A voluntary at the end of a service.
Pha\u00ebthon: The son of Helios (Phœbus), that is, the son of light, or of the sun. He is fabled to have obtained permission to drive the chariot of the sun, in doing which his want of skill would have set the world on fire, had he not been struck with a thunderbolt by Jupiter, and hurled headlong into the river Po.
Pitch: A throw; a toss; a cast, as of something from the hand; as, a good pitch in quoits.
Physiological: Of or pertaining to physiology; relating to the science of the functions of living organism; as, physiological botany or chemistry.
Pilot balloon: A small, unmanned balloon sent up to indicate the direction of air currents.
Prasinous: Grass-green; clear, lively green, without any mixture.
Proceleusmatic: A foot consisting of four short syllables.
partial: Of, pertaining to, or affecting, a part only; not general or universal; not total or entire; as, a partial eclipse of the moon.
Pituitary: Secreting mucus or phlegm; as, the pituitary membrane, or the mucous membrane which lines the nasal cavities.
Probe-pointed: Having a blunt or button-shaped extremity; -- said of cutting instruments.
Phytochemistry: Chemistry in its relation to vegetable bodies; vegetable chemistry.
Pitchy: Partaking of the qualities of pitch; resembling pitch.
Phyllopoda: An order of Entomostraca including a large number of species, most of which live in fresh water. They have flattened or leaflike legs, often very numerous, which they use in swimming. Called also Branchiopoda.
Pastil: A small cone or mass made of paste of gum, benzoin, cinnamon, and other aromatics, -- used for fumigating or scenting the air of a room.
Precious: Of great price; costly; as, a precious stone.
Plano-orbicular: Plane or flat on one side, and spherical on the other.
pro-lifer: One who is opposed to voluntary abortion; one who is pro-life, especially an activist in the campaign to make abortion illegal.
Perdicine: Of or pertaining to the family Perdicidæ, or partridges.
Pitchfork: To pitch or throw with, or as with, a pitchfork.
Peridium: The envelope or coat of certain fungi, such as the puffballs and earthstars.
Postulatory: Of the nature of a postulate.
Perstringe: To touch; to graze; to glance on.
Pterylosis: The arrangement of feathers in definite areas.
Polygonometry: The doctrine of polygons; an extension of some of the principles of trigonometry to the case of polygons.
Prostration: The act of prostrating, throwing down, or laying fiat; as, the prostration of the body.
Perique: A kind of tobacco with medium-sized leaf, small stem, tough and gummy fiber, raised in Louisiana, and cured in its own juices, so as to be very dark colored, usually black. It is marketed in tightly wrapped rolls called carottes.
Phasing: Pertaining to phase or differences of phase.
Preachman: A preacher; -- so called in contempt.
Pinfeathered: Having part, or all, of the feathers imperfectly developed.
Paleontology: The science which treats of the ancient life of the earth, or of fossils which are the remains of such life.
Patrician: Originally, a member of any of the families constituting the populus Romanus, or body of Roman citizens, before the development of the plebeian order; later, one who, by right of birth or by special privilege conferred, belonged to the nobility.
Paludose: Growing or living in marshy places; marshy.
Perforator: One who, or that which, perforates; esp., a cephalotome.
Perfectional: Of or pertaining to perfection; characterized by perfection.
Potluck: Whatever may chance to be in the pot, or may be provided for a meal.
Pepsi: Pepsi Cola; -- a familiar contraction; as, I prefer Pepsi to Coke.
Patronage: To act as a patron of; to maintain; to defend.
Pectineal: Of or pertaining to the pecten.
Posology: The science or doctrine of doses; dosology.
Praam: A flat-bottomed boat or lighter, -- used in Holland and the Baltic, and sometimes armed in case of war.
Planet: A celestial body which revolves about the sun in an orbit of a moderate degree of eccentricity. It is distinguished from a comet by the absence of a coma, and by having a less eccentric orbit. See Solar system.
Pyrite: A common mineral of a pale brass-yellow color and brilliant metallic luster, crystallizing in the isometric system; iron pyrites; iron disulphide.
Paroxytone: A word having an acute accent on the penultimate syllable.
Prepense: Devised, contrived, or planned beforehand; preconceived; premeditated; aforethought; -- usually placed after the word it qualifies; as, malice prepense.
Photospheric: Of or pertaining to the photosphere.
Psychopomp: A leader or guide of souls .
Plagiostomous: Of or pertaining to the Plagiostomi.
Preserver: One who, or that which, preserves, saves, or defends, from destruction, injury, or decay; esp., one who saves the life or character of another.
Platen: The part of a printing press which presses the paper against the type and by which the impression is made.
pachuca tank: A high and narrow tank, with a central cylinder for the introduction of compressed air, used in the agitation and settling of pulp (pulverized ore and water) during treatment by the cyanide process; -- so named because, though originally devised in New Zealand, it was first practically introduced in Pachuca, Mexico.
Penalty: Penal retribution; punishment for crime or offense; the suffering in person or property which is annexed by law or judicial decision to the commission of a crime, offense, or trespass.
Plater: A horse that runs chiefly in plate, esp. selling-plate, races; hence, an inferior race horse.
Polyuria: A persistently excessive flow of watery urine, with low specific gravity and without the presence of either protein or sugar. It is generally accompanied with more or less thirst.
Pitiful: Full of pity; tender-hearted; compassionate; kind; merciful; sympathetic.
Presentness: The quality or state of being present; presence.
Paganity: The state of being a pagan; paganism.
Passionately: In a passionate manner; with strong feeling; ardently.
Plenitude: The quality or state of being full or complete; fullness; completeness; abundance; as, the plenitude of space or power.
Peat: A substance of vegetable origin, consisting of roots and fibers, moss, etc., in various stages of decomposition, and found, as a kind of turf or bog, usually in low situations, where it is always more or less saturated with water.  It is often dried and used for fuel.
Pear: The fleshy pome, or fruit, of a rosaceous tree (Pyrus communis), cultivated in many varieties in temperate climates; also, the tree which bears this fruit. See Pear family, below.
Peripteral: Having columns on all sides; -- said of an edifice. See Apteral.
Pean: A song of praise and triumph. See Pæan.
Praxinoscope: An instrument, similar to the phenakistoscope, for presenting to view, or projecting upon a screen, images the natural motions of real objects.
Peal: To utter or give forth loudly; to cause to give out loud sounds; to noise abroad.
Peeress: The wife of a peer; a woman ennobled in her own right, or by right of marriage.
Peak: To raise to a position perpendicular, or more nearly so; as, to peak oars, to hold them upright; to peak a gaff or yard, to set it nearer the perpendicular.
Peag: A kind of aboriginal shell money, or wampum, of the Atlantic coast of the United States; -- originally applied only to polished white cylindrical beads.  See also wampum.
Pyrotechnic: Of or pertaining to fireworks, or the art of forming them.
Plaudit: A mark or expression of applause; praise bestowed.
Privy: A partaker; a person having an interest in any action or thing; one who has an interest in an estate created by another; a person having an interest derived from a contract or conveyance to which he is not himself a party.  The term, in its proper sense, is distinguished from party.
Proven\u00e7al: A native or inhabitant of Provence in France.
Pseudovary: The organ in which pseudova are produced; -- called also pseudovarium.
Profundity: The quality or state of being profound; depth of place, knowledge, feeling, etc.
Prevenance: A going before; anticipation in sequence or order.
Paludal: Of or pertaining to marshes or fens; marshy.
Poachy: Wet and soft; easily penetrated by the feet of cattle; -- said of land
Pseudocarp: That portion of an anthocarpous fruit which is not derived from the ovary, as the soft part of a strawberry or of a fig.
Physemaria: A group of simple marine organisms, usually classed as the lowest of the sponges. They have inflated hollow bodies.
Propretor: A magistrate who, having been pretor at home, was appointed to the government of a province.
Pyrosmalite: A mineral, usually of a pale brown or of a gray or grayish green color, consisting chiefly of the hydrous silicate of iron and manganese; -- so called from the odor given off before the blowpipe.
Postpliocene: Of or pertaining to the period immediately following the Pliocene; Pleistocene. Also used as a noun. See Quaternary.
parasiticidal: Capable of destroying parasites, especially capable of expelling or destroying parasitic worms.
Postulated: Assumed without proof; as, a postulated inference.
Pancarte: A royal charter confirming to a subject all his possessions.
Pagurian: Any one of a tribe of anomuran crustaceans, of which Pagurus is a type; the hermit crab. See Hermit crab, under Hermit.
Pedigerous: Bearing or having feet or legs.
Preignition: Ignition in an internal-combustion engine while the inlet valve is open or before compression is completed.
Peacock Throne: A famous throne formerly of the kings of Delhi, India, but since 1739, when it was carried off by Nadir Shah, held by the shahs of Persia (now Iran); -- so called from its bearing a fully expanded peacock's tail done in gems.
Pompeian: Of, pertaining to, or characteristic of, Pompeii, an ancient city of Italy, buried by an eruption of Vesuvius in 79 a. d., and partly uncovered by modern excavations.
Pedarian: One of a class eligible to the office of senator, but not yet chosen, who could sit and speak in the senate, but could not vote; -- so called because he might indicate his opinion by walking over to the side of the party he favored when a vote was taken.
Prognathi: A comprehensive group of mankind, including those that have prognathous jaws.
Photoplay: A play for representation or exhibition by moving pictures; also, the moving-picture representation of a play.
Pandemonium: The great hall or council chamber of demons or evil spirits.
Plover: Any one of numerous species of limicoline birds belonging to the family Charadridæ, and especially those belonging to the subfamily Charadrinsæ. They are prized as game birds.
Petrescent: Petrifying; converting into stone; as, petrescent water.
Peremptorily: In a peremptory manner; absolutely; positively.
Purple: To make purple; to dye of purple or deep red color; as, hands purpled with blood.
peppy: Full of pep; spirited; bouncy{2}; as, the peppy and interesting talk.
Puffiness: The quality or state of being puffy.
paper: To cover or line with paper, especially with wallpaper; to furnish with paper hangings; to wallpaper; as, to paper a room or a house.
pang: A paroxysm of extreme pain or anguish; a sudden and transitory agony; a throe; as, the pangs of death.
Prefigurement: The act of prefiguring; prefiguration; also, that which is prefigured.
Purposely: With purpose or design; intentionally; with predetermination; designedly.
Purpureo-: A combining form signifying of a purple or purple-red color. Specif. (Chem.), used in designating certain brilliant purple-red compounds of cobaltic chloride and ammonia, similar to the roseocobaltic compounds. See Cobaltic.
Parental: Of or pertaining to a parent or to parents; as, parental authority; parental obligations; parental affection.
Pleomorphic: Pertaining to pleomorphism; as, the pleomorphic character of bacteria.
Palmales: A natural family of chiefly tropical trees and shrubs coextensive with the family Palmae; -- the palms.
Priapean: A species of hexameter verse so constructed as to be divisible into two portions of three feet each, having generally a trochee in the first and the fourth foot, and an amphimacer in the third; -- applied also to a regular hexameter verse when so constructed as to be divisible into two portions of three feet each.
Placoides: A group of fishes including the sharks and rays; the Elasmobranchii; -- called also Placoidei.
Pycnite: A massive subcolumnar variety of topaz.
Placeman: One who holds or occupies a place; one who has office under government.
Putrefy: To become putrid; to decay offensively; to rot.
Poinciana: A prickly tropical shrub (Cæsalpinia, formerly Poinciana, pulcherrima), with bipinnate leaves, and racemes of showy orange-red flowers with long crimson filaments.
Paradactylum: The side of a toe or finger.
Polemic: One who writes in support of one opinion, doctrine, or system, in opposition to another; one skilled in polemics; a controversialist; a disputant.
Proudly: In a proud manner; with lofty airs or mien; haughtily; arrogantly; boastfully.
Precarious: Depending on the will or pleasure of another; held by courtesy; liable to be changed or lost at the pleasure of another; as, precarious privileges.
Poly: A whitish woolly plant (Teucrium Polium) of the order Labiatæ, found throughout the Mediterranean region. The name, with sundry prefixes, is sometimes given to other related species of the same genus.
Pupal: Of or pertaining to a pupa, or the condition of a pupa.
Paradised: Placed in paradise; enjoying delights as of paradise.
Pole: Either extremity of an axis of a sphere; especially, one of the extremities of the earth's axis; as, the north pole.
Planer tree: A small-leaved North American tree (Planera aquatica) related to the elm, but having a wingless, nutlike fruit.
Polo: A Spanish gypsy dance characterized by energetic movements of the body while the feet merely shuffle or glide, with unison singing and rhythmic clapping of hands.
Peopled: Stocked with, or as with, people; inhabited.
Pastoral: A poem describing the life and manners of shepherds; a poem in which the speakers assume the character of shepherds; an idyl; a bucolic.
Phenose: A sweet amorphous deliquescent substance obtained indirectly from benzene, and isometric with, and resembling, dextrose.
paperhanging: The application of wallpaper to walls for decorative purposes.
penicillin: Any of a variety of substances having a structure containing a beta-lactam ring fused to a thiirane ring, to which a carboxyl group is attached, but most commonly interpreted as benzyl penicillin.  They are notable as powerful antibacterial agents of relatively low toxicity which have found extensive use in medicine for treating bacterial infections.  They are categorized as one of the classes of beta-lactam antibiotic.  They are produced naturally by some fungi and bacteria, and industrial production processes almost invariably start from some form of the penicillin nucleus produced by fermentation of microorganisms.  The fermentation products are then chemically modified to produce derivatives of enhanced potency, safety, or antibacterial spectrum.  The first penicillin to see extensive use clinically (during World War II) was penicillin G, also called benzypenicillin, and commonly simply “penicillin”.
Polysyndetic: Characterized by polysyndeton, or the multiplication of conjunctions.
Picture: To draw or paint a resemblance of; to delineate; to represent; to form or present an ideal likeness of; to bring before the mind.
Pipemouth: Any fish of the genus Fistularia; -- called also tobacco pipefish. See Fistularia.
Pipeclay: To whiten or clean with pipe clay, as a soldier's accouterments.
Polemonium: A genus of gamopetalous perennial herbs, including the Jacob's ladder and the Greek valerian.
Pasturage: Grazing ground; grass land used for pasturing; pasture.
Perichondrium: The membrane of fibrous connective tissue which closely invests cartilage, except where covering articular surfaces.
Preconsign: To consign beforehand; to make a previous consignment of.
Pepper box: A buttress on the left-hand wall of a fives court as the game is played at Eton College, England.
Pyoxanthose: A greenish yellow crystalline coloring matter found with pyocyanin in pus.
Perfuse: To suffuse; to fill full or to excess.
Principle: To equip with principles; to establish, or fix, in certain principles; to impress with any tenet, or rule of conduct, good or ill.
Peer: To be, or to assume to be, equal.
Posthumously: In a posthumous manner; after one's decease.
Proudness: The quality of being proud; pride.
Pronate: Somewhat prone; inclined; as, pronate trees.
Poudrette: A manure made from night soil, dried and mixed with charcoal, gypsum, etc.
Presphenoidal: Of or pertaining to the presphenoid bone; presphenoid.
Protohippus: A genus of fossil horses from the Lower Pliocene. They had three toes on each foot, the lateral ones being small.
Paillon: A thin leaf of metal, as for use in gilding or enameling, or to show through a translucent medium.
Paganish: Of or pertaining to pagans; heathenish.
Parer: One who, or that which, pares; an instrument for paring.
Polluted: Defiled; made unclean or impure; debauched.
Porporino: A composition of quicksilver, tin, and sulphur, forming a yellow powder, sometimes used by mediæval artists, for the sake of economy, instead of gold.
Persuasion: The act of persuading; the act of influencing the mind by arguments or reasons offered, or by anything that moves the mind or passions, or inclines the will to a determination.
Personality: That which constitutes distinction of person; the externally evident aspects of the character or behavior of a person; individuality.
Poundrate: A rate or proportion estimated at a certain amount for each pound; poundage.
pitsaw: A large two-handed saw formerly used to cut logs into planks; one man stood above the log and the other in a pit below.
Petzite: A telluride of silver and gold, related to hessite.
Pruinose: Frosty; covered with fine scales, hairs, dust, bloom, or the like, so as to give the appearance of frost.
Photobiotic: Requiring light to live; incapable of living without light; as, photobiotic plant cells.
Paraphragma: One of the outer divisions of an endosternite of Crustacea.
Phlebotomy: The act or practice of opening a vein for letting blood, in the treatment of disease; venesection; bloodletting.
Pectinal: A fish whose bones resemble comb teeth.
Pansophical: All-wise; claiming universal knowledge; as, pansophical pretenders.
Pyrroline: A nitrogenous base, C4H7N, obtained as a colorless liquid by the reduction of pyrrole.
Pyramidic: Of or pertaining to a pyramid; having the form of a pyramid; pyramidal.
Papiliones: The division of Lepidoptera which includes the butterflies.
Putrescence: The state of being putrescent; putrescent matter.
Puncto: A nice point of form or ceremony.
Pestilently: In a pestilent manner; mischievously; destructively.
Postman: A post or courier; a letter carrier.
Phlogosis: Inflammation of external parts of the body; erysipelatous inflammation.
Pot-walloper: A voter in certain boroughs of England, where, before the passage of the reform bill of 1832, the qualification for suffrage was to have boiled (walloped) his own pot in the parish for six months.
Prickly ash: A prickly shrub (Xanthoxylum Americanum) with yellowish flowers appearing with the leaves; also called toothache tree. All parts of the plant are pungent and aromatic.  The southern species is Xanthoxylum Carolinianum.
Pentachenium: A dry fruit composed of five carpels, which are covered by an epigynous calyx and separate at maturity.
Pallone: An Italian game, played with a large leather ball.
Palpebral: Of or pertaining to the eyelids.
Peevishness: The quality of being peevish; disposition to murmur; sourness of temper.
Pollard: To lop the tops of, as trees; to poll; as, to pollard willows.
Protector: One who, or that which, defends or shields from injury, evil, oppression, etc.; a defender; a guardian; a patron.
Penicillate: Having the form of a pencil; furnished with a pencil of fine hairs; ending in a tuft of hairs like a camel's-hair brush, as the stigmas of some grasses.
Pegador: A species of remora (Echeneis naucrates). See Remora.
Photometric: Of or pertaining to photometry, or to a photometer.
Physicochemical: Involving the principles of both physics and chemistry; dependent on, or produced by, the joint action of physical and chemical agencies.
Potentize: To render the latent power of (anything) available.
Potassoxyl: The radical KO, derived from, and supposed to exist in, potassium hydroxide and other compounds.
Portfolio: A portable case for holding loose papers, prints, drawings, etc.
Pagodite: Agalmatolite; -- so called because sometimes carved by the Chinese into the form of pagodas. See Agalmatolite.
Phrenomagnetism: The power of exciting the organs of the brain by magnetic or mesmeric influence.
Primness: The quality or state of being prim; affected formality or niceness; preciseness; stiffness.
Pulas: The East Indian leguminous tree Butea frondosa. See Gum Butea, under Gum.
Picine: Of or pertaining to the woodpeckers (Pici), or to the Piciformes.
Peeler: A nickname for a policeman; -- so called from Sir Robert Peel.
Penguin: Any bird of the order Impennes, or Ptilopteri.  They are covered with short, thick feathers, almost scalelike on the wings, which are without true quills.  They are unable to fly, but use their wings to aid in diving, in which they are very expert.  See King penguin, under Jackass.
Prime: To be renewed, or as at first.
Puppetish: Resembling a puppet in appearance or action; of the nature of a puppet.
Peristyle: A range of columns with their entablature, etc.; specifically, a complete system of columns, whether on all sides of a court, or surrounding a building, such as the cella of a temple. Used in the former sense, it gives name to the larger and inner court of a Roman dwelling, the peristyle. See Colonnade.
Plummet: A piece of lead attached to a line, used in sounding the depth of water.
Primp: To be formal or affected in dress or manners; -- often with up.
Passeres: An order, or suborder, of birds, including more that half of all the known species.  It embraces all singing birds (Oscines), together with many other small perching birds.
Pauline: Of or pertaining to the apostle Paul, or his writings; resembling, or conforming to, the writings of Paul; as, the Pauline epistles; Pauline doctrine.
Peneplain: A land surface reduced by erosion to the general condition of a plain, but not wholly devoid of hills; a base-level plain.
Primipilar: Of or pertaining to the captain of the vanguard of a Roman army.
Pharmacosiderite: A hydrous arsenate of iron occurring in green or yellowish green cubic crystals; cube ore.
Polynomial: Containing many names or terms; multinominal; as, the polynomial theorem.
Prelacy: The office or dignity of a prelate; church government by prelates.
Perpetrator: One who perpetrates; esp., one who commits an offense or crime.
Plumber: One who works in lead; esp., one who furnishes, fits, and repairs lead pipes.
Pteranodon: A genus of American Cretaceous pterodactyls destitute of teeth. Several species are known, some of which had an expanse of wings of twenty feet or more.
Pimelic: Pertaining to, or designating, a substance obtained from certain fatty substances, and subsequently shown to be a mixture of suberic and adipic acids.
Preaortic: In front, or on the ventral side, of the aorta.
Pitman: One who works in a pit, as in mining, in sawing timber, etc.
Phase out: To halt (an activity) in steps, or gradually; as, to phase out use of 386-based PC's.
pachouli: A small East Indian shrubby mint (Pogostemon cablin); a fragrant oil from its leaves is used in perfumes.
Perusal: The act of carefully viewing or examining.
Proportionality: The state of being in proportion.
Perfectionment: The act of bringing to perfection, or the state of having attained to perfection.
Pagination: The act or process of paging a book; also, the characters used in numbering the pages; page number.
Pharisaism: The notions, doctrines, and conduct of the Pharisees, as a sect.
Purparty: A share, part, or portion of an estate allotted to a coparcener.
Pentastich: A composition consisting of five verses.
peacetime: A period of time during which there is no war; as, civil liberties are valued more highly in peacetime than in war.
Probabiliorist: One who holds, in opposition to the probabilists, that a man is bound to do that which is most probably right.
Purgatorian: One who holds to the doctrine of purgatory.
Phraseologist: A collector or coiner of phrases.
Propane: A heavy gaseous hydrocarbon, C3H8, of the paraffin series, occurring naturally dissolved in crude petroleum, and also made artificially; -- called also propyl hydride.
Parietary: Any one of several species of Parietaria. See 1st Pellitory.
Pesterous: Inclined to pester. Also, vexatious; encumbering; burdensome.
Prisage: A right belonging to the crown of England, of taking two tuns of wine from every ship importing twenty tuns or more, -- one before and one behind the mast. By charter of Edward I. butlerage was substituted for this.
Pericambium: A layer of thin-walled young cells in a growing stem, in which layer certain new vessels originate.
Polychromous: Of or pertaining to polychromy; many-colored; polychromatic.
Pedigree clause: A clause sometimes inserted in contracts or specifications, requiring that a material of construction, as cement, must be of a brand that has stood the test of a specified number of years' use in an important public work.
Posteriors: The hinder parts, as of an animal's body.
Phalangist: Any arboreal marsupial of the genus Phalangista.  The vulpine phalangist (Phalangista vulpina) is the largest species, the full grown male being about two and a half feet long.  It has a large bushy tail.
Pieplant: A plant (Rheum Rhaponticum) the leafstalks of which are acid, and are used in making pies; the garden rhubarb.
panfish: Any of numerous small food fishes; especially those not available on the market.
Polyconic: Pertaining to, or based upon, many cones.
Promerops: Any one of several species of very brilliant birds belonging to Promerops, Epimarchus, and allied genera, closely related to the paradise birds, and mostly native of New Guinea. They have a long curved beak and a long graduated tail.
patroller: An individual or a member of a group that patrols an area.
Pervert: One who has been perverted; one who has turned to error, especially in religion; -- opposed to convert. See the Synonym of Convert.
Parasceve: Among the Jews, the evening before the Sabbath.
Planimetry: The mensuration of plane surfaces; -- distinguished from stereometry, or the mensuration of volumes.
pacemaker: a specialized bit of heart tissue that controls the heartbeat.
Prompt: A limit of time given for payment of an account for produce purchased, this limit varying with different goods. See Prompt-note.
Ponghee: A Buddhist priest of the higher orders in Burmah.
Puffer: One who puffs; one who praises with noisy or extravagant commendation.
Predicability: The quality or state of being predicable, or affirmable of something, or attributed to something.
Parasang: A Persian measure of length, which, according to Herodotus and Xenophon, was thirty stadia, or somewhat more than three and a half miles.  The measure varied in different times and places, and, as now used, is estimated at from three and a half to four English miles.
Poyou: A South American armadillo (Dasypus sexcinctus). Called also sixbanded armadillo.
Party-coated: Having a motley coat, or coat of divers colors.
Pyocyanin: A blue coloring matter found in the pus from old sores, supposed to be formed through the agency of a species of bacterium (Bacillus pyocyaneus).
Pancratiastic: Of or pertaining to the pancratium.
Pooh-pooh: To make light of; to treat with derision or contempt, as if by saying pooh! pooh!
Polychronious: Enduring through a long time; chronic.
Pyrognostic: Of or pertaining to characters developed by the use of heat; pertaining to the characters of minerals when examined before the blowpipe; as, the pyrognostic characters of galena.
Procambium: The young tissue of a fibrovascular bundle before its component cells have begun to be differentiated.
Promove: To move forward; to advance; to promote.
Poking-stick: A small stick or rod of steel, formerly used in adjusting the plaits of ruffs.
Piggish: Relating to, or like, a pig; greedy.
Patchwork: Work composed of pieces sewed together, esp. pieces of various colors and figures; hence, anything put together of incongruous or ill-adapted parts; something irregularly or clumsily composed; a thing patched up.
Proverbialize: To turn into a proverb; to speak in proverbs.
Phonic: Of or pertaining to sound; of the nature of sound; acoustic.
Provincialist: One who lives in a province; a provincial.
Practicable: That may be practiced or performed; capable of being done or accomplished with available means or resources; feasible; as, a practicable method; a practicable aim; a practicable good.
Platinocyanide: A double cyanide of platinum and some other metal or radical; a salt of platinocyanic acid.
Pelletise: To form into small balls; as, to pelletize ore.  The spelling pelletise is mostly British.
Penicil: A tent or pledget for wounds or ulcers.
Postdate: A date put to a bill of exchange or other paper, later than that when it was actually made.
Prolificate: To make prolific; to fertilize; to impregnate.
Potiche: A vase with a separate cover, the body usually rounded or polygonal in plan with nearly vertical sides, a neck of smaller size, and a rounded shoulder.
Proportionate: To make proportional; to adjust according to a settled rate, or to due comparative relation; to proportion; as, to proportionate punishment to crimes.
Penetrable: Capable of being penetrated, entered, or pierced. Used also figuratively.
partsong: A song with two or more voice parts.
Prefidence: The quality or state of being prefident.
Pteryla: One of the definite areas of the skin of a bird on which feathers grow; -- contrasted with apteria.
Phase converter: A machine for converting an alternating current into an alternating current of a different number of phases and the same frequency.
Polygynian: Having many styles; belonging to the order Polygynia.
Parthenogenetic: Of, pertaining to, or produced by, parthenogenesis; as, parthenogenetic forms.
Philistine: Of or pertaining to the Philistines.
Pericellular: Surrounding a cell; as, the pericellular lymph spaces surrounding ganglion cells.
Procedendo: A writ by which a cause which has been removed on insufficient grounds from an inferior to a superior court by certiorari, or otherwise, is sent down again to the same court, to be proceeded in there.
Perfervid: Very fervid; too fervid; glowing; ardent.
Papillomatous: Of, pertaining to, or consisting of, papillomata.
Pot-valiant: Having the courage given by drink.
Perplexed: Entangled, involved, or confused; hence, embarrassd; puzzled; doubtful; anxious.
Periproct: The region surrounding the anus, particularly of echinoderms.
Passional: Of or pertaining to passion or the passions; exciting, influenced by, or ministering to, the passions.
Prescious: Foreknowing; having foreknowledge; as, prescious of ills.
Pseudosphere: The surface of constant negative curvature generated by the revolution of a tractrix. This surface corresponds in non-Euclidian space to the sphere in ordinary space. An important property of the surface is that any figure drawn upon it can be displaced in any way without tearing it or altering in size any of its elements.
Petrescence: The process of changing into stone; petrification.
Papistic: Of or pertaining to the Church of Rome and its doctrines and ceremonies; pertaining to popery; popish; -- used disparagingly.
Perityphlitis: Inflammation of the connective tissue about the cæcum.
Prodigal: One who expends money extravagantly, viciously, or without necessity; one that is profuse or lavish in any expenditure; a waster; a spendthrift.
Perigraph: A careless or inaccurate delineation of anything.
Picoid: Like or pertaining to the Pici.
Pomme blanche: The prairie turnip. See under Prairie.
Penetrant: Having power to enter or pierce; penetrating; sharp; subtile; as, penetrant cold.
Purfling: Ornamentation on the border of a thing; specifically, the inlaid border of a musical instrument, as a violin.
Poundcake: A kind of rich, sweet cake; -- so called from the ingredients being used by pounds, or in equal quantities.
Protometals: A finer form of metals, indicated by enhanced lines in their spark spectra (which are also observed in the spectra of some stars), obtained at the highest available laboratory temperatures (Lockyer); as protocalcium, protochromium, protocopper, protonickel, protosilicon, protostrontium, prototitanium, protovanadium.
Platinochloride: A double chloride of platinum and some other metal or radical; a salt of platinochloric acid.
Pray: To address earnest request to; to supplicate; to entreat; to implore; to beseech.
Pithiness: The quality or state of being pithy.
Penang lawyer: A kind of walking stick made from the stem of an East Asiatic palm (Licuala acutifida).
Persulphocyanogen: An orange-yellow substance, produced by the action of chlorine or boiling dilute nitric acid and sulphocyanate of potassium; -- called also pseudosulphocyanogen, perthiocyanogen, and formerly sulphocyanogen.
Pompelmous: A shaddock, esp. one of large size.
Phototypy: The art or process of producing phototypes.
Pollinctor: One who prepared corpses for the funeral.
palm: The inner and somewhat concave part of the hand between the bases of the fingers and the wrist.
Pilentum: An easy chariot or carriage, used by Roman ladies, and in which the vessels, etc., for sacred rites were carried.
Pram: a perambulator{3}; -- British informal shortened form.
Patriciate: The patrician class; the aristocracy; also, the office of patriarch.
Pseudonym: A fictitious name assumed for the time, as by an author; a pen name; an alias.
Patricianism: The rank or character of patricians.
Post-temporal: Situated back of the temporal bone or the temporal region of the skull; -- applied especially to a bone which usually connects the supraclavicle with the skull in the pectoral arch of fishes.
Piquancy: The quality or state of being piquant.
Polymerous: Having many parts or members in each set.
Primogenitureship: The state or privileges of the firstborn.
Perspicacious: Having the power of seeing clearly; quick-sighted; sharp of sight.
Photomechanical: Pertaining to, or designating, any photographic process in which a printing surface is obtained without the intervention of hand engraving.
Pace: To walk over with measured tread; to move slowly over or upon; as, the guard paces his round.
Pendice: A sloping roof; a lean-to; a penthouse.
Philomath: A lover of learning; a scholar.
Pack: To make up packs, bales, or bundles; to stow articles securely for transportation.
Pentadactyl: Having five digits to the hand or foot.
Pilosity: The quality or state of being pilose; hairiness.
Pit: To place or put into a pit or hole.
Pons: A bridge; -- applied to several parts which connect others, but especially to the pons Varolii, a prominent band of nervous tissue situated on the ventral side of the medulla oblongata and connected at each side with the hemispheres of the cerebellum; the mesocephalon. See Brain.
Prescience: Knowledge of events before they take place; foresight.
Phal\u00e6na: A linnæan genus which included the moths in general.
Pone: An original writ, now superseded by the writ of certiorari, for removing a case from an inferior court into the Court of Exchequer.
Psychoanalysis: A method or process of psychotherapeutic analysis and treatment pf psychoneuroses, based on the work of Dr. Sigmund Freud (1856- 1939) of Vienna. The method rests upon the theory that neurosis is characteristically due to repression of desires consciously rejected but subconsciously persistent; it consists in a close analysis of the patient's mental history, effort being made to bring unconsciuos and preconscious material to consciousness; the methods include analysis of transferance and resistance.  In some variants, stress is laid upon the dream life, and of treatment by means of suggestion.
Phytolithology: The branch of science which treats of fossil plants; -- usually called paleobotany, sometimes paleophytology.
Pasch: The passover; the feast of Easter.
Pediatric: Pertaining to the care and medical treatment of children.
Persienne: Properly, printed calico, whether Oriental or of fanciful design with flowers, etc., in Western work. Hence, as extended in English, material of a similar character.
Pilgrimize: To wander as a pilgrim; to go on a pilgrimage.
Pantler: The servant or officer, in a great family, who has charge of the bread and the pantry.
Pollock: A marine gadoid fish (Pollachius carbonarius), native both of the European and American coasts. It is allied to the cod, and like it is salted and dried. In England it is called coalfish, lob, podley, podling, pollack, etc.
Polecat: A small European carnivore of the Weasel family (Putorius fœtidus). Its scent glands secrete a substance of an exceedingly disagreeable odor. Called also fitchet, foulmart, and European ferret.
Paucispiral: Having few spirals, or whorls; as, a paucispiral operculum or shell.
Prevarication: The act of prevaricating, shuffling, or quibbling, to evade the truth or the disclosure of truth; a deviation from the truth and fair dealing.
Phyllome: A foliar part of a plant; any organ homologous with a leaf, or produced by metamorphosis of a leaf.
Portraiture: To represent by a portrait, or as by a portrait; to portray.
Predorsal: Situated in front of the back; immediately in front, or on the ventral side the dorsal part of the vertebral column.
Palpable: Capable of being touched and felt; perceptible by the touch; as, a palpable form.
Pygobranchia: A division of opisthobranchiate mollusks having the branchiæ in a wreath or group around the anal opening, as in the genus Doris.
Phormium: A genus of liliaceous plants, consisting of one species (Phormium tenax). See Flax-plant.
pastor: A shepherd; one who has the care of flocks and herds.
Pneumonic: A medicine for affections of the lungs.
Predispose: To dispose or incline beforehand; to give a predisposition or bias to; as, to predispose the mind to friendship.
Promising: Making a promise or promises; affording hope or assurance; as, promising person; a promising day.
Paroxysm: The fit, attack, or exacerbation, of a disease that occurs at intervals, or has decided remissions or intermissions.
Pr\u00e6oral: Same as Preoral, Prepubis, Prescapula, etc.
Phalanstery: An association or community organized on the plan of Fourier. See Fourierism.
Phonetization: The act, art, or process of representing sounds by phonetic signs.
Protoxidize: To combine with oxygen, as any elementary substance, in such proportion as to form a protoxide.
Pontificality: The state and government of the pope; the papacy.
paired: Organized into compatible pairs; -- used of gloves, socks, etc.  See pair{1}, v. t.
Ptyalism: Salivation, or an excessive flow of saliva.
Pliant: Capable of plying or bending; readily yielding to force or pressure without breaking; flexible; pliable; lithe; limber; plastic; as, a pliant thread; pliant wax.  Also used figuratively: Easily influenced for good or evil; tractable; as, a pliant heart.
Perigynous: Having the ovary free, but the petals and stamens borne on the calyx; -- said of flower such as that of the cherry or peach.
Paratonnerre: A conductor of lightning; a lightning rod.
Peneidae: A natural family of tropical prawns.
Phloramine: A basic amido derivative of phloroglucin, having an astringent taste.
Phacolite: A colorless variety of chabazite; the original was from Leipa, in Bohemia.
Parka: An outer garment made of the skins of birds or mammals, worn by Eskimos, etc.
paradox: A tenet or proposition contrary to received opinion; an assertion or sentiment seemingly contradictory, or opposed to common sense; that which in appearance or terms is absurd, but yet may be true in fact.
Pseudonymity: The using of fictitious names, as by authors.
parados: An intercepting mound, erected in any part of a fortification to protect the defenders from a rear or ricochet fire; a traverse.
parallax second: An annual parallax of one second of an arc; -- applied to celestial objects outside the solar system.  It is used to measure the distance of an astronomical object from the Earth.  A star which has an annual parallax of one second of an arc is considered to be one parsec (3.26 light years) distant from the earth.  See parsec in the vocabulary.
Perennibranchiate: Having branchæ, or gills, through life; -- said especially of certain Amphibia, like the menobranchus. Opposed to caducibranchiate.
Pectosic: Of, pertaining to, resembling, or derived from, pectose; specifically, designating an acid supposed to constitute largely ordinary pectin or vegetable jelly.
Perennibranchiata: Those Batrachia which retain their gills through life, as the menobranchus.
Postage: The price established by law to be paid for the conveyance of a letter or other mailable matter by a public post.
Polygenesis: The theory that living organisms originate in cells or embryos of different kinds, instead of coming from a single cell; -- opposed to monogenesis.
Prematurity: The quality or state of being premature; early, or untimely, ripeness; as, the prematurity of genius.
Polytype: To produce a polytype of; as, to polytype an engraving.
Peduncle: The stem or stalk that supports the flower or fruit of a plant, or a cluster of flowers or fruits.
Proruption: The act or state of bursting forth; a bursting out.
Ployment: The act or movement of forming a column from a line of troops on some designated subdivision; -- the opposite of deployment.
Perseid: One of a group of shooting stars which appear yearly about the 10th of August, and cross the heavens in paths apparently radiating from the constellation Perseus. They are probably fragments of Swift's comet 1862 (III).
Polych\u00e6ta: One of the two principal groups of Chætopoda. It includes those that have prominent parapodia and fascicles of setæ. See Illust. under Parapodia.
Pewee: A common American tyrant flycatcher (Sayornis phœbe, or Sayornis fuscus). Called also pewit, and phœbe.
Pandanus: A genus of endogenous plants, native to tropical lands from Africa to Polynesia. See Screw pine.
Postfrontal: Situated behind the frontal bone or the frontal region of the skull; -- applied especially to a bone back of and below the frontal in many animals.
Paune: A kind of bread. See Pone.
Progress: To make progress in; to pass through.
Pudder: A pother; a tumult; a confused noise; turmoil; bustle.
Papillose: Covered with, or bearing, papillæ; resembling papillæ; papillate; papillar; papillary.
Precede: To go before in order of time; to occur first with relation to anything.
Plaintful: Containing a plaint; complaining; expressing sorrow with an audible voice.
Polyphagy: The practice or faculty of subsisting on many kinds of food.
panting: The act or process of breathing heavily, usually after exertion.
Petersham: A rough, knotted woolen cloth, used chiefly for men's overcoats; also, a coat of that material.
Peccability: The state or quality of being peccable; liability to sin.
Panthera: The genus of large felines including the lions; leopards; snow leopards; jaguars; tigers; cheetahs; and saber-toothed tigers.
Primer: Originally, a small prayer book for church service, containing the little office of the Virgin Mary; also, a work of elementary religious instruction.
Phocenic: Of or pertaining to dolphin oil or porpoise oil; -- said of an acid (called also delphinic acid) subsequently found to be identical with valeric acid.
Phylarch: The chief of a phyle, or tribe.
Pomm\u00e9: Having the ends terminating in rounded protuberances or single balls; -- said of a cross.
Purdah: A curtain or screen; also, a cotton fabric in blue and white stripes, used for curtains.
Potsdam group: A subdivision of the Primordial or Cambrian period in American geology; -- so named from the sandstone of Potsdam, New York. See Chart of Geology.
Paraboloid: The solid generated by the rotation of a parabola about its axis; any surface of the second order whose sections by planes parallel to a given line are parabolas.
Protomorphic: Having the most primitive character; in the earliest form; as, a protomorphic layer of tissue.
Proc\u0153lia: A division of Crocodilia, including the true crocodiles and alligators, in which the dorsal vertebræ are concave in front.
Physiognomize: To observe and study the physiognomy of.
Peytrel: The breastplate of a horse's armor or harness. [Spelt also peitrel.] See Poitrel.
Photo-electric: Pert. to, or capable of developing, photo-electricity.
Penguinery: A breeding place, or rookery, of penguins.
Prion: any of several types of protein particle lacking nucleic acid, believed to be the cause of certain slow-developing infectious diseases such as scapie in sheep, and Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease and Kuru in humans.
Phosphorous: Of or pertaining to phosphorus; resembling or containing phosphorus; specifically, designating those compounds in which phosphorus has a lower valence as contrasted with phosphoric compounds; as, phosphorous acid, H3PO3.
Printshop: A shop where prints are sold.
Prior: a prior conviction; -- said of an accused criminal.
Provincialism: A word, or a manner of speaking, peculiar to a province or a district remote from the mother country or from the metropolis; a provincial characteristic; hence, narrowness; illiberality.
Preludial: Of or pertaining to a prelude; of the nature of a prelude; introductory.
Paradigmatize: To set forth as a model or example.
parity check: The act or process of testing whether a byte or other data structure has an even or odd number of bits set to the value of 1; -- it is used primarily to detect errors in data, especially in memory banks or in data transmitted over a communications line.  The parity can be changed by assigning one bit in each data structure as the parity bit, so that the total number of bits set to the value of 1 is odd (odd parity) or even (even parity).  If parity is used for error checking the writing and reading systems must first agree on which type of parity (odd or even) to use; if the reading system detects a deviation from the agreed parity, it signals an error, to be handled by the error-handling processes of the system.
popcorn: See pop corn under pop, n..
Paleness: The quality or condition of being pale; want of freshness or ruddiness; a sickly whiteness; lack of color or luster; wanness.
Pekinese: a Chinese breed of small short-legged dogs with a long silky coat and broad flat muzzle.
Practisant: An agent or confederate in treachery.
Pastel: A crayon made of a paste composed of a color ground with gum water.
panamica: A low stingless nettle (Pilea involucrata) of Central and South America having velvety brownish-green toothed leaves and clusters of small green flowers.
Pester: To trouble; to disturb; to annoy; to harass with petty vexations.
Pigeon: To pluck; to fleece; to swindle by tricks in gambling.
Pragmatism: The quality or state of being pragmatic; in literature, the pragmatic, or philosophical, method.
Paster: One who pastes; as, a paster in a government department.
Pinking: The act of piercing or stabbing.
Presently: At present; at this time; now.
Provection: A carrying forward, as of a final letter, to a following word; as, for example, a nickname for an ekename.
Postposition: The act of placing after, or the state of being placed after.
Pre\u00ebmptor: One who preëmpts; esp., one who preëmpts public land.
Proto\u00f6rganism: An organism whose nature is so difficult to determine that it might be referred to either the animal or the vegetable kingdom.
Plaid: Having a pattern or colors which resemble a Scotch plaid; checkered or marked with bars or stripes at right angles to one another; as, plaid muslin.
Pentosan: One of a class of substances (complex carbohydrates widely distributed in plants, as in fruits, gums, woods, hay, etc.) which yield pentoses on hydrolysis.
Plain: To plane or level; to make plain or even on the surface.
Plait: To fold; to double in narrow folds; to pleat; as, to plait a ruffle.
Parvis: A court of entrance to, or an inclosed space before, a church; hence, a church porch; -- sometimes formerly used as place of meeting, as for lawyers.
Poitrel: The breastplate of the armor of a horse. See Peytrel.
Powerless: Destitute of power, force, or energy; weak; impotent; not able to produce any effect.
Plateful: Enough to fill a plate; as much as a plate will hold.
Polyspast: A machine consisting of many pulleys; specifically, an apparatus formerly used for reducing luxations.
Phase in: To begin an activity or to incorporate new elements or replace older elements of an activity in steps, or by degrees.
Possessor: One who possesses; one who occupies, holds, owns, or controls; one who has actual participation or enjoyment, generally of that which is desirable; a proprietor.
Prorhinal: Situated in front of the nasal chambers.
Polymorph: A substance capable of crystallizing in several distinct forms; also, any one of these forms.  Cf. Allomorph.
Pteridophyta: A class of flowerless plants, embracing ferns, horsetails, club mosses, quillworts, and other like plants. See the Note under Cryptogamia.
Police: To keep in order by police.
Premosaic: Relating to the time before Moses; as, premosaic history.
Pseudo-heart: Any contractile vessel of invertebrates which is not of the nature of a real heart, especially one of those pertaining to the excretory system.
Peptonuria: The presence of peptone, or a peptonelike body, in the urine; now referred to as proteinuria.
Pharmacon: A medicine or drug; also, a poison.
Pentapetalous: Having five petals, or flower leaves.
Policy: A ticket or warrant for money in the public funds.
Pyruvil: A complex nitrogenous compound obtained by heating together pyruvic acid and urea.
Pinochle: A game at cards, played with forty-eight cards, being all the cards above the eight spots in two packs.
Pharmacology: Knowledge of drugs or medicines; the art of preparing medicines.
Peludo: The South American hairy armadillo (Dasypus villosus).
Preference: The act of Preferring, or the state of being preferred; the setting of one thing before another; precedence; higher estimation; predilection; choice; also, the power or opportunity of choosing; as, to give him his preference.
Pentafid: Divided or cleft into five parts.
Payment: The act of paying, or giving compensation; the discharge of a debt or an obligation.
Peppermint: An aromatic and pungent plant of the genus Mentha (Mentha piperita), much used in medicine and confectionery.
Polysyllabism: The quality or state of being polysyllabic.
Piperonal: A white crystalline substance obtained by oxidation of piperic acid, and regarded as a complex aldehyde.
Presidio: A place of defense; a fortress; a garrison; a fortress; a garrison or guardhouse.
Plumule: The first bud, or gemmule, of a young plant; the bud, or growing point, of the embryo, above the cotyledons. See Illust. of Radicle.
Provencial: Of or pertaining to Provence in France.
Papulose: Having papulæ; papillose; as, a papulose leaf.
Physopod: One of the Physopoda; a thrips.
Physalia: A genus of large oceanic Siphonophora which includes the Portuguese man-of-war.
Putter: To act inefficiently or idly; to occupy oneself in a liesurely manner; to trifle; to potter; as, to putter around in the garden.
Pseudovum: An egglike germ produced by the agamic females of some insects and other animals, and by the larvæ of certain insects. It is capable of development without fertilization. See Illust. of Pædogenesis.
Puttee: A kind of gaiter of waterproof cloth wrapped around the leg, used by soldiers, etc.
Perfectible: Capable of becoming, or being made, perfect.
Preceptor: One who gives commands, or makes rules; specifically, the master or principal of a school; a teacher; an instructor.
parallel-park: To park (a vehicle) parallel to the curb; -- contrasted with angle-park; as, to get a driver's license, one needs to be able to parallel-park.
Preterit: The preterit; also, a word in the preterit tense.
Pinching: Compressing; nipping; griping; niggardly; as, pinching cold; a pinching parsimony.
Pingle: A small piece of inclosed ground.
Painty: Unskillfully painted, so that the painter's method of work is too obvious; also, having too much pigment applied to the surface.
Pioned: A Shakespearean word of disputed meaning; perh., “abounding in marsh marigolds.”
Piperylene: A hydrocarbon obtained by decomposition of certain piperidine derivatives.
Phryganeid: Any insect belonging to the Phryganeides.
Pinnate: Consisting of several leaflets, or separate portions, arranged on each side of a common petiole, as the leaves of a rosebush, a hickory, or an ash. See Abruptly pinnate, and Illust., under Abruptly.
Prattle: Trifling or childish tattle; empty talk; loquacity on trivial subjects; prate; babble.
Par\u00e1 cress: An annual asteraceous herb (Spilances oleracea) grown in tropical countries as a pungent salad, and also used medicinally.
paddymelon: Any of several small reddish-brown wallabies of scrubby areas of Australia and New Guinea, especially those belonging to the genus Thylogale.
Prelatist: One who supports of advocates prelacy, or the government of the church by prelates; hence, a high-churchman.
Processionalist: One who goes or marches in a procession.
Parmesan: Of or pertaining to Parma in Italy.
Platinum: A metallic element of atomic number 78, one of the noble metals, classed with silver and gold as a precious metal, occurring native or alloyed with other metals and also as the platinum arsenide (sperrylite). It is a heavy tin-white metal which is ductile and malleable, but very infusible (melting point 1772° C), and characterized by its resistance to strong chemical reagents. It is used for crucibles in laboratory operations, as a catalyst, in jewelry, for stills for sulphuric acid, rarely for coin, and in the form of foil and wire for many purposes. Specific gravity 21.5. Atomic weight 195.1.  Symbol Pt.  Formerly called platina.
Physali\u00e6: An order of Siphonophora which includes Physalia.
Propterygium: The anterior of three principal cartilages in the fins of some fishes.
Point alphabet: An alphabet for the blind with a system of raised points corresponding to letters.
Peach-colored: Of the color of a peach blossom.
Pluteal: Of or pertaining to a pluteus.
Peduncled: Having a peduncle; supported on a peduncle; pedunculate.
Plunket: A kind of blue color; also, anciently, a kind of cloth, generally blue.
Pedicellina: A genus of Bryozoa, of the order Entoprocta, having a bell-shaped body supported on a slender pedicel. See Illust. under Entoprocta.
Peltier effect: The production or absorption of heat at the junction of two metals on the passage of a current. Heat generated by the passage of the current in one direction will be absorbed if the current is reversed.
Panathen\u00e6a: The most ancient and important festival of Athens, celebrated in honor of Athena, the tutelary goddess of the city.
Photographic: Of or pertaining to photography; obtained by photography; used ib photography; as a photographic picture; a photographic camera.
Plain-laid: Consisting of strands twisted together in the ordinary way; as, a plain-laid rope. See Illust. of Cordage.
Passing: Exceedingly; excessively; surpassingly; as, passing fair; passing strange.
Perkinism: A remedial treatment, by drawing the pointed extremities of two rods, each of a different metal, over the affected part; tractoration, -- first employed by Dr. Elisha Perkins of Norwich, Conn. See Metallotherapy.
Phyllody: A retrograde metamorphosis of the floral organs to the condition of leaves.
Post-impressionism: In the broadest sense, the theory or practice of any of several groups of painters of the early 1900's, or of these groups taken collectively, whose work and theories have in common a tendency to reaction against the scientific and naturalistic character of impressionism and neo-impressionism. In a strict sense the term post-impressionism is used to denote the effort at self-expression, rather than representation, shown in the work of Cézanne, Matisse, etc.; but it is more broadly used to include cubism, the theory or practice of a movement in both painting and  sculpture which lays stress upon volume as the important attribute of objects and attempts its expression by the use of geometrical figures or solids only; and futurism, a theory or practice which attempts to place the observer within the picture and to represent simultaneously a number of consecutive movements and impressions. In practice these theories and methods of the post-impressionists change with great rapidity and shade into one another, so that a picture may be both cubist and futurist in character. They tend to, and sometimes reach, a condition in which both representation and traditional decoration are entirely abolished and a work of art becomes a purely subjective expression in an arbitrary and personal language.
Portable: Capable of being borne or carried; easily transported; conveyed without difficulty; as, a portable bed, desk, engine.
Point: To direct the point of something, as of a finger, for the purpose of designating an object, and attracting attention to it; -- with at.
Pseudobacteria: Microscopic organic particles, molecular granules, powdered inorganic substances, etc., which in form, size, and grouping resemble bacteria.
Pampero: A violent wind from the west or southwest, which sweeps over the pampas of South America and the adjacent seas, often doing great damage.
Pause: To cause to stop or rest; -- used reflexively.
Parrakeet: Any one of numerous species of small parrots having a graduated tail, which is frequently very long; -- called also paroquet and paraquet.
Popish: Of or pertaining to the pope; taught or ordained by the pope; hence, of or pertaining to the Roman Catholic Church; -- often used opprobriously.
Prox: “The ticket or list of candidates at elections, presented to the people for their votes.”
Prologue: To introduce with a formal preface, or prologue.
Phosphorate: To impregnate, or combine, with phosphorus or its compounds; as, phosphorated oil.
Polyzoary: The compound organism of a polyzoan.
Polych\u0153rany: A government by many chiefs, princes, or rules.
Pineweed: A low, bushy, nearly leafless herb (Hypericum Sarothra), common in sandy soil in the Eastern United States.
Ponderability: The quality or state of being ponderable.
Pantalet: One of the legs of the loose drawers worn by children and women; a pant leg; particularly, the lower part of such a garment, coming below the knee, often made in a separate piece; -- chiefly in the plural.
Prog: Victuals got by begging, or vagrancy; victuals of any kind; food; supplies.
Prod: To thrust some pointed instrument into; to prick with something sharp; as, to prod a soldier with a bayonet; to prod oxen; hence, to goad, to incite, to worry; as, to prod a student.
Proa: A sailing canoe of the Ladrone Islands and Malay Archipelago, having its lee side flat and its weather side like that of an ordinary boat. The ends are alike. The canoe is long and narrow, and is kept from overturning by a cigar-shaped log attached to a frame extending several feet to windward. It has been called the flying proa, and is the swiftest sailing craft known.
Pesterment: The act of pestering, or the state of being pestered; vexation; worry.
Plano-concave: Plane or flat on one side, and concave on the other; as, a plano-concave lens. See Lens.
Photopsia: An affection of the eye, in which the patient perceives luminous rays, flashes, coruscations, etc. See phosphene.
Proplastics: The art of making molds for castings.
Pretentious: Full of pretension; disposed to lay claim to more than is one's; presuming; assuming.
Pro-: A prefix signifying before, in front, forth, for, in behalf of, in place of, according to; as, propose, to place before; proceed, to go before or forward; project, to throw forward; prologue, part spoken before (the main piece); propel, prognathous; provide, to look out for; pronoun, a word instead of a noun; proconsul, a person acting in place of a consul; proportion, arrangement according to parts.
Punster: One who puns, or is skilled in, or given to, punning; a quibbler; a low wit.
Putour: A keeper of a brothel; a procurer.
Pyrocatechin: A white crystalline substance, C6H4(OH)2, of the phenol series, found in various plants; -- so called because first obtained by distillation of gum catechu. Called also catechol, oxyphenol. etc.
Pickpurse: One who steals purses, or money from purses.
Phosphonic: Pertaining to, or designating, certain derivatives of phosphorous acid containing a hydrocarbon radical, and analogous to the sulphonic acid.
Phytolite: An old name for a fossil plant.
Phalangoidea: A division of Arachnoidea, including the daddy longlegs or harvestman (Phalangium) and many similar kinds. They have long, slender, many-jointed legs; usually a rounded, segmented abdomen; and chelate jaws. They breathe by tracheæ. Called also Phalangides, Phalangidea, Phalangiida, and Opilionea.
Polybasic: Capable of neutralizing, or of combining with, several molecules of a monacid base; having several hydrogen atoms capable of being replaced by basic radicals; -- said of certain acids; as, sulphuric acid is polybasic.
Phlorol: A liquid metameric with xylenol, belonging to the class of phenols, and obtained by distilling certain salts of phloretic acid.
Particular: A separate or distinct member of a class, or part of a whole; an individual fact, point, circumstance, detail, or item, which may be considered separately; as, the particulars of a story.
Plitt: An instrument of punishment or torture resembling the knout, used in Russia.
Potcher: One who, or that which, potches.
Pirn: A quill or reed on which thread or yarn is wound; a bobbin; also, the wound yarn on a weaver's shuttle; also, the reel of a fishing rod.
Pierce: To enter; to penetrate; to make a way into or through something, as a pointed instrument does; -- used literally and figuratively.
Piles: The small, troublesome tumors or swellings about the anus and lower part of the rectum which are technically called hemorrhoids. See Hemorrhoids. [The singular pile is sometimes used.]
Piler: One who places things in a pile.
pastis: An anise-based liqueur similar to absinthe but yellowish in color and containing no wormwood.
Plantable: Capable of being planted; fit to be planted.
Pickle-herring: A herring preserved in brine; a pickled herring.
Piled: Formed from a pile or fagot; as, piled iron.
Piping: A small cord covered with cloth, -- used as trimming for women's dresses.
Pupil: A youth or scholar of either sex under the care of an instructor or tutor.
Pyrrhic: An ancient Greek martial dance, to the accompaniment of the flute, its time being very quick.
Portionist: A scholar at Merton College, Oxford, who has a certain academical allowance or portion; -- corrupted into postmaster.
Pyrophone: A musical instrument in which the tones are produced by flames of hydrogen, or illuminating gas, burning in tubes of different sizes and lengths.
Platoon: Formerly, a body of men who fired together; also, a small square body of soldiers to strengthen the angles of a hollow square.
Pinafore: An apron for a child to protect the front part of dress; a tier.
Persist: To stand firm; to be fixed and unmoved; to stay; to continue steadfastly; especially, to continue fixed in a course of conduct against opposing motives; to persevere; -- sometimes conveying an unfavorable notion, as of doggedness or obstinacy.
Partheniad: A poem in honor of a virgin.
Paramagnetic: Having or exhibiting paramagnetism; -- opposed to diamagnetic and contrasted with ferromagnetic.
Profert: The exhibition or production of a record or paper in open court, or an allegation that it is in court.
Plumularia: Any hydroid belonging to Plumularia and other genera of the family Plumularidæ. They generally grow in plumelike forms.
Platitudinarian: One addicted to uttering platitudes, or stale and insipid truisms.
Phial: To put or keep in, or as in, a phial.
Payable: That may, can, or should be paid; suitable to be paid; justly due.
pachydermal: Of or relating to the pachyderms; as, pachydermal dentition.
Patronizing: Showing condescending favor; assuming the manner of airs of a superior toward another.
Phasmid: Any orthopterous insect of the family Phasmidæ, as a leaf insect or a stick insect.
Peltate: Shield-shaped; scutiform; (Bot.) having the stem or support attached to the lower surface, instead of at the base or margin; -- said of a leaf or other organ.
Pilser: An insect that flies into a flame.
Pari-: A combining form signifying equal; as, paridigitate, paripinnate.
Popgun: A child's gun; a tube and rammer for shooting pellets, with a popping noise, by compression of air.
Passive flight: Flight, such as gliding and soaring, accomplished without the use of motive power.
pacesetter: A horse used to set the pace in racing.
Panstereorama: A model of a town or country, in relief, executed in wood, cork, pasteboard, or the like.
Posingly: So as to pose or puzzle.
Palma Christi: A plant (Ricinus communis) with ornamental peltate and palmately cleft foliage, growing as a woody perennial in the tropics, and cultivated as an herbaceous annual in temperate regions; -- called also castor-oil plant.
Pina colada: a sweet mixed drink made from rum, pineapple juice, and cream of coconut, mixed with crushed ice.
Plethysmograph: An instrument for determining and registering the variations in the size or volume of a limb, as the arm or leg, and hence the variations in the amount of blood in the limb.
Philoprogenitiveness: The love of offspring; fondness for children.
Polliwig: A tadpole; -- called also purwiggy and porwigle.
Peddle: To sell from place to place; to retail by carrying around from customer to customer; to hawk; hence, to retail in very small quantities; as, to peddle vegetables or tinware.
Pentachloride: A chloride having five atoms of chlorine in each molecule; as, phosphorus pentachloride.
packer: A person whose business is to pack things; especially, one who packs food for preservation or for the market; as, a pork packer.
Phytophaga: A division of Hymenoptera; the sawflies.
Polyphyletic: Pertaining to, or characterized by, descent from more than one root form, or from many different root forms; polygenetic; -- opposed to monophyletic.
Princedom: The jurisdiction, sovereignty, rank, or estate of a prince.
Pd: The chemical symbol for palladium, an element of the platinum group of atomic number 46.
Pandanales: An order of plants including the families Typhaceae; Sparganiaceae; and Pandanaceae.
Pi: To put into a mixed and disordered condition, as type; to mix and disarrange the type of; as, to pi a form.
Picle: A small piece of land inclosed with a hedge; a close.
Porterhouse: A house where porter is sold.
Phonoscope: An instrument for observing or exhibiting the motions or properties of sounding bodies; especially, an apparatus invented by König for testing the quality of musical strings.
Pallas: Pallas Athena, the Grecian goddess of wisdom, called also Athena, Pallas Athene or Athene, and identified, at a later period, with the Roman Minerva.
PC: A personal computer; a computer{2} designed for use by one person at a time; -- contrasted with shared-time computers such as mainframes and minicomputers, which may be accessed by multiple users each operating from a different input device (in the 1990's, usually a terminal).  A personal computer typically uses a microprocessor for its CPU.
Post-tragus: A ridge within and behind the tragus in the ear of some animals.
Pother: To harass and perplex; to worry.
Peloria: Abnormal regularity; the state of certain flowers, which, being naturally irregular, have become regular through a symmetrical repetition of the special irregularity.
Patness: Fitness or appropriateness; striking suitableness; convenience.
Phytelephas: A genus of South American palm trees, the seeds of which furnish the substance called vegetable ivory.
Pedomancy: Divination by examining the soles of the feet.
Protatic: Of or pertaining to the protasis of an ancient play; introductory.
Prebendal: Of or pertaining to a prebend; holding a prebend; as, a prebendal priest or stall.
Ponderal: Estimated or ascertained by weight; -- distinguished from numeral; as, a ponderal drachma.
Polyarchist: One who advocates polyarchy; -- opposed to monarchist.
Panslavic: Pertaining to all the Slavic races.
Producibility: The quality or state of being producible.
Psychophysics: The science of the connection between nerve action and consciousness; the science which treats of the relations of the psychical and physical in their conjoint operation in man; the doctrine of the relation of function or dependence between body and soul.
Prophragma: An internal dorsal chitinous process between the first two divisions of the thorax of insects.
Pileiform: Having the form of a pileus or cap; pileate.
Pastorally: In a pastoral or rural manner.
Pinweed: Any plant of the genus Lechea, low North American herbs with branching stems, and very small and abundant leaves and flowers.
Pelagic: Of or pertaining to the ocean; -- applied especially to animals that live at the surface of the ocean, away from the coast.  Compare benthic.
Puler: One who pules; one who whines or complains; a weak person.
Pulex: A genus of parasitic insects including the fleas. See Flea.
Phytogenesis: The doctrine of the generation of plants.
Platanus: A genus of trees; the plane tree.
Popularization: The act of making popular, or of introducing among the people.
Permissible: That may be permitted; allowable; admissible.
Propination: The act of pledging, or drinking first, and then offering the cup to another.
Phono: A South American butterfly (Ithonia phono) having nearly transparent wings.
Pentabasic: Capable of uniting with five molecules of a monacid base; having five acid hydrogen atoms capable of substitution by a basic radical; -- said of certain acids.
Perilla: A genus of labiate herbs, of which one species (Perilla ocimoides, or Perilla Nankinensis) is often cultivated for its purple or variegated foliage.
Protandric: Having male sexual organs while young, and female organs later in life.
Promote: To urge on or incite another, as to strife; also, to inform against a person.
Physiognomic: Of or pertaining to physiognomy; according with the principles of physiognomy.
Plausible: Worthy of being applauded; praiseworthy; commendable; ready.
Polygony: Any plant of the genus Polygonum.
Pharology: The art or science which treats of lighthouses and signal lights.
Prunus: A genus of trees with perigynous rosaceous flowers, and a single two-ovuled carpel which usually becomes a drupe in ripening.
Pleurothotonus: A species of tetanus, in which the body is curved laterally.
Perruquier: A marker of perukes or wigs.
Piper: One who plays on a pipe, or the like, esp. on a bagpipe.
Pupa: Any insect in that stage of its metamorphosis which usually immediately precedes the adult, or imago, stage.
Pentadactyloid: Having the form of, or a structure modified from, a pentadactyl limb.
pachytene: The third stage of the prophase of meiosis, the stage in which the pairing of homologous chromosomes has been completed.
Pendent: Supported from above; suspended; depending; pendulous; hanging; as, a pendent leaf.
Piped: Formed with a pipe; having pipe or pipes; tubular.
Pylangium: The first and undivided part of the aortic trunk in the amphibian heart.
Protophyte: Any unicellular plant, or plant forming only a plasmodium, having reproduction only by fission, gemmation, or cell division.
Palmette: A floral ornament, common in Greek and other ancient architecture; -- often called the honeysuckle ornament.
Petalite: A rare mineral, occurring crystallized and in cleavable masses, usually white, or nearly so, in color. It is a silicate of aluminia and lithia.
Pejorative: Implying or imputing evil; depreciatory; disparaging; unfavorable.
Palmetto: A name given to palms of several genera and species growing in the West Indies and the Southern United States.  In the United States, the name is applied especially to the Chamærops Palmetto, or Sabal Palmetto, the cabbage tree of Florida and the Carolinas.  See Cabbage tree, under Cabbage.
Planula: In embryonic development, a vesicle filled with fluid, formed from the morula by the divergence of its cells in such a manner as to give rise to a central space, around which the cells arrange themselves as an envelope; an embryonic form intermediate between the morula and gastrula. Sometimes used as synonymous with gastrula.
Photochemical: Of or pertaining to chemical action of light, or produced by it; as, the photochemical changes of the visual purple of the retina.
Pylagore: a deputy of a State at the Amphictyonic council.
Pleuroptera: A group of Isectivora, including the colugo.
Peyers glands: Patches of lymphoid nodules, in the walls of the small intestiness; agminated glands; -- called also Peyer's patches. In typhoid fever they become the seat of ulcers which are regarded as the characteristic organic lesion of that disease.
Protosilicate: A silicate formed with the lowest proportion of silicic acid, or having but one atom of silicon in the molecule.
Panpharmacon: A medicine for all diseases; a panacea.
Preside: To be set, or to sit, in the place of authority; to occupy the place of president, chairman, moderator, director, etc.; to direct, control, and regulate, as chief officer; as, to preside at a public meeting; to preside over the senate.
Plagal: Having a scale running from the dominant to its octave; -- said of certain old church modes or tunes, as opposed to those called authentic, which ran from the tonic to its octave.
Pirogue: A dugout canoe; by extension, any small boat.
Phrase: To use proper or fine phrases.
Pleiophyllous: Having several leaves; -- used especially when several leaves or leaflets appear where normally there should be only one.
Postscapula: The part of the scapula behind or below the spine, or mesoscapula.
Pelta: A small shield, especially one of an approximately elliptic form, or crescent-shaped.
Pensiveness: The state of being pensive; serious thoughtfulness; seriousness.
Polygordius: A genus of marine annelids, believed to be an ancient or ancestral type. It is remarkable for its simplicity of structure and want of parapodia. It is the type of the order Archiannelida, or Gymnotoma. See Loeven's larva.
Prerequisite: Something previously required, or necessary to an end or effect proposed.
Prostrate: To lay fiat; to throw down; to level; to fell; as, to prostrate the body; to prostrate trees or plants.
Pneumothorax: A condition in which air or other gas is present in the cavity of the chest; -- called also pneumatothorax.
Parenthetically: In a parenthetical manner; by way of parenthesis; by parentheses.
Predestinarianism: The system or doctrine of the predestinarians.
Portemonnaie: A small pocketbook or wallet for carrying money.
Papaver: A genus of plants, including the poppy.
Prevention: The act of going, or state of being, before.
Pathop\u0153ia: A speech, or figure of speech, designed to move the passion.
Perseverance: The act of persevering; persistence in anything undertaken; continued pursuit or prosecution of any business, or enterprise begun.
Palamede\u00e6: An order, or suborder, including the kamichi, and allied South American birds; -- called also screamers.  In many anatomical characters they are allied to the Anseres, but they externally resemble the wading birds.
Pigeonwing: A wing of a pigeon, or a wing like it.
Pickeer: To make a raid for booty; to maraud; also, to skirmish in advance of an army. See Picaroon.
Paragogic: Of, pertaining to, or constituting, a paragoge; added to the end of, or serving to lengthen, a word.
Profession: The act of professing or claiming; open declaration; public avowal or acknowledgment; as, professions of friendship; a profession of faith.
Pouch-shell: A small British and American pond snail (Bulinus hypnorum).
Ponderosity: The quality or state of being ponderous; weight; gravity; heaviness, ponderousness; as, the ponderosity of gold.
Placentalia: A division of Mammalia including those that have a placenta, or all the orders above the marsupials.
Present value: The principal which, drawing interest at a given rate, will amount to the given sum at the date on which this is to be paid; thus, interest being at 6%, the present value of $106 due one year hence is $100.
Paramorphism: The change of one mineral species to another, so as to involve a change in physical characters without alteration of chemical composition.
Ptysmagogue: A medicine that promotes the discharge of saliva.
Precentor: A leader of a choir; a directing singer.
Purvey: To purchase provisions; to provide; to make provision.
Provinciate: To convert into a province or provinces.
Powdered: Reduced to a powder; sprinkled with, or as with, powder.
Primeness: The quality or state of being first.
Pursuer: One who pursues or chases; one who follows in haste, with a view to overtake.
Potstone: A variety of steatite sometimes manufactured into culinary vessels.
Pitter-patter: With, or with the sound of, alternating light beats; as, his heart went pitter-patter.
Princesse: A term applied to a lady's long, close-fitting dress made with waist and skirt in one.
