Precursor: One who, or that which, precedes an event, and indicates its approach; a forerunner; a harbinger.
Parial: See Pair royal, under Pair, n.
Pachydactyl: A bird or other animal having thick toes.
Permeation: The act of permeating, passing through, or spreading throughout, the pores or interstices of any substance.
Phenicine: A purple powder precipitated when a sulphuric solution of indigo is diluted with water.
Pamperos: A tribe of Indians inhabiting the pampas of South America.
Pyroelectric: A substance which becomes electrically polar when heated, exhibiting opposite charges of statical electricity at two separate parts, especially the two extremities.
Prostitution: The act or practice of prostituting or offering the body to an indiscriminate intercourse with men; common lewdness of a woman.
Proctocele: Inversion and prolapse of the mucous coat of the rectum, from relaxation of the sphincter, with more or less swelling; prolapsus ani.
Paro\u00f6phoron: A small mass of tubules near the ovary in some animals, and corresponding with the parepididymis of the male.
Pipewort: Any plant of a genus (Eriocaulon) of aquatic or marsh herbs with soft grass-like leaves.
Pedro: The five of trumps in certain varieties of auction pitch.
Propulsion: The act driving forward or away; the act or process of propelling; as, steam propulsion.
Pediluvy: The bathing of the feet, a bath for the feet.
Pfennig: A small copper coin of Germany. It is the hundredth part of a mark, or about a quarter of a cent in United States currency.
Preterperfect: Old name of the tense also called preterit.
Pseudo-symmetry: A kind of symmetry characteristic of certain crystals which from twinning, or other causes, come to resemble forms of a system other than that to which they belong, as the apparently hexagonal prisms of aragonite.
Procreation: The act of begetting; generation and production of young.
Pulpiness: the quality or state of being pulpy.
Primula: The genus of plants including the primrose (Primula vera).
Phlyctenular: Characterized by the presence of small pustules, or whitish elevations resembling pustules; as, phlyctenular ophthalmia.
Pox: To infect with the pox, or syphilis.
Pargetory: Something made of, or covered with, parget, or plaster.
Pandemic: Affecting a whole people or a number of countries; everywhere epidemic.
Poodle: A breed of dogs having curly hair, and often showing remarkable intelligence in the performance of tricks.
paleencephalon: The more primitive parts of the brain phylogenetically; it includes most structures other than the cerebral cortex.
Proconsulate: The office jurisdiction of a proconsul, or the term of his office.
Placoganoidei: A division of ganoid fishes including those that have large external bony plates and a cartilaginous skeleton.
Pachyote: One of a family of bats, including those which have thick external ears.
Preataxic: Occurring before the symptom ataxia has developed; -- applied to the early symptoms of locomotor ataxia.
Propinyl: A hydrocarbon radical regarded as an essential residue of propine and allied compounds.
Plodding: Progressing in a slow, toilsome manner; characterized by laborious diligence; as, a plodding peddler; a plodding student; a man of plodding habits.
pelycosaur: A large primitive reptile having a tall spinal sail; of the Permian or late Paleozoic in Europe and North America.
Pharmaceutic: Of or pertaining to the knowledge or art of pharmacy, or to the art of preparing medicines according to the rules or formulas of pharmacy; as, pharmaceutical preparations.
Prescriptibility: The quality or state of being prescriptible.
Plethoric: Haeving a full habit of body; characterized by plethora or excess of blood; as, a plethoric constitution; -- used also metaphorically.
Pretex: To frame; to devise; to disguise or excuse; hence, to pretend; to declare falsely.
Pedial: Pertaining to the foot, or to any organ called a foot; pedal.
Prurigo: A papular disease of the skin, of which intense itching is the chief symptom, the eruption scarcely differing from the healthy cuticle in color.
Productus: An extinct genus of brachiopods, very characteristic of the Carboniferous rocks.
Prelude: To introduce with a previous performance; to play or perform a prelude to; as, to prelude a concert with a lively air.
Pyrolignite: A crude acetate produced by treating pyroligneous acid with a metal or basic compound; as, pyrolignite of iron (iron liquor).
Praise: Commendation for worth; approval expressed; honor rendered because of excellence or worth; laudation; approbation.
Psittaceous: Of or pertaining to the parrots, or the Psittaci.
Poseur: A person who poses or attitudizes, esp. mentally.
Page: To mark or number the pages of, as a book or manuscript; to furnish with folios.
Presentment: The act of presenting, or the state of being presented; presentation.
Polyurethane: any polymer containing [-NH.CO.O-] linkages; such polymers are much used as the basis of light but rigid foams for packaging (polyurethane foam) and for hard coatings, as on floors.
Protectingly: By way of protection; in a protective manner.
Pharyngotome: An instrument for incising or scarifying the tonsils, etc.
Protactic: Giving a previous narrative or explanation, as of the plot or personages of a play; introductory.
Pharyngotomy: The operation of making an incision into the pharynx, to remove a tumor or anything that obstructs the passage.
Phonographer: One versed or skilled in phonography.
Palearctic: Belonging to a region of the earth's surface which includes all Europe to the Azores, Iceland, and all temperate Asia.
Platymeter: An apparatus for measuring the capacity of condensers, or the inductive capacity of dielectrics.
Phenomenalism: That theory which limits positive or scientific knowledge to phenomena only, whether material or spiritual.
Perlustration: The act of viewing all over.
Provinciality: The quality or state of being provincial; peculiarity of language characteristic of a province.
Pressman: One of a press gang, who aids in forcing men into the naval service; also, one forced into the service.
punch line: The final sentence, phrase, or word in a joke or humorous story that is unexpected and produces the humorous effect; the point of a joke.
Pillared: Supported or ornamented by pillars; resembling a pillar, or pillars.
Petrifactive: Having the quality of converting organic matter into stone; petrifying.
Pondweed: Any aquatic plant of the genus Potamogeton, of which many species are found in ponds or slow-moving rivers.
Progressional: Of or pertaining to progression; tending to, or capable of, progress.
Protozoan: Of or pertaining to the Protozoa.
Photochemistry: The branch of chemistry which relates to the effect of light in producing chemical changes, as in photography.
Pennyroyal: An aromatic herb (Mentha Pulegium) of Europe; also, a North American plant (Hedeoma pulegioides) resembling it in flavor.
Palisade: To surround, inclose, or fortify, with palisades.
Perpetrate: To do or perform; to carry through; to execute, commonly in a bad sense; to commit (as a crime, an offense); to be guilty of; as, to perpetrate a foul deed.
Pay Cerps: A staff corps in the United States navy, consisting of pay directors, pay inspectors, paymasters, passed assistant paymasters, and assistant paymasters, having relative rank from captain to ensign, respectively.
Pipa: The Surinam toad (Pipa Americana), noted for its peculiar breeding habits.
palaetiology: The science which explains, by the law of causation, the past condition and changes of the earth; the explanation of past events in terms of scientific causes, such as geological causes.
pachinko: A popular Japanese pinball game played on a vertical board.
Pseudodox: Not true in opinion or doctrine; false.
Pylon: A low tower, having a truncated pyramidal form, and flanking an ancient Egyptian gateway.
Pitta: Any one of a large group of bright-colored clamatorial birds belonging to Pitta, and allied genera of the family Pittidæ. Most of the species are varied with three or more colors, such as blue, green, crimson, yellow, purple, and black. They are called also ground thrushes, and Old World ant thrushes; but they are not related to the true thrushes.
paperback: having a flexible binding; -- of books.  Contrasted to hardcover or hardbacked or hardbound.
phoney: something or someone that is phony.
paramagnet: A substance exhibiting paramagnetism, i.e. a substance whose magnetization is proportional to the strength of the magnetic field applied to it.
Philippian: Of or pertaining to Philippi, a city of ancient Macedonia.
Parotic: On the side of the auditory capsule; near the external ear.
panda: A small Asiatic mammal (Ailurus fulgens) having fine soft fur, which inhabits the mountains of Northern India.  It was once thought to be related to the bears, but is now believed to be more closely related to raccoons.  It has reddish-brown fur on the back and sides, and black fur on the legs and underside.  Called also the lesser panda.
Partly: In part; in some measure of degree; not wholly.
Protractive: Drawing out or lengthening in time; prolonging; continuing; delaying.
Plaguily: In a plaguing manner; vexatiously; extremely.
Propenyl: A hypothetical hydrocarbon radical, C3H5, isomeric with allyl and glyceryl, and regarded as the essential residue of glycerin.  Cf. Allyl, and Glyceryl.
Photograph: To practice photography; to take photographs.
Padre: A Christian priest or monk; used as a term of address for priests in some churches (especially Roman or Orthodox Catholic in Italy, Spain, Portugal, and Spanish America); -- also used in the American military.
Photogenic: Of or pertaining to photogeny; producing or generating light.
patrilineal: tracing descent through the male line; as, a patrilineal society.
Pineal: Of or pertaining to a pine cone; resembling a pine cone.
Polysyndeton: A figure by which the conjunction is often repeated, as in the sentence, “We have ships and men and money and stores.” Opposed to asyndeton.
Pertinence: The quality or state of being pertinent; justness of relation to the subject or matter in hand; fitness; appositeness; relevancy; suitableness.
Pitiable: Deserving pity; wworthy of, or exciting, compassion; miserable; lamentable; piteous; as, pitiable persons; a pitiable condition; pitiable wretchedness.
Priestery: Priests, collectively; the priesthood; -- so called in contempt.
Prehensile: Adapted to seize or grasp; seizing; grasping; as, the prehensile tail of a monkey.
Philomathy: The love of learning or letters.
Pseudorhabdite: One of the peculiar rodlike corpuscles found in the integument of certain Turbellaria. They are filled with a soft granular substance.
Priggism: The quality or state of being priggish; the manners of a prig.
Paragenesis: The science which treats of minerals with special reference to their origin.
Promissory: Containing a promise or binding declaration of something to be done or forborne.
Proportionately: In a proportionate manner; with due proportion; proportionally.
Prytaneum: A public building in certain Greek cities; especially, a public hall in Athens regarded as the home of the community, in which official hospitality was extended to distinguished citizens and strangers.
Petitor: One who seeks or asks; a seeker; an applicant.
Photometer: An instrument for measuring the intensity of light, or, more especially, for comparing the relative intensities of different lights, or their relative illuminating power.
Prospector: One who prospects; especially, one who explores a region for minerals and precious metals.
P\u00e8re: Father; -- often used after French proper names to distinguish a father from his son; as, Dumas père.
Paronomastic: Of or pertaining to paronomasia; consisting in a play upon words.
Parol: Given or done by word of mouth; oral; also, given by a writing not under seal; as, parol evidence.
Phthalein: One of a series of artificial organic dyes made as condensation products of the phenols with phthalic acid, and well represented by phenol phthaleïn. Their alkaline solutions are fluorescent.
Parasphenoid: Near the sphenoid bone; -- applied especially to a bone situated immediately beneath the sphenoid in the base of the skull in many animals.
Protozoa: The lowest of the grand divisions of the animal kingdom.
Perspirability: The quality or state of being perspirable.
Pourparler: A consultation preliminary to a treaty.
Pubes: The hair which appears upon the lower part of the hypogastric region at the age of puberty.
Panteutonic: Of or pertaining to all the Teutonic races.
Proportionally: In proportion; in due degree; adapted relatively; as, all parts of the building are proportionally large.
Paronymous: Having the same derivation; allied radically; conjugate; -- said of certain words, as man, mankind, manhood, etc.
paideutics: The science or art of teaching.
Proof-arm: To arm with proof armor; to arm securely; as, to proof-arm herself.
Passibility: The quality or state of being passible; aptness to feel or suffer; sensibility.
Prepositional: Of or pertaining to a preposition; of the nature of a preposition.
Pumiciform: Resembling, or having the structure of, pumice.
Pollux: A fixed star of the second magnitude, in the constellation Gemini.  Cf. 3d Castor.
Periscians: Those who live within a polar circle, whose shadows, during some summer days, will move entirely round, falling toward every point of the compass.
Prismoid: A body that approaches to the form of a prism.
Punction: A puncturing, or pricking; a puncture.
Provisionally: By way of provision for the time being; temporarily.
Phraseologic: Of or pertaining to phraseology; consisting of a peculiar form of words.
Phototaxis: The influence of light on the movements of low organisms, as various infusorians, the zoöspores of certain algæ, etc.; also, the tendency to follow definite directions of motion or assume definite positions under such influence. If the migration is toward the source of light, it is termed positive phototaxis; if away from the light, negative phototaxis.
Prebend: A payment or stipend; esp., the stipend or maintenance granted to a prebendary out of the estate of a cathedral or collegiate church with which he is connected. See Note under Benefice.
pacifical: Of or pertaining to peace; pacific.
Perispomenon: A word which has the circumflex accent on the last syllable.
Predilection: A previous liking; a prepossession of mind in favor of something; predisposition to choose or like; partiality.
Predicative: Expressing affirmation or predication; affirming; predicating, as, a predicative term.
Praiseworthiness: The quality or state of being praiseworthy.
Py\u00e6mia: A form of blood poisoning produced by the absorption of pyogenic microorganisms into the blood, usually from a wound or local inflammation. It is characterized by multiple abscesses throughout the body, and is attended with irregularly recurring chills, fever, profuse sweating, and exhaustion.
Poison bush: Any fabaceous shrub of the genus Gastrolobium, the herbage of which is poisonous to stock; also, any species of several related genera, as Oxylobium, Gompholobium, etc.
Phrenitis: Inflammation of the brain, or of the meninges of the brain, attended with acute fever and delirium; -- called also cephalitis.
Papaveraceae: A natural family of herbs or shrubs having milky and often colored juices and capsular fruits.
Pulverize: To become reduced to powder; to fall to dust; as, the stone pulverizes easily.
Phytology: The science of plants; a description of the kinds and properties of plants; botany.
Polling: The act of topping, lopping, or cropping, as trees or hedges.
Prohibitive: That prohibits; prohibitory; as, a tax whose effect is prohibitive.
Portfire: A case of strong paper filled with a composition of niter, sulphur, and mealed powder, -- used principally to ignite the priming in proving guns, and as an incendiary material in shells.
Padlock: To fasten with, or as with, a padlock; to stop; to shut; to confine as by a padlock.
Palmatisect: Divided, as a palmate leaf, down to the midrib, so that the parenchyma is interrupted.
Pillow lace: Lace made by hand with bobbins on a pillow.
Periodic: Of or pertaining to a period or periods, or to division by periods.
Prop: That which sustains an incumbent weight; that on which anything rests or leans for support; a support; a stay; as, a prop for a building.
Paragnathous: Having both mandibles of equal length, the tips meeting, as in certain birds.
Percale: A fine cotton fabric, having a linen finish, and often printed on one side, -- used for women's and children's wear, and for bedsheets.
Plutus: The son of Jason and Ceres, and the god of wealth. He was represented as bearing a cornucopia, and as blind, because his gifts were bestowed without discrimination of merit.
Phonomotor: An instrument in which motion is produced by the vibrations of a sounding body.
Patellula: A cuplike sucker on the feet of certain insects.
Prostatic: Of or pertaining to the prostate gland.
Pleyt: An old term for a river boat.
Panicum: A genus of grasses, including several hundred species, some of which are valuable; panic grass.
Prefecundation: A term collectively applied to the changes or conditions preceding fecundation, especially to the changes which the ovum undergoes before fecundation.
Presbyterian: One who maintains the validity of ordination and government by presbyters; a member of the Presbyterian church.
Postero: - (&unr_;). A combining form meaning posterior, back; as, postero-inferior, situated back and below; postero-lateral, situated back and at the side.
Puzzel: A harlot; a drab; a hussy.
Pericardiac: Of or pertaining to pericardium; situated around the heart.
Phyllorhine: Of or pertaining to Phyllorhina and other related genera of bats that have a leaflike membrane around the nostrils.
patternlike: resembling a pattern or shape or outline.
Produce race: A race to be run by the produce of horses named or described at the time of entry.
Philogyny: Fondness for women; uxoriousness; -- opposed to misogyny.
Pictish: Of or pertaining to Picts; resembling the Picts.
Petiole: A leafstalk; the footstalk of a leaf, connecting the blade with the stem. See Illust. of Leaf.
Primero: A game at cards, now unknown.
Parade: To make an exhibition or spectacle of one's self, as by walking in a public place.
Putrefaction: The act or the process of putrefying; the offensive decay of albuminous or other matter.
Pernoctation: The act or state of passing the whole night; a remaining all night.
Platinochloric: Pertaining to, derived from, or designating, an acid consisting of platinous chloride and hydrochloric acid, called platinochloric acid, or chloroplatinous, acid.
Prosopolepsy: Respect of persons; especially, a premature opinion or prejudice against a person, formed from his external appearance.
Plasticity: The quality or state of being plastic.
Photophone: An apparatus for the production of sound by the action of rays of light.
Palingenetic: Of or pertaining to palingenesis: as, a palingenetic process.
Phono-: A combining form from Gr. &unr_; sound, tone; as, phonograph, phonology.
Photophony: The art or practice of using the photophone.
Perfectly: In a perfect manner or degree; in or to perfection; completely; wholly; throughly; faultlessly.
Pinchers: An instrument having two handles and two grasping jaws working on a pivot; -- used for griping things to be held fast, drawing nails, etc.
Parthenope: One of the Sirens, who threw herself into the sea, in despair at not being able to beguile Ulysses by her songs.
Paleography: An ancient manner of writing; ancient writings, collectively; as, Punic paleography.
Pincoffin: A commercial preparation of garancin, yielding fine violet tints.
Prevailing: Having superior force or influence; efficacious; persuasive.
Pike: A foot soldier's weapon, consisting of a long wooden shaft or staff, with a pointed steel head. It is now superseded by the bayonet.
Pageant: To exhibit in show; to represent; to mimic.
paltry: Mean; vile; worthless; despicable; contemptible; pitiful; trifling; as, a paltry excuse; paltry gold.
Pika: Any one of several species of tailless rodents of the genus Ochotona (formerly Lagomys), resembling small rabbits, but with short ears alnd legs. They inhabit the high mountains of Asia and America. Called also calling hare, and crying hare and rock rabbit. See Chief hare.
Pleopod: One of the abdominal legs of a crustacean. See Illust. under Crustacea.
Puzzle-headed: Having the head full of confused notions; given to getting perplexed over simple matters; also, characteristic of persons that are so.
Parament: Ornamental hangings, furniture, etc., as of a state apartment; rich and elegant robes worn by men of rank; -- chiefly in the plural.
Particularism: A minute description; a detailed statement.
Paleologist: One versed in paleology; a student of antiquity.
Penal: Of or pertaining to punishment, to penalties, or to crimes and offenses; pertaining to criminal jurisprudence
Publicist: A writer on the laws of nature and nations; one who is versed in the science of public right, the principles of government, etc.
Psilosopher: A superficial or narrow pretender to philosophy; a sham philosopher.
Pentail: A peculiar insectivore (Ptilocercus Lowii) of Borneo; -- so called from its very long, quill-shaped tail, which is scaly at the base and plumose at the tip.
Proteolytic: Converting proteid or albuminous matter into soluble and diffusible products, as peptones.
Police power: The inherent power of a government to regulate its police affairs.
Perbromide: A bromide having a higher proportion of bromine than any other bromide of the same substance or series.
Peculium: The saving of a son or a slave with the father's or master's consent; a little property or stock of one's own; any exclusive personal or separate property.
Pruriginous: Tending to, or caused by, prurigo; affected by, or of the nature of, prurigo.
Petiolar: Of or pertaining to petiole, or proceeding from it; as, a petiolar tendril; growing or supported upon a petiole; as, a petiolar gland; a petiolar bud.
Poppit: a small plastic bead  with opposed holes and protuberant knobs, so shaped that the beads may be fastened to each other in chains and detached easily, and can be used to form variable-length chains for use as necklaces, bracelets, or other ornamental objects.  Also called poppet and poppit bead.
Platinize: To cover or combine with platinum.
Pteropodous: Of or pertaining to the Pteropoda.
Perfidy: The act of violating faith or allegiance; violation of a promise or vow, or of trust reposed; faithlessness; treachery.
Progenerate: To beget; to generate; to produce; to procreate; as, to progenerate a race.
Pantology: A systematic view of all branches of human knowledge; a work of universal information.
Puerility: The quality of being puerile; childishness; puerileness.
Patchouli: A small shrubby mintlike plant (Pogostemon cablin syn. Pogostemon Patchouli) of the East Indies, yielding an essential oil from which a highly valued perfume is made.
Pearmain: The name of several kinds of apples; as, the blue pearmain, winter pearmain, and red pearmain.
Phelloderm: A layer of green parenchimatous cells formed on the inner side of the phellogen.
Protectiveness: The quality or state of being protective.
Preen: To dress up neatly and smartly; to make oneself well-groomed and well-dressed.
Protrusive: Thrusting or impelling forward; as, protrusive motion.
Preraphaelite: One who favors or practices art as it was before Raphael; one who favors or advocates preraphaelitism.
Perula: One of the scales of a leaf bud.
Pomace: The substance of apples, or of similar fruit, crushed by grinding.
Provoking: Having the power or quality of exciting resentment; tending to awaken passion or vexation; as, provoking words or treatment.
Petrohyoid: Pertaining to petrous, oe periotic, portion of the skull and the hyoid arch; as, the petrohyoid muscles of the frog.
Pyrotartaric: Pertaining to, or designating, an acid obtained as a white crystalline substance by the distillation of tartaric acid.
Proteiform: Changeable in form; resembling a Proteus, or an amœba.
Primulaceous: Of or pertaining to an order of herbaceous plants (Primulaceæ), of which the primrose is the type, and the pimpernel, the cyclamen, and the water violet are other examples.
PAC: A political action committee, a committee formed by an organization or special-interest group to raise money to support candidates for office or to influence legislation.  A PAC provides a legal means for corporations in the U. S. to support political candidates even when direct contributions from corporations to candidates is forbidden by law.  In theory, the corporation may not itself contribute to a PAC, but may pay the expenses of raising money from individuals.  PACs may also be formed by organizations other than commercial corporations, such as trade associations.
Proseminary: A seminary which prepares pupils for a higher institution.
Pandiculation: A stretching and stiffening of the trunk and extremities, as when fatigued and drowsy.
Preambulation: A walking or going before; precedence.
Photography: The science which relates to the action of light on sensitive bodies in the production of pictures, the fixation of images, and the like.
Pluckiness: The quality or state of being plucky.
Pi\u00e9douche: A pedestal of small size, used to support small objects, as busts, vases, and the like.
Pre\u00ebxistentism: The theory of a preëxistence of souls before their association with human bodies.
paysheet: the total amount of money paid in wages; as, the company had a large paysheet.
Pargasite: A dark green aluminous variety of amphibole, or hornblende.
Phonology: The science or doctrine of the elementary sounds uttered by the human voice in speech, including the various distinctions, modifications, and combinations of tones; phonetics. Also, a treatise on sounds.
Purana: One of a class of sacred Hindoo poetical works in the Sanskrit language which treat of the creation, destruction, and renovation of worlds, the genealogy and achievements of gods and heroes, the reigns of the Manus, and the transactions of their descendants. The principal Puranas are eighteen in number, and there are the same number of supplementary books called Upa Puranas.
Physostomous: Having a duct to the air bladder.
Posset: To curdle; to turn, as milk; to coagulate; as, to posset the blood.
Preceptive: Containing or giving precepts; of the nature of precepts; didactic; as, the preceptive parts of the Scriptures.
Parusia: A figure of speech by which the present tense is used instead of the past or the future, as in the animated narration of past, or in the prediction of future, events.
Pommett\u00e9: Having two balls or protuberances at each end; -- said of a cross.
Prescapular: Of or pertaining to the prescapula; supraspinous.
Phylactocarp: A branch of a plumularian hydroid specially modified in structure for the protection of the gonothecæ.
Parallelogram: A right-lined quadrilateral figure, whose opposite sides are parallel, and consequently equal; -- sometimes restricted in popular usage to a rectangle, or quadrilateral figure which is longer than it is broad, and with right angles.
Pentateuchal: Of or pertaining to the Pentateuch.
Predella: The step, or raised secondary part, of an altar; a superaltar; hence, in Italian painting, a band or frieze of several pictures running along the front of a superaltar, or forming a border or frame at the foot of an altarpiece.
Philadelphian: A native or an inhabitant of Philadelphia.
Predigest: To subject (food) to predigestion or artificial digestion.
Propylic: Pertaining to, derived from, or containing, propyl; as, propylic alcohol.
Perturbability: The quality or state of being perturbable.
Priced: Rated in price; valued; as, high-priced goods; low-priced labor.
Polony: A kind of sausage made of meat partly cooked.
Preconception: The act of preconceiving; conception or opinion previously formed.
Proverbially: In a proverbial manner; by way of proverb; hence, commonly; universally; as, it is proverbially said; the bee is proverbially busy.
Plasson: The albuminous material composing the body of a cytode.
Patefaction: The act of opening, disclosing, or manifesting; open declaration.
Pedimana: A division of marsupials, including the opossums.
Piquant: Stimulating to the taste; giving zest; tart; sharp; pungent; as, a piquant anecdote.
packaged: Enclosed in a package{2} or protective covering; as, packaged cereals.
Pyramidoid: A solid resembling a pyramid; -- called also pyramoid.
Pick-me-up: A stimulant, restorative, or tonic; a bracer.
Plashing: The cutting or bending and intertwining the branches of small trees, as in hedges.
Put-off: A shift for evasion or delay; an evasion; an excuse.
Paraselene: A mock moon; an image of the moon which sometimes appears at the point of intersection of two lunar halos.  Cf. Parhelion.
Pharmacodymanics: That branch of pharmacology which treats of the action and the effects of medicines in the body, and also their distribution in various bodily tissues over time, and their breakdown and excretion.
parrotfish: Any of several gaudy tropical fishes of the family Scaridae having parrotlike beaks formed by fusion of teeth.
Puggry: A light scarf wound around a hat or helmet to protect the head from the sun.
Phytophagous: Feeding on plants; herbivorous; as, a phytophagous animal.
Pentamerus: A genus of extinct Paleozoic brachiopods, often very abundant in the Upper Silurian.
Peabody bird: An American sparrow (Zonotrichia albicollis) having a conspicuous white throat. The name is imitative of its note. Called also White-throated sparrow.
Perich\u00e6tial: Of or pertaining to the perichæth.
Plymouth Brethren: The members of a religious sect which first appeared at Plymouth, England, about 1830. They protest against sectarianism, and reject all official ministry or clergy. Also called Brethren, Christian Brethren, Plymouthists, etc. The Darbyites are a division of the Brethren.
Poussette: To perform a certain movement in a dance.
Physiophyly: The tribal history of the functions, or the history of the paleontological development of vital activities, -- being a branch of phylogeny. See Morphophyly.
Potestate: A chief ruler; a potentate. [Obs.] Wyclif.
Pontifician: One who adheres to the pope or papacy; a papist.
Praxis: Use; practice; especially, exercise or discipline for a specific purpose or object.
Pharisee: One of a sect or party among the Jews, noted for a strict and formal observance of rites and ceremonies and of the traditions of the elders, and whose pretensions to superior sanctity led them to separate themselves from the other Jews.
Peri\u0153ci: Those who live on the same parallel of latitude but on opposite meridians, so that it is noon in one place when it is midnight in the other. Compare Antœci.
Pomposity: The quality or state of being pompous; pompousness.
Prisoner: One who is confined in a prison.
Piggery: A place where swine are kept.
Pyritaceous: Of or pertaining to pyrites. See Pyritic.
Patentee: One to whom a grant is made, or a privilege secured, by patent.
Puncture: To pierce with a small, pointed instrument, or the like; to prick; to make a puncture in; as, to puncture the skin.
Pseudoneuroptera: division of insects (Zoöl.) reticulated wings, as in the Neuroptera, but having an active pupa state. It includes the dragon flies, May flies, white ants, etc. By some zoölogists they are classed with the Orthoptera; by others, with the Neuroptera.
Picra: The powder of aloes with canella, formerly officinal, employed as a cathartic.
Politicaster: A petty politician; a pretender in politics.
Pug-faced: Having a face like a monkey or a pug; monkey-faced.
Pushpin: A child's game played with pins.
Precipitance: The quality or state of being precipitant, or precipitate; headlong hurry; excessive or rash haste in resolving, forming an opinion, or executing a purpose; precipitation; as, the precipitancy of youth.
Psitta-co-fulvine: A yellow pigment found in the feathers of certain parrots.
Psittaci: The order of birds which comprises the parrots.
Pha\u00ebton: A four-wheeled carriage (with or without a top), open, or having no side pieces, in front of the seat. It is drawn by one or two horses.
Poachiness: The state of being poachy; marshiness.
Phatagin: The long-tailed pangolin (Manis tetradactyla); -- called also ipi.
Placentary: Having reference to the placenta; as, the placentary system of classification.
Put-up: Arranged; plotted; -- in a bad sense; as, a put-up job.
Poly-: A combining form or prefix from Gr. poly`s, many; as, polygon, a figure of many angles; polyatomic, having many atoms; polychord, polyconic.
Phocacean: Any species of Phoca; a seal.
Pentavalent: Having a valence of five; -- said of certain atoms and radicals.
Pentathionic: Pertaining to, or designating, an acid of sulphur obtained by leading hydrogen sulphide into a solution of sulphur dioxide; -- so called because it contains five atoms of sulphur.
Prate: Talk to little purpose; trifling talk; unmeaning loquacity.
Placit: A decree or determination; a dictum.
Pyrheliometer: An instrument for measuring the direct heating effect of the sun's rays.
Placid: Pleased; contented; unruffied; undisturbed; serene; peaceful; tranquil; quiet; gentle.
Peroxidation: Act, process, or result of peroxidizing; oxidation to a peroxide.
Pyro\u00fcric: Pertaining to, or designating, an acid now called cyanuric acid. See Cyanuric.
Pullman car: A kind of sleeping car; also, a palace car; -- often shortened to Pullman.
Polyp: One of the feeding or nutritive zooids of a hydroid or coral.
Petrary: An ancient war engine for hurling stones.
Pelycosauria: An order of extinct reptiles including edaphosaurus and dimetrodon.
Parhelion: A mock sun appearing in the form of a bright light, sometimes near the sun, and tinged with colors like the rainbow, and sometimes opposite to the sun.  The latter is usually called an anthelion.  Often several mock suns appear at the same time.  Cf. Paraselene.
Paraschematic: Of or pertaining to a change from the right form, as in the formation of a word from another by a change of termination, gender, etc.
Photo-engraving: The process of obtaining an etched or engraved plate from the photographic image, to be used in printing; also, a picture produced by such a process.
Plumming: The operation of finding, by means of a mine dial, the place where to sink an air shaft, or to bring an adit to the work, or to find which way the lode inclines.
Permeable: Capable of being permeated, or passed through; yielding passage; passable; penetrable; -- used especially of substances which allow the passage of fluids; as, wood is permeable to oil; glass is permeable to light.
Photoheliometer: A double-lens instrument for measuring slight variations of the sun's diameter by photography, utilizing the common chord of two overlapping images.
Propel: To drive forward; to urge or press onward by force; to move, or cause to move; as, the wind or steam propels ships; balls are propelled by gunpowder.
Physically: In a physical manner; according to the laws of nature or physics; by physical force; not morally.
Polyptoton: A figure by which a word is repeated in different forms, cases, numbers, genders, etc., as in Tennyson's line, -- “My own heart's heart, and ownest own, farewell.”
Prosperity: The state of being prosperous; advance or gain in anything good or desirable; successful progress in any business or enterprise; attainment of the object desired; good fortune; success; as, commercial prosperity; national prosperity.
Proper: Properly; hence, to a great degree; very; as, proper good.
Premaxilla: A bone on either side of the middle line between the nose and mouth, forming the anterior part of each half of the upper jawbone; the intermaxilla. In man the premaxillæ become united and form the incisor part of the maxillary bone.
Pittle-pattle: To talk unmeaningly; to chatter or prattle.
Parterre: An ornamental and diversified arrangement of beds or plots, in which flowers are cultivated, with intervening spaces of gravel or turf for walking on.
Pharyngolaryngeal: Of or pertaining both to pharynx and the larynx.
Plagiostomi: An order of fishes including the sharks and rays; -- called also Plagiostomata.
Pelisse: An outer garment for men or women, originally of fur, or lined with fur; a lady's or child's long outer garment, made of silk or other fabric.
Passage: The act of passing; transit from one place to another; movement from point to point; a going by, over, across, or through; as, the passage of a man or a carriage; the passage of a ship or a bird; the passage of light; the passage of fluids through the pores or channels of the body.
Petitioning: The act of presenting apetition; a supplication.
Pretorium: The general's tent in a Roman camp; hence, a council of war, because held in the general's tent.
Penology: The science or art of punishment.
Pappus: The hairy or feathery appendage of the achenes of thistles, dandelions, and most other plants of the order Compositæ; also, the scales, awns, or bristles which represent the calyx in other plants of the same order.
Proximally: On or toward a proximal part; proximad.
Pistillody: The metamorphosis of other organs into pistils.
Pur\u00e9e: A dish made by boiling any article of food to a pulp and rubbing it through a sieve; as, a purée of fish, or of potatoes; especially, a soup the thickening of which is so treated.
Panderous: Of or relating to a pander; characterizing a pander.
paradoxism: An avant-garde movement in literature, art, and philosophy, based on excessive used of antitheses, antinomies, contradictions, oxymorons, and paradoxes.
Prier: One who pries; one who inquires narrowly and searches, or is inquisitive.
Puerileness: The quality of being puerile; puerility.
Presignification: The act of signifying or showing beforehand.
Phototelegraphy: Telegraphy by means of light, as by the heliograph or the photophone. Also, less properly, telephotography.
Pitying: Expressing pity; as, a pitying eye, glance, or word.
Prolongable: Capable of being prolonged; as, life is prolongable by care.
Polled: Deprived of a poll, or of something belonging to the poll. Specifically: (a) Lopped; -- said of trees having their tops cut off. (b) Cropped; hence, bald; -- said of a person. “The polled bachelor.” Beau. & Fl. (c) Having cast the antlers; -- said of a stag. (d) Without horns; as, polled cattle; polled sheep.
Profitable: Yielding or bringing profit or gain; gainful; lucrative; useful; helpful; advantageous; beneficial; as, a profitable trade; profitable business; a profitable study or profession.
Pointleted: Having a small, distinct point; apiculate.
pachysandra: Any plant of the genus Pachysandra; they are low-growing evergreen herbs or subshrubs having dentate leaves and used as ground cover.
Poker: Any imagined frightful object, especially one supposed to haunt the darkness; a bugbear.
Piceous: Of or pertaining to pitch; resembling pitch in color or quality; pitchy.
Permian: Belonging or relating to the period, and also to the formation, next following the Carboniferous, and regarded as closing the Carboniferous age and Paleozoic era.
Pyrites: A name given to a number of metallic minerals, sulphides of iron, copper, cobalt, nickel, and tin, of a white or yellowish color.
Pupivora: A group of parasitic Hymenoptera, including the ichneumon flies, which destroy the larvæ and pupæ of insects.
palaeopathology: The study of diseases of former times (as inferred from fossil evidence).
Persisting: Inclined to persist; tenacious of purpose; persistent.
Perplexiveness: The quality of being perplexing; tendency to perplex.
Prothetic: Of or pertaining to prothesis; as, a prothetic apparatus.
Panchway: A Bengalese four-oared boat for passengers.
Place: To assign a place to; to put in a particular spot or place, or in a certain relative position; to direct to a particular place; to fix; to settle; to locate; as, to place a book on a shelf; to place balls in tennis.
Pooler: A stick for stirring a tan vat.
Paxwax: The strong ligament of the back of the neck in quadrupeds.  It connects the back of the skull with dorsal spines of the cervical vertebræ, and helps to support the head. Called also paxywaxy and packwax.
Polygamia: A Linnæan class of plants, characterized by having both hermaphrodite and unisexual flowers on the same plant.
Plack: A small copper coin formerly current in Scotland, worth less than a cent.
Propagate: To have young or issue; to be produced or multiplied by generation, or by new shoots or plants; as, rabbits propagate rapidly.
Placoid: Any fish having placoid scales, as the sharks.
Purveyor: One who provides victuals, or whose business is to make provision for the table; a victualer; a caterer.
Planometer: An instrument for gauging or testing a plane surface. See Surface gauge, under Surface.
Pikeman: A soldier armed with a pike.
Printing: The act, art, or practice of impressing letters, characters, or figures on paper, cloth, or other material; the business of a printer, including typesetting and presswork, with their adjuncts; typography; also, the act of producing photographic prints.
Pretext: Ostensible reason or motive assigned or assumed as a color or cover for the real reason or motive; pretense; disguise.
Pedestal: The base or foot of a column, statue, vase, lamp, or the like; the part on which an upright work stands.  It consists of three parts, the base, the die or dado, and the cornice or surbase molding. See Illust. of Column.
Priory: A religious house presided over by a prior or prioress; -- sometimes an offshoot of, an subordinate to, an abbey, and called also cell, and obedience. See Cell, 2.
Poison: To act as, or convey, a poison.
Piperine: A white crystalline compound of piperidine and piperic acid. It is obtained from the black pepper (Piper nigrum) and other species.
Planchet: A flat piece of metal; especially, a disk of metal ready to be stamped as a coin.
Porti\u00e8re: A curtain hanging across a doorway.
Polytocous: Bearing fruit repeatedly, as most perennial plants; polycarpic.
Pastorage: The office, jurisdiction, or duty, of a pastor; pastorate.
Precipitation: The act of precipitating, or the state of being precipitated, or thrown headlong.
Potter: To poke; to push; also, to disturb; to confuse; to bother.
Potboy: A boy who carries pots of ale, beer, etc.; a menial in a public house.
Perishableness: The quality or state of being perishable; liability to decay or destruction.
Placidity: The quality or state of being placid; calmness; serenity.
Podrida: A miscellaneous dish of meats. See Olla-podrida.
Professorial: Of or pertaining to a professor; as, the professional chair; professional interest.
Proportionable: Capable of being proportioned, or made proportional; also, proportional; proportionate.
Patience: The state or quality of being patient; the power of suffering with fortitude; uncomplaining endurance of evils or wrongs, as toil, pain, poverty, insult, oppression, calamity, etc.
Polysilicic: Of or pertaining to compounds formed by the condensation of two or more molecules of silicic acid.
Periodical: A magazine or other publication which appears at stated or regular intervals.
Pleomorphism: The property of crystallizing under two or more distinct fundamental forms, including dimorphism and trimorphism.
Pipit: Any one of numerous species of small singing birds belonging to Anthus and allied genera, of the family Motacillidæ. They strongly resemble the true larks in habits, colors, and the great length of the hind claw. They are, therefore, often called titlarks, and pipit larks.
Poorly: Somewhat ill; indisposed; not in health.
Polymyoid: Having numerous vocal muscles; of or pertaining to the Polymyodæ.
Polyplastic: Assuming, or having the power of assuming, many forms; as, a polyplastic element which does not preserve its original shape.
Pulkha: A Laplander's traveling sledge. See Sledge.
Photogrammeter: A phototheodolite, or a camera designed for use in photogrammetry.
Pembroke table: A style of four-legged drop-leaf table in vogue in England, chiefly in the later Georgian period.
Phanerogamic: Having visible flowers containing distinct stamens and pistils; -- said of plants.
Pentastyle: Having five columns in front; -- said of a temple or portico in classical architecture.
Phanerogamia: That one of the two primary divisions of the vegetable kingdom which contains the phanerogamic, or flowering, plants.
Padge: The barn owl; -- called also pudge, and pudge owl.
Pomology: The science of fruits; a treatise on fruits; the cultivation of fruits and fruit trees.
Pillage: To take spoil; to plunder; to ravage.
Protagonist: One who takes the leading part in a drama; hence, one who takes lead in some great scene, enterprise, conflict, or the like.
Packfong: A Chinese alloy of nickel, zinc, and copper, resembling German silver.
Polyembryony: The production of two or more embryos in one seed, due either to the existence and fertilization of more than one embryonic sac or to the origination of embryos outside of the embryonic sac.
Precisive: Cutting off; (Logic) exactly limiting by cutting off all that is not absolutely relative to the purpose; as, precisive censure; precisive abstraction.
Plinth: In classical architecture, a vertically faced member immediately below the circular base of a column; also, the lowest member of a pedestal; hence, in general, the lowest member of a base; a sub-base; a block upon which the moldings of an architrave or trim are stopped at the bottom. See Illust. of Column.
Probationary: Of or pertaining to probation; serving for trial.
Percheron: One of a breed of draught horses originating in Perche, an old district of France; -- called also Percheron-Norman.
Pennipotent: Strong of wing; strong on the wing.
pacer: One who, or that which, paces.
Playmate: A companion in diversions; a playfellow.
Pandanaceae: A natural family of woody plants including the pandanus tree (the screw pine) and freycinetia.
Pleach: To unite by interweaving, as branches of trees; to plash; to interlock.
Perdifoil: A deciduous plant; -- opposed to evergreen.
Porcelain: A fine translucent or semitransculent kind of earthenware, made first in China and Japan, but now also in Europe and America; -- called also China, or China ware.
Pseudoblepsis: False or depraved sight; imaginary vision of objects.
Planting: The act or operation of setting in the ground for propagation, as seeds, trees, shrubs, etc.; the forming of plantations, as of trees; the carrying on of plantations, as of sugar, coffee, etc.
patina: A dish or plate of metal or earthenware; a patella.
Parsley: An aromatic umbelliferous herb (Carum Petroselinum), having finely divided leaves which are used in cookery and as a garnish.
Pupiparous: Bearing, or containing, a pupa; -- said of the matured larvæ, or larval skins, of certain Diptera.
Patelliform: Having the form of a patella.
pachyderm: Any of various nonruminant hoofed mammals having very thick skin, including the elephant, rhinoceros, and hippopotamus, one of the Pachydermata.
Pedomotive: Moved or worked by the action of the foot or feet on a pedal or treadle.
Paragenic: Originating in the character of the germ, or at the first commencement of an individual; -- said of peculiarities of structure, character, etc.
Porcupine: Any Old Word rodent of the genus Hystrix, having the back covered with long, sharp, erectile spines or quills, sometimes a foot long. The common species of Europe and Asia (Hystrix cristata) is the best known.
Placophora: A division of gastropod Mollusca, including the chitons.  The back is covered by eight shelly plates.  Called also Polyplacophora. See Illust. under Chiton, and Isopleura.
Puff-legged: Having a conspicuous tuft of feathers on the legs.
Pendulousness: The quality or state of being pendulous; the state of hanging loosely; pendulosity.
Pteroglossal: Having the tongue finely notched along the sides, so as to have a featherlike appearance, as the toucans.
Poleax: Anciently, a kind of battle-ax with a long handle; later, an ax or hatchet with a short handle, and a head variously patterned; -- used by soldiers, and also by sailors in boarding a vessel.
Present: The position of a soldier in presenting arms; as, to stand at present.
Perquisite: Something gained from a place or employment over and above the ordinary salary or fixed wages for services rendered; especially, a fee allowed by law to an officer for a specific service.
Proleg: One of the fleshy legs found on the abdominal segments of the larvæ of Lepidoptera, sawflies, and some other insects. Those of Lepidoptera have a circle of hooks. Called also proped, propleg, and falseleg.
Phantasmatography: A description of celestial phenomena, as rainbows, etc.
Palo blanco: A western American hackberry (Celtis reticulata), having light-colored bark.
Policeman: A member of a body of police; a constable.
Parvanimity: The state or quality of having a little or ignoble mind; pettiness; meanness; -- opposed to magnanimity.
Pusane: A piece of armor for the breast; often, an addition to, or reënforcement of. the breastplate; -- called also pesane.
Peep sight: An adjustable piece, pierced with a small hole to peep through in aiming, attached to a rifle or other firearm near the breech; -- distinguished from an open sight.
Parcel post: That branch of the post office having to do with the collection, transmission, and delivery of parcels{4}.  The British Inland Parcel Post was established in 1883.  The rates in 1913, dating from 1897, were 3d. for parcels not exceeding one pound and 1d. for each additional pound up to the limit of 10 pounds.  A general parcel post was established in the United States by Act of August 24, 1912, which took effect Jan. 1, 1913.  At that time, parcels could not exceed 11 pounds in weight nor 72 inches in length and girth combined.  Provision is made from insuring parcels, and also for sending parcels C.O.D.  The rates of postage vary with the distance. See Zone, below.
Poppy: A raised ornament frequently having the form of a final. It is generally used on the tops of the upright ends or elbows which terminate seats, etc., in Gothic churches.
Practician: One who is acquainted with, or skilled in, anything by practice; a practitioner.
Pentecoster: An officer in the Spartan army commanding fifty men.
Phlorone: A yellow crystalline substance having a peculiar unpleasant odor, resembling the quinones, and obtained from beechwood tar and coal tar, as also by the oxidation of xylidine; -- called also xyloquinone.
Peles hair: Glass threads or fibers formed by the wind from bits blown from frothy lava or from the tips of lava jets or from bits of liquid lava thrown into the air.  It often collects in thick masses resembling tow.
Pieman: A man who makes or sells pies.
Pentelic: Of or pertaining to Mount Pentelicus, near Athens, famous for its fine white marble quarries; obtained from Mount Pentelicus; as, the Pentelic marble of which the Parthenon is built.
Pasturer: One who pastures; one who takes cattle to graze. See Agister.
Phenolphthalein: A white or yellowish white crystalline substance, C20H14O4, formed by condensation of the anhydride of phthalic acid and phenol. Its solution in alkalies is brilliant red, but is decolorized by acids.  This reaction, being very delicate, is used as an indicator.  It is sometimes used as a laxative in veterinary medicine.
Pedipalpus: One of the second pair of mouth organs of arachnids.  In some they are leglike, but in others, as the scorpion, they terminate in a claw.
PCP: a drug originally taken in the form of powder ("dust") for its hallucinogenic effects.
Phillyrin: A glucoside extracted from Phillyrea as a bitter white crystalline substance. It is sometimes used as a febrifuge.
Pederasty: Sexual activity between two males; sodomy; the “crime against nature“; -- used especially when one partner is a boy.
Pomologist: One versed in pomology; one who culticvates fruit trees.
pestillation: The act of pounding and bruising with a pestle in a mortar.
Palinodial: Of or pertaining to a palinode, or retraction.
Phenomenist: One who believes in the theory of phenomenalism.
Palato-: A combining form used in anatomy to indicate relation to the palate, or connection with the palate; as in palatolingual.
Phototelescope: A telescope adapted for taking photographs of the heavenly bodies.
Perihelion: That point of the orbit of a planet or comet which is nearest to the sun; -- opposed to aphelion.
Prizer: One who contends for a prize; a prize fighter; a challenger.
Palification: The act or practice of driving piles or posts into the ground to make it firm.
Punctuate: To mark with points; to separate into sentences, clauses, etc., by points or stops which mark the proper pauses in expressing the meaning.
Prolatum: A prolate spheroid. See Ellipsoid of revolution, under Ellipsoid.
Phthisis: A wasting or consumption of the tissues. The term was formerly applied to many wasting diseases, but is now usually restricted to pulmonary phthisis, or consumption. See Consumption.
Phonetic: Of or pertaining to the voice, or its use.
Perch: To place or to set on, or as on, a perch.
parasol: A kind of small umbrella used by women as a protection from the sun.
Perca: A genus of fishes, including the fresh-water perch.
Predominance: The quality or state of being predominant; superiority; ascendency; prevalence; predomination.
Pottage: A kind of food made by boiling vegetables or meat, or both together, in water, until soft; a thick soup or porridge.
Prudery: The quality or state of being prudish; excessive or affected scrupulousness in speech or conduct; stiffness; coyness.
Perceptivity: The quality or state of being perceptive; power of perception.
Phanerocrystalline: Distinctly crystalline; -- used of rocks. Opposed to cryptocrystalline.
Pallium: A large, square, woolen cloak which enveloped the whole person, worn by the Greeks and by certain Romans.  It is the Roman name of a Greek garment.
Phonographic: Of or pertaining to phonography; based upon phonography.
Panegyrist: One who delivers a panegyric; a eulogist; one who extols or praises, either by writing or speaking.
Pediculina: A division of parasitic hemipterous insects, including the true lice. See Illust. in Appendix.
Pectinate: Resembling the teeth of a comb.
Proteranthous: Having flowers appearing before the leaves; -- said of certain plants.
parenchymal: Of, pertaining to, or consisting of, parenchyma.
Pithless: Destitute of pith, or of strength; feeble.
Pentadecatoic: Of, pertaining to, or derived from, pentadecane, or designating an acid related to it.
Prototype: An original or model after which anything is copied; the pattern of anything to be engraved, or otherwise copied, cast, or the like; a primary form; exemplar; archetype.
Plutonic: Of or pertaining to Pluto; Plutonian; hence, pertaining to the interior of the earth; subterranean.
Plectognath: Of or pertaining to the Plectognathi.
Peptohydrochloric: Designating a hypothetical acid (called peptohydrochloric acid, pepsinhydrochloric acid, and chloropeptic acid) which is supposed to be formed when pepsin and dilute (0.1-0.4 per cent) hydrochloric acid are mixed together.
Phytozo\u00f6n: A plantlike animal. The term is sometimes applied to zoöphytes.
Pennatulacea: A division of alcyonoid corals, including the seapens and related kinds.  They are able to move about by means of the hollow muscular peduncle, which also serves to support them upright in the mud. See Pennatula, and Illust. under Alcyonaria.
Pilch: A gown or case of skin, or one trimmed or lined with fur.
Presume: To suppose or assume something to be, or to be true, on grounds deemed valid, though not amounting to proof; to believe by anticipation; to infer; as, we may presume too far.
Phantasm: An image formed by the mind, and supposed to be real or material; a shadowy or airy appearance; sometimes, an optical illusion; a phantom; a dream.
Pity: To be compassionate; to show pity.
Pontvolant: A kind of light bridge, used in sieges, for surprising a post or outwork which has but a narrow moat; a flying bridge.
Professorship: The office or position of a professor, or public teacher.
Pith: To destroy the central nervous system of (an animal, as a frog), as by passing a stout wire or needle up and down the vertebral canal.
Pemphigus: A somewhat rare skin disease, characterized by the development of blebs upon different parts of the body.
Pentaglot: A work in five different tongues.
Pita: A fiber obtained from the Agave Americana and other related species, -- used for making cordage and paper. Called also pita fiber, and pita thread.
Pintos: A mountain tribe of Mexican Indians living near Acapulco. They are remarkable for having the dark skin of the face irregularly spotted with white. Called also speckled Indians.
Provocative: Anything that is provocative; a stimulant; as, a provocative of appetite.
Pince-nez: Eyeglasses kept on the nose by a spring.
Pleochroism: The property possessed by some crystals, of showing different colors when viewed in the direction of different axes.
Prodigality: Extravagance in expenditure, particularly of money; excessive liberality; profusion; waste; -- opposed to frugality, economy, and parsimony.
Pro\u00f6stracum: The anterior prolongation of the guard of the phragmocone of belemnites and allied fossil cephalopods, whether horny or calcareous. See Illust. of Phragmocone.
Playfellow: A companion in amusements or sports; a playmate.
Paludicol\u00e6: A division of birds, including the cranes, rails, etc.
Profligacy: The quality of state of being profligate; a profligate or very vicious course of life; a state of being abandoned in moral principle and in vice; dissoluteness.
Pheasantry: A place for keeping and rearing pheasants.
Pleurisy: An inflammation of the pleura, usually accompanied with fever, pain, difficult respiration, and cough, and with exudation into the pleural cavity.
Prevaricate: To evade by a quibble; to transgress; to pervert.
Peculiarity: The quality or state of being peculiar; individuality; singularity.
Phaseolus: A genus of leguminous plants, including the Lima bean, the kidney bean, the scarlet runner, etc. See Bean.
Paternalism: The theory or practice of paternal government. See Paternal government, under Paternal.
Primatical: Of or pertaining to a primate.
Projector: One who projects a scheme or design; hence, one who forms fanciful or chimerical schemes.
Pleistocene: Of or pertaining to the epoch, or the deposits, following the Tertiary, and immediately preceding man.
Phalansterian: One who favors the system of phalansteries proposed by Fourier.
Post-tympanic: Situated behind the tympanum, or in the skull, behind the auditory meatus.
Proletary: A citizen of the lowest class, who served the state, not with property, but only by having children; hence, a common person.
Plumbagineous: Pertaining to natural order (Plumbagineæ) of gamopetalous herbs, of which Plumbago is the type. The order includes also the marsh rosemary, the thrift, and a few other genera.
Proclitic: Leaning forward; -- said of certain monosyllabic words which are so closely attached to the following word as not to have a separate accent.
Phonetism: The science which treats of vocal sounds.
Polytomous: Subdivided into many distinct subordinate parts, which, however, not being jointed to the petiole, are not true leaflets; -- said of leaves.
Posnet: A little basin; a porringer; a skillet.
Penniform: Having the form of a feather or plume.
Pinchbeck: Made of pinchbeck; sham; cheap; spurious; unreal.
Prosenchyma: A general term applied to the tissues formed of elongated cells, especially those with pointed or oblique extremities, as the principal cells of ordinary wood.
Phonetist: One versed in phonetics; a phonologist.
Procrustes: A celebrated legendary highwayman of Attica, who tied his victims upon an iron bed, and, as the case required, either stretched or cut of their legs to adapt them to its length; -- whence the metaphorical phrase, the bed of Procrustes.
Porphyrize: To cause to resemble porphyry; to make spotted in composition, like porphyry.
Perbromic: Pertaining to, or designating, the highest oxygen acid, HBrO4, of bromine.
Preventive: That which prevents, hinders, or obstructs; that which intercepts access; in medicine, something to prevent disease; a prophylactic.
Phytomer: An organic element of a flowering plant; a phyton.
Picryl: The hypothetical radical of picric acid, analogous to phenyl.
Postillator: One who postillates; one who expounds the Scriptures verse by verse.
Perversion: The act of perverting, or the state of being perverted; a turning from truth or right; a diverting from the true intent or object; a change to something worse; a turning or applying to a wrong end or use.
Phase splitting: The dephasing of the two parts of a single alternating current in two dissimilar branches of a given circuit.
Precipitately: In a precipitate manner; headlong; hastily; rashly.
Petrogale: Any Australian kangaroo of the genus Petrogale, as the rock wallaby (Petrogale penicillata).
Perturbation: The act of perturbing, or the state of being perturbed; esp., agitation of mind.
Poephaga: A group of herbivorous marsupials including the kangaroos and their allies.
Percursory: Running over slightly or in haste; cursory.
Peri: An imaginary being, male or female, like an elf or fairy, represented as a descendant of fallen angels, excluded from paradise till penance is accomplished.
Pers: Light blue; grayish blue; -- a term applied to different shades at different periods.
Pileorhiza: A cap of cells which covers the growing extremity of a root; a rootcap.
Pressor: Causing, or giving rise to, pressure or to an increase of pressure; as, pressor nerve fibers, stimulation of which excites the vasomotor center, thus causing a stronger contraction of the arteries and consequently an increase of the arterial blood pressure; -- opposed to depressor.
Petition: To make a petition or solicitation.
Pylorus: The opening from the stomach into the intestine.
Parsonish: Appropriate to, or like, a parson; -- used in disparagement.
Perdure: To last or endure for a long time; to be perdurable or lasting.
Preternaturalness: The quality or state of being preternatural.
Para grass: A tall rather coarse grass (Panicum molle formerly Panicum barbinode) grown in the tropics for pasturage, and introduced into the southern United States from Brazilas a valuable pasture grass.
Psalmography: The act or practice of writing psalms, or sacred songs.
Pyrazine: A feebly basic solid, C4H4N2, obtained by distilling piperazine with zinc dust, and in other ways. Also, by extension, any of various derivatives of the same.
Pumper: One who pumps; the instrument or machine used in pumping.
Place-kick: To make a place kick; to make (a goal) by a place kick.
Pungled: Shriveled or shrunken; -- said especially of grain which has lost its juices from the ravages of insects, such as the wheat midge, or Trips (Thrips cerealium).
Pattern matching: A technique in automated data analysis, usually performed on a computer, by which a group of characteristic properties of an unknown object is compared with the comparable groups of characteristics of a set of known objects, to discover the idenity or proper classification of the unknown object.
Per-: A prefix used to signify through, throughout, by, for, or as an intensive as perhaps, by hap or chance; perennial, that lasts throughout the year; perforce, through or by force; perfoliate, perforate; perspicuous, evident throughout or very evident; perplex, literally, to entangle very much.
Propriety: Individual right to hold property; ownership by personal title; property.
Phyllophagan: One of a group of marsupials including the phalangists.
Pacha: A civil or military authority in Turkey or Egypt; same as Pasha.
Prelibation: A tasting beforehand, or by anticipation; a foretaste; as, a prelibation of heavenly bliss.
Pericystitis: Inflammation of the tissues surrounding the bladder.
Plagihedral: Having an oblique spiral arrangement of planes, as levogyrate and dextrogyrate crystals.
Perigord pie: A pie made of truffles, much esteemed by epicures.
Perspectography: The science or art of delineating objects according to the laws of perspective; the theory of perspective.
paintable: Lending itself to being painted; as, a highly paintable landscape; made of sturdy eminently paintable wood.  Opposite of unpaintable.
Purr: The low murmuring sound made by a cat; pur. See Pur.
Pl\u00fccker tube: A vacuum tube, used in spectrum analysis, in which the part through which the discharge takes place is a capillary tube, thus producing intense incandescence of the contained gases.
Polycystidea: A division of Gregarinæ including those that have two or more internal divisions of the body.
Parelectronomy: A condition of the muscles induced by exposure to severe cold, in which the electrical action of the muscle is reversed.
piss away: To waste; to squander; to fritter away; as, he pissed away his opportunity to get the job by arriving late for the interview.
Pisolitic: Composed of, containing, or resembling, pisolite.
Photoscopic: Of or pertaining to the photoscope or its uses.
Pataca: The Spanish dollar; -- called also patacoon.
Purl: A circle made by the notion of a fluid; an eddy; a ripple.
Pirouette: To perform a pirouette; to whirl, like a dancer.
Precipitous: Steep, like a precipice; as, a precipitous cliff or mountain.
Pseudo-cone: One of the soft gelatinous cones found in the compound eyes of certain insects, taking the place of the crystalline cones of others.
Pothook: An S-shaped hook on which pots and kettles are hung over an open fire.
Polytheist: One who believes in, or maintains the doctrine of, a plurality of gods.
Papier-mach\u00e9: A hard and strong substance made of a pulp from paper, mixed with size or glue, etc.  It is formed into various articles, usually by means of molds.
Prepared: Made fit or suitable; adapted; ready; as, prepared food; prepared questions.
Plano-conical: Plane or flat on one side, and conical on the other.
Punnet: A broad, shallow basket, for displaying fruit or flowers.
Pachymeningitis: Inflammation of the dura mater or outer membrane of the brain.
Preparer: One who, or that which, prepares, fits, or makes ready.
Pile-worn: Having the pile worn off; threadbare.
pecs: The pectoral muscles; -- a contraction used by body-building and health enthusiasts.   Used similarly to abs and delts.
Procreator: One who begets; a father or sire; a generator.
Porbeagle: A species of shark (Lamna cornubica), about eight feet long, having a pointed nose and a crescent-shaped tail; -- called also mackerel shark.
Precedented: Having a precedent; authorized or sanctioned by an example of a like kind.
pearler: A diver who searches for molluscs containing pearls; a pearl diver.
Phyllobranchia: A crustacean gill composed of lamellæ.
Padishah: Chief ruler; monarch; sovereign; -- a title of the Sultan of Turkey, and of the Shah of Persia.
Pignoration: The act of pledging or pawning.
Pursuance: The act of pursuing or prosecuting; a following out or after.
Platetrope: One of a pair of a paired organs.
Phantascope: An optical instrument or toy, resembling the phenakistoscope, and illustrating the same principle; -- called also phantasmascope.
pen-friend: A person one comes to know by by frequent friendly correspondence; a pen pal.
Pendulosity: The state or quality of being pendulous.
Pretendingly: As by right or title; arrogantly; presumptuously.
Polemoniaceous: Of or pertaining to a natural order of plants (Polemoniaceæ), which includes Polemonium, Phlox, Gilia, and a few other genera.
Polymerism: The state, quality, or relation of two or more polymeric substances.
Paraglobulin: A protein in blood serum, belonging to the group of globulins. See Fibrinoplastin.
Patroon: One of the proprietors of certain tracts of land with manorial privileges and right of entail, under the old Dutch governments of New York and New Jersey.
Providential: Effected by, or referable to, divine direction or superintendence; as, the providential contrivance of thing; a providential escape.
Pollinium: A coherent mass of pollen, as in the milkweed and most orchids.
Piggin: A small wooden pail or tub with an upright stave for a handle, -- often used as a dipper.
Pomegranate: The fruit of the tree Punica Granatum; also, the tree itself (see Balaustine), which is native in the Orient, but is successfully cultivated in many warm countries, and as a house plant in colder climates. The fruit is as large as an orange, and has a hard rind containing many rather large seeds, each one separately covered with crimson, acid pulp.
Pronouncement: The act of pronouncing; a declaration; a formal announcement.
Piccadil: A high, stiff collar for the neck; also, a hem or band about the skirt of a garment, -- worn by men in the 17th century.
Poultry: Domestic fowls reared for the table, or for their eggs or feathers, such as cocks and hens, capons, turkeys, ducks, and geese.
Pontifical: A book containing the offices, or formulas, used by a pontiff.
Pontee: An iron rod used by glass makers for manipulating the hot glass; -- called also, puntil, puntel, punty, and ponty. See Fascet.
Precipitant: Any force or reagent which causes the formation of a precipitate.
Preceptory: A religious house of the Knights Templars, subordinate to the temple or principal house of the order in London. See Commandery, n., 2.
Preteritive: Used only or chiefly in the preterit or past tenses, as certain verbs.
Personify: To regard, treat, or represent as a person; to represent as a rational being.
Paleosaurus: A genus of fossil saurians found in the Permian formation.
Pellile: The redshank; -- so called from its note.
Pehlevi: An ancient Persian dialect in which words were partly represented by their Semitic equivalents.  It was in use from the 3d century (and perhaps earlier) to the middle of the 7th century, and later in religious writings.
Plurality: The state of being plural, or consisting of more than one; a number consisting of two or more of the same kind; as, a plurality of worlds; the plurality of a verb.
Purgation: The act of purging; the act of clearing, cleansing, or putifying, by separating and carrying off impurities, or whatever is superfluous; the evacuation of the bowels.
Pensioner: One in receipt of a pension; hence, figuratively, a dependent.
Popes head: A long-handled brush for dusting ceilings, etc., also for washing windows.
Petaline: Pertaining to a petal; attached to, or resembling, a petal.
Promulgation: The act of promulgating; publication; open declaration; as, the promulgation of the gospel.
Political: Having, or conforming to, a settled system of administration.
Pterygopodium: A specially modified part of the ventral fin in male elasmobranchs, which serves as a copulatory organ, or clasper.
Pup: To bring forth whelps or young, as the female of the canine species.
Plectognathi: An order of fishes generally having the maxillary bone united with the premaxillary, and the articular united with the dentary.
Plantain: Any plant of the genus Plantago, but especially the Plantago major, a low herb with broad spreading radical leaves, and slender spikes of minute flowers.  It is a native of Europe, but now found near the abode of civilized man in nearly all parts of the world.
Proemptosis: The addition of a day to the lunar calendar.
Prolusion: A trial before the principal performance; a prelude; hence, an introductory essay or exercise.
Pseudospore: A peculiar reproductive cell found in some fungi.
Perfunctory: Done merely to get rid of a duty; performed mechanically and as a thing of rote; done in a careless and superficial manner; characterized by indifference; as, perfunctory admonitions.
Pine-tree State: Maine; -- a nickname alluding to the pine tree in its coat of arms.
Palmitic: Pertaining to, or obtained from, palmitin or palm oil; as, palmitic acid (C16H32O2), a white crystalline substance belonging to the fatty acid series.  It is readily soluble in hot alcohol, and melts to a liquid oil at 62° C.
Palmitin: A solid crystallizable fat, found abundantly in animals and in vegetables.  It occurs mixed with stearin and olein in the fat of animal tissues, with olein and butyrin in butter, with olein in olive oil, etc.  Chemically, it is a glyceride of palmitic acid, three molecules of palmitic acid being united to one molecule of glyceryl, and hence it is technically called tripalmitin, or glyceryl tripalmitate.
Porcelanite: A semivitrified clay or shale, somewhat resembling jasper; -- called also porcelain jasper.
pastrami: A highly seasoned cut of smoked beef.
Pampered: Fed luxuriously; indulged to the full; hence, luxuriant; as, pampered children.
Plower: One who plows; a plowman; a cultivator.
Pasteurian: Of or pertaining to Louis Pasteur.
Pyjama: In India and Persia, thin loose trowsers or drawers; in Europe and America, drawers worn at night, or a kind of nightdress with legs.  Usually used in the plural.  See pajamas.
Pellmell: In utter confusion; with confused violence.
Pamperer: One who, or that which, pampers.
Psychophysical: Of or pertaining to psychophysics; involving the action or mutual relations of the psychical and physical in man.
Pardon: To absolve from the consequences of a fault or the punishment of crime; to free from penalty; -- applied to the offender.
Pulpitish: Of or pertaining to the pulpit; like preaching.
Pus: The yellowish white opaque creamy matter produced by the process of suppuration. It consists of innumerable white nucleated cells floating in a clear liquid.
Pr\u00e6texta: A white robe with a purple border, worn by a Roman boy before he was entitled to wear the toga virilis, or until about the completion of his fourteenth year, and by girls until their marriage. It was also worn by magistrates and priests.
Photo-etching: A photo-engraving produced by any process involving the etching of the plate.
Parepididymis: A small body containing convoluted tubules, situated near the epididymis in man and some other animals, and supposed to be a remnant of the anterior part of the Wolffian body.
Pseudograph: A false writing; a spurious document; a forgery.
Personate: Having the throat of a bilabiate corolla nearly closed by a projection of the base of the lower lip; masked, as in the flower of the snapdragon.
Phyto-: A combining form from Gr. fyto`n a plant; as, phytochemistry, phytography.
Protraction: A drawing out, or continuing; the act of delaying the termination of a thing; prolongation; continuance; delay; as, the protraction of a debate.
Pronely: In a prone manner or position.
Palenque: A collective name for the Indians of Nicaragua and Honduras.
Pouncing: The art or practice of transferring a design by means of pounce.
Psoriasis: The state of being affected with psora.
Pierian: Of or pertaining to Pierides or Muses.
Polyarchy: A government by many persons, of whatever order or class.
Pederero: A term formerly applied to a short piece of chambered ordnance.
Phyton: One of the parts which by their repetition make up a flowering plant, each being a single joint of a stem with its leaf or leaves; a phytomer.
Pleura: The smooth serous membrane which closely covers the lungs and the adjacent surfaces of the thorax; the pleural membrane.
Proficience: The quality of state of being proficient; advance in the acquisition of any art, science, or knowledge; progression in knowledge; improvement; adeptness; as, to acquire proficiency in music.
Primary: That which stands first in order, rank, or importance; a chief matter.
Percutient: Striking; having the power of striking.
Proximad: Toward a proximal part; on the proximal side of; proximally.
Prognosticator: One who prognosticates; a foreknower or foreteller of a future course or event by present signs.
Procuratorship: The office or term of a procurator.
Picturer: One who makes pictures; a painter.
Psychomachy: A conflict of the soul with the body.
Paroxysmal: Of the nature of a paroxysm; characterized or accompanied by paroxysms; as, a paroxysmal pain; paroxysmal temper.
Palpitation: A rapid pulsation; a throbbing; esp., an abnormal, rapid beating of the heart as when excited by violent exertion, strong emotion, or by disease.
Pretor: A civil officer or magistrate among the ancient Romans.
Pictured: Furnished with pictures; represented by a picture or pictures; as, a pictured scene.
Paytine: An alkaloid obtained from a white bark resembling that of the cinchona, first brought from Payta, in Peru.
Pain: To inflict suffering upon as a penalty; to punish.
Pail: A vessel of wood or tin, etc., usually cylindrical and having a bail, -- used esp. for carrying liquids, as water or milk, etc.; a bucket.  It may, or may not, have a cover.
Paid: Receiving pay; compensated; hired; as, a paid attorney.
Puzzler: One who, or that which, puzzles or perplexes.
Physoclisti: An order of teleost in which the air bladder has no opening.
Pais: The country; the people of the neighborhood.
Pseudo-peripteral: Falsely or imperfectly peripteral, as a temple having the columns at the sides attached to the walls, and an ambulatory only at the ends or only at one end.
Polydipsia: Excessive and constant thirst occasioned by disease.
Parallel standards: Two or more metals coined without any attempt by the government to regulate their values.
Publicness: The quality or state of being public, or open to the view or notice of people at large; publicity; notoriety; as, the publicness of a sale.
Proratable: Capable of being prorated, or divided proportionately.
Philanthropistic: Pertaining to, or characteristic of, a philanthropist.
Poinsettia: A Mexican shrub (Euphorbia pulcherrima) with very large and conspicuous vermilion bracts below the yellowish flowers.
Piacularity: The quality or state of being piacular; criminality; wickedness.
Photomicrograph: An enlarged or macroscopic photograph of a microscopic object. See Microphotograph.
Pre\u00ebxist: To exist previously; to exist before something else.
Performer: One who performs, accomplishes, or fulfills; as, a good promiser, but a bad performer; especially, one who shows skill and training in any art; as, a performer of the drama; a performer on the harp.
Physiography: The science which treats of the earth's exterior physical features, climate, life, etc., and of the physical movements or changes on the earth's surface, as the currents of the atmosphere and ocean, the secular variations in heat, moisture, magnetism, etc.; physical geography.
Phagocyte: A leucocyte which plays a part in retrogressive processes by taking up (eating), in the form of fine granules, the parts to be removed.
Primigenial: First born, or first of all; original; primary. See Primogenial.
Pr\u00e6coces: A division of birds including those whose young are able to run about when first hatched.
Plateresque: Resembling silver plate; -- said of certain architectural ornaments.
Pelasgian: Of or pertaining to the Pelasgians, an ancient people of Greece, of roving habits.
Principality: Sovereignty; supreme power; hence, superiority; predominance; high, or the highest, station.
Pliancy: The quality or state of being pliant in sense; as, the pliancy of a rod.
Peninsular: Of or pertaining to a peninsula; as, a peninsular form; peninsular people; the peninsular war.
Philostorgy: Natural affection, as of parents for their children.
Passerina: A genus of small North American bush-loving finches; the New World buntings.
Photorelief: A printing surface in relief, obtained by photographic means and subsequent manipulations.
