Publicly: With exposure to popular view or notice; without concealment; openly; as, property publicly offered for sale; an opinion publicly avowed; a declaration publicly made.
Preclude: To put a barrier before; hence, to shut out; to hinder; to stop; to impede.
Panne: A fabric resembling velvet, but having the nap flat and less close.
Porous: Full of pores; having interstices in the skin or in the substance of the body; having spiracles or passages for fluids; permeable by liquids; as, a porous skin; porous wood.
Plowland: Land that is plowed, or suitable for tillage.
Pro thyalosoma: The investing portion, or spherical envelope, surrounding the eccentric germinal spot of the germinal vesicle.
Publishment: The act or process of making publicly known; publication.
Parenthesize: To make a parenthesis of; to include within parenthetical marks.
Proprietorship: The state of being proprietor; ownership.
Pangothic: Of, pertaining to, or including, all the Gothic races.
Perturb: To disturb; to agitate; to vex; to trouble; to disquiet.
Peruvian: Of or pertaining to Peru, in South America.
Postnuptial: Being or happening after marriage; as, a postnuptial settlement on a wife.
Postgraduate: Of, pertaining to, or designating, the studies pursued after graduation, esp., after receiving the bachelor's degree at a college; graduate.
Pandean pipes: A primitive wind instrument, consisting of a series of short hollow reeds or pipes, graduated in length by the musical scale, and fastened together side by side; a syrinx; a mouth organ; -- said to have been invented by the god Pan.  Called also pipes of Pan, Pan's pipes and Panpipes.
Pyin: An albuminoid constituent of pus, related to mucin, possibly a mixture of substances rather than a single body.
Playhouse: A building used for dramatic exhibitions; a theater.
Pachacamac: A divinity worshiped by the ancient Peruvians as the creator of the universe.
Puma: A large American carnivore (Felis concolor), found from Canada to Patagonia, especially among the mountains. Its color is tawny, or brownish yellow, without spots or stripes. Called also catamount, cougar, American lion, mountain lion, and panther or painter.
Pecuniary: Relating to money; monetary; as, a pecuniary penalty; a pecuniary reward.
Pump: To work, or raise water, a pump.
Phlegmagogue: A medicine supposed to expel phlegm.
Premotion: Previous motion or excitement to action.
Popularly: In a popular manner; so as to be generally favored or accepted by the people; commonly; currently; as, the story was popularity reported.
Practitioner: One who is engaged in the actual use or exercise of any art or profession, particularly that of law or medicine.
Purgatorial: Of or pertaining to purgatory; expiatory.
Pugilist: One who fights with his fists; esp., a professional prize fighter; a boxer.
Phloroglucin: A sweet white crystalline substance, metameric with pyrogallol, and obtained by the decomposition of phloretin, and from certain gums, as catechu, kino, etc. It belongs to the class of phenols. [Called also phloroglucinol.]
Pinxit: A word appended to the artist's name or initials on a painting, or engraved copy of a painting; as, Rubens pinxit, Rubens painted (this).
Propend: To lean toward a thing; to be favorably inclined or disposed; to incline; to tend.
Pedotrophy: The art of nourishing children properly.
Pelleted: Made of, or like, pellets; furnished with pellets.
Polystyle: Having many columns; -- said of a building, especially of an interior part or court; as, a polystyle hall.
Photochromotype: To represent by a colored print made by any photomechanical process.
Phenanthroline: Either of two metameric nitrogenous hydrocarbon bases, C12H8N2, analogous to phenanthridine, but more highly nitrogenized.
Peculiarize: To make peculiar; to set apart or assign, as an exclusive possession.
Parrotiopsis: A genus of trees containing only one species, a deciduous tree of Himalaya.
Phonography: A description of the laws of the human voice, or sounds uttered by the organs of speech.
Piprine: Of or pertaining to the pipras, or the family Pipridæ.
Pallid: Deficient in color; pale; wan; as, a pallid countenance; pallid blue.
Panicle: A pyramidal form of inflorescence, in which the cluster is loosely branched below and gradually simpler toward the end.
Proscolex: An early larval form of a trematode worm; a redia. See Redia.
paperboy: A boy who sells or delivers newspapers.
Prelatess: A woman who is a prelate; the wife of a prelate.
Pompet: The ball formerly used to ink the type.
paperer: One whose occupation is decorating walls with wallpaper.
packrat: Any of several bushy-tailed rodents of the genus Neotoma of western North America, especially Neotoma cinerea, which hoard food and other objects in their nests.
Perfectibility: The quality or state of being perfectible.
Patriotic: Inspired by patriotism; actuated by love of one's country; zealously and unselfishly devoted to the service of one's country; as, a patriotic statesman, vigilance.
Physophor\u00e6: An order of Siphonophora, furnished with an air sac, or float, and a series of nectocalyces. See Illust. under Nectocalyx.
Pan-American Congress: Any of several meetings of delegates from various American states;
Prelature: The state or dignity of a prelate; prelacy.
Protest: A solemn declaration of opinion, commonly a formal objection against some act; especially, a formal and solemn declaration, in writing, of dissent from the proceedings of a legislative body; as, the protest of lords in Parliament.
Pettychaps: Any one of several species of small European singing birds of the subfamily Sylviinæ, as the willow warbler, the chiff-chaff, and the golden warbler (Sylvia hortensis).
Phaneroglossal: Having a conspicious tongue; -- said of certain reptiles and insects.
Proc\u0153le: A lateral cavity of the prosencephalon; a lateral ventricle of the brain.
Primiparous: Belonging to a first birth; bearing young for the first time.
passe-partout: That by which one can pass anywhere; a safe-conduct.
Pepo: Any fleshy fruit with a firm rind, as a pumpkin, melon, or gourd. See Gourd.
Primine: The outermost of the two integuments of an ovule.
Prehnitic: Pertaining to, or designating, a tetrabasic acid of benzene obtained as a white crystalline substance; -- probably so called from the resemblance of the wartlike crystals to the mammillæ on the surface of prehnite.
parole board: A group of individuals with authority to determine whether a prisoner will be granted parole{5} from a particular prison.
Pronouncer: One who pronounces, utters, or declares; also, a pronouncing book.
Periblast: The protoplasmic matter which surrounds the entoblast, or cell nucleus, and undergoes segmentation.
Planarian: One of the Planarida, or Dendrocœla; any turbellarian worm.
Prian: A fine, white, somewhat friable clay; also, the ore contained in a mixture of clay and pebbles.
Pyridine: A nitrogenous base, C5H5N, obtained from the distillation of bone oil or coal tar, and by the decomposition of certain alkaloids, as a colorless liquid with a peculiar pungent odor. It is the nucleus of a large number of organic substances, among which several vegetable alkaloids, as nicotine and certain of the ptomaïnes, may be mentioned. See Lutidine.
Platyc\u0153lian: Flat at the anterior and concave at the posterior end; -- said of the centra of the vertebræ of some extinct dinouaurs.
Propulsation: The act of driving away or repelling; a keeping at a distance.
Parfocal: With the lower focal points all in the same plane; -- said of sets of eyepieces so mounted that they may be interchanged without varying the focus of the instrument (as a microscope or telescope) with which they are used.
piton: A metal spike having a sharpened point on one end, and a hole through which a rope can be passed on the other; it is driven into the face of a rock cliff during climbing, and used as an anchor point for a rope.
Polyonomous: Having many names or titles; polyonymous.
Prophylaxis: The art of preserving from, or of preventing, disease; the observance of the rules necessary for the preservation of health; preservative or preventive treatment.
Persistent: Inclined to persist; having staying qualities; tenacious of position or purpose.
Pentandria: A Linnæan class of plants having five separate stamens.
Polestar: Polaris, or the north star. See North star, under North.
Privation: The act of depriving, or taking away; hence, the depriving of rank or office; degradation in rank; deprivation.
Pustulation: The act of producing pustules; the state of being pustulated.
Prebronchial: Situated in front of the bronchus; -- applied especially to an air sac on either side of the esophagus of birds.
Pinnulate: Having each pinna subdivided; -- said of a leaf, or of its pinnæ.
Pitch-faced: Having the arris defined by a line beyond which the rock is cut away, so as to give nearly true edges; -- said of squared stones that are otherwise quarry-faced.
Phytotomy: The dissection of plants; vegetable anatomy.
Photodynamics: The relation of light to the movements of plants and their organs; the study of the phenomena of curvatures induced by the stimulus of light.
Petrify: To become stone, or of a stony hardness, as organic matter by calcareous deposits.
Pomarine: Having the nostril covered with a scale.
Pseudoc\u0153lia: The fifth ventricle in the mammalian brain. See Ventricle.
Parietine: A piece of a fallen wall; a ruin.
Pteranodontia: A group of pterodactyls destitute of teeth, as in the genus Pteranodon.
Patter: A quick succession of slight sounds; as, the patter of rain; the patter of little feet.
Platitudinous: Abounding in platitudes; of the nature of platitudes; uttering platitudes.
Ponderous: Very heavy; weighty; as, a ponderous shield; a ponderous load; the ponderous elephant.
Phosphorescent: Shining with a phosphoric light; luminous without sensible heat.
Plangency: The quality or state of being plangent; a beating sound.
Purpose: To have a purpose or intention; to discourse.
Patten: A clog or sole of wood, usually supported by an iron ring, worn to raise the feet from the wet or the mud.
Pursue: To go in pursuit; to follow.
Postliminiary: Pertaining to, or involving, the right of postliminium.
Perpender: A large stone reaching through a wall so as to appear on both sides of it, and acting as a binder; -- called also perbend, perpend stone, and perpent stone.
Petrostearine: A solid unctuous material, of which candles are made.
Pickle: To preserve or season in pickle; to treat with some kind of pickle; as, to pickle herrings or cucumbers.
patchcord: A conducting cord  with a plug at each end, used to make connections between circuit terminals at a patchboard.
Prosperous: Tending to prosperity; favoring; favorable; helpful.
Pennyworth: A penny's worth; as much as may be bought for a penny.
Particle physics: That branch of physics which investigates the nature of matter, and in particular the properties and behavior of the elementary particles (fundamental particles), of which matter is composed.  Included in this field is the more specialized branch of high-energy physics.
Peristeria: A genus of orchidaceous plants. See Dove plant.
Pregustation: The act of tasting beforehand; foretaste.
Practice: To perform certain acts frequently or customarily, either for instruction, profit, or amusement; as, to practice with the broadsword or with the rifle; to practice on the piano.
Plighter: One who, or that which, plights.
Perineum: The region which is included within the outlet of the pelvis, and is traversed by the urinogenital canal and the rectum.
Professional: A person who prosecutes anything professionally, or for a livelihood, and not in the character of an amateur; a professional worker.
Preapprehension: An apprehension or opinion formed before examination or knowledge.
Platypod: An animal having broad feet, or a broad foot.
Pronaos: The porch or vestibule of a temple.
Pestalozzian: Belonging to, or characteristic of, a system of elementary education which combined manual training with other instruction, advocated and practiced by Jean Henri Pestalozzi (1746-1827), a Swiss teacher.
Philanderer: One who hangs about women; a male flirt.
Ptisan: A decoction of barley with other ingredients; a farinaceous drink.
Parallel: To be parallel; to correspond; to be like.
Propound: To offer for consideration; to exhibit; to propose; as, to propound a question; to propound an argument.
Pyridyl: A hypothetical radical, C5H4N, regarded as the essential residue of pyridine, and analogous to phenyl.
parry: A warding off of a thrust or blow, as in sword and bayonet exercises or in boxing; hence, figuratively, a defensive movement in debate or other intellectual encounter.
Puffin: An arctic sea bird Fratercula arctica) allied to the auks, and having a short, thick, swollen beak, whence the name; -- called also bottle nose, cockandy, coulterneb, marrot, mormon, pope, and sea parrot.
Posit: To dispose or set firmly or fixedly; to place or dispose in relation to other objects.
patrol wagon: An enclosed truck used by police to transport prisoners.
Pegging: The act or process of fastening with pegs.
Pernor: One who receives the profits, as of an estate.
Predestine: To decree beforehand; to foreordain; to predestinate.
Prepay: To pay in advance, or beforehand; as, to prepay postage.
Privet: An ornamental European shrub (Ligustrum vulgare), much used in hedges; -- called also prim.
Prittle-prattle: Empty talk; trifling loquacity; prattle; -- used in contempt or ridicule.
Polygenetic: Having many distinct sources; originating at various places or times.
Parthenocissus: A genus of woody vines having disklike tips on the tendrils.
Phytography: The science of describing plants in a systematic manner; also, a description of plants.
Polytheistic: Of or pertaining to polytheism; characterized by polytheism; professing or advocating polytheism; as, polytheistic worship; a polytheistic author, or nation.
Propheticalness: The quality or state of being prophetical; power or capacity to foretell.
Pimp: To procure women for the gratification of others' lusts; to pander.
Peculiarness: The quality or state of being peculiar; peculiarity.
Proud: Feeling or manifesting pride, in a good or bad sense
Palmary: Worthy of the palm; palmy; preëminent; superior; principal; chief; as, palmary work.
Provocation: The act of provoking, or causing vexation or, anger.
partaker: One who partakes; a sharer; a participator.
Provisory: Of the nature of a proviso; containing a proviso or condition; conditional; as, a provisory clause.
Phyllotaxy: The order or arrangement of leaves on the stem; the science of the relative position of leaves.
Palladic: Of, pertaining to, or derived from, palladium; -- used specifically to designate those compounds in which the element has a higher valence as contrasted with palladious compounds.
Pycnidium: In certain fungi, a flask-shaped cavity from the surface of the inner walls of which spores are produced.
Parish: Of or pertaining to a parish; parochial; as, a parish church; parish records; a parish priest; maintained by the parish; as, parish poor.
Pronotum: The dorsal plate of the prothorax in insects. See Illust. of Coleoptera.
Petrous: Like stone; hard; stony; rocky; as, the petrous part of the temporal bone.
Point switch: A switch made up of a rail from each track, both rails being tapered far back and connected to throw alongside the through rail of either track.
Penrack: A rack for pens not in use.
Petaliform: Having the form of a petal; petaloid; petal-shaped.
Prutenic: Prussian; -- applied to certain astronomical tables published in the sixteenth century, founded on the principles of Copernicus, a Prussian.
Pseudologist: One who utters falsehoods; a liar.
Paternity: The relation of a father to his child; fathership; fatherhood; family headship; as, the divine paternity.
Payer: One who pays; specifically, the person by whom a bill or note has been, or should be, paid.
parallelepiped: A prism whose bases are parallelograms.
Payee: The person to whom money is to be, or has been, paid; the person named in a bill or note, to whom, or to whose order, the amount is promised or directed to be paid. See Bill of exchange, under Bill.
Programme: That which is written or printed as a public notice or advertisement; a scheme; a prospectus; especially, a brief outline or explanation of the order to be pursued, or the subjects embraced, in any public exercise, performance, or entertainment; a preliminary sketch.
Phase displacement: A charge of phase whereby an alternating current attains its maximum later or earlier. An inductance would cause a lag, a capacity would cause an advance, in phase.
Piaster: A silver coin of Spain and various other countries. See Peso. The Spanish piaster (commonly called peso, or peso duro) is of about the value of the American dollar. The Italian piaster, or scudo, was worth from 80 to 100 cents. The Turkish and Egyptian piasters are now worth about four and a half cents.
Policed: Regulated by laws for the maintenance of peace and order, enforced by organized administration.
Prolongate: To prolong; to extend in space or in time.
Protrusile: Capable of being protruded or thrust out; protractile; protrusive.
Pentecostal: Of or pertaining to Pentecost or to Whitsuntide.
Pentacrinin: A red and purple pigment found in certain crinoids of the genus Pentacrinus.
Permulator: A special form of rotary converter with stationary commutator and rotating brushes, in which the exciting field is induced by the alternating current in a short-circuited magnetic core instead of being produced by an external magnet.
Psalmograph: A writer of psalms; a psalmographer.
Plugger: One who, or that which, plugs.
Palatize: To modify, as the tones of the voice, by means of the palate; to palatalize; as, to palatize a letter or sound.
Prepubic: Situated in front of, or anterior to, the pubis; pertaining to the prepubis.
Pinaster: A species of pine (Pinus Pinaster) growing in Southern Europe.
Pincher: One who, or that which, pinches.
Polaris: The polestar. See North star, under North.
Panelation: The act of impaneling a jury.
Plagiarism: The act or practice of plagiarizing.
Potassamide: A yellowish brown substance obtained by heating potassium in ammonia.
Plowpoint: A detachable share at the extreme front end of the plow body.
Plagiarist: One who plagiarizes, or purloins the words, writings, or ideas of another, and passes them off as his own; a literary thief; a plagiary.
Photo-electric cell: A cell (as one of two electrodes embedded in selenium) which by exposure to light generates an electric current.
Perverter: One who perverts (a person or thing).
Polystome: An animal having many mouths; -- applied to Protozoa.
Poncho: A kind of cloak worn by the Spanish Americans, having the form of a blanket, with a slit in the middle for the head to pass through.  A kind of poncho made of rubber or painted cloth is used by the mounted troops in the United States service.
Papeterie: A case or box containing paper and materials for writing.
Peacemaker: One who makes peace by reconciling parties that are at variance.
Protozoic: Of or pertaining to the Protozoa.
Publication: The act of publishing or making known; notification to the people at large, either by words, writing, or printing; proclamation; divulgation; promulgation; as, the publication of the law at Mount Sinai; the publication of the gospel; the publication of statutes or edicts.
Printing in: A process by which cloud effects or other features not in the original negative are introduced into a photograph. Portions, such as the sky, are covered while printing and the blank space thus reserved is filled in by printing from another negative.
Prepubis: A bone or cartilage, of some animals, situated in the middle line in front of the pubic bones.
Pentadecane: A hydrocarbon of the paraffin series, (C15H32) found in petroleum, tar oil, etc., and obtained as a colorless liquid; -- so called from the fifteen carbon atoms in the molecule.
Plurally: In a plural manner or sense.
Protuberation: The act of swelling beyond the surrounding surface.
Paludina: Any one of numerous species of freshwater pectinibranchiate mollusks, belonging to Paludina, Melantho, and allied genera.  They have an operculated shell which is usually green, often with brown bands.  See Illust. of Pond snail, under Pond.
Paludine: Of or pertaining to a marsh.
Porphyry: A term used somewhat loosely to designate a rock consisting of a fine-grained base (usually feldspathic) through which crystals, as of feldspar or quartz, are disseminated. There are red, purple, and green varieties, which are highly esteemed as marbles.
Packera: A genus of American or East Asian perennial herbs with yellow to orange or red flower rays; it is sometimes included in genus Senecio.
Photothermic: Of or pertaining to both light and heat.
Putting: The throwing of a heavy stone, shot, etc., with the hand raised or extended from the shoulder; -- originally, a Scottish game.
Pedestaled: Placed on, or supported by, a pedestal; figuratively, exalted.
Phlogistication: The act or process of combining with phlogiston.
Pilot: To direct the course of, as of a ship, where navigation is dangerous.
Pancreatic: Of or pertaining to the pancreas; as, the pancreatic secretion, digestion, ferments.
Pepsi Cola: A carbonated soft drink flavored by extract from the cola nut (kola nut).  The nut is found on trees of the species Cola acuminata and Cola nitida.
Poyntel: Paving or flooring made of small squares or lozenges set diagonally.
Prejudication: The act of prejudicating, or of judging without due examination of facts and evidence; prejudgment.
Perivitelline: Situated around the vitellus, or between the vitellus and zona pellucida of an ovum.
Pillow: To rest or lay upon, or as upon, a pillow; to support; as, to pillow the head.
Pasteboard: A stiff thick kind of paper board, formed of several single sheets pasted one upon another, or of paper macerated and pressed into molds, etc.
Phytopathology: The science of diseases to which plants are liable.
Perficient: One who performs or perfects a work; especially, one who endows a charity.
Pinniform: Shaped like a fin or feather.
Pyrotritartaric: Designating an acid which is more commonly called uric acid.
Precipitable: Capable of being precipitated, or cast to the bottom, as a substance in solution. See Precipitate, n. (Chem.)
Pensive: Thoughtful, sober, or sad; employed in serious reflection; given to, or favorable to, earnest or melancholy musing.
Protoplasmic: Of or pertaining to the first formation of living bodies.
Puke: Of a color supposed to be between black and russet.
Passement: Lace, gimp, braid etc., sewed on a garment.
Prolegomenon: A preliminary remark or observation; an introductory discourse prefixed to a book or treatise.
Peaceful: Possessing or enjoying peace; not disturbed by war, tumult, agitation, anxiety, or commotion; quiet; tranquil; as, a peaceful time; a peaceful country; a peaceful end.
Pitcherful: The quantity a pitcher will hold.
Parthian: Of or pertaining to ancient Parthia, in Asia.
Packing: The act or process of one who packs.
Passman: One who passes for a degree, without honors. See Classman, 2.
Pettitoes: The toes or feet of a pig, -- often used as food; sometimes, in contempt, the human feet.
Paralactic: Designating an acid called paralactic acid. See Lactic acid, under Lactic.
Prosodical: Of or pertaining to prosody; according to the rules of prosody.
Pearlite: A glassy volcanic rock of a grayish color and pearly luster, often having a spherulitic concretionary structure due to the curved cracks produced by contraction in cooling. See Illust. under Perlitic.
Plaza: A public square in a city or town.
Porime: A theorem or proposition so easy of demonstration as to be almost self-evident.
Pesade: The motion of a horse when, raising his fore quarters, he keeps his hind feet on the ground without advancing; rearing.
Pundit: A learned man; a teacher; esp., a Brahman versed in the Sanskrit language, and in the science, laws, and religion of the Hindoos; in Cashmere, any clerk or native official.
Petalous: Having petals; petaled; -- opposed to apetalous.
Planometry: The art or process of producing or gauging a plane surface.
Phenicious: Of a red color with a slight mixture of gray.
Pated: Having a pate; -- used only in composition; as, long-pated; shallow-pated.
Pronation: The act of turning the palm or palmar surface of the forefoot downward.
Pyrosulphuric: Pertaining to, or designating, an acid called also disulphuric acid) obtained by distillation of certain sulphates, as a colorless, thick, oily liquid, H2S2O7 resembling sulphuric acid. It is used in the solution of indigo, in the manufacture of alizarin, and in dehydration.
Psilology: Love of empty of empty talk or noise.
Primogenial: First born, made, or generated; original; primary; elemental; as, primogenial light.
Pentadelphous: Having the stamens arranged in five clusters, those of each cluster having their filaments more or less united, as the flowers of the linden.
Phallus: The emblem of the generative power in nature, carried in procession in the Bacchic orgies, or worshiped in various ways.
Phonograph: A character or symbol used to represent a sound, esp. one used in phonography.
Paleotechnic: Belonging to, or connected with, ancient art.
Proustite: A sulphide of arsenic and silver of a beautiful cochineal-red color, occurring in rhombohedral crystals, and also massive; ruby silver.
Procrastination: The act or habit of procrastinating, or putting off to a future time; delay; dilatoriness.
Prophetize: To give predictions; to foreshow events; to prophesy.
Premunitory: Of or pertaining to a premunire; as, a premunitory process.
Pseudopod: Any protoplasmic filament or irregular process projecting from any unicellular organism, or from any animal or plant call.
Perich\u00e6tous: Surrounded by setæ; -- said of certain earthworms (genus Perichætus).
Parashah: A lesson from the Torah, or Law, from which at least one section is read in the Jewish synagogue on every Sabbath and festival.
Platinotype: A permanent photographic picture or print in platinum black.
Playwright: A maker or adapter of plays.
Papyrine: Imitation parchment, made by soaking unsized paper in dilute sulphuric acid.
Purgative: Having the power or quality of purging; cathartic.
Phocine: Of or pertaining to the seal tribe; phocal.
Proteus: A sea god in the service of Neptune who assumed different shapes at will. Hence, one who easily changes his appearance or principles.
Pent: Penned or shut up; confined; -- often with up.
Peach: A well-known high-flavored juicy fruit, containing one or two seeds in a hard almond-like endocarp or stone.  In the wild stock the fruit is hard and inedible.
Paulownia: A genus of trees of the order Scrophulariaceæ, consisting of one species, Paulownia imperialis.
Peace: To make or become quiet; to be silent; to stop.
Pectostraca: A degenerate order of Crustacea, including the Rhizocephala and Cirripedia.
Prestriction: Obstruction, dimness, or defect of sight.
payslip: a slip of paper included with a person's salary payment, that records how much money the person has earned and how much tax or insurance etc. has been taken out.
Prick: To be punctured; to suffer or feel a sharp pain, as by puncture; as, a sore finger pricks.
Photodrome: An apparatus consisting of a large wheel with spokes, which when turning very rapidly is illuminated by momentary flashes of light passing through slits in a rotating disk.  By properly timing the succession of flashes the wheel is made to appear to be motionless, or to rotate more or less slowly in either direction.
Prosthesis: The addition to the human body of some artificial part, to replace one that is wanting, as a log or an eye; -- called also prothesis.
Pedantry: The act, character, or manners of a pedant; vain ostentation of learning.
Prononc\u00e9: Strongly marked; decided, as in manners, etc.
Piepoudre: An ancient court of record in England, formerly incident to every fair and market, of which the steward of him who owned or had the toll was the judge.
Pellitory: A composite plant (Anacyclus Pyrethrum) of the Mediterranean region, having finely divided leaves and whitish flowers. The root is the officinal pellitory, and is used as an irritant and sialogogue. Called also bertram, and pellitory of Spain.
Protagon: A nitrogenous phosphorized principle found in brain tissue. By decomposition it yields neurine, fatty acids, and other bodies.
Paragraphistical: Of or relating to a paragraphist.
Pooping: The act or shock of striking a vessel's stern by a following wave or vessel.
Primigenious: First formed or generated; original; primigenial.
Pipewood: An ericaceous shrub (Leucothoë acuminata) of the southern United States, from the wood of which pipe bowls are made.
Postscript: A paragraph added to a letter after it is concluded and signed by the writer; an addition made to a book or composition after the main body of the work has been finished, containing something omitted, or something new occurring to the writer.
part-time: A working schedule occupying less than full time, i.e. less than 35 hours per week.
Paddlewood: The light elastic wood of the Aspidosperma excelsum, a tree of Guiana having a fluted trunk readily split into planks.
Photozincography: A process, analogous to photolithography, for reproducing photographed impressions transferred to zinc plate.
Polyactinia: An old name for those Anthozoa which, like the actinias, have numerous simple tentacles.
Porosity: The quality or state of being porous; -- opposed to density.
Poteen: especially, whisky illicitly distilled by the Irish peasantry.
Portulaca: A genus of polypetalous plants; also, any plant of the genus.
Peronate: A term applied to the stipes or stalks of certain fungi which are covered with a woolly substance which at length becomes powdery.
Par\u00e1: The southern arm of the Amazon in Brazil; also, a seaport on this arm.
paranoid: Affected with paranoia; as, a paranoid schizophrenic.
pissoir: a public urinal, in European countries.
paranoia: A chronic form of insanity characterized by very gradual impairment of the intellect, systematized delusion, and usually by delusions of persecution or mandatory delusions producing homicidal tendency.  In its mild form paranoia may consist in the well-marked crotchetiness exhibited in persons commonly called “cranks.”   Paranoiacs usually show evidences of bodily and nervous degeneration, and many have hallucinations, esp. of sight and hearing.
Penality: The quality or state of being penal; liability to punishment.
Petworth marble: A kind of shell marble occurring in the Wealden clay at Petworth, in Sussex, England; -- called also Sussex marble.
-poda: A New Latin plural combining form or suffix from Gr. &unr_;, &unr_;, foot; as, hexapoda, myriapoda. See -pod.
phosgene: A reactive chemical substance (COCl2), also called carbonyl choride, used in synthesis of numerous substances.  In the First Worlds War it was also used as a poisonous gas in combat.
Prosing: Writing prose; speaking or writing in a tedious or prosy manner.
Plaque: Any flat, thin piece of metal, clay, ivory, or the like, used for ornament, or for painting pictures upon, as a slab, plate, dish, or the like, hung upon a wall; also, a smaller decoration worn on the person, as a brooch.
Polymer: Any one of two or more substances related to each other by polymerism; specifically, a substance produced from another substance by chemical polymerization.
Pleuritic: Of or pertaining to pleurisy; as, pleuritic symptoms.
Pluff: A puff, as of smoke from a pipe, or of dust from a puffball; a slight explosion, as of a small quantity of gunpowder.
Perilous: Full of, attended with, or involving, peril; dangerous; hazardous; as, a perilous undertaking.
Penult: The last syllable but one of a word; the syllable preceding the final one.
Pertinacity: The quality or state of being pertinacious; obstinacy; perseverance; persistency.
Piassava: A fibrous product of two Brazilian palm trees (Attalea funifera and Leopoldinia Piassaba), -- used in making brooms, and for other purposes. Called also piaçaba and piasaba.
Penmanship: The use of the pen in writing; the art of writing; style or manner of writing; chirography; as, good or bad penmanship.
Puppetry: Action or appearance resembling that of a puppet, or puppet show; hence, mere form or show; affectation.
Polychord: A musical instrument of ten strings.
Pare: To cut off, or shave off, the superficial substance or extremities of; as, to pare an apple; to pare a horse's hoof.
Para: A piece of Turkish money, usually copper, the fortieth part of a piaster, or about one ninth of a cent.
Pseudoneuropterous: Of or pertaining to the Pseudoneuroptera.
Park: To promenade or drive in a park; also, of horses, to display style or gait on a park drive.
paleogeography: The study of the geography of ancient times or ancient epochs.
Ply: A fold; a plait; a turn or twist, as of a cord.
Propagulum: A runner terminated by a germinating bud.
Parr: A young salmon in the stage when it has dark transverse bands; -- called also samlet, skegger, and fingerling.
Pontifice: Bridgework; structure or edifice of a bridge.
Peritreme: That part of the integument of an insect which surrounds the spiracles.
Pterylography: The study or description of the arrangement of feathers, or of the pterylæ, of birds.
Papuars: The native black race of Papua or New Guinea, and the adjacent islands.
Platband: A border of flowers in a garden, along a wall or a parterre; hence, a border.
Prothoracic: Of or pertaining to the prothorax.
Patache: A tender to a fleet, formerly used for conveying men, orders, or treasure.
Pledgeor: One who pledges, or delivers anything in pledge; a pledger; -- opposed to pledgee.
Pressive: Pressing; urgent; also, oppressive; as, pressive taxation.
Plumbum: The technical name of lead. See Lead.
Planipennia: A suborder of Neuroptera, including those that have broad, flat wings, as the ant-lion, lacewing, etc. Called also Planipennes.
Pulmonarian: Any arachnid that breathes by lunglike organs, as the spiders and scorpions. Also used adjectively.
Polychloride: A chloride containing more than one atom of chlorine in the molecule.
Permeability: The quality or state of being permeable.
Penciling: The work of the pencil or bruch; as, delicate penciling in a picture.
Prudentiality: The quality or state of being prudential.
Productivity: The quality or state of being productive; productiveness.
Prolonge: A rope with a hook and a toggle, sometimes used to drag a gun carriage or to lash it to the limber, and for various other purposes.
Pulverulent: Consisting of, or reducible to, fine powder; covered with dust or powder; powdery; dusty.
parings: Parts that are pared or cut off.
Possessory: Of or pertaining to possession, either as a fact or a right; of the nature of possession; as, a possessory interest; a possessory lord.
Parcener: A coheir, or one of two or more persons to whom an estate of inheritance descends jointly, and by whom it is held as one estate.
Pentaptych: A picture, or combination of pictures, consisting of a centerpiece and double folding doors or wings, as for an altarpiece.
Pick off: to put out a baserunner who is off base by tagging him/her, especially by a quick throw from the pitcher or catcher.
Protection: The act of protecting, or the state of being protected; preservation from loss, injury, or annoyance; defense; shelter; as, the weak need protection.
Portal: Of or pertaining to a porta, especially the porta of the liver; as, the portal vein, which enters the liver at the porta, and divides into capillaries after the manner of an artery.
Penis: The erectile external sexual organ of males, used in copulation, and in mammals, also for urination.
Polymeric: Having the same percentage composition (that is, having the same elements united in the same proportion by weight), but different molecular weights; -- often used with with; thus, cyanic acid (CNOH), fulminic acid (C2N2O2H2), and cyanuric acid (C3N3O3H3), are polymeric with each other.
Preamble: To make a preamble to; to preface; to serve as a preamble.
Pedalian: Relating to the foot, or to a metrical foot; pedal.
Profaneness: The quality or state of being profane; especially, the use of profane language.
Purify: To grow or become pure or clear.
Phonascetics: Treatment for restoring or improving the voice.
Precisianism: The quality or state of being a precisian; the practice of a precisian.
Planorbis: Any fresh-water air-breathing mollusk belonging to Planorbis and other allied genera, having shells of a discoidal form.
packsaddle: A saddle to which loads can be attached.
Pici: A division of birds including the woodpeckers and wrynecks.
Pick: A sharp-pointed tool for picking; -- often used in composition; as, a toothpick; a picklock.
Pice: A small copper coin of the East Indies, worth less than a cent.
Pica: The genus that includes the magpies.
pact: An agreement; a league; a compact; a covenant.
Planiform: Having a plane surface; as, a planiform, gliding, or arthrodial articulation.
Pseudoscopic: Of, pertaining to, or formed by, a pseudoscope; having its parts appearing with the relief reversed; as, a pseudoscopic image.
Phosphaturia: The excessive discharge of phosphates in the urine.
Pleurocentrum: One of the lateral elements in the centra of the vertebræ in some fossil batrachians.
pace: A single movement from one foot to the other in walking; a step.
Panslavism: A scheme or desire to unite all the Slavic races into one confederacy.
paca: A large burrowing South American rodent (Agouti paca syn. Cuniculus paca, formerly Cœlogenys paca), having blackish brown fur, with four parallel rows of white spots along its sides; the spotted cavy.  It is closely allied to the agouti and the Guinea pig and is highly esteemed as food.
Plead: To discuss, defend, and attempt to maintain by arguments or reasons presented to a tribunal or person having uthority to determine; to argue at the bar; as, to plead a cause before a court or jury.
Parral: The rope or collar by which a yard or spar is held to the mast in such a way that it may be hoisted or lowered at pleasure.
Prosody: That part of grammar which treats of the quantity of syllables, of accent, and of the laws of versification or metrical composition.
Planch: To make or cover with planks or boards; to plank.
Preachify: To discourse in the manner of a preacher.
Photographer: One who practices, or is skilled in, photography.
Paraleipsis: A pretended or apparent omission; a figure by which a speaker artfully pretends to pass by what he really mentions; as, for example, if an orator should say, “I do not speak of my adversary's scandalous venality and rapacity, his brutal conduct, his treachery and malice.”
Plyer: One who, or that which, plies
Particle accelerator: A large and expensive scientific instrument used by physicists to accelerate elementary particles (such as protons or electrons) to speeds near that of light, for the purpose of investigating the fundamental properties of matter; sometimes also called an atom smasher, since the particles thus accelerated are often directed at targets of atoms which are fragmented by the impact into their more fundamental component particles.
Proscenium: The part where the actors performed; the stage.
Pistachio green: A light yellowish green color resembling that of the pistachio nut.
Pinery: A pine forest; a grove of pines.
Pinnigrade: An animal of the seal tribe, moving by short feet that serve as paddles.
Phlebotomize: To let blood from by opening a vein; to bleed.
Physiologize: To speculate in physiology; to make physiological investigations.
Putridity: The quality of being putrid; putrefaction; rottenness.
Pinacolin: A colorless oily liquid related to the ketones, and obtained by the decomposition of pinacone; hence, by extension, any one of the series of which pinacolin proper is the type.
Papyrean: Of or pertaining to papyrus, or to paper; papyraceous.
Planetary: Of or pertaining to the planets; as, planetary inhabitants; planetary motions; planetary year.
Pretender: One who lays claim, or asserts a title (to something); a claimant.
Plebiscite: A vote by universal male suffrage; especially, in France, a popular vote, as first sanctioned by the National Constitution of 1791.
Prothallus: The minute primary growth from the spore of ferns and other Pteridophyta, which bears the true sexual organs; the oöphoric generation of ferns, etc.
Postmaster-general: The chief officer of the post-office department of a government. In the United States the postmaster-general is a member of the cabinet.
Pricksong: Music written, or noted, with dots or points; -- so called from the points or dots with which it is noted down.
Porterage: The work of a porter; the occupation of a carrier or of a doorkeeper.
Predesignate: A term used by Sir William Hamilton to define propositions having their quantity indicated by a verbal sign; as, all, none, etc.; -- contrasted with preindesignate, defining propositions of which the quantity is not so indicated.
Presignify: To intimate or signify beforehand; to presage.
Preceptress: A woman who is the principal of a school; a female teacher.
Pedigree: A line of ancestors; descent; lineage; genealogy; a register or record of a line of ancestors.
Piracy: The act or crime of a pirate.
Punctured: Having the surface covered with minute indentations or dots.
Potently: With great force or energy; powerfully; efficaciously.
Panoply: Defensive armor in general; a full suit of defensive armor.
Pindaric: Of or pertaining to Pindar, the Greek lyric poet; after the style and manner of Pindar; as, Pindaric odes.
Pretorship: The office or dignity of a pretor.
Planetoid: A body resembling a planet; an asteroid.
Provine: To lay a stock or branch of a vine in the ground for propagation.
Papaphobia: Intense fear or dread of the pope, or of the Roman Catholic Church.
Photophilous: Light-loving; growing in strong light, as many plants.
Panpsychism: The theory that all nature is psychical or has a psychical aspect; the theory that every particle of matter has a psychical character or aspect.
parti-colored: Having sections or patches colored differently and usually brightly.  Same as Party-colored.
Prelatically: In a prelatical manner; with reference to prelates.
Promotive: Tending to advance, promote, or encourage.
Pilot valve: A small hand-operated valve to admit liquid to operate a valve difficult to turn by hand.
Pendulum: A body so suspended from a fixed point as to swing freely to and fro by the alternate action of gravity and momentum.  It is used to regulate the movements of clockwork and other machinery.
Previously: Beforehand; antecedently; as, a plan previously formed.
Polygynist: One who practices or advocates polygyny.
Peabird: The wryneck; -- so called from its note.
Professionalism: The following of a profession, sport, etc., as an occupation; -- opposed to amateurism.
Peptogenous: Capable of yielding, or being converted into, peptone.
Pulicene: Pertaining to, or abounding in, fleas; pulicose.
Periodide: An iodide containing a higher proportion of iodine than any other iodide of the same substance or series.
pedicab: a tricycle (usually propelled by pedalling); used in the Orient for transporting passengers for hire; as, boys who once pulled rickshaws now pedal pedicabs.
Pessimize: To hold or advocate the doctrine of pessimism.
Pattern: To make or design (anything) by, from, or after, something that serves as a pattern; to copy; to model; to imitate.
Parula: The type genus of the Parulidae: wood warblers.
Phratry: A subdivision of a phyle, or tribe, in Athens.
Plaint: Audible expression of sorrow; lamentation; complaint; hence, a mournful song; a lament.
Preciously: In a precious manner; expensively; extremely; dearly. Also used ironically.
Palmistry: The art or practice of divining or telling fortunes, or of judging of character, by the lines and marks in the palm of the hand; chiromancy.
Postulant: One who makes a request or demand; hence, a candidate.
Pneumoskeleton: A chitinous structure which supports the gill in some invertebrates.
Portmote: In old English law, a court, or mote, held in a port town.
Phlogistian: A believer in the existence of phlogiston.
Pantophagist: A person or an animal that has the habit of eating all kinds of food.
Polyphotal: Pertaining to or designating arc lamps so constructed that more than one can be used on a single circuit.
Protomartyr: The first martyr; the first who suffers, or is sacrificed, in any cause; -- applied esp. to Stephen, the first Christian martyr.
Psalmody: The act, practice, or art of singing psalms or sacred songs; also, psalms collectively, or a collection of psalms.
Pancratiast: One who engaged in the contests of the pancratium.
Permutation: The act of permuting; exchange of the thing for another; mutual transference; interchange.
panhandle: To accost people in a public place and ask for money; to beg.
Placebo: The first antiphon of the vespers for the dead.
Preternaturally: In a preternatural manner or degree.
Paulist: A member of The Institute of the Missionary Priests of St. Paul the Apostle, founded in 1858 by the Rev. I. T. Hecker of New York.  The majority of the members were formerly Protestants.
Pleuroderes: A group of fresh-water turtles in which the neck can not be retracted, but is bent to one side, for protection. The matamata is an example.
Polycrotic: Of or pertaining to polycrotism; manifesting polycrotism; as, a polycrotic pulse; a polycrotic pulse curve.
Perissad: Odd; not even; -- said of elementary substances and of radicals whose valence is not divisible by two without a remainder. Contrasted with artiad.
Pentamerous: Divided into, or consisting of, five parts; also, arranged in sets, with five parts in each set, as a flower with five sepals, five petals, five, or twice five, stamens, and five pistils.
Puit: A well; a small stream; a fountain; a spring.
Perverse: Turned aside; hence, specifically, turned away from the right; willfully erring; wicked; perverted.
Piffle: Act of piffling; trifling talk or action; piddling; twaddle.
Provokement: The act that which, provokes; one who excites anger or other passion, or incites to action; as, a provoker of sedition.
Paronymy: The quality of being paronymous; also, the use of paronymous words.
Pulpiteer: One who speaks in a pulpit; a preacher; -- so called in contempt.
Phytolacca: A genus of herbaceous plants, some of them having berries which abound in intensely red juice; poke, or pokeweed.
Preclusion: The act of precluding, or the state of being precluded; a shutting out.
Postable: Capable of being carried by, or as by, post.
Portman: An inhabitant or burgess of a port, esp. of one of the Cinque Ports.
Porthook: One of the iron hooks to which the port hinges are attached.
palomino: A horse of light tan or golden color with cream or white mane and tail, and often having white markings on the legs and face.
Presentiment: Previous sentiment, conception, or opinion; previous apprehension; especially, an antecedent impression or conviction of something unpleasant, distressing, or calamitous, about to happen; anticipation of evil; foreboding.
Perpetual: Neverceasing; continuing forever or for an unlimited time; unfailing; everlasting; continuous.
Parotoid: Resembling the parotid gland; -- applied especially to cutaneous glandular elevations above the ear in many toads and frogs.
Prompt-note: A memorandum of a sale, and time when payment is due, given to the purchaser at a sale of goods.
Primrose League: A league of both sexes among the Conservatives, founded in 1883. So called because primrose was (erroneously, it is said) taken to be the favorite flower of the Conservative statesman Benjamin Disraeli, Earl of Beaconsfield.
Prop\u00e6deutics: The preliminary learning connected with any art or science; preparatory instruction.
Photic: Of or pert. to light; specif., relating to the production of light by the lower animals.
Pi\u00f1a cloth: A fine fabric for scarfs, handkerchiefs, embroidery, etc., woven from the fiber obtained from the leaf of the sterile pineapple plant. It is delicate, soft, and transparent, with a tinge of pale yellow.
Peorias: An Algonquin tribe of Indians who formerly inhabited a part of Illinois.
Perspective: A glass through which objects are viewed.
Procreant: One who, or that which, procreates.
Pulverulence: The state of being pulverulent; abundance of dust or powder; dustiness.
Personnel: The body of persons employed in some public service, as the army, navy, etc.; -- distinguished from matériel.
Plagate: Having plagæ, or irregular enlongated color spots.
Presage: To form or utter a prediction; -- sometimes used with of.
Polar: The right line drawn through the two points of contact of the two tangents drawn from a given point to a given conic section. The given point is called the pole of the line. If the given point lies within the curve so that the two tangents become imaginary, there is still a real polar line which does not meet the curve, but which possesses other properties of the polar. Thus the focus and directrix are pole and polar. There are also poles and polar curves to curves of higher degree than the second, and poles and polar planes to surfaces of the second degree.
Polycrotism: That state or condition of the pulse in which the pulse curve, or sphygmogram, shows several secondary crests or elevations; -- contrasted with monocrotism and dicrotism.
Philhellene: A friend of Greece, or of the Greeks; a philhellenist.
Pyuria: A morbid condition in which pus is discharged in the urine.
Promenade: To walk for pleasure, display, or exercise.
Peterman: A fisherman; -- so called after the apostle Peter.
Persicot: A cordial made of the kernels of apricots, nectarines, etc., with refined spirit.
Preterition: The act of passing, or going past; the state of being past.
Parus: The type genus of the family Paridae.
Passiveness: The quality or state of being passive; unresisting submission.
Perscrutation: A thorough searching; a minute inquiry or scrutiny.
Powdery: Easily crumbling to pieces; friable; loose; as, a powdery spar.
Post-abdomen: That part of a crustacean behind the cephalothorax; -- more commonly called abdomen.
Pipra: Any one of numerous species of small clamatorial birds belonging to Pipra and allied genera, of the family Pipridæ. The male is usually glossy black, varied with scarlet, yellow, or sky blue. They chiefly inhabit South America.
Percher: One who, or that which, perches.
Philathea: An international, interdenominational organization of Bible classes of young women.
Precedence: The act or state of preceding or going before in order of time; priority; as, one event has precedence of another.
payables: money that a person or organization expects and is obligated to pay on notes and accounts.
Predicant: One who predicates, affirms, or proclaims; specifically, a preaching friar; a Dominican.
Perfusive: Of a nature to flow over, or to spread through.
Pelt: A blow or stroke from something thrown.
Plasmation: The act of forming or molding.
Pell: A skin or hide; a pelt.
Peppery: Of or pertaining to pepper; having the qualities of pepper; hot; pungent.
Proofless: Wanting sufficient evidence to induce belief; not proved.
Papboat: A kind of sauce boat or dish.
Pelf: Money; riches; lucre; gain; -- generally conveying the idea of something ill-gotten or worthless.  It has no plural.
Painful: Full of pain; causing uneasiness or distress, either physical or mental; afflictive; disquieting; distressing.
Parataxis: The mere ranging of propositions one after another, without indicating their connection or interdependence; -- opposed to syntax.
Palladious: Of, pertaining to, or containing, palladium; -- used specifically to designate those compounds in which palladium has a lower valence as compared with palladic compounds.
Paleaceous: Chaffy; resembling or consisting of paleæ, or chaff; furnished with chaff; as, a paleaceous receptacle.
Pulley: To raise or lift by means of a pulley.
Puddening: A quantity of rope-yarn, or the like, placed, as a fender, on the bow of a boat.
Pickoff: a play in which a base runner is picked off. See pick off.
Pilot lamp: A small incandescent telltale lamp on a dynamo or battery circuit to show approximately by its brightness the voltage of the current.
Phlogiston: The hypothetical principle of fire, or inflammability, regarded by Stahl as a chemical element.
Pailful: The quantity that a pail will hold.
Potichomania: The art or process of coating the inside of glass vessels with engravings or paintings, so as to give them the appearance of painted ware.
Pompeian red: A brownish red approaching maroon, supposed to be imitated from the color of the wall panels of houses in Pompeii, which were decorated during the last age of the Republic.
Pyjamas: A garment, similar to the Oriental pyjama (which see), adopted among Europeans, Americans, and other Occidentals, for wear in the dressing room and during sleep; also, a suit of drawers and blouse for such wear.
Pyrotechny: The use and application of fire in science and the arts.
Pleadable: Capable of being pleaded; capable of being alleged in proof, defense, or vindication; as, a right or privilege pleadable at law.
Podostomata: An order of Bryozoa of which Rhabdopleura is the type. See Rhabdopleura.
Postscenium: The part of a theater behind the scenes; the back part of the stage of a theater.
Pr\u00e6cipe: A writ commanding something to be done, or requiring a reason for neglecting it.
Plowtail: The hind part or handle of a plow.
Pygopodes: A division of swimming birds which includes the grebes, divers, auks, etc., in which the legs are placed far back.
Parochialism: The quality or state of being parochial in form or nature; a system of management peculiar to parishes.
Pupipara: A division of Diptera in which the young are born in a stage like the pupa. It includes the sheep tick, horse tick, and other parasites. Called also Homaloptera.
Princewood: The wood of two small tropical American trees (Hamelia ventricosa, and Cordia gerascanthoides). It is brownish, veined with lighter color.
Polygynia: A Linnæan order of plants having many styles.
Phimosis: A condition of the penis in which the prepuce can not be drawn back so as to uncover the glans penis.
Perofskite: A titanate of lime occurring in octahedral or cubic crystals.
Pigeonry: A place for pigeons; a dovecote.
Paraguay tea: See Mate, the leaf of the Brazilian holly.
Pulvinate: Curved convexly or swelled; as, a pulvinated frieze.
Paradoxure: Any species of Paradoxurus, a genus of Asiatic viverrine mammals allied to the civet, as the musang, and the luwack or palm cat (Paradoxurus hermaphroditus). See Musang.
Pauperization: The act or process of reducing to pauperism.
Plowgate: The Scotch equivalent of the English word plowland.
Pycnaspidean: Having the posterior side of the tarsus covered with small irregular scales; -- said of certain birds.
Pot lace: Lace whose pattern includes one or more representations of baskets or bowls from which flowers spring.
Proscriber: One who, or that which, proscribes, denounces, or prohibits.
Pantochronometer: An instrument combining a compass, sundial, and universal time dial.
Phyllous: Homologous with a leaf; as, the sepals, petals, stamens, and pistils are phyllous organs.
Perivisceral: Around the viscera; as, the perivisceral cavity.
Perineorrhaphy: The operation of sewing up a ruptured perineum.
Porraceous: Resembling the leek in color; greenish.
Philomot: Of the color of a dead leaf.
Pichey: A Brazilian armadillo (Dasypus minutus); the little armadillo.
Poetize: To write as a poet; to compose verse; to idealize.
Parablast: A portion of the mesoblast (of peripheral origin) of the developing embryo, the cells of which are especially concerned in forming the first blood and blood vessels.
Parallax: The apparent displacement, or difference of position, of an object, as seen from two different stations, or points of view.
Passeriformes: The largest order of birds comprising about half the known species: rooks; finches; sparrows; tits; warblers; robins; wrens; swallows; etc.; in four suborders: Eurylaimi; Tyranni; Menurae; Oscines or Passeres.
Pape: A spiritual father; specifically, the pope.
Petulance: The quality or state of being petulant; temporary peevishness; pettishness; capricious ill humor.
Phaseless: Without a phase, or visible form.
Plerome: The central column of parenchyma in a growing stem or root.
Psalmist: A writer or composer of sacred songs; -- a title particularly applied to David and the other authors of the Scriptural psalms.
Piercing: Forcibly entering, or adapted to enter, at or by a point; perforating; penetrating; keen; -- used also figuratively; as, a piercing instrument, or thrust.
Pedagogics: The science or art of teaching; the principles and rules of teaching; pedagogy.
Pentapody: A measure or series consisting of five feet.
Polyacoustics: The art of multiplying or magnifying sounds.
Polymnite: A stone marked with dendrites and black lines, and so disposed as to represent rivers, marshes, etc.
Paddler: One who, or that which, paddles.
Puissantness: The state or quality of being puissant; puissance; power.
Parkeriaceae: A natural family of ferns coextensive with the genus Ceratopteris; sometimes it is included in the family Polypodiaceae.
Pyritohedron: The pentagonal dodecahedron, a common form of pyrite.
Paleo-: A combining form meaning old, ancient; as, palearctic, paleontology, paleothere, paleography.
Phagedenic: Of, like, or pertaining to, phagedena; used in the treatment of phagedena; as, a phagedenic ulcer or medicine.
painkiller: A medicine used in to relieve pain.
Palsgrave: A count or earl who presided in the domestic court, and had the superintendence, of a royal household in Germany.
Portpane: A cloth for carrying bread, so as not to touch it with the hands.
Phthiriasis: A disease (morbus pediculous) consisting in the excessive multiplication of lice on the human body.
Paradisiac: Of or pertaining to paradise; suitable to, or like, paradise; paradisaic.
Parjanya: The Hindu god of rain; sometimes identified with Indra.
Pelotage: Packs or bales of Spanish wool.
Powderflask: A flask in which gunpowder is carried, having a charging tube at the end.
Piddock: Any species of Pholas; a pholad. See Pholas.
Polytheize: To adhere to, advocate, or inculcate, the doctrine of polytheism.
Premonstrator: One who, or that which, premonstrates.
Plutonism: The theory, early advanced in geology, that the successive rocks of the earth"s crust were formed by igneous fusion; -- opposed to the Neptunian theory.
Passenger mileage: Passenger miles collectively; the total number of miles traveled by passengers on a railroad during a given period.
Phototropic: of or pertaining to phototropism; exhibiting phototropism; same as Heliotropic.
paddlebox: a wooden covering for the upper part of the paddle wheel of a steam vessel.
Plutonist: One who adopts the geological theory of igneous fusion; a Plutonian. See Plutonism.
Pioneers Day: In Utah, a legal holiday, July 24, commemorated the arrival, in 1847, of Brigham Young and his followers at the present site of Salt Lake City.
Paternoster: The Lord's prayer, so called from the first two words of the Latin version.
Plumcot: A cross between the plum and apricot.
Putid: Rotten; fetid; stinking; base; worthless. Jer. Taylor.
Pyrexial: Of or pertaining to fever; feverish.
Perimorph: A crystal of one species inclosing one of another species. See Endomorph.
Pretended: Making a false appearance; unreal; false; as, pretended friend.
Pectination: The state of being pectinated; that which is pectinated.
Polyprotodonta: A division of marsupials in which there are more fore incisor teeth in each jaw.
Photophobia: A dread or intolerance of light.
Plenal: Full; complete; as, a plenal view or act.
Pusillanimity: The quality of being pusillanimous; weakness of spirit; cowardliness.
Proctucha: A division of Turbellaria including those that have an intestine terminating posteriorly.
paperclip: A folder wire or plastic fastener for holding sheets of paper together.
Predicable: Anything affirmable of another; especially, a general attribute or notion as affirmable of, or applicable to, many individuals.
Primate: The chief ecclesiastic in a national church; one who presides over other bishops in a province; an archbishop.
Prettyism: Affectation of a pretty style, manner, etc.
Preindesignate: Having no sign expressive of quantity; indefinite. See Predesignate.
Pequots: A tribe of Indians who formerly inhabited Eastern Connecticut.
Petrolatum: A semisolid unctuous substance, neutral, and without taste or odor, derived from petroleum by distilling off the lighter portions and purifying the residue. It is a yellowish, fatlike mass, transparent in thin layers, and somewhat fluorescent. It is used as a bland protective dressing, and as a substitute for fatty materials in ointments.
Palapteryx: A large extinct ostrichlike bird of New Zealand.
Pot-bellied: Having a protuberant belly, like the bottom of a pot.
Pant: A quick breathing; a catching of the breath; a gasp.
Pterosauria: An extinct order of flying reptiles of the Mesozoic age; the pterodactyls; -- called also Pterodactyli, and Ornithosauria.
Plantage: A word used once by Shakespeare to designate plants in general, or anything that is planted.
Phyllo-: A combining form from Gr. &unr_; a leaf; as, phyllopod, phyllotaxy.
Pentacrinus: A genus of large, stalked crinoids, of which several species occur in deep water among the West Indies and elsewhere.
Papion: A West African baboon (Cynocephalus sphinx), allied to the chacma. Its color is generally chestnut, varying in tint.
Peruse: To observe; to examine with care.
Postillation: The act of postillating; exposition of Scripture in preaching.
Prescriptible: Depending on, or derived from, prescription; proper to be prescribed.
Photovisual: Of certain achromatic lenses, having the same focus for the actinic and for the brightest of the visual rays.
Presbyteral: Of or pertaining to a presbyter or presbytery; presbyterial.
Percolate: To pass through fine interstices; to filter; as, water percolates through porous stone.
Palaver: To make palaver with, or to; to used palaver; to talk idly or deceitfully; to employ flattery; to cajole; as, to palaver artfully.
patrilineage: The line of descent traced through the paternal side of the family.
Phototheodolite: An arrangement of two photographic cameras, the plates of which may be brought into exactly the same plane, used in surveying and map making. From the differences between two pictures taken at the same moment, measurements in all dimensions of the region may be obtained.
Ph\u00e6nogamous: Having true flowers with with distinct floral organs; flowering.
Phytonomy: The science of the origin and growth of plants.
Polygamize: To practice polygamy; to marry several wives.
Powdike: A dike a marsh or fen.
Promptitude: The quality of being prompt; quickness of decision and action when occasion demands; alacrity; as, promptitude in obedience.
peace-loving: Inclined or disposed to peace; as, peace-loving citizens.  Opposed to warlike or belligerent.
Picaresque: Applied to that class of literature in which the principal personage is the Spanish picaro, meaning a rascal, a knave, a rogue, an adventurer.
Pittacal: A dark blue substance obtained from wood tar. It consists of hydrocarbons which when oxidized form the orange-yellow eupittonic compounds, the salts of which are dark blue.
Puddle-bar: An iron bar made at a single heat from a puddle-ball hammering and rolling.
Polarimeter: An instrument for determining the amount of polarization of light, or the proportion of polarized light, in a partially polarized ray.
Polverine: Glassmaker's ashes; a kind of potash or pearlash, brought from the Levant and Syria, -- used in the manufacture of fine glass.
Paleontographical: Of or pertaining to the description of fossil remains.
Pavonian: Of or pertaining to a peacock.
Prosencephalic: Of or pertaining to the prosencephalon.
Polygenic: Of or relating to polygeny; polygenetic.
Pericranium: The periosteum which covers the cranium externally; the region around the cranium.
Physa: A genus of fresh-water Pulmonifera, having reversed spiral shells. See Pond snail, under Pond.
Pellagrous: Pertaining to, or affected with, or attendant on, pellagra; as, pellagrous insanity.
Pedicure: Professional care of the feet, toes, and toenails.
Purposive: Having or indicating purpose or design.
Propolis: Same as Bee glue, under Bee.
Praiseworthy: Worthy of praise or applause; commendable; as, praiseworthy action; he was praiseworthy.
Plebification: A rendering plebeian; the act of vulgarizing.
Parure: An ornament or decoration for the person; esp., a decoration consisting of a set of ornaments to be used together; as, a parure of rubies or of embroideries.
Paraphrastic: Paraphrasing; of the nature of paraphrase; explaining, or translating in words more clear and ample than those of the author; not literal; free.
Pioneering: groundbreaking; originating; -- of efforts that begin work in a field or on a topic not previously widely known.
Platter: A large plate or shallow dish on which meat or other food is brought to the table.
Peerless: Having no peer or equal; matchless; superlative.
Perimetric: Of or pertaining to the perimeter, or to perimetry; as, a perimetric chart of the eye.
Publicity pamphlet: A pamphlet which, in some States of the United States having the initiative or referendum, is mailed to the voters to inform them as to the nature of a measure submitted by the initiative or referendum. The pamphlet contains a copy of the proposed law and arguments for and against it by those favoring and opposing it, respectively.
paved: covered with a firm surface; -- of pathways or roadways.
Pithy: Consisting wholly, or in part, of pith; abounding in pith; as, a pithy stem; a pithy fruit.
Parallelopiped: A solid, the faces of which are six parallelograms, the opposite pairs being parallel, and equal to each other; a prism whose base is a parallelogram.
Polyzo\u00f6n: One of the individual zooids forming the compound organism of a polyzoan.
Periodicity: The quality or state of being periodical, or regularly recurrent; as, the periodicity in the vital phenomena of plants.
Peroneal: Of or pertaining to the fibula; in the region of the fibula.
Pulvillus: One of the minute cushions on the feet of certain insects.
Pomacentroid: Pertaining to the Pomacentridæ, a family of bright-colored tropical fishes having spiny opercula; -- often called coral fishes.
Purfle: A hem, border., or trimming, as of embroidered work.
Personation: The act of personating, or conterfeiting the person or character of another.
Parorchis: The part of the epididymis, or the corresponding part of the excretory duct of the testicle, which is derived from the Wolffian body.
Princeling: A petty prince; a young prince.
Presentoir: An ornamental tray, dish, or the like, used as a salver.
Papyrograph: An apparatus for multiplying writings, drawings, etc., in which a paper stencil, formed by writing or drawing with corrosive ink, is used.  The word is also used of other means of multiplying copies of writings, drawings, etc. See Copygraph, Hectograph, Manifold.
Paraconine: A base resembling and isomeric with conine, and obtained as a colorless liquid from butyric aldehyde and ammonia.
Parcel: Part or half; in part; partially.
Propionic: Pertaining to, derived from, or designating, an organic acid which is produced in the distillation of wood, in the fermentation of various organic substances, as glycerin, calcium lactate, etc., and is obtained as a colorless liquid having a sharp, pungent odor. Propionic acid is so called because it is the first or lowest member of the fatty acid series whose salts have a fatty feel.
Provident: Foreseeing wants and making provision to supply them; prudent in preparing for future exigencies; cautious; economical; -- sometimes followed by of; as, aprovident man; an animal provident of the future.
Precedential: Of the nature of a precedent; having force as an example for imitation; as, precedential transactions.
Pueblo: A communistic building erected by certain Indian tribes of Arizona and New Mexico. It is often of large size and several stories high, and is usually built either of stone or adobe. The term is also applied to any Indian village in the same region.
Perameles: Any marsupial of the genus Perameles, which includes numerous species found in Australia. They somewhat resemble rabbits in size and form. See Illust. under Bandicoot.
Pseudofilaria: One of the two elongated vibratile young formed by fission of the embryo during the development of certain Gregarinæ.
Porphyrization: The act of porphyrizing, or the state of being porphyrized.
Polissoir: A polishing or grinding implement or instrument.
Peripetalous: Surrounding, or situated about, the petals.
Patas: A West African long-tailed monkey (Cercopithecus ruber); the red monkey.
Photo-: A combining form from Gr. fw^s, fwto`s, light; as, photography, phototype, photometer.
Phreatic: Subterranean; -- applied to sources supplying wells.
Pluries: A writ issued in the third place, after two former writs have been disregarded.
Pellucid: Transparent; clear; limpid; translucent; not opaque.
Precipitantly: With rash or foolish haste; in headlong manner.
Penetrability: The quality of being penetrable; susceptibility of being penetrated, entered, or pierced.
Peccavi: I have sinned; -- used colloquially to express confession or acknowledgment of an offense; -- used rarely, superseded by the approximate equivalent mea culpa.
Provincial: A person belonging to a province; one who is provincial.
Paspy: A kind of minuet, in triple time, of French origin, popular in the reign of Queen Elizabeth and for some time after; -- called also passing measure, and passymeasure.
Pickaninny: A small child; especially, a negro or mulatto infant.  Now (2001) used primarily in the latter sense, and in that sense often considered derogatory.
Phallic: Of or pertaining to the phallus, or to phallism.
parked: p. p. of park, v. t., 2; -- of vehicles; as, there were four parked cars across the street.
passe: Past; gone by; hence, past one's prime; worn; faded; as, a passée belle.
Penicillamine: A substance (C5H11NO2S) which is a degradation product of the penicillins.  Chemically it is 3-mercapto-D-valine.  It has chelating properties and is used in medicine as an antirheumatic and to chelate copper in cases of hepatolenticular degeneration (Wilson's disease).
Plowshare: The share of a plow, or that part which cuts the slice of earth or sod at the bottom of the furrow.
Preorder: To order to arrange beforehand; to foreordain.
Primus: One of the bishops of the Episcopal Church of Scotland, who presides at the meetings of the bishops, and has certain privileges but no metropolitan authority.
Pompillion: An ointment or pomatum made of black poplar buds.
Phenylene: A hypothetic radical (C6H4) occurring in certain derivatives of benzene; as, phenylene diamine.
Phlegmonous: Having the nature or properties of phlegmon; as, phlegmonous pneumonia.
Pelargonic: Pertaining to, or designating, an organic acid (called also nonoic acid) found in the leaves of the geranium (Pelargonium) and allied plants.
Popular: Of or pertaining to the common people, or to the whole body of the people, as distinguished from a select portion; as, the popular voice; popular elections.
Pigskin: The skin of a pig, -- used chiefly for making saddles; hence, a colloquial or slang term for a saddle.
Plimsolls mark: A mark conspicuously painted on the port side of all British sea-going merchant vessels, to indicate the limit of submergence allowed by law; -- so called from Samuel Plimsoll, by whose efforts the act of Parliament to prevent overloading was procured.
Philippium: A rare and doubtful metallic element said to have been discovered in the mineral samarskite.
Paunch: To pierce or rip the belly of; to eviscerate; to disembowel.
Proteid: an older, imprecise term replaced by protein.
Protein: any polymer of an amino acid joined by peptide (amide) bonds.  Most natural proteins have alpha-amino acids as the monomeric constituents.  All classical enzymes are composed of protein, and control most of the biochemical transformations carrie dout in living cells.  They may be soluble, as casein, albumins, and other globular proteins, or insoluble (e. g. "structural proteins"), as collagen or keratin.  "albumin", an older term for protein, is now used primarily to refer to certain specific soluble globular proteins found in eggs or blood serum, e.g.  bovine serum albumin, the main soluble protein in teh serum of cattle, used as an enzymatically inert protein in biochemical research.
Potentiometer: An instrument for measuring or comparing electrial potentials or electro-motive forces.
Pedunculata: A division of Cirripedia, including the stalked or goose barnacles.
Pipsissewa: A low evergreen plant (Chimaphila umbellata), with narrow, wedge-lanceolate leaves, and an umbel of pretty nodding fragrant blossoms. It has been used in nephritic diseases. Called also prince's pine.
Pedunculate: Having a peduncle; growing on a peduncle; as, a pedunculate flower; a pedunculate eye, as in a lobster.
Plebeianism: The quality or state of being plebeian.
Pinnace: A small vessel propelled by sails or oars, formerly employed as a tender, or for coast defence; -- called originally, spynace or spyne.
Plasterer: One who applies plaster or mortar.
Preliminary: That which precedes the main discourse, work, design, or business; something introductory or preparatory; as, the preliminaries to a negotiation or duel; to take one's preliminaries the year before entering college.
Pitfall: A pit deceitfully covered to entrap wild beasts or men; a trap of any kind.
Pampre: An ornament, composed of vine leaves and bunches of grapes, used for decorating spiral columns.
Pinetum: A plantation of pine trees; esp., a collection of living pine trees made for ornamental or scientific purposes.
Periosteal: Situated around bone; of or pertaining to the periosteum.
Profoundness: The quality or state of being profound; profundity; depth.
Priceless: Too valuable to admit of being appraised; of inestimable worth; invaluable.
Punctualist: One who is very exact in observing forms and ceremonies.
Poling: The act of supporting or of propelling by means of a pole or poles; as, the poling of beans; the poling of a boat.
Pedireme: A crustacean, some of whose feet serve as oars.
paste-up: A composition of a flat object on a board or other backing; as, they showed him a paste-up of the book jacket.
Psychrometer: An instrument for measuring the tension of the aqueous vapor in the atmosphere, being essentially a wet and dry bulb hygrometer.
Psarolite: A silicified stem of tree fern, found in abundance in the Triassic sandstone.
Paracyanogen: A polymeric modification of cyanogen, obtained as a brown or black amorphous residue by heating mercuric cyanide.
Perceptibility: The quality or state of being perceptible; as, the perceptibility of light or color.
Pathognomonic: Specially or decisively characteristic of a disease; indicating with certainty a disease; as, a pathognomonic symptom.
Promptuary: That from which supplies are drawn; a storehouse; a magazine; a repository.
Proprietorial: Of or pertaining to ownership; proprietary; as, proprietorial rights.
Purchasable: Capable of being bought, purchased, or obtained for a consideration; hence, venal; corrupt.
Prescutum: The first of the four pieces composing the dorsal part, or tergum, of a thoracic segment of an insect. It is usually small and inconspicuous.
Pennatula: Any one of numerous species of Pennatula, Pteroides, and allied genera of Alcyonaria, having a featherlike form; a sea-pen.  The zooids are situated along one edge of the side branches.
Portage: To carry (goods, boats, etc.) overland between navigable waters.
Plumulose: Having hairs branching out laterally, like the parts of a feather.
Pasteurs fluid: An artificial nutrient fluid invented by Pasteur for the study of alcoholic fermentation, but used also for the cultivation of bacteria and other organisms. It contains all the elements of protoplasm, and was originally made of the ash of yeast, some ammonia compound, sugar, and water.
Provisorship: The office or position of a provisor.
Pretend: To put in, or make, a claim, truly or falsely; to allege a title; to lay claim to, or strive after, something; -- usually with to.
Plain-spoken: Speaking with plain, unreserved sincerity; also, spoken sincerely; as, plain-spoken words.
Plashet: A small pond or pool; a puddle.
Peculate: To appropriate to one's own use the property of the public; to steal public moneys intrusted to one's care; to embezzle.
Prevent: To come before the usual time.
Plethora: Overfullness; especially, excessive fullness of the blood vessels; repletion; that state of the blood vessels or of the system when the blood exceeds a healthy standard in quantity; hyperæmia; -- opposed to anæmia.
Palama: A membrane extending between the toes of a bird, and uniting them more or less closely together.
Pannus: A very vascular superficial opacity of the cornea, usually caused by granulation of the eyelids.
Prevene: To come before; to anticipate; hence, to hinder; to prevent.
Pileate: Having the form of a cap for the head.
Pubis: The ventral and anterior of the three principal bones composing either half of the pelvis; sharebone; pubic bone.
Public school: In Great Britain, any of various schools maintained by the community, wholly or partly under public control, or maintained largely by endowment and not carried on chiefly for profit; specif., and commonly, any of various select and usually expensive endowed schools which give a liberal modern education or prepare pupils for the universities. Eton, Harrow, Rugby, and Winchester are of this class.
Protopine: An alkaloid found in opium in small quantities, and extracted as a white crystalline substance.
Palindrome: A word, verse, or sentence, that is the same when read backward or forward; as, madam; Hannah; or Lewd did I live, & evil I did dwel.
Pigtailed: Having a tail like a pig's; as, the pigtailed baboon.
Parisyllabic: Having the same number of syllables in all its inflections.
Placitory: Of or pertaining to pleas or pleading, in courts of law.
Pretty: In some degree; moderately; considerably; rather; almost; -- less emphatic than very; as, I am pretty sure of the fact; pretty cold weather.
Portate: Borne not erect, but diagonally athwart an escutcheon; as, a cross portate.
Possessival: Of or pertaining to the possessive case; as, a possessival termination.
Pusillanimous: Destitute of a manly or courageous strength and firmness of mind; of weak spirit; mean-spirited; spiritless; cowardly; -- said of persons, as, a pusillanimous prince.
Pavo: A genus of birds, including the peacocks.
Pyriform: Having the form of a pear; pear-shaped.
Plainsman: One who lives in the plains.
Pave: To lay or cover with stone, brick, or other material, so as to make a firm, level, or convenient surface for vehicles, horses, carriages, or persons on foot, to travel on; to floor with brick, stone, or other solid material; as, to pave a street; to pave a court.
parts: The local environment; as, he hasn't been seen around these parts in years.
Parting: The act of parting or dividing; the state of being parted; division; separation.
Psalmistry: The use of psalms in devotion; psalmody.
Poinder: The keeper of a cattle pound; a pinder.
