Pout: The European whiting pout or bib.
Pour: A stream, or something like a stream; a flood.
Prender: The power or right of taking a thing before it is offered.
Press cake: A cake of compressed substance, as: in gunpowder manufacture, the cake resulting from compressing the meal powder; in the treatment of coal tar, the pressed product at various stages of the process; or, in beet-sugar manufacture, the vegetable residue after the sugar juice has been expressed.
Polysyllabic: Pertaining to a polysyllable; containing, or characterized by, polysyllables; consisting of more than three syllables.
Pontage: A duty or tax paid for repairing bridges.
Pleonastic: Of or pertaining to pleonasm; of the nature of pleonasm; redundant.
Preponderant: Preponderating; outweighing; overbalancing; -- used literally and figuratively; as, a preponderant weight; of preponderant importance.
Propyl\u00e6um: Any court or vestibule before a building or leading into any inclosure.
Proboscidea: An order of large mammals including the elephants and mastodons.
Perforative: Having power to perforate or pierce.
Polaristic: Pertaining to, or exhibiting, poles; having a polar arrangement or disposition; arising from, or dependent upon, the possession of poles or polar characteristics; as, polaristic antagonism.
Pentalpha: A five-pointed star, resembling five alphas joined at their bases; -- used as a symbol.
Plumbic: Of, pertaining to, resembling, or containing, lead; -- used specifically to designate those compounds in which it has a higher valence as contrasted with plumbous compounds; as, plumbic oxide.
Peltry: Pelts or skins, collectively; skins with the fur on them; furs.
Peaceable: Begin in or at peace; tranquil; quiet; free from, or not disposed to, war, disorder, or excitement; not quarrelsome.
Ptenoglossa: A division of gastropod mollusks having the teeth of the radula arranged in long transverse rows, somewhat like the barbs of a feather.
pearly everlasting: an American everlasting (Anaphalis margaritacea) having foliage with soft wooly hairs and corymbose heads with pearly-white scarious involucres.
Parkinsons: A disease causing parkinsonism, a degenerative nervous disorder; sometimes used loosely as a synonym for parkinsonism.  More precisely, parkinson's disease is the term for the underlying physiological disorder and parkinsonism is the term for the set of symptoms associated with the disease.  See parkinsonism.
Palpator: One of a family of clavicorn beetles, including those which have very long maxillary palpi.
Pernancy: A taking or reception, as the receiving of rents or tithes in kind, the receiving of profits.
ping-pong: An indoor modification of lawn tennis played with small bats, or battledores, and a very light, hollow, celluloid ball, on a large table divided across the middle by a net.  Also called table tennis.
Porter: A carrier; one who carries or conveys burdens, luggage, etc.; for hire.
Privily: In a privy manner; privately; secretly.
Preregnant: One who reigns before another; a sovereign predecessor.
Protovertebra: One of the primitive masses, or segments, into which the mesoblast of the vertebrate embryo breaks up on either side of the anterior part of the notochord; a mesoblastic, or protovertebral, somite. See Illust. of Ectoderm.
Proboscidiform: Having the form or uses of a proboscis; as, a proboscidiform mouth.
Poss: To push; to dash; to throw.
Pansy: A plant of the genus Viola (Viola tricolor) and its blossom, originally purple and yellow.  Cultivated varieties have very large flowers of a great diversity of colors.  Called also heart's-ease, love-in-idleness, and many other quaint names.
Posterity: The race that proceeds from a progenitor; offspring to the furthest generation; the aggregate number of persons who are descended from an ancestor of a generation; descendants; -- contrasted with ancestry; as, the posterity of Abraham.
Palmate: A salt of palmic acid; a ricinoleate.
Prick-eared: Having erect, pointed ears; -- said of certain dogs.
Peirastic: Fitted for trial or test; experimental; tentative; treating of attempts.
Pointsman: A man who has charge of railroad points or switches.
Perpetration: The act of perpetrating; a doing; -- commonly used of doing something wrong, as a crime.
Polariscopic: Of or pertaining to the polariscope; obtained by the use of a polariscope; as, polariscopic observations.
Psorosperm: A minute parasite, usually the young of Gregarinæ, in the pseudonavicula stage.
Ponderary: Of or pertaining to weight; as, a ponderary system.
Penelope: A genus of curassows, including the guans.
Pteron: The region of the skull, in the temporal fossa back of the orbit, where the great wing of the sphenoid, the temporal, the parietal, and the frontal hones approach each other.
Putidity: The quality or state of being putrid.
Presternum: The anterior segment of the sternum; the manubrium.
Polish: A smooth, glossy surface, usually produced by friction; a gloss or luster.
Prismatic: Resembling, or pertaining to, a prism; as, a prismatic form or cleavage.
Platy-: A combining form from Gr. platy`s broad, wide, flat; as, platypus, platycephalous.
Percolator: One who, or that which, filters.
Pewfellow: One who occupies the same pew with another.
Pygidium: The caudal plate of trilobites, crustacean, and certain insects. See Illust. of Limulus and Trilobite.
Plouter: Act of ploutering; floundering; act or sound of splashing.
Peavey: A cant hook having the end of its lever armed with a spike; it is used for handling logs.
Plectognathic: Of or pertaining to the Plectognathi.
Pursy: Fat and short-breathed; fat, short, and thick; swelled with pampering; as, pursy insolence.
Pahlavi: The language of Sassanian Persia.  See Pehlevi.
Primates: The highest order of mammals. It includes man, together with the apes and monkeys.  Cf. Pitheci.
Peaked: Pointed; ending in a point; as, a peaked roof.
Phantasmagoric: Of or pertaining to phantasmagoria; phantasmagorial.
Phantasmagoria: An optical effect produced by a magic lantern. The figures are painted in transparent colors, and all the rest of the glass is opaque black. The screen is between the spectators and the instrument, and the figures are often made to appear as in motion, or to merge into one another.
Practically: In a practical way; not theoretically; really; as, to look at things practically; practically worthless.
Passementerie: Trimmings, esp. of braids, cords, gimps, beads, or tinsel.
Polyacid: Capable of neutralizing, or of combining with, several molecules of a monobasic acid; having more than one hydrogen atom capable of being replaced by acid radicals; -- said of certain bases; as, calcium hydrate and glycerin are polyacid bases.
Procrastinator: One who procrastinates, or defers the performance of anything.
Prelation: The setting of one above another; preference.
Precautionary: Of or pertaining to precaution, or precautions; as, precautionary signals.
Palmatilobed: Palmate, with the divisions separated less than halfway to the common center.
Patristics: That departnent of historical theology which treats of the lives and doctrines of the Fathers of the church.
Pyrula: A genus of large marine gastropods having a pear-shaped shell.  It includes the fig-shells. See Illust. in Appendix.
Peri-: A prefix used to signify around, by, near, over, beyond, or to give an intensive sense; as, perimeter, the measure around; perigee, point near the earth; periergy, work beyond what is needed; perispherical, quite spherical.
Permanence: The quality or state of being permanent; continuance in the same state or place; duration; fixedness; as, the permanence of institutions; the permanence of nature.
Phytological: Of or pertaining to phytology; botanical.
Perversity: The quality or state of being perverse; perverseness.
Pia mater: The delicate and highly vascular membrane immediately investing the brain and spinal cord.
Peperine: A volcanic rock, formed by the cementing together of sand, scoria, cinders, etc.
Procinct: A state of complete readiness for action.
palatine: Of or pertaining to the palate; palatal.
Photochromy: The art or process of reproducing colors by photography.
Pseudo-bulb: An aërial corm, or thickened stem, as of some epiphytic orchidaceous plants.
Pinedrops: A reddish herb (Pterospora andromedea) of the United States, found parasitic on the roots of pine trees.
Plan: To form a delineation of; to draught; to represent, as by a diagram.
Paralogize: To reason falsely; to draw conclusions not warranted by the premises.
Phlegmasia: An inflammation; more particularly, an inflammation of the internal organs.
Polyphagous: Eating, or subsisting on, many kinds of food; as, polyphagous animals.
Pouchong: A superior kind of souchong tea.
Phenetol: The ethyl ether of phenol, obtained as an aromatic liquid, C6H5.O.C2H5.
Phthongometer: An instrument for measuring vocal sounds.
Pollucite: A colorless transparent mineral, resembling quartz, occurring with castor or castorite on the island of Elba. It is a silicate of alumina and cæsia. Called also pollux.
Prelumbar: Situated immediately in front of the loins; -- applied to the dorsal part of the abdomen.
Pursuable: Capable of being, or fit to be, pursued, followed, or prosecuted.
prescriptivist: A person who believes that acceptable practices should be prescribed by an authority rather than be determined by the usage of the general public; especially, a supporter of prescriptive{2} rules of grammar; -- also used attributively, as prescriptivist grammar.
Philanthropy: Love to mankind; benevolence toward the whole human family; universal good will; desire and readiness to do good to all men; -- opposed to misanthropy.
Prosencephalon: The anterior segment of the brain, including the cerebrum and olfactory lobes; the forebrain.
prescriptivism: The doctrine that acceptable grammatical rules should be prescribed by authority, rather than be determined by common usage.
Pseudonavicula: One of the minute spindle-shaped embryos of Gregarinæ and some other Protozoa.
Possessionary: Of or pertaining to possession; arising from possession.
Proximity: The quality or state of being next in time, place, causation, influence, etc.; immediate nearness, either in place, blood, or alliance.
Purposer: One who brings forward or proposes anything; a proposer.
Portamento: In singing, or in the use of the bow, a gradual carrying or lifting of the voice or sound very smoothly from one note to another; a gliding from tone to tone.
Philosopher: One who philosophizes; one versed in, or devoted to, philosophy.
Piebald: Having spots and patches of black and white, or other colors; mottled; pied.
Perigynium: Some unusual appendage about the pistil, as the bottle-shaped body in the sedges, and the bristles or scales in some other genera of the Sedge family, or Cyperaceæ.
Pluvi\u00f4se: The fifth month of the French republican calendar adopted in 1793. It began January 20, and ended February 18. See Vendémiaire.
Penannular: Nearly annular; having nearly the form of a ring.
Paramour: By or with love, esp. the love of the sexes; -- sometimes written as two words.
Puckerer: One who, or that which, puckers.
Palometa: A type of pompano (Palometa simillima) that is smaller than the Florida pompano; it is common in West Indies.  Called also the California pompano.
Polymathist: One versed in many sciences; a person of various learning.
Pellet: To form into small balls; to pelletize.
Plowwright: One who makes or repairs plows.
Phenanthridine: A nitrogenous hydrocarbon base, C13H9N, analogous to phenanthrene and quinoline.
Platycnemic: Of, relating to, or characterized by, platycnemism.
Productibility: The state of being productible; producibility.
Pillau: An Oriental dish consisting of rice boiled with mutton, fat, or butter.
Persnickety: Finicky or fussy; demanding attention to petty details; -- of people.
Phytolithologist: One versed in phytolithology; a paleobotanist.
Primitive: An original or primary word; a word not derived from another; -- opposed to derivative.
Pollicate: Having a curved projection or spine on the inner side of a leg joint; -- said of insects.
Proposition: The act of setting or placing before; the act of offering.
peal out: To give off a loud pealing sound; to peal.
Peristomial: Of or pertaining to a peristome.
Piscine: Of or pertaining to a fish or fishes; as, piscine remains.
Piscina: A niche near the altar in a church, containing a small basin for rinsing altar vessels.
Potto: A nocturnal mammal (Perodictius potto) of the Lemur family, found in West Africa. It has rudimentary forefingers. Called also aposoro, and bush dog.
Pancratic: Of or pertaining to the pancratium; athletic.
Psalter: The Book of Psalms; -- often applied to a book containing the Psalms separately printed.
Porridge: A food made by boiling some leguminous or farinaceous substance, or the meal of it, in water or in milk, making of broth or thin pudding; as, barley porridge, milk porridge, bean porridge, etc.
Plate: To cover or overlay with gold, silver, or other metals, either by a mechanical process, as hammering, or by a chemical process, as electrotyping.
Purgatory: A state or place of purification after death; according to the Roman Catholic creed, a place, or a state believed to exist after death, in which the souls of persons are purified by expiating such offenses committed in this life as do not merit eternal damnation, or in which they fully satisfy the justice of God for sins that have been forgiven. After this purgation from the impurities of sin, the souls are believed to be received into heaven.
Pathan: A native or inhabitant of Afghanistan, especially of the Pashtun tribes of southern Afghanistan.
Pagoda: A term by which Europeans designate religious temples and tower-like buildings of the Hindoos and Buddhists of India, Farther India, China, and Japan, -- usually but not always, devoted to idol worship.
Photoxylography: The process of producing a representation of an object on wood, by photography, for the use of the wood engraver.
Platy: Like a plate; consisting of plates.
Pharmacognosis: That branch of pharmacology which treats of unprepared medicines or simples; -- usually called pharmacognosy, and also pharmacography, and pharmacomathy.
Prenunciation: The act of announcing or proclaiming beforehand.
Pectize: To congeal; to change into a gelatinous mass.
Pigpen: A pen, or sty, for pigs.
Promulger: One who promulges or publishes what was before unknown.
Patch: To mend by sewing on a piece or pieces of cloth, leather, or the like; as, to patch a coat.
Poplar: Any tree of the genus Populus; also, the timber, which is soft, and capable of many uses.
Peoples party: A party formed in 1891, advocating an increase of the currency, public ownership and operation of railroads, telegraphs, etc., an income tax, limitation in ownership of land, etc.
Prussiate: A salt of prussic acid; a cyanide.
Perichondrial: Of or pertaining to the perichondrium; situated around cartilage.
Pleural: Of or pertaining to the pleura or pleuræ, or to the sides of the thorax.
Patriotical: Patriotic; that pertains to a patriot.
Piacle: A heinous offense which requires expiation.
Pedesis: Same as Brownian movement, under Brownian.
Pogamoggan: An aboriginal weapon consisting of a stone or piece of antler fastened to the end of a slender wooden handle, used by American Indians from the Great Plains to the Mackenzie River.
Pun: To persuade or affect by a pun.
Patibulary: Of or pertaining to the gallows, or to execution.
Porphyrite: A rock with a porphyritic structure; as, augite porphyrite.
Pue: To make a low whistling sound; to chirp, as birds.
Psychometry: The art of measuring the duration of mental processes, or of determining the time relations of mental phenomena.
Purification: The act of purifying; the act or operation of separating and removing from anything that which is impure or noxious, or heterogeneous or foreign to it; as, the purification of liquors, or of metals.
Pimento: Allspice; -- applied both to the tree and its fruit. See Allspice.
Preformative: A formative letter at the beginning of a word.
Pur: The low, murmuring sound made by a cat to express contentment or pleasure.
particulate: Matter composed of particles; -- often used in the pl.; as, the quantity of particulates in auto exhaust is strictly regulated.
Polysulphide: A sulphide having more than one atom of sulphur in the molecule; -- contrasted with monosulphide.
Paleocrystic: Of, pertaining to, or derived from, a former glacial formation.
Passacaglia: An old Italian or Spanish dance tune, in slow three-four measure, with divisions on a ground bass, resembling a chaconne.
Professionally: In a professional manner or capacity; by profession or calling; in the exercise of one's profession; one employed professionally.
Predate: To date anticipation; to affix to (a document) an earlier than the actual date; to antedate; as, a predated deed or letter.
Proportional: Any number or quantity in a proportion; as, a mean proportional.
Phosphoresce: To shine as phosphorus; to be phosphorescent; to emit a phosphoric light.
Pietistic: Of or pertaining to the Pietists; hence, in contempt, affectedly or demonstratively religious.
Pastry: The place where pastry is made.
Podophthalmic: Having the eyes on movable footstalks, or pedicels.
Perich\u00e6th: The leafy involucre surrounding the fruit stalk of mosses; perichætium; perichete.
Psychrometrical: Of or pertaining to the psychrometer or psychrometry.
Privacy: The state of being in retirement from the company or observation of others; seclusion.
Prandial: Of or pertaining to a repast, especially to dinner.
Polychromatic: Showing a variety, or a change, of colors.
Pulsatile: Capable of being struck or beaten; played by beating or by percussion; as, a tambourine is a pulsatile musical instrument.
Prangos: A genus of umbelliferous plants, one species of which (Prangos pabularia), found in Tibet, Cashmere, Afghanistan, etc., has been used as fodder for cattle.  It has decompound leaves with very long narrow divisions, and a highly fragrant smell resembling that of new clover hay.
Piano: A well-known musical instrument somewhat resembling the harpsichord, and consisting of a series of wires of graduated length, thickness, and tension, struck by hammers moved by keys.
Propodite: The sixth joint of a typical leg of a crustacean; usually, the penultimate joint.
Phyle: A local division of the people in ancient Athens; a clan; a tribe.
Primrose: Of or pertaining to the primrose; of the color of a primrose; -- hence, flowery; gay.
Potassium: An Alkali element, occurring abundantly but always combined, as in the chloride, sulphate, carbonate, or silicate, in the minerals sylvite, kainite, orthoclase, muscovite, etc. Atomic weight 39.0. Symbol K (Kalium).
Painim: A pagan; an infidel; -- used also adjectively.
Propylene: A colorless gaseous hydrocarbon (C3H6) of the ethylene series, having a garlic odor. It occurs in coal gas, and is produced artificially in various ways. Called also propene.
Phlox: A genus of American herbs, having showy red, white, or purple flowers.
Prospectus: A summary, plan, or scheme of something proposed, affording a prospect of its nature; especially, an exposition of the scheme of an unpublished literary work.
Postcommissure: A transverse commisure in the posterior part of the roof of the third ventricle of the brain; the posterior cerebral commisure.
Protosulphide: That one of a series of sulphides of any element which has the lowest proportion of sulphur; a sulphide with but one atom of sulphur in the molecule.
Plainness: The quality or state of being plain.
Pauciloquent: Uttering few words; brief in speech.
Puntello: One of the points sometimes drilled as guides for cutting away superfluous stone.
Plenilunary: Of or pertaining to the full moon.
Predisposition: The act of predisposing, or the state of being predisposed; previous inclination, tendency, or propensity; predilection; -- applied to the mind; as, a predisposition to anger.
Photo-epinasty: A disproportionately rapid growth of the upper surface of dorsiventral organs, such as leaves, through the stimulus of exposure to light.
Prickpunch: A pointed steel punch, to prick a mark on metal.
Polyeidism: The quality or state of being polyeidic.
Pinion: To bind or confine the wings of; to confine by binding the wings.
Perivascular: Around the blood vessels; as, perivascular lymphatics.
Pantisocracy: A Utopian community, in which all should rule equally, such as was devised by Coleridge, Lovell, and Southey, in their younger days.
Pillowcase: A removable case or covering for a pillow, usually of white linen or cotton cloth.
Petrine: Of or pertaining to St. Peter; as, the Petrine Epistles.
Prizing: The application of a lever to move any weighty body, as a cask, anchor, cannon, car, etc. See Prize, n., 5.
Point appliqu\u00e9: Lace having a needle-made design applied to a net ground, this ground often being machine-made.
Prickmadam: A name given to several species of stonecrop, used as ingredients of vermifuge medicines. See Stonecrop.
Phosphine: Chrysaniline, often in the form of a salt.
Phillygenin: A pearly crystalline substance obtained by the decomposition of phillyrin.
Paradoxical: Of the nature of a paradox.
Panache: A plume or bunch of feathers, esp. such a bunch worn on the helmet; any military plume, or ornamental group of feathers.
Phasing transformer: Any of several transformers (there must be at least two) for changing phase.
Prickwood: A shrub (Euonymus Europæus); -- so named from the use of its wood for goads, skewers, and shoe pegs. Called also spindle tree.
Prolixity: The quality or state of being prolix; great length; minute detail; as, prolixity in discourses and writings.
Pacane: A species of hickory. See Pecan.
paregmenon: Juxtaposing words having a common derivation, as in the phrase "sense and sensibility".
Pyrognostics: The characters of a mineral observed by the use of the blowpipe, as the degree of fusibility, flame coloration, etc.
Practicality: The quality or state of being practical; practicalness.
Patriarch: The father and ruler of a family; one who governs his family or descendants by paternal right; -- usually applied to heads of families in ancient history, especially in Biblical and Jewish history to those who lived before the time of Moses.
Pullback: That which holds back, or causes to recede; a drawback; a hindrance.
Polacca: A vessel with two or three masts, used in the Mediterranean. The masts are usually of one piece, and without tops, caps, or crosstrees.
Prickly: Full of sharp points or prickles; armed or covered with prickles; as, a prickly shrub.
Puppet: A small image in the human form; a doll.
Peripatus: A genus of lowly organized arthropods, found in South Africa, Australia, and tropical America. It constitutes the order Malacopoda.
Pipe: To perform, as a tune, by playing on a pipe, flute, fife, etc.; to utter in the shrill tone of a pipe.
Panspermatist: A believer in panspermy; one who rejects the theory of spontaneous generation; a biogenist.
Pentyl: The hypothetical radical, C5H11, of pentane and certain of its derivatives. Same as Amyl.
Premaxillary: Situated in front of the maxillary bones; pertaining to the premaxillæ; intermaxillary.
Pentacoccous: Composed of five united carpels with one seed in each, as certain fruits.
Payndemain: The finest and whitest bread made in the Middle Ages; -- called also paynemain, payman.
Psilanthropic: Pertaining to, or embodying, psilanthropy. “A psilanthropic explanation.”
Pathmaker: One who, or that which, makes a way or path.
Pupigerous: Bearing or containing a pupa; -- said of dipterous larvæ which do not molt when the pupa is formed within them.
Pronephros: The head kidney. See under Head.
Protyle: The hypothetical homogeneous cosmic material of the original universe, supposed to have been differentiated into what are recognized as distinct chemical elements.
Paracrostic: A poetical composition, in which the first verse contains, in order, the first letters of all the verses of the poem.
Predecessor: One who precedes; one who has preceded another in any state, position, office, etc.; one whom another follows or comes after, in any office or position.
Precrural: Situated in front of the leg or thigh; as, the precrural glands of the horse.
Prowess: Distinguished bravery; valor; especially, military bravery and skill; gallantry; intrepidity; fearlessness.
Pemmican: Among the North American Indians, meat cut in thin slices, divested of fat, and dried in the sun.
Petasus: The winged cap of Mercury; also, a broad-brimmed, low-crowned hat worn by Greeks and Romans.
Pate: The head of a person; the top, or crown, of the head.
Piston ring: A spring packing ring, or any of several such rings, for a piston.
Phycoerythrin: A red coloring matter found in algæ of the subclass Florideæ.
Pycnogonida: A class of marine arthropods in which the body is small and thin, and the eight legs usually very long; -- called also Pantopoda.
Piffero: A fife; also, a rude kind of oboe or a bagpipe with an inflated skin for reservoir.
Pumice: A very light porous volcanic scoria, usually of a gray color, the pores of which are capillary and parallel, giving it a fibrous structure. It is supposed to be produced by the disengagement of watery vapor without liquid or plastic lava. It is much used, esp. in the form of powder, for smoothing and polishing. Called also pumice stone.
Parapetalous: Growing by the side of a petal, as a stamen.
Perchloric: Pertaining to, or designating, the highest oxygen acid (HClO4), of chlorine; -- called also hyperchloric.
Paracmastic: Gradually decreasing; past the acme, or crisis, as a distemper.
Peristaltic: Applied to the peculiar wormlike wave motion of the intestines and other similar structures, produced by the successive contraction of the muscular fibers of their walls, forcing their contents onwards; as, peristaltic movement.
Prosoma: The anterior of the body of an animal, as of a cephalopod; the thorax of an arthropod.
Pantoscopic: Literally, seeing everything; -- a term applied to eyeglasses or spectacles divided into two segments, the upper being designed for distant vision, the lower for vision of near objects.
Playbook: A book of dramatic compositions; a book of the play.
Padelion: A plant with pedately lobed leaves; the lady's mantle.
Premier: The first minister of state; the prime minister.
Perform: To do, execute, or accomplish something; to acquit one's self in any business; esp., to represent sometimes by action; to act a part; to play on a musical instrument; as, the players perform poorly; the musician performs on the organ.
Probably: In a probable manner; in likelihood.
Promuscis: The proboscis of hemipterous insects. See Illust. under Hemiptera.
Paludism: The morbid phenomena produced by dwelling among marshes; malarial disease or disposition.
Pied: Variegated with spots of different colors; party-colored; spotted; piebald.
Pigfish: Any one of several species of salt-water grunts; -- called also hogfish.
Phorminx: A kind of lyre used by the Greeks.
Pier: Any detached mass of masonry, whether insulated or supporting one side of an arch or lintel, as of a bridge; the piece of wall between two openings.
Pink-sterned: Having a very narrow stern; -- said of a vessel.
Pterygopalatine: Of or pertaining to the pterygoid processes and the palatine bones.
Pigweed: A name of several annual weeds. See Goosefoot, and Lamb's-quarters.
Postil: To write postils, or marginal notes; to comment; to postillate.
Pyralid: Any moth of the family Pyralidæ. The species are numerous and mostly small, but some of them are very injurious, as the bee moth, meal moth, hop moth, and clover moth.
Planer: One who, or that which, planes; a planing machine; esp., a machine for planing wood or metals.
Palstave: A peculiar bronze adz, used in prehistoric Europe about the middle of the bronze age.
Poikilothermal: Having a varying body temperature. See Homoiothermal.
Prelal: Of or pertaining to printing; typographical.
Putage: Prostitution or fornication on the part of a woman.
Pyramidal: One of the carpal bones. See Cuneiform, n., 2 (b).
Plashoot: A hedge or fence formed of branches of trees interlaced, or plashed.
Pictograph: A picture or hieroglyph representing and expressing an idea.
Pythian: Of or pertaining to Delphi, to the temple of Apollo, or to the priestess of Apollo, who delivered oracles at Delphi.
Pomaceous: Like an apple or pear; producing pomes.
Phycochrome: A bluish green coloring matter of certain algæ.
Polypetalous: Consisting of, or having, several or many separate petals; as, a polypetalous corolla, flower, or plant.
Precoracoid: The anterior part of the coracoid (often closely united with the clavicle) in the shoulder girdle of many reptiles and amphibians.
Pellage: A customs duty on skins of leather.
payload: The part of a missile or torpedo that carries the explosive charge.
Ping-pong ball: the small hollow celluloid ball used for the game of ping-pong.
Polewig: The European spotted goby (Gobius minutus); -- called also pollybait.
Preclusive: Shutting out; precluding, or tending to preclude; hindering.
Prefatorily: In a prefatory manner; by way of preface.
Piment: Wine flavored with spice or honey. See Pigment, 3.
Prance: To spring or bound, as a horse in high mettle.
Press: An apparatus or machine by which any substance or body is pressed, squeezed, stamped, or shaped, or by which an impression of a body is taken; sometimes, the place or building containing a press or presses.
Prest: To give as a loan; to lend.
Purtenance: That which pertains or belongs to something; esp., the heard, liver, and lungs of an animal.
Pestilence: Specifically, the disease known as the plague; hence, any contagious or infectious epidemic disease that is virulent and devastating.
Piccage: Money paid at fairs for leave to break ground for booths.
Penknife: A small pocketknife; formerly, a knife used for making and mending quill pens.
Posy: A brief poetical sentiment; hence, any brief sentiment, motto, or legend; especially, one inscribed on a ring.
Panama hat: A fine plaited hat, made in Central America of the young leaves of a plant (Carludovica palmata).
Post: With post horses; hence, in haste; as, to travel post.
Purchaser: One who purchases; one who acquires property for a consideration, generally of money; a buyer; a vendee.
Phosphonium: The hypothetical radical PH4, analogous to ammonium, and regarded as the nucleus of certain derivatives of phosphine.
Petrology: The department of science which is concerned with the mineralogical and chemical composition of rocks, and with their classification: lithology.
Phycomycetes: A large, important class of parasitic or saprophytic fungi, the algal or algalike fungi. The plant body ranges from an undifferentiated mass of protoplasm to a well-developed and much-branched mycelium. Reproduction is mainly sexual, by the formation of conidia or sporangia; but the group shows every form of transition from this method through simple conjugation to perfect sexual reproduction by egg and sperm in the higher forms.
Plaquette: A small plaque, esp., in modern medal engraving, a small and delicate bas-relief, whether cast or struck from a die, or of form other than circular.
Portend: To indicate (events, misfortunes, etc.) as in future; to foreshow; to foretoken; to bode; -- now used esp. of unpropitious signs.
Pilaster: An upright architectural member right-angled in plan, constructionally a pier (See Pier, 1 (b)), but architecturally corresponding to a column, having capital, shaft, and base to agree with those of the columns of the same order. In most cases the projection from the wall is one third of its width, or less.
Pulmonate: Having breathing organs that act as lungs.
Portent: That which portends, or foretoken; esp., that which portends evil; a sign of coming calamity; an omen; a sign.
Papist: A Roman Catholic; one who adheres to the Church of Rome and the authority of the pope; -- an offensive designation applied to Roman Catholics by their opponents.
Pacification: The act or process of pacifying, or of making peace between parties at variance; reconciliation.
Prognosis: The act or art of foretelling the course and termination of a disease; also, the outlook afforded by this act of judgment; as, the prognosis of hydrophobia is bad.
Pickering: The sauger of the St.Lawrence River.
Podocarp: A stem, or footstalk, supporting the fruit.
Plank-sheer: The course of plank laid horizontally over the timberheads of a vessel's frame.
Putative: Commonly thought or deemed; supposed; reputed; as, the putative father of a child.
Peanut gallery: The cheapest seats in a theater, being typically those farthest from the stage, as in the uppermost balcony.
Peristeropodous: Having pigeonlike feet; -- said of those gallinaceous birds that rest on all four toes, as the curassows and megapods.
Pachyrhizus: A small genus of tropical vines having tuberous roots.
Putredinous: Proceeding from putrefaction, or partaking of the putrefactive process; having an offensive smell; stinking; rotten.
Pantophagy: The habit or power of eating all kinds of food.
Protoxide: That one of a series of oxides having the lowest proportion of oxygen. See Proto-, 2 (b).
Pesky: Pestering; vexatious; troublesome. Used also as an intensive.
Parapterum: A special plate situated on the sides of the mesothorax and metathorax of certain insects.
Pentoic: Pertaining to, or desingating, an acid (called also valeric acid) derived from pentane.
Perigenesis: A theory which explains inheritance by the transmission of the type of growth force possessed by one generation to another.
Personalism: The quality or state of being personal; personality.
Packway: A path, as over mountains, followed by pack animals.
Pervade: To pass or flow through, as an aperture, pore, or interstice; to permeate.
parang: A stout strait-edged knife used in Malayasia and Indonesia.
Pedantic: Of or pertaining to a pedant; characteristic of, or resembling, a pedant; ostentatious of learning; as, a pedantic writer; a pedantic description; a pedantical affectation.
Propeptone: A product of gastric digestion intermediate between albumin and peptone, identical with hemialbumose.
Pelage: The covering, or coat, of a mammal, whether of wool, fur, or hair.
piss off: To leave immediately; to scram; -- chiefly British, and sometimes considered vulgar.
Pembroke: A breed of dog, the smaller and straight-legged variety of Welsh corgi having pointed ears and a short tail.
Plumpness: The quality or state of being plump.
Proparoxytone: A word which has the acute accent on the antepenult.
Planoblast: Any free-swimming gonophore of a hydroid; a hydroid medusa.
Parlando: Speaking; in a speaking or declamatory manner; to be sung or played in the style of a recitative.
Permanent: Continuing in the same state, or without any change that destroys form or character; remaining unaltered or unremoved; abiding; durable; fixed; stable; lasting; as, a permanent impression.
Polyonomy: The use of a variety of names for the same object.
Paripinnate: Pinnate with an equal number of leaflets on each side; having no odd leaflet at the end.
Petronel: A sort of hand cannon, or portable firearm, used in France in the 15th century.
Pr\u00e9cis: A concise or abridged statement or view; an abstract; a summary.
Pontine: Of or pertaining to an extensive marshy district between Rome and Naples.
Priority: The quality or state of being prior or antecedent in time, or of preceding something else; as, priority of application.
Photochromoscope: A device for giving shifting effects of color to a photograph. The unmounted print, made translucent, is illuminated from behind with colored light.
Patrimony: A right or estate inherited from one's father; or, in a larger sense, from any ancestor.
Ponibility: The capability of being placed or located.
Physiogeny: The germ history of the functions, or the history of the development of vital activities, in the individual, being one of the branches of ontogeny. See Morphogeny.
Pessary: An instrument or device to be introduced into and worn in the vagina, to support the uterus, or remedy a malposition.
Priapulacea: A suborder of Gephyræa, having a cylindrical body with a terminal anal opening, and usually with one or two caudal gills.
Phonometer: An instrument for measuring sounds, as to their intensity, or the frequency of the vibrations.
Per\u00e6opod: One of the thoracic legs of a crustacean. See Illust. of Crustacea.
Pyrena: A nutlet resembling a seed, or the kernel of a drupe.
Pathos: That quality or property of anything which touches the feelings or excites emotions and passions, esp., that which awakens tender emotions, such as pity, sorrow, and the like; contagious warmth of feeling, action, or expression; pathetic quality; as, the pathos of a picture, of a poem, or of a cry.
Persuader: One who, or that which, persuades or influences.
Perigone: Any organ inclosing the essential organs of a flower; a perianth.
Paleographist: One versed in paleography; a paleographer.
Pyrethrin: A substance resembling, and isomeric with, ordinary camphor, and extracted from the essential oil of feverfew; -- called also Pyrethrum camphor.
Persuaded: Prevailed upon; influenced by argument or entreaty; convinced.
Procreate: To generate and produce; to beget; to engender.
Ponderousness: The quality or state of being ponderous; ponderosity.
Poutingly: In a pouting, or a sullen, manner.
Pronghorn: An American antelope (Antilocapra Americana), native of the plain near the Rocky Mountains. The upper parts are mostly yellowish brown; the under parts, the sides of the head and throat, and the buttocks, are white. The horny sheath of the horns is shed annually. Called also cabrée, cabut, prongbuck, and pronghorned antelope.
Pinfish: The sailor's choice (Diplodus rhomboides syn. Lagodon rhomboides).
Peccary: A pachyderm of the genus Dicotyles.
Pompon: Any trifling ornament for a woman's dress or bonnet.
Pompom: an ornamental ball or tuft of wool, feathers, or other fluffy material used as a decoration on clothing such as hats and slippers.
Progeny: Descendants of the human kind, or offspring of other animals; children; offspring; race, lineage.
Polka: A dance of Polish origin, but now common everywhere. It is performed by two persons in common time.
Pentecost: A solemn festival of the Jews; -- so called because celebrated on the fiftieth day (seven weeks) after the second day of the Passover (which fell on the sixteenth of the Jewish month Nisan); -- hence called, also, the Feast of Weeks. At this festival an offering of the first fruits of the harvest was made. By the Jews it was generally regarded as commemorative of the gift of the law on the fiftieth day after the departure from Egypt.
Portingal: Of or pertaining to Portugal; Portuguese.
Pristine: Belonging to the earliest period or state; original; primitive; primeval; as, the pristine state of innocence; the pristine manners of a people; pristine vigor.
Prodigally: In a prodigal manner; with profusion of expense; extravagantly; wasteful; profusely; lavishly; as, an estate prodigally dissipated.
Plani-: Combining forms signifying flat, level, plane; as planifolious, planimetry, plano-concave.
Prosaist: A writer of prose; an unpoetical writer.
Parieto-: A combining form used to indicate connection with, or relation to, the parietal bones or the parietal segment of the skull; as, the parieto-mastoid suture.
Plaster: To cover with a plaster, as a wound or sore.
patrolling: The activity of going around or through an area at regular intervals for security purposes.
Pomelo: A variety of shaddock, called also grape fruit.
Psalmographer: A writer of psalms, or sacred songs and hymns.
Prosaism: That which is in the form of prose writing; a prosaic manner.
Pompous: Displaying pomp; stately; showy with grandeur; magnificent; as, a pompous procession.
Physic: To treat with physic or medicine; to administer medicine to, esp. a cathartic; to operate on as a cathartic; to purge.
Psilop\u00e6dic: Having down upon the pterylæ only; -- said of the young of certain birds.
Preterient: Passed through; antecedent; previous; as, preterient states.
Progenitorship: The state of being a progenitor.
Plankton: All the animals and plants, taken collectively, which live at or near the surface of salt or fresh waters.
Prolonger: One who, or that which, causes an extension in time or space.
Passionary: A book in which are described the sufferings of saints and martyrs.
Peristole: Peristaltic action, especially of the intestines.
Puce: Of a dark brown or brownish purple color.
Puck: A disk of vulcanized rubber used in the game of hockey, as the object to be driven through the goals.
Podophthalmia: The stalk-eyed Crustacea, -- an order of Crustacea having the eyes supported on movable stalks. It includes the crabs, lobsters, and prawns. Called also Podophthalmata, and Decapoda.
Persian: A native or inhabitant of Persia.
Pragmaticalness: The quality or state of being pragmatical.
Phalanx: A body of heavy-armed infantry formed in ranks and files close and deep. There were several different arrangements, the phalanx varying in depth from four to twenty-five or more ranks of men.
Petechi\u00e6: Small crimson, purple, or livid spots, like flea-bites, due to extravasation of blood, which appear on the skin in malignant fevers, etc.
Pallidness: The quality or state of being pallid; paleness; pallor; wanness.
Padella: A large cup or deep saucer, containing fatty matter in which a wick is placed, -- used for public illuminations, as at St. Peter's, in Rome.  Called also padelle.
Pseudoscope: An instrument which exhibits objects with their proper relief reversed; -- an effect opposite to that produced by the stereoscope.
Pyromagnetic: Acting by the agency of heat and magnetism; as, a pyromagnetic machine for producing electric currents.
Proveditor: One employed to procure supplies, as for an army, a steamer, etc.; a purveyor; one who provides for another.
Poorness: The quality or state of being poor (in any of the senses of the adjective).
Pentandrian: Of or pertaining to the class Pentadria; having five stamens.
Paraboloidal: Of, pertaining to, or resembling, a paraboloid.
President: One who is elected or appointed to preside; a presiding officer, as of a legislative body.
Pietra dura: Hard and fine stones in general, such as are used for inlay and the like, as distinguished from the softer stones used in building; thus, a Florentine mosaic is a familiar instance of work in pietra dura, though the ground may be soft marble.
Prepose: To place or set before; to prefix.
Preact: To act beforehand; to perform previously.
Prepollence: The quality or state of being prepollent; superiority of power; predominance; prevalence.
Pedestrianism: The act, art, or practice of a pedestrian; walking or running; traveling or racing on foot.
Portion: To separate or divide into portions or shares; to parcel; to distribute.
Phyllostome: Any bat of the genus Phyllostoma, or allied genera, having large membranes around the mouth and nose; a nose-leaf bat.
Prescriptive: Consisting in, or acquired by, immemorial or long-continued use and enjoyment; as, a prescriptive right of title; pleading the continuance and authority of long custom.
Pelican: Any large webfooted bird of the genus Pelecanus, of which about a dozen species are known.  They have an enormous bill, to the lower edge of which is attached a pouch in which captured fishes are temporarily stored.
paeony: Any of numerous plants widely cultivated for their showy single or double red or pink or white flowers; the Peony.
Potlid: The lid or cover of a pot.
Phoneidoscope: An instrument for studying the motions of sounding bodies by optical means. It consists of a tube across the end of which is stretched a film of soap solution thin enough to give colored bands, the form and position of which are affected by sonorous vibrations.
Peripheral: Of or pertaining to a periphery; constituting a periphery; peripheric.
Pentastichous: Having, or arranged in, five vertical ranks, as the leaves of an apple tree or a cherry tree.
pandore: An ancient musical instrument, of the lute kind; a bandore.
Point man: the lead soldier in a foot patrol under combat conditions.
Parsimony: Closeness or sparingness in the expenditure of money; -- generally in a bad sense; excessive frugality; niggardliness.
Phlogistic: Of or pertaining to phlogiston, or to belief in its existence.
Pericarp: The ripened ovary; the walls of the fruit. See Illusts. of Capsule, Drupe, and Legume.
Precation: The act of praying; supplication; entreaty.
Plain-dealing: Practicing plain dealing; artless. See Plain dealing, under Dealing.
Polychromate: A compound which exhibits, or from which may be prepared, a variety of colors, as certain solutions derived from vegetables, which display colors by fluorescence.
Parabronchium: One of the branches of an ectobronchium or entobronchium.
Pretibial: Situated in front of the tibia.
Prenomination: The act of prenominating; privilege of being named first.
Plexure: The act or process of weaving together, or interweaving; that which is woven together.
Peculiarly: In a peculiar manner; particularly; in a rare and striking degree; unusually.
Palatableness: The quality or state of being agreeable to the taste; relish; acceptableness.
Postgeniture: The condition of being born after another in the same family; -- distinguished from primogeniture.
Peremptoriness: The quality of being peremptory; positiveness.
Posthouse: A house established for the convenience of the post, where relays of horses can be obtained.
Proxene: An officer who had the charge of showing hospitality to those who came from a friendly city or state.
Prefect: A Roman officer who controlled or superintended a particular command, charge, department, etc.; as, the prefect of the aqueducts; the prefect of a camp, of a fleet, of the city guard, of provisions; the pretorian prefect, who was commander of the troops guarding the emperor's person.
Preciousness: The quality or state of being precious; costliness; dearness.
Potamian: A river tortoise; one of a group of tortoises (Potamites, or Trionychoidea) having a soft shell, webbed feet, and a sharp beak. See Trionyx.
Polyanthus: The oxlip. So called because the peduncle bears a many-flowered umbel. See Oxlip. (b) A bulbous flowering plant of the genus Narcissus (Narcissus Tazetta, or Narcissus polyanthus of some authors). See Illust. of Narcissus.
Plasmic: Of, pertaining to, or connected with, plasma; plasmatic.
Plasmid: A piece of DNA, usually circular, functioning as part of the genetic material of a cell, not integrated with the chromosome and replicating independently of the chromosome, but transferred, like the chromosome, to subsequent generations of daughter cells.  In bacteria, plasmids often carry the genes for antibiotic resistance; they are exploited in genetic engineering as the vehicles for introduction of extraneous DNA into cells, to alter the genetic makeup of the cell.  The cells thus altered may produce desirable proteins which are extracted and used; in the case of genetically altered plant cells, the altered cells may grow into complete plants with changed properties, as for example, increased resistance to disease.
Podophyllous: Having thin, flat, leaflike locomotive organs.
Primacy: The state or condition of being prime or first, as in time, place, rank, etc., hence, excellency; supremacy.
Plasmin: A proteid body, separated by some physiologists from blood plasma. It is probably identical with fibrinogen.
Prepositive: Put before; prefixed; as, a prepositive particle.
Penetrating: Having the power of entering, piercing, or pervading; sharp; subtile; penetrative; as, a penetrating odor.
Psychogenesis: Genesis through an internal force, as opposed to natural selection.
Precipitability: The quality or state of being precipitable.
Provost: A person who is appointed to superintend, or preside over, something; the chief magistrate in some cities and towns; as, the provost of Edinburgh or of Glasgow, answering to the mayor of other cities; the provost of a college, answering to president; the provost or head of certain collegiate churches.
Permissibility: The quality of being permissible; permissibleness; allowableness.
Pollex: The first, or preaxial, digit of the fore limb, corresponding to the hallux in the hind limb; the thumb. In birds, the pollex is the joint which bears the bastard wing.
Polystomata: A division of trematode worms having more two suckers. Called also Polystomea and Polystoma.
Polymorphosis: The assumption of several structural forms without a corresponding difference in function; -- said of sponges, etc.
Primordially: At the beginning; under the first order of things; originally.
Pannikel: The brainpan, or skull; hence, the crest.
Polydactylism: The possession of more that the normal number of digits.
Pronephric: Of or pertaining to the pronephros.
Pyroxanthin: A yellow crystalline hydrocardon extracted from crude wood spirit; -- called also eblanin.
Proterogynous: Having the pistil come to maturity before the stamens; protogynous; -- opposed to proterandrous.
Posttertiary: Following, or more recent than, the Tertiary; Quaternary.
Pedetentous: Proceeding step by step; advancing cautiously.
Piedmont: Noting the region of foothills near the base of a mountain chain.
Purpurin: A dyestuff resembling alizarin, found in madder root, and extracted as an orange or red crystalline substance.
Paintership: The state or position of being a painter.
Ptarmigan: Any grouse of the genus Lagopus, of which numerous species are known. The feet are completely feathered. Most of the species are brown in summer, but turn white, or nearly white, in winter.
Piquet: A game at cards played between two persons, with thirty-two cards, all the deuces, threes, fours, fives, and sixes, being set aside.
Pontic: Of or pertaining to the Pontus, Euxine, or Black Sea.
Peristeromorphous: Like or pertaining to the pigeons or Columbæ.
Preform: To form beforehand, or for special ends.
Phycoph\u00e6ine: A brown coloring matter found in certain algæ.
Piling: A series of piles; piles considered collectively; as, the piling of a bridge.
Punctilious: Attentive to punctilio; very nice or exact in the forms of behavior, etiquette, or mutual intercourse; precise; exact in the smallest particulars.
Proletariat: The indigent class in the State; the body of proletarians.
Perchant: A bird tied by the foot, to serve as decoy to other birds by its fluttering.
Pr\u00e9cieuse: An affected woman of polite society, esp. one of the literary women of the French salons of the 17th century.  See aslo preciosity.
Pressing: Urgent; exacting; importunate; as, a pressing necessity.
Powder: To be reduced to powder; to become like powder; as, some salts powder easily.
Pregnancy: The condition of being pregnant; the state of being with young.
Proletarian: Of or pertaining to the proletaries; belonging to the commonalty; hence, mean; vile; vulgar.
Phalangeal: Of or pertaining to the phalanges. See Phalanx, 2.
Patulous: Open; expanded; slightly spreading; having the parts loose or dispersed; as, a patulous calyx; a patulous cluster of flowers.
Probity: Tried virtue or integrity; approved moral excellence; honesty; rectitude; uprightness.
Predal: Of or pertaining to prey; plundering; predatory.
Punnology: The art or practice of punning; paronomasia.
paintbox: A box containing a collection of cubes or tubes of artists' paint.
Paragraphic: Pertaining to, or consisting of, a paragraph or paragraphs.
Parrock: A croft, or small field; a paddock.
Powwow: To use conjuration, with noise and confusion, for the cure of disease, etc., as among the North American Indians.
Phenix: A bird fabled to exist single, to be consumed by fire by its own act, and to rise again from its ashes.  Hence, an emblem of immortality.
Pyrotechnist: One skilled in pyrotechny; one who manufactures fireworks.
Purulence: The quality or state of being purulent; the generation of pus; also, the pus itself.
Proglottis: One of the free, or nearly free, segments of a tapeworm. It contains both male and female reproductive organs, and is capable of a brief independent existence.
Prosobranchiata: The highest division, or subclass, of gastropod mollusks, including those that have the gills situated anteriorly, or forward of the heart, and the sexes separate.
Processioning: A proceeding prescribed by statute for ascertaining and fixing the boundaries of land. See 2d Procession.
Prefix: That which is prefixed; esp., one or more letters or syllables combined or united with the beginning of a word to modify its signification; as, pre- in prefix, con- in conjure.
Praseo-: A combining form signifying green; as, praseocobalt, a green variety of cobalt.
Proximal: Toward or nearest, as to a body, or center of motion of dependence; proximate.
Paviin: A glucoside found in species of the genus Pavia of the Horse-chestnut family.
Pinto: Any pied animal; esp., a pied or “painted” horse.
Postcommunion: The concluding portion of the communion service.
Procuratorial: Of or pertaining to a procurator, or proctor; made by a proctor.
Puddling: The process of working clay, loam, pulverized ore, etc., with water, to render it compact, or impervious to liquids; also, the process of rendering anything impervious to liquids by means of puddled material.
Pluteus: The free-swimming larva of sea urchins and ophiurans, having several long stiff processes inclosing calcareous rods.
Polychroite: The coloring matter of saffron; -- formerly so called because of the change of color on treatment with certain acids; -- called also crocin, and safranin.
Pronged: Having prongs or projections like the tines of a fork; as, a three-pronged fork.
proenzyme: Any one of a class of proteins that are converted, in the normal course of cellular metabolism, into one or more active enzymes; also called zymogen.  The conversion usually is due to a specific cleavage of a peptide bond by another enzyme, or may be due to acid.
Prong-hoe: A hoe with prongs to break the earth.
Pollinose: Having the surface covered with a fine yellow dust, like pollen.
Papyrus: A tall rushlike plant (Cyperus Papyrus) of the Sedge family, formerly growing in Egypt, and now found in Abyssinia, Syria, Sicily, etc. The stem is triangular and about an inch thick.
Peroxide: An oxide containing more oxygen than some other oxide of the same element. Formerly peroxides were regarded as the highest oxides.  Cf. Per-, 2.
Pyrogenic: Producing heat; -- said of substances, as septic poisons, which elevate the temperature of the body and cause fever.
Planaria: Any species of turbellarian worms belonging to Planaria, and many allied genera. The body is usually flat, thin, and smooth. Some species, in warm countries, are terrestrial.
Polynia: The open sea supposed to surround the north pole.
Priscillianist: A follower of Priscillian, bishop of Avila in Spain, in the fourth century, who mixed various elements of Gnosticism and Manicheism with Christianity.
Pholas: Any one of numerous species of marine bivalve mollusks of the genus Pholas, or family Pholadidæ. They bore holes for themselves in clay, peat, and soft rocks.
Pacifico: A peaceful person; -- applied specif. by the Spaniards to the natives in Cuba and the Philippine Islands who did not oppose the Spanish arms.
Phasel: The French bean, or kidney bean.
Preformation: An old theory of the preëxistence of germs.  Cf. Emboîtement.
Philharmonic: One who loves harmony or music;
Propense: Leaning toward, in a moral sense; inclined; disposed; prone; as, women propense to holiness.
panoptic: Including everying visible in one view; as, a panoptic aerial photograph of the missile base; a panoptic stain used in microscopy.
Protuberance: That which is protuberant swelled or pushed beyond the surrounding or adjacent surface; a swelling or tumor on the body; a prominence; a bunch or knob; an elevation.
parenchyma: The soft cellular substance of the tissues of plants and animals, like the pulp of leaves, the soft tissue of glands, and the like.
Penetrance: The quality or state of being penetrant; power of entering or piercing; penetrating power or quality; as, the penetrancy of subtile effluvia.
Protuberancy: The quality or state of being protuberant; protuberance; prominence.
Picnicker: One who takes part in a picnic.
Plug: To stop with a plug; to make tight by stopping a hole.
Patrimonial: Of or pertaining to a patrimony; inherited from ancestors; as, a patrimonial estate.
Placodermi: An extinct group of fishes, supposed to be ganoids. The body and head were covered with large bony plates. See Illust. under Pterichthys, and Coccosteus.
pathologist: One skilled in pathology; an investigator in pathology; as, the pathologist of a hospital, whose duty it is to determine the causes of the diseases.
-plasty: A combining form denoting the act or process of forming, development, growth; as, autoplasty, perineoplasty.
Paratactic: Of pertaining to, or characterized by, parataxis.
Perforation: The act of perforating, or of boring or piercing through.
Puncher: One who, or that which, punches.
pallbearer: One of those who attend the coffin at a funeral; -- so called from the pall being formerly carried by them.
Pronoun: A word used instead of a noun or name, to avoid the repetition of it. The personal pronouns in English are I, thou or you, he, she, it, we, ye, and they.
Procephalic: Pertaining to, or forming, the front of the head.
Plectrum: A small instrument of ivory, wood, metal, or quill, used in playing upon the lyre and other stringed instruments.
pachyglossia: The condition of having an enlarged thick tongue.
Password: A word to be given before a person is allowed to pass; a watchword; a countersign.
Phylactol\u00e6matous: Of or pertaining to the Phylactolæma.
Percuss: To strike or tap in an examination by percussion. See Percussion, 3.
Palestra: A wrestling school; hence, a gymnasium, or place for athletic exercise in general.
Petaurist: Any flying marsupial of the genera Petaurus, Phalangista, Acrobata, and allied genera. See Flying mouse, under Flying, and Phalangister.
Parqueted: Formed in parquetry; inlaid with wood in small and differently colored figures.
Pretermission: The act of passing by or omitting; omission.
Prolegate: The deputy or substitute for a legate.
Percentage: A certain rate per cent; the allowance, duty, rate of interest, discount, or commission, on a hundred.
pen-and-ink: A drawing executed with pen and ink.
Palliative: That which palliates; a palliative agent.
Pilled: Stripped of hair; scant of hair; bald.
Perpetuation: The act of making perpetual, or of preserving from extinction through an endless existence, or for an indefinite period of time; continuance.
Precoetanean: One contemporary with, but older than, another.
Postulation: The act of postulating, or that which is postulated; assumption; solicitation; suit; cause.
Peakish: Of or relating to a peak; or to peaks; belonging to a mountainous region.
Parnassian: One of a school of French poets of the Second Empire (1852-70) who emphasized metrical form and made little use of emotion as poetic material; -- so called from the name (Parnasse contemporain) of the volume in which their first poems were collected in 1866.
Predestinarian: One who believes in or supports the doctrine of predestination.
Parametritis: Inflammation of the cellular tissue in the vicinity of the uterus.
Presidency: The function or condition of one who presides; superintendence; control and care.
Paralyzation: The act or process of paralyzing, or the state of being paralyzed.
Pippin: An apple from a tree raised from the seed and not grafted; a seedling apple.
Periganglionic: Surrounding a ganglion; as, the periganglionic glands of the frog.
Pooped: Having a poop; furnished with a poop.
Pseudh\u00e6mal: Pertaining to the vascular system of annelids.
Prepenial: Situated in front of, or anterior to, the penis.
Puddly: Consisting of, or resembling, puddles; muddy; foul.
Prejudice: To cause to have prejudice; to prepossess with opinions formed without due knowledge or examination; to bias the mind of, by hasty and incorrect notions; to give an unreasonable bent to, as to one side or the other of a cause; as, to prejudice a critic or a juryman.
Preambulary: Of or pertaining to a preamble; introductory; contained or provided for in a preamble.
Philter: To impregnate or mix with a love potion; as, to philter a draught.
Purlin: In root construction, a horizontal member supported on the principals and supporting the common rafters.
Puffy: Swelled with air, or any soft matter; tumid with a soft substance; bloated; fleshy; as, a puffy tumor.
Provender: Dry food for domestic animals, as hay, straw, corn, oats, or a mixture of ground grain; feed.
Pennant: A small flag; a pennon.  The narrow pennant, or long pennant (called also whip or coach whip) is a long, narrow piece of bunting, carried at the masthead of a government vessel in commission.  The board pennant is an oblong, nearly square flag, carried at the masthead of a commodore's vessel.
Pontile: Of or pertaining to the pons Varolii. See Pons.
Phlogopite: A kind of mica having generally a peculiar bronze-red or copperlike color and a pearly luster. It is a silicate of aluminia, with magnesia, potash, and some fluorine. It is characteristic of crystalline limestone or dolomite and serpentine. See Mica.
Parisienne: A female native or resident of Paris.
Preremote: More remote in previous time or prior order.
Pietist: One of a class of religious reformers in Germany in the 17th century who sought to revive declining piety in the Protestant churches; -- often applied as a term of reproach to those who make a display of religious feeling. Also used adjectively.
Pietism: The principle or practice of the Pietists.
Pseudepigraphy: The ascription of false names of authors to works.
Peppercorn: A dried berry of the black pepper (Piper nigrum).
Parturient: Bringing forth, or about to bring forth, young; fruitful.
Prospective: The scene before or around, in time or in space; view; prospect.
Placebo effect: a reaction by a patient who receives a placebo{2}, in which the symptoms of illness are lessened or an anticipated effect is experienced.  Because the placebo{2} itself has no pharmacological activity, this reaction is mediated by the expectations of the patient receiving the placebo{2}; the reaction is considered as an example of the power of suggestion.
Pucker: A fold; a wrinkle; a collection of folds.
Papillulate: Having a minute papilla in the center of a larger elevation or depression.
Pappiform: Resembling the pappus of composite plants.
Penates: The household gods of the ancient Romans. They presided over the home and the family hearth. See Lar.
Polymerization: The act or process of changing to a polymeric form; the condition resulting from such change.
Pyramid: To use, or to deal in, in a pyramiding transaction. See Pyramid, v. i.
Pacific: The Pacific Ocean, the largest ocean.
Poematic: Pertaining to a poem, or to poetry; poetical.
Palla: An oblong rectangular piece of cloth, worn by Roman ladies, and fastened with brooches.
Pricking-up: The first coating of plaster in work of three coats upon laths. Its surface is scratched once to form a better key for the next coat. In the United States called scratch coat.
Potentiality: The quality or state of being potential; possibility, not actuality; inherent capability or disposition, not actually exhibited.
p\u00e6dogenetic: Producing young while in the immature or larval state; -- said of certain insects, etc.
Prehnite: A pale green mineral occurring in crystalline aggregates having a botryoidal or mammillary structure, and rarely in distinct crystals. It is a hydrous silicate of alumina and lime.
Pathognomy: Expression of the passions; the science of the signs by which human passions are indicated.
pally: Having the relationship of friends or pals; -- used colloquially.
Periphery: The outside or superficial portions of a body; the surface.
Pulmonic: Relating to, or affecting the lungs; pulmonary.
Pyx: To test as to weight and fineness, as the coins deposited in the pyx.
Planching: The laying of floors in a building; also, a floor of boards or planks.
Prometheus: The son of Iapetus (one of the Titans) and Clymene, fabled by the poets to have surpassed all mankind in knowledge, and to have formed men of clay to whom he gave life by means of fire stolen from heaven. Jupiter, being angry at this, sent Mercury to bind Prometheus to Mount Caucasus, where a vulture preyed upon his liver.
Parlor match: A friction match that contains little or no sulphur.
Priest-ridden: Controlled or oppressed by priests; as, a priest-ridden people.
Pestilential: Having the nature or qualities of a pestilence.
Polyzoan: Any species of Polyzoa; one of the Polyzoa.
Phantasmagorial: Of, relating to, or resembling phantasmagoria; phantasmagoric.
Platten: To flatten and make into sheets or plates; as, to platten cylinder glass.
Pyloric: Of, pertaining to, or in the region of, the pylorus; as, the pyloric end of the stomach.
Partible: Admitting of being parted; divisible; separable; susceptible of severance or partition; as, an estate of inheritance may be partible.
Passionate: To affect with passion; to impassion.
Polygala: A genus of bitter herbs or shrubs having eight stamens and a two-celled ovary (as the Seneca snakeroot, the flowering wintergreen, etc.); milkwort.
Porphyritic: Relating to, or resembling, porphyry, that is, characterized by the presence of distinct crystals, as of feldspar, quartz, or augite, in a relatively fine-grained base, often aphanitic or cryptocrystalline.
pachometer: An instrument for measuring thickness, as of the glass of a mirror, or of paper; a pachymeter.
Pragmatize: To consider, represent, or embody (something unreal) as fact; to materialize.
Philosophate: To play the philosopher; to moralize.
Photo-engrave: To engrave by a photomechanical process; to make a photo-engraving of.
Pentacid: Capable of neutralizing, or combining with, five molecules of a monobasic acid; having five hydrogen atoms capable of substitution by acid residues; -- said of certain complex bases.
Polenta: Pudding made of Indian meal; also, porridge made of chestnut meal.
Prelatize: To uphold or encourage prelacy; to exercise prelatical functions.
Psychiatria: The application of the healing art to mental diseases.
Polewards: Toward a pole of the earth.
Progressist: One who makes, or holds to, progress; a progressionist.
Photic region: The uppermost zone of the sea, which receives the most light.
Polythelism: The condition of having more than two teats, or nipples.
Peignoir: A woman's loose dressing sack; hence, a loose morning gown or wrapper.
Pistacia: The name of a genus of trees, including the tree which bears the pistachio (Pistacia vera), the Mediterranean mastic tree (Pistacia Lentiscus), and the species (Pistacia Terebinthus) which yields Chian or Cyprus turpentine.
Patellar: Of or pertaining to the patella, or kneecap.
Purist: One who aims at excessive purity or nicety, esp. in the choice of language.
Purism: Rigid purity; the quality of being affectedly pure or nice, especially in the choice of language; over-solicitude as to purity.
Phototrichromatic: Designating a photomechanical process for making reproductions in natural colors by three printings.
Pegmatitic: Of, pertaining to, or resembling, pegmatite; as, the pegmatic structure of certain rocks resembling graphic granite.
Photology: The doctrine or science of light, explaining its nature and phenomena; optics.
Pedality: The act of measuring by paces.
Philopena: A present or gift which is made as a forfeit in a social game that is played in various ways; also, the game itself.
Polyiodide: A iodide having more than one atom of iodine in the molecule.
Pyrophorus: Any one of several substances or mixtures which phosphoresce or ignite spontaneously on exposure to air, as a heated mixture of alum, potash, and charcoal, or a mixture of charcoal and finely divided lead.
Penny-a-liner: One who furnishes matter to public journals at so much a line; a poor writer for hire; a hack writer.
Prejudge: To judge before hearing, or before full and sufficient examination; to decide or sentence by anticipation; to condemn beforehand.
Pucka: Good of its kind; -- variously used as implying substantial, real, fixed, sure, etc., and specif., of buildings, made of brick and mortar.
Pedometer: An instrument for including the number of steps in walking, and so ascertaining the distance passed over.  It is usually in the form of a watch; an oscillating weight by the motion of the body causes the index to advance a certain distance at each step.
Pyromorphous: Having the property of crystallizing by the agency of fire.
Porites: An important genus of reef-building corals having small twelve-rayed calicles, and a very porous coral. Some species are branched, others grow in large massive or globular forms.
Photo-electrotype: An electrotype plate formed in a mold made by photographing on prepared gelatine, etc.
Pythagoreanism: The doctrines of Pythagoras or the Pythagoreans.
Peptonize: To convert into peptone; to digest or dissolve by means of a proteolytic ferment; as, peptonized food.
Pipelayer: One who lays conducting pipes in the ground, as for water, gas, etc.
Pre\u00ebmptioner: One who holds a prior right to purchase certain public land.
Perineurial: Surrounding nerves or nerve fibers; of or pertaining to the perineurium.
Palmarium: One of the bifurcations of the brachial plates of a crinoid.
Puseyism: The principles of Dr. Pusey and others at Oxford, England, as exhibited in various publications, esp. in a series which appeared from 1833 to 1841, designated “ Tracts for the Times;” tractarianism. See Tractarianism.
Plaguy: Vexatious; troublesome; tormenting; as, a plaguy horse. [Colloq.] Also used adverbially; as, “He is so plaguy proud.”
Press work: The work of a press agent.
Pocket: To put, or conceal, in the pocket; as, to pocket the change.
Plague: To infest or afflict with disease, calamity, or natural evil of any kind.
Periapt: A charm worn as a protection against disease or mischief; an amulet.
Pea-jacket: A thick loose double-breasted woolen jacket, or coat, commonly worn by sailors in cold weather.
Plasmon: A flourlike food preparation made from skim milk, and consisting essentially of the unaltered proteid of milk. It is also used in making biscuits and crackers, for mixing with cocoa, etc. A mixture of this with butter, water, and salt is called Plasmon butter, and resembles clotted cream in appearance.
Parnellite: One of the adherents of Charles Stewart Parnell (1846-91) in his advocacy of home rule for Ireland.
Paillasse: An under bed or mattress of straw.
Phylogenetic: Relating to phylogenesis, or the race history of a type of organism.
Photogrammetry: A method of surveying or map making by photography, used also in determining the height and motions of clouds, sea waves, and the like.
Pyroxenic: Containing pyroxene; composed chiefly of pyroxene.
Pad elephant: An elephant that is furnished with a pad for carrying burdens instead of with a howdah for carrying passengers.
Plumbagin: A crystalline substance said to be found in the root of a certain plant of the Leadwort (Plumbago) family.
Partite: Divided nearly to the base; as, a partite leaf is a simple separated down nearly to the base.
Partita: A suite; a set of variations.
Pirate: To publish, as books or writings, without the permission of the author.
Photochronography: Art of recording or measuring intervals of time by the photochronograph.
Pan-Anglican: Belonging to, or representing, the whole Church of England; used less strictly, to include the Protestant Episcopal Church of the United States; as, the Pan-Anglican Conference at Lambeth, in 1888.
Perisystole: The interval between the diastole and systole of the heart. It is perceptible only in the dying.
Pontooning: The act, art, or process of constructing pontoon bridges.
Polytechnic: Comprehending, or relating to, many arts and sciences; -- applied particularly to schools in which many branches of art and science are taught with especial reference to their practical application; as, a polytechnic institute; also to exhibitions of machinery and industrial products.
Poser: One who, or that which, puzzles; a difficult or inexplicable question or fact.
Polt-foot: Having a distorted foot, or a clubfoot or clubfeet.
Photochronograph: An instrument for recording minute intervals of time. The record is made by the power of a magnetic field, due to an electric signaling current, to turn the plane of polarization of light. A flash, coinciding in time and duration with the signal, is thus produced and is photographed on a moving plate.
Pluralize: To take a plural; to assume a plural form; as, a noun pluralizes.
Phrenosin: A nitrogenous body, related to cerebrin, supposed to exist in the brain.
Papoose: A babe or young child of Indian parentage in North America.
Pinnothere: A crab of the genus pinnotheres. See Oyster crab, under Oyster.
Petitionee: A person cited to answer, or defend against, a petition.
Parelcon: The addition of a syllable or particle to the end of a pronoun, verb, or adverb.
Palmatifid: Palmate, with the divisions separated but little more than halfway to the common center.
Protectorate: Government by a protector; -- applied especially to the government of England by Oliver Cromwell.
Pentoxide: An oxide containing five atoms of oxygen in each molecule; as, phosphorus pentoxide, P2O5.
Patricidal: Of or pertaining to patricide; parricidal.
Prorate: To divide or distribute proportionally; to assess pro rata.
Peplis: A genus of plants including water purslane.
Paramatta: A light fabric of cotton and worsted, resembling bombazine or merino.
Puppy: To bring forth whelps; to pup.
Petrifaction: The process of petrifying, or changing into stone; conversion of any organic matter (animal or vegetable) into stone, or a substance of stony hardness.
Phenanthrene: A complex hydrocarbon, C14H10, found in coal tar, and obtained as a white crystalline substance with a bluish fluorescence.
Pos\u00e9: Standing still, with all the feet on the ground; -- said of the attitude of a lion, horse, or other beast.
Producent: One who produces, or offers to notice.
Perlitic: Relating to or resembling perlite, or pearlstone; as, the perlitic structure of certain rocks. See Pearlite.
Pinfold: A place in which stray cattle or domestic animals are confined; a pound; a penfold.
Papillote: A small piece of paper on which women roll up their hair to make it curl; a curl paper.
pain: Punishment suffered or denounced; suffering or evil inflicted as a punishment for crime, or connected with the commission of a crime; penalty.
Parchmentize: To convert to a parchmentlike substance, especially by sulphuric acid.
Proportionment: The act or process of dividing out proportionally.
Pentagynia: A Linnæan order of plants, having five styles or pistils.
Pavement: To furnish with a pavement; to pave.
Pelure: A crisp, hard, thin paper, sometimes used for postage stamps.
Peltiers cross: A cross formed of two strips of different metals, to illustrate the Peltier effect.
patchboard: A circuit board where circuits are completed and modified by making connections with patchcords.
Perineal: Of or pertaining to the perineum.
Pressboard: A kind of highly sized rag paper or board, sometimes containing a small admixture of wood pulp; -- so called because used originally, as now, in presses for pressing and finishing knit underwear.
Phanar: A quarter of Constantinople which, after the Turkish conquest of the city, became the chief Greek quarter; hence, the Greek officials of Turkey, or phanariots, as a class.
Poculiform: Having the shape of a goblet or drinking cup.
parkinsonism: A degenerative nervous disorder occurring mostly in persons older than 60 years, characterized in advanced stages by rhythmic muscular tremors, especially in the hands, and by rigidity of movement, a drooping posture, slow speech, and a masklike facial expression; the term designates a set of symptoms, and the underlying disease causing these symptoms is most commonly Parkinson's disease.  Parkinsonism results from a deficiency in the neurotransmitter dopamine caused by degeneration of the cells producing that agent.  It can be mitigated by chemotherapy with agents such as levodopa (3-hydroxy-L-tyrosine).
Powderhorn: A horn in which gunpowder is carried.
Perplexity: The quality or state of being perplexed or puzzled; complication; intricacy; entanglement; distraction of mind through doubt or difficulty; embarrassment; bewilderment; doubt.
Paraphernal: Of or pertaining to paraphernalia; as, paraphernal property.
Pisciform: Having the form of a fish; resembling a fish.
Participialize: To form into, or put in the form of, a participle.
Perjured: Guilty of perjury; having sworn falsely; forsworn.
Prenominate: To forename; to name beforehand; to tell by name beforehand.
Phillipsite: A hydrous silicate of aluminia, lime, and soda, a zeolitic mineral commonly occurring in complex twin crystals, often cruciform in shape; -- called also christianite.
Parsonic: Of or pertaining to a parson; clerical.
Province: A country or region, more or less remote from the city of Rome, brought under the Roman government; a conquered country beyond the limits of Italy.
Phonetician: One versed in phonetics; a phonetist.
Panzoism: A term used to denote all of the elements or factors which constitute vitality or vital energy.
Piercel: A kind of gimlet for making vents in casks; -- called also piercer.
Parapeptone: A proteinaceous body formed in small quantity by the peptic digestion of proteids.  It can be converted into peptone by pancreatic juice, but not by gastric juice.
Parapodium: One of the lateral appendages of an annelid; -- called also foot tubercle.
Piercer: One who, or that which, pierces or perforates
pegged: Tapering toward teh bottom; as, pegged pants.
Penstemon: A large genus of subshrubs or herbs having showy blue or purple or red or yellow or white flowers; found mostly in Western North America.
Pennywort: A European trailing herb (Linaria Cymbalaria) with roundish, reniform leaves. It is often cultivated in hanging baskets.
Performable: Admitting of being performed, done, or executed; practicable.
Pygal: Situated in the region of the rump, or posterior end of the backbone; -- applied especially to the posterior median plates in the carapace of chelonians.
Prosylogism: A syllogism preliminary or logically essential to another syllogism; the conclusion of such a syllogism, which becomes a premise of the following syllogism.
Polyacron: A solid having many summits or angular points; a polyhedron.
Penchant: A game like bézique, or, in the game, any queen and jack of different suits held together.
Provide: To procure supplies or means in advance; to take measures beforehand in view of an expected or a possible future need, especially a danger or an evil; -- followed by against or for; as, to provide against the inclemency of the weather; to provide for the education of a child.
Perpetually: In a perpetual manner; constantly; continually.
Pyroxene: A common mineral occurring in monoclinic crystals, with a prismatic angle of nearly 90°, and also in massive forms which are often laminated. It varies in color from white to dark green and black, and includes many varieties differing in color and composition, as diopside, malacolite, salite, coccolite, augite, etc. They are all silicates of lime and magnesia with sometimes alumina and iron.
