Pyroxene is an essential constituent of many rocks, especially basic igneous rocks, as basalt, gabbro, etc.
Pachak: The fragrant roots of the Saussurea Costus, exported from India to China, and used for burning as incense.  It is supposed to be the costus of the ancients.
Pavilion: To furnish or cover with, or shelter in, a tent or tents.
Panacean: Having the properties of a panacea.
Perfumer: One who, oe that which, perfumes.
Pulpitry: The teaching of the pulpit; preaching.
parent: One who begets, or brings forth, offspring; a father or a mother.
Prostitutor: One who prostitutes; one who submits himself, of or offers another, to vile purposes.
Pneumology: The science which treats of the lungs.
Parroter: One who simply repeats what he has heard.
Plagiocephalic: Having an oblique lateral deformity of the skull.
Podura: Any small leaping thysanurous insect of the genus Podura and related genera; a springtail.
Potlatch: Among the Kwakiutl, Chimmesyan, and other Indians of the northwestern coast of North America, a ceremonial distribution by a man of gifts to his own and neighboring tribesmen, often, formerly, to his own impoverishment. Feasting, dancing, and public ceremonies accompany it.
Presumptuous: Full of presumption; presuming; overconfident or venturesome; audacious; rash; taking liberties unduly; arrogant; insolent; as, a presumptuous commander; presumptuous conduct.
Ptyalin: An unorganized amylolytic ferment, on enzyme, present in human mixed saliva and in the saliva of some animals.
Parter: One who, or which, parts or separates.
Pangenesis: An hypothesis advanced by Darwin in explanation of heredity.
Prenotion: A notice or notion which precedes something else in time; previous notion or thought; foreknowledge.
Pererration: A wandering, or rambling, through various places.
Protrusion: The act of protruding or thrusting forward, or beyond the usual limit.
Peart: Active; lively; brisk; smart; -- often applied to convalescents; as, she is quite peart to-day.
Pledgee: The one to whom a pledge is given, or to whom property pledged is delivered.
Paddle: An implement with a broad blade, which is used without a fixed fulcrum in propelling and steering canoes and boats.
parapsychologist: One who studies or is versed in parapsychology.
Piperidine: An oily liquid alkaloid, C5H11N, having a hot, peppery, ammoniacal odor. It is related to pyridine, and is obtained by the decomposition of piperine.
Ph\u00e6nogam: Any plant of the class Phænogamia.
Post-fine: A duty paid to the king by the cognizee in a fine of lands, when the same was fully passed; -- called also the king's silver.
Pharynx: The part of the alimentary canal between the cavity of the mouth and the esophagus. It has one or two external openings through the nose in the higher vertebrates, and lateral branchial openings in fishes and some amphibias.
Petunse: Powdered fledspar, kaolin, or quartz, used in the manufacture of porcelain.
Prolegomenary: Of the nature of a prolegomenon; preliminary; introductory; prefatory.
Plagiocephaly: Oblique lateral deformity of the skull.
Palmetto flag: Any of several flags adopted by South Carolina after its secession.  That adopted in November, 1860, had a green cabbage palmetto in the center of a white field; the final one, January, 1861, had a white palmetto in the center of a blue field and a white crescent in the upper left-hand corner.
Polyzoa: Same as Bryozoa. See Illust. under Bryozoa, and Phylactolæmata.
Pinite: Any fossil wood which exhibits traces of having belonged to the Pine family.
Prima facie: At first view; on the first appearance.
Prioress: A lady superior of a priory of nuns, and next in dignity to an abbess.
Pyritic: Of or pertaining to pyrites; consisting of, or resembling, pyrites.
Palmitolic: Pertaining to, or designating, an artificial acid of the oleic acid series, isomeric with linoleic acid.
PROLOG: A declarative higher-level programming language in which instructions are written not as explicit procedural data-manipulation commands, but as logical statements.  The language has built-in resolution procedures for logical inference.
Preferment: The act of choosing, or the state of being chosen; preference.
Puffing: a. & n. from Puff, v. i. & t.
Paraxylene: A hydrocarbon (C6H4(CH3)2) of the aromatic series obtained as a colorless liquid by the distillation of camphor with zinc chloride.  It is one of the three metamers of xylene.  Cf. Metamer, and Xylene.
Plant: To perform the act of planting.
Poor-john: A small European fish, similar to the cod, but of inferior quality.
Pangolin: Any one of several species of Manis, Pholidotus, and related genera, found in Africa and Asia. They are covered with imbricated scales, and feed upon ants. Called also scaly ant-eater.
Plane: Of a boat, to lift more or less out of the water while in motion, after the manner of a hydroplane; to hydroplane.
Poor-will: A bird of the Western United States (Phalænoptilus Nutalli) allied to the whip-poor-will.
Plank: To cover or lay with planks; as, to plank a floor or a ship.
Phrygian cap: A close-fitting cap represented in Greek art as worn by Orientals, assumed to have been conical in shape. It has been adopted in modern art as the so-called liberty cap, or cap of liberty.
Pituitous: Consisting of, or resembling, pituite or mucus; full of mucus; discharging mucus.
Pensionary: One who receives a pension; a pensioner.
Patavinity: The use of local or provincial words, as in the peculiar style or diction of Livy, the Roman historian; -- so called from Patavium, now Padua, the place of Livy's nativity.
Pentamera: An extensive division of Coleoptera, including those that normally have five-jointed tarsi. It embraces about half of all the known species of the Coleoptera.
Patio: A paved yard or floor where ores are cleaned and sorted, or where ore, salt, mercury, etc., are trampled by horses, to effect intermixture and amalgamation.
Portgreve: In old English law, the chief magistrate of a port or maritime town.; a portreeve.
Post note: A note issued by a bank, payable at some future specified time, as distinguished from a note payable on demand.
Privateersman: An officer or seaman of a privateer.
Placability: The quality or state of being placable or appeasable; placable disposition.
Phalangite: A soldier belonging to a phalanx.
Pendicler: An inferior tenant; one who rents a pendicle or croft.
Pillion: A panel or cushion saddle; the under pad or cushion of saddle; esp., a pad or cushion put on behind a man's saddle, on which a woman may ride.
Pyrotechnics: The art of making fireworks; the manufacture and use of fireworks; pyrotechny.
parody: To write a parody upon; to burlesque.
Picric: Pertaining to, or designating, a strong organic acid (called picric acid), intensely bitter.
Plastin: A substance associated with nuclein in cell nuclei, and by some considered as the fundamental substance of the nucleus.
Plastid: A formative particle of albuminous matter; a monad; a cytode. See the Note under Morphon.
Phonetics: The doctrine or science of sounds; especially those of the human voice; phonology.
Paralbumin: A proteidlike body found in the fluid from ovarian cysts and elsewhere.  It is generally associated with a substance related to, if not identical with, glycogen.
Plastic: Having the power to give form or fashion to a mass of matter; as, the plastic hand of the Creator.
Polycarpic: Bearing fruit repeatedly, or year after year.
Prosper: To be successful; to succeed; to be fortunate or prosperous; to thrive; to make gain.
pathematic: Of, pertaining to, or designating, emotion or suffering.
Predesign: To design or purpose beforehand; to predetermine.
Perinephritis: Inflammation of the cellular tissue around the kidney.
Preciosity: Fastidious refinement, esp. in language; specif., the affected purism and sententiousness characteristic of the French précieuses of the 17th century.
Pacinian: Of, pertaining to, or discovered by, Filippo Pacini (1812-1883), an Italian physician of the 19th century.
Protean: Of or pertaining to Proteus; characteristic of Proteus.
Platting: Plaited strips or bark, cane, straw, etc., used for making hats or the like.
Personally: In a personal manner; by bodily presence; in person; not by representative or substitute; as, to deliver a letter personally.
Palpicorn: One of a group of aquatic beetles (Palpicornia) having short club-shaped antennæ, and long maxillary palpi.
Piedmontite: A manganesian kind of epidote, from Piedmont. See Epidote.
Polybranchia: A division of Nudibranchiata including those which have numerous branchiæ on the back.
Psychozoic: Designating, or applied to the Era of man; as, the psychozoic era.
Predatory: Characterized by plundering; practicing rapine; plundering; pillaging; as, a predatory excursion; a predatory party.
Pterodactyl: An extinct flying reptile; one of the Pterosauria. See Illustration in Appendix.
Piezometer: An instrument for measuring the compressibility of liquids.
Picayunish: Petty; paltry; mean; as, a picayunish business.
Pajamas: Originally, in India, loose drawers or trousers, such as those worn, tied about the waist, by Mohammedan men and women; by extension, a similar garment adopted among Europeans, Americans, etc., for wear in the dressing room and during sleep; also, a suit consisting of drawers and a loose upper garment for such wear.
Poor-spirited: Of a mean spirit; cowardly; base.
Photoprint: Any print made by a photomechanical process.
Protestantism: The quality or state of being protestant, especially against the Roman Catholic Church; the principles or religion of the Protestants.
Particularize: To mention or attend to particulars; to give minute details; to be circumstantial; as, to particularize in a narrative.
Parasital: Of or pertaining to parasites; parasitic.
Periostracum: A chitinous membrane covering the exterior of many shells; -- called also epidermis.
plate tectonics: A geological theory which holds that the crust of the earth (the lithosphere) is divided into a small number of large separate plates which float and move slowly around on the more plastic asthenosphere, breaking apart and moving away from each other at points where magma upwells from below, and, driven by such upwellings and other currents on the athenosphere, sliding past each other, colliding with each other, and in some cases being submerged (subducted) one below the other.  This theory is now widely accepted, and explains many geological phenomena such as the clustered locations of earthquakes, mountain building, volcanism, and the similarities observed between the geology of continents, such as South America and Africa which are now far apart, but, according to the theory, were once joined together.  The motions of such tectonic plates are very slow, typically only several centimeters per year, but over tens and hundreds of millions of years, cause very large changes in the relative positions of the continents.  The consequence of such movement of plates is called continental drift.
Postulate: To beg, or assume without proof; as, to postulate conclusions.
Plantership: The occupation or position of a planter, or the management of a plantation, as in the United States or the West Indies.
Preferable: Worthy to be preferred or chosen before something else; more desirable; as, a preferable scheme.
Potsherd: A piece or fragment of a broken pot.
Pan-American: Of or pertaining to both North and South America.
Pinesap: A reddish fleshy herb of the genus Monotropa (Monotropa hypopitys), formerly thought to be parasitic on the roots of pine trees, but more probably saprophytic.
parapsychological: Of or pertaining to parapsychology; pertaining to forces or mental processes outside the possibilities defined by natural or scientific laws; as, parapsychological research.
Phthalimide: An imido derivative of phthalic acid, obtained as a white crystalline substance, C6H4.(CO)2NH, which has itself (like succinimide) acid properties, and forms a series of salts.  Cf. Imido acid, under Imido.
Planispheric: Of or pertaining to a planisphere.
Profection: A setting out; a going forward; advance; progression.
Protectoral: Of or pertaining to a protector; protectorial; as, protectoral power.
Phanariot: One of the Greeks of Constantinople who after the Turkish conquest became powerful in clerical and other offices under Turkish patronage.
Placitum: A public court or assembly in the Middle Ages, over which the sovereign president when a consultation was held upon affairs of state.
Prover: One who, or that which, proves.
Paper: A substance in the form of thin sheets or leaves intended to be written or printed on, or to be used in wrapping.  It is made of rags, straw, bark, wood, or other fibrous material, which is first reduced to pulp, then molded, pressed, and dried.
Presidentship: The office and dignity of president; presidency.
Pannage: The food of swine in the woods, as beechnuts, acorns, etc.; -- called also pawns.
Preadvertise: To advertise beforehand; to preannounce publicly.
Personage: Form, appearance, or belongings of a person; the external appearance, stature, figure, air, and the like, of a person.
Pleurosigma: A genus of diatoms of elongated elliptical shape, but having the sides slightly curved in the form of a letter S.  Pleurosigma angulatum has very fine striations, and is a favorite object for testing the high powers of microscopes.
Palpability: The quality of being palpable, or perceptible by the touch.
Postscripted: Having a postscript; added in a postscript.
Pentathlon: A fivefold athletic performance peculiar to the great national games of the Greeks, including leaping, foot racing, wrestling, throwing the discus, and throwing the spear.
Polyspermy: Fullness of sperm, or seed; the passage of more than one spermatozoön into the vitellus in the impregnation of the ovum.
Paronomasia: A play upon words; a figure by which the same word is used in different senses, or words similar in sound are set in opposition to each other, so as to give antithetical force to the sentence; punning.
Predicrotic: A term applied to the pulse wave sometimes seen in a pulse curve or sphygmogram, between the apex of the curve and the dicrotic wave.
Perrier: A short mortar used formerly for throwing stone shot.
Presentimental: Of nature of a presentiment; foreboding.
Perfidious: Guilty of perfidy; violating good faith or vows; false to trust or confidence reposed; teacherous; faithless; as, a perfidious friend.
Pedantism: The office, disposition, or act of a pedant; pedantry.
Primage: A charge in addition to the freight; originally, a gratuity to the captain for his particular care of the goods (sometimes called hat money), but now belonging to the owners or freighters of the vessel, unless by special agreement the whole or part is assigned to the captain.
Pro\u00f6tic: In front of the auditory capsule; -- applied especially to a bone, or center of ossification, in the periotic capsule.
Pettifogger: A lawyer who deals in petty cases; an attorney whose methods are mean and tricky; an inferior lawyer.
Pleurapophysis: One of the ventral processes of a vertebra, or the dorsal element in each half of a hemal arch, forming, or corresponding to, a vertebral rib.
Perfecter: One who, or that which, makes perfect.
Princess: A female prince; a woman having sovereign power, or the rank of a prince.
Peba: An armadillo (Tatusia novemcincta) which is found from Texas to Paraguay; -- called also tatouhou.
Parmelia: The type genus of the Parmeliaceae; a large genus of chiefly alpine foliaceous lichens.
Pollan: A lake whitefish (Coregonus pollan), native of Ireland. In appearance it resembles a herring.
Paresis: Incomplete paralysis, affecting motion but not sensation.
Pepsinogen: A proenzyme, the antecedent of the enzyme pepsin.  A substance contained in the form of granules in the peptic cells of the gastric glands.  It is readily convertible into pepsin. Also called propepsin.
Proprietor: One who has the legal right or exclusive title to anything, whether in possession or not; an owner; as, the proprietor of farm or of a mill.
Patela: A large flat-bottomed trading boat peculiar to the river Ganges; -- called also puteli.
Percussive: Striking against; percutient; as, percussive force.
Phenakistoscope: A revolving disk on which figures drawn in different relative attitudes are seen successively, so as to produce the appearance of an object in actual motion, as an animal leaping, etc., in consequence of the persistence of the successive visual impressions of the retina. It is often arranged so that the figures may be projected upon a screen.
Pomp: To make a pompons display; to conduct.
Platyptera: A division of Pseudoneuroptera including the species which have four broad, flat wings, as the termites, or white-ants, and the stone flies (Perla).
Portland stone: A yellowish-white calcareous freestone from the Isle of Portland in England, much used in building.
Paraph: To add a paraph to; to sign, esp. with the initials.
Postentry: A second or subsequent, at the customhouse, of goods which had been omitted by mistake.
Pome: To grow to a head, or form a head in growing.
Poultice: To apply a poultice to; to dress with a poultice.
Parella: A name for two kinds of dock (Rumex Patientia and Rumex Hydrolapathum).
Palmerworm: Any hairy caterpillar which appears in great numbers, devouring herbage, and wandering about like a palmer.  The name is applied also to other voracious insects.
Prognathous: Having the jaws projecting beyond the upper part of the face; -- opposed to orthognathous. See Gnathic index, under Gnathic.
Picul: A commercial weight varying in different countries and for different commodities. In Borneo it is 1355/8 lbs.; in China and Sumatra, 1331/2 lbs.; in Japan, 1331/3 lbs.; but sometimes 130 lbs., etc. Called also, by the Chinese, tan.
Prefrontal: Situated in front of the frontal bone, or the frontal region of the skull; ectethmoid, as a certain bone in the nasal capsule of many animals, and certain scales of reptiles and fishes.
Panicled: Furnished with panicles; arranged in, or like, panicles; paniculate.
Pratincole: Any bird of the Old World genus Glareola, or family Glareolidæ, allied to the plovers. They have long, pointed wings and a forked tail.
Pronunciamento: A proclamation or manifesto; a formal announcement or declaration.
Picus: A genus of woodpeckers, including some of the common American and European species.
Pantry: An apartment or closet in which bread and other provisions are kept.
Poorbox: A receptacle in which money given for the poor is placed.
Pompom girl: a female cheerleader, especially one who waves a pompon{5} while performing a cheering routine.
Permiss: A permitted choice; a rhetorical figure in which a thing is committed to the decision of one's opponent.
Portulacaceous: Of or pertaining to a natural order of plants (Portulacaceæ), of which Portulaca is the type, and which includes also the spring beauty (Claytonia) and other genera.
Pluripresence: Presence in more places than one.
Plathelminthes: Same as Platyelminthes; -- an older term.
Pieceless: Not made of pieces; whole; entire.
paginate: To number the pages of (a book or manuscript).
Ptolemaist: One who accepts the astronomical system of Ptolemy.
Picrite: A dark green igneous rock, consisting largely of chrysolite, with hornblende, augite, biotite, etc.
Plateau: A flat surface; especially, a broad, level, elevated area of land; a table-land.
Papescent: Containing or producing pap; like pap.
Phlogisticate: To combine phlogiston with; -- usually in the form and sense of the p. p. or the adj.; as, highly phlogisticated substances.
Porifera: A grand division of the Invertebrata, including the sponges; -- called also Spongiæ, Spongida, and Spongiozoa. The principal divisions are Calcispongiæ, Keratosa or Fibrospongiæ, and Silicea.
Pentecostals: Offerings formerly made to the parish priest, or to the mother church, at Pentecost.
Publican: A farmer of the taxes and public revenues; hence, a collector of toll or tribute. The inferior officers of this class were often oppressive in their exactions, and were regarded with great detestation.
Partially: In part; not totally; as, partially true; the sun partially eclipsed.
Physician: A person skilled in physic, or the art of healing; one duty authorized to prescribe remedies for, and treat, diseases; a doctor of medicine.
Plant-eating: Eating, or subsisting on, plants; as, a plant-eating beetle.
Pistillation: The act of pounding or breaking in a mortar; pestillation.
Patt\u00e9: Narrow at the inner, and very broad at the other, end, or having its arms of that shape; -- said of a cross. See Illust. (8) of Cross.
Precessional: Of or pertaining to pression; as, the precessional movement of the equinoxes.
Ploce: A figure in which a word is separated or repeated by way of emphasis, so as not only to signify the individual thing denoted by it, but also its peculiar attribute or quality; as, “His wife's a wife indeed.”
Plasmodial: Of or pertaining to, or like, a plasmodium; as, the plasmodial form of a life cycle.
Podetium: A stalk which bears the fructification in some lichens, as in the so-called reindeer moss.
Pyrometric: Pertaining to, or obtained by, the pyrometer; as, pyrometrical instruments; pyrometrical measurements.
Phycomater: A gelatin in which the algæ spores have been supposed to vegetate.
Prefer: To carry or bring (something) forward, or before one; hence, to bring for consideration, acceptance, judgment, etc.; to offer; to present; to proffer; to address; -- said especially of a request, prayer, petition, claim, charge, etc.
Predeclare: To declare or announce beforehand; to preannounce.
Pericardium: The double baglike fold of serous membrane which incloses the heart.
Pauper: A very poor person; one without any means of support, especially one dependent on private or public charity.  Also used adjectively; as, pauper immigrants, pauper labor.
perambulating: Strolling or walking around; as, in the field we met some perambulating veterans.
Photographone: A device, consisting essentially of an electric arc and a camera, by which a series of photographs of the variations of the arc due to sound waves are obtained for reproduction by means of a selenium cell and a telephone.
Primordian: A name given to several kinds of plums; as, red primordian, amber primordian, etc.
Pharisaic: Of or pertaining to the Pharisees; resembling the Pharisees.
Peritoneal: Of or pertaining to the peritoneum.
Paucity: Fewness; smallness of number; scarcity; rarity.
Plunder: The act of plundering or pillaging; robbery. See Syn. of Pillage.
Plesiosauria: An extinct order of Mesozoic marine reptiles including the genera Plesiosaurus, and allied forms; -- called also Sauropterygia.
Pecker: One who, or that which, pecks; specif., a bird that pecks holes in trees; a woodpecker.
Photologic: Pertaining to photology, or the doctrine of light.
Philogynist: A lover or friend of women; one who esteems woman as the higher type of humanity; -- opposed to misogynist.
part-timer: Somone who works part-time; a part-time employee.  Contrasted with full-timer.
Poacher: One who poaches; one who kills or catches game or fish contrary to law.
Petalody: The metamorphosis of various floral organs, usually stamens, into petals.
Polyadelphia: A Linnæan class of plants having stamens united in three or more bodies or bundles by the filaments.
Pizzle: The penis; -- so called in some animals, as the bull.
Portland cement: A cement having the color of the Portland stone of England, made by calcining an artificial mixture of carbonate of lime and clay, or sometimes certain natural limestones or chalky clays. It contains a large proportion of clay, and hardens under water.
Procrustean: Of or pertaining to Procrustes, or the mode of torture practiced by him; producing conformity by violent means; as, the Procrustean treatment; a Procrustean limit. See Procrustes.
Paragrapher: A writer of paragraphs; a paragraphist.
Pinacone: A white crystalline substance related to the glycols, and made from acetone; hence, by extension, any one of a series of substances of which pinacone proper is the type.
Polyhedral: Having many sides, as a solid body.
Pliability: The quality or state of being pliable; flexibility; as, pliability of disposition.
Peculation: The act or practice of peculating, or of defrauding the public by appropriating to one's own use the money or goods intrusted to one's care for management or disbursement; embezzlement.
Pinefinch: A small American bird (Spinus spinus syn. Chrysomitris spinus); -- called also pine siskin, and American siskin.
Pentatomic: Having five atoms in the molecule.
Persifleur: One who indulges in persiflage; a banterer; a quiz.
Physico-theology: Theology or divinity illustrated or enforced by physics or natural philosophy.
Phyllocyanin: A blue coloring matter extracted from chlorophyll.
Paries: The triangular middle part of each segment of the shell of a barnacle.
Pisiform: A small bone on the ulnar side of the carpus in man and many mammals. See Illust. of Artiodactyla.
Peerage: The rank or dignity of a peer.
Pedage: A toll or tax paid by passengers, entitling them to safe-conduct and protection.
Pellagrin: One who is afficted with pellagra.
Prurient: Uneasy with desire; itching; especially, having a lascivious curiosity or propensity; lustful.
Prolapse: To fall down or out; to protrude.
Propodial: Of or pertaining to the propodialia, or the parts of the limbs to which they belong.
Pass-parole: An order passed from front to rear by word of mouth.
Penitentiaryship: The office or condition of a penitentiary of the papal court.
Protozo\u00f6nite: One of the primary, or first-formed, segments of an embryonic arthropod.
Pedicellaria: A peculiar forcepslike organ which occurs in large numbers upon starfishes and echini. Those of starfishes have two movable jaws, or blades, and are usually nearly, or quite, sessile; those of echini usually have three jaws and a pedicel. See Illustration in Appendix.
Polander: A native or inhabitant of Poland; a Pole.
Psychal: Of or pertaining to the soul; psychical.
Potency: The quality or state of being potent; physical or moral power; inherent strength; energy; ability to effect a purpose; capability; efficacy; influence.
Pullet: A young hen, or female of the domestic fowl.
Ptilopteri: An order of birds including only the penguins.
Plenarty: The state of a benefice when occupied.
Peddlery: The trade, or the goods, of a peddler; hawking; small retail business, like that of a peddler.
Pinnatifid: Divided in a pinnate manner, with the divisions not reaching to the midrib.
Pipage: Transportation, as of petroleum oil, by means of a pipe conduit; also, the charge for such transportation.
P: the sixteenth letter of the English alphabet, is a nonvocal consonant whose form and value come from the Latin, into which language the letter was brought, through the ancient Greek, from the Phœnician, its probable origin being Egyptian.  Etymologically P is most closely related to b, f, and v; as hobble, hopple; father, paternal; recipient, receive. See B, F, and M.
Percipience: The faculty, act or power of perceiving; perception.
Pounced: Furnished with claws or talons; as, the pounced young of the eagle.
Phantom circuit: The equivalent of an additional circuit or wire, in reality not existing, obtained by certain arrangements of real circuits, as in some multiplex telegraph systems.
Pointless: Having no point; blunt; wanting keenness; obtuse; as, a pointless sword; a pointless remark.
Protectionism: The doctrine or policy of protectionists. See Protection, 4.
Pugnacity: Inclination or readiness to fight; quarrelsomeness.
Perciformes: An extensive tribe or suborder of fishes, including the true perches (Percidæ); the pondfishes (Centrarchidæ); the sciænoids (Sciænidæ); the sparoids (Sparidæ); the serranoids (Serranidæ), and some other related families.
Pantometer: An instrument for measuring angles for determining elevations, distances, etc.
Pimple: Any small acuminated elevation of the cuticle, whether going on to suppuration or not.
Pentacron: A solid having five summits or angular points.
Pleurosteon: The antero-lateral piece which articulates the sternum of birds.
Parablastic: Of or pertaining to the parablast; as, the parablastic cells.
Philosophy: Literally, the love of, inducing the search after, wisdom; in actual usage, the knowledge of phenomena as explained by, and resolved into, causes and reasons, powers and laws.
pct: Percent; a fractional proportion, multiplied by 100.
pesto: A sauce used in Italian cuisine, typically made by blending olive oil, basil, garlic, pine nuts, and grated parmesan cheese; it is served hot or cold over pasta, meat, or fish.  Where pine nuts are expensive, sunflower seeds are sometimes substituted.
Plumassier: One who prepares or deals in ornamental plumes or feathers.
Pulverizer: One who, or that which, pulverizes.
Pyramidion: The small pyramid which crowns or completes an obelisk.
Pygarg: A quadruped, probably the addax, an antelope having a white rump.
Poplin: A fabric of many varieties, usually made of silk and worsted, -- used especially for women's dresses.
Propension: The quality or state of being propense; propensity.
Productile: Capable of being extended or prolonged; extensible; ductile.
Purfile: A sort of ancient trimming of tinsel and thread for women's gowns; -- called also bobbinwork.
Pimpship: The office, occupation, or persom of a pimp.
Pantisocratist: One who favors or supports the theory of a pantisocracy.
Passant: Passing from one to another; in circulation; current.
Plesimorphism: The property possessed by some substances of crystallizing in closely similar forms while unlike in chemical composition.
Polished: Made smooth and glossy, as by friction; hence, highly finished; refined; polite; as, polished plate; polished manners; polished verse.
Phoca: A genus of seals. It includes the common harbor seal and allied species. See Seal.
Pectolite: A whitish mineral occurring in radiated or fibrous crystalline masses.  It is a hydrous silicate of lime and soda.
Photoglyphic: Pertaining to the art of engraving by the action of light.
Purree: A yellow coloring matter. See Euxanthin.
Postboy: One who rides post horses; a position; a courier.
Proteroglypha: A suborder of serpents including those that have permanently erect grooved poison fangs, with ordinary teeth behind them in the jaws. It includes the cobras, the asps, and the sea snakes. Called also Proteroglyphia.
Prohibitory: Tending to prohibit, forbid, or exclude; implying prohibition; forbidding; as, a prohibitory law; a prohibitory price.
Prosaicism: The quality or state of being prosaic; a prosaic manner or style.
Polypidom: A coral, or corallum; also, one of the coral-like structure made by bryozoans and hydroids.
Propyl: The hypothetical radical C3H7, regarded as the essential residue of propane and related compounds.
Phenyl: A hydrocarbon radical (C6H5) regarded as the essential residue of benzene, and the basis of an immense number of aromatic derivatives.
Pomposo: Grand and dignified; in grand style.
Passable: Capable of being passed, traveled, navigated, traversed, penetrated, or the like; as, the roads are not passable; the stream is passablein boats.
Perilymph: The fluid which surrounds the membranous labyrinth of the internal ear, and separates it from the walls of the chambers in which the labyrinth lies.
Pliosaurus: An extinct genus of marine reptiles allied to Plesiosaurus, but having a much shorter neck.
Protect: To cover or shield from danger or injury; to defend; to guard; to preserve in safety; as, a father protects his children.
Paging: The marking or numbering of the pages of a book.
Pagina: The surface of a leaf or of a flattened thallus.
Photosynthesis: The process of constructive metabolism by which carbohydrates are formed from water vapor and the carbon dioxide of the air in the chlorophyll-containing tissues of plants exposed to the action of light. It was formerly called assimilation, but this is now commonly used as in animal physiology. The details of the process are not yet clearly known. Baeyer's theory is that the carbon dioxide is reduced to carbon monoxide, which, uniting with the hydrogen of the water in the cell, produces formaldehyde, the latter forming various sugars through polymerization. Vines suggests that the carbohydrates are secretion products of the chloroplasts, derived from decomposition of previously formed proteids. The food substances are usually quickly translocated, those that accumulate being changed to starch, which appears in the cells almost simultaneously with the sugars. The chloroplasts perform photosynthesis only in light and within a certain range of temperature, varying according to climate. This is the only way in which a plant is able to organize carbohydrates. All plants without a chlorophyll apparatus, as the fungi, must be parasitic or saprophytic.
Petrologist: One who is versed in petrology.
Plumery: Plumes, collectively or in general; plumage.
parodist: One who writes a parody; one who parodies.
Puritan: Of or pertaining to the Puritans; resembling, or characteristic of, the Puritans.
Pyrosome: Any compound ascidian of the genus Pyrosoma. The pyrosomes form large hollow cylinders, sometimes two or three feet long, which swim at the surface of the sea and are very phosphorescent.
Pythagorean: A follower of Pythagoras; one of the school of philosophers founded by Pythagoras.
Parietic: Pertaining to, or designating, an acid found in the lichen Parmelia parietina, and called also chrysophanic acid.
Piligerous: Bearing hair; covered with hair or down; piliferous.
Prakrit: Any one of the popular dialects descended from, or akin to, Sanskrit; -- in distinction from the Sanskrit, which was used as a literary and learned language when no longer spoken by the people. Pali is one of the Prakrit dialects.
Pintsch gas: A kind of oil gas extensively used for lighting railroad cars, which carry it in compressed form.
Peppergrass: Any herb of the cruciferous genus Lepidium, especially the garden peppergrass, or garden cress, Lepidium sativum; -- called also pepperwort. All the species have a pungent flavor.
Phosphoryl: The radical PO, regarded as the typical nucleus of certain compounds.
Pudding fish: A large, handsomely colored, blue and bronze, labroid fish (Iridio radiatus, syn. Platyglossus radiatus) of Florida, Bermuda, and the West Indies. Called also pudiano, doncella, and, at Bermuda, bluefish.
Piperazine: A crystalline substance, (C2H4NH)2, formed by action of ammonia on ethylene bromide, by reduction of pyrazine, etc. It is a strong base, and is used as a remedy for gout.
Persecute: To pursue in a manner to injure, grieve, or afflict; to beset with cruelty or malignity; to harass; especially, to afflict, harass, punish, or put to death, for adherence to a particular religious creed or mode of worship.
Postpone: To defer to a future or later time; to put off; also, to cause to be deferred or put off; to delay; to adjourn; as, to postpone the consideration of a bill to the following day, or indefinitely.
Pretorian: A soldier of the pretorian guard.
Planing: a. & vb. n. fr. Plane, v. t.
Pseudo-galena: False galena, or blende. See Blende (a).
Pentagynian: Of or pertaining to plants of the order Pentagyna; having five styles.
Perfective: Tending or conducing to make perfect, or to bring to perfection; -- usually followed by of.
Precision: The quality or state of being precise; exact limitation; exactness; accuracy; strict conformity to a rule or a standard; definiteness.
Pathogeny: The generation, and method of development, of disease; as, the pathogeny of yellow fever is unsettled.
Phanerocodonic: Having an umbrella-shaped or bell-shaped body, with a wide, open cavity beneath; -- said of certain jellyfishes.
Polygalic: Of, pertaining to, or obtained from, Polygala; specifically, designating an acrid glucoside (called polygalic acid, senegin, etc.), resembling, or possibly identical with, saponin.
Phycoxanthin: A yellowish coloring matter found in certain algæ.
Photism: A luminous image or appearance of a hallucinatory character.
Potargo: A kind of sauce or pickle.
Photonephograph: A nephoscope registering by photography, commonly consisting of a pair of cameras used simultaneously.
Partnership: The state or condition of being a partner; as, to be in partnership with another; to have partnership in the fortunes of a family or a state.
Posture: To assume a particular posture or attitude; to contort the body into artificial attitudes, as an acrobat or contortionist; also, to pose.
Podical: Anal; -- applied to certain organs of insects.
Picene: A hydrocarbon (C&unr_;H&unr_;) extracted from the pitchy residue of coal tar and petroleum as a bluish fluorescent crystalline substance.
Physiocrat: One of the followers of Quesnay of France, who, in the 18th century, founded a system of political economy based upon the supremacy of natural order.
Pigmentation: A deposition, esp. an excessive deposition, of coloring matter; as, pigmentation of the liver.
Perforata: A division of corals including those that have a porous texture, as Porites and Madrepora; -- opposed to Aporosa.
Power: Ability to act, regarded as latent or inherent; the faculty of doing or performing something; capacity for action or performance; capability of producing an effect, whether physical or moral: potency; might; as, a man of great power; the power of capillary attraction; money gives power.
Pecten: A vascular pigmented membrane projecting into the vitreous humor within the globe of the eye in birds, and in many reptiles and fishes; -- also called marsupium.
Proteidea: An order of aquatic amphibians having prominent external gills and four legs. It includes Proteus and Menobranchus (Necturus).  Called also Proteoidea, and Proteida.
Poise: To hang in equilibrium; to be balanced or suspended; hence, to be in suspense or doubt.
Purificatory: Serving or tending to purify; purificative.
Penta-: A combining form denoting five; as, pentacapsular; pentagon.
Photoluminescence: luminescence induced by exposure to light waves in the infrared to ultraviolet range.
peachwood: A tropical tree Caesalpinia echinata, having a prickly trunk; its heavy red wood yields a red dye and is used for cabinetry.
Paleozo\u00f6ogy: The science of extinct animals, a branch of paleontology.
Purview: The body of a statute, or that part which begins with “ Be it enacted, ” as distinguished from the preamble.
Pan-Americanism: The principle or advocacy of a political alliance or union of all the states of America.
Pandour: One of a class of Hungarian mountaineers serving in the Austrian army that served as local militia in Croatia; -- so called from Pandur, a principal town in the region from which they originally came.  They were noted for their ruthlessness.
Pelter: A pinchpenny; a mean, sordid person; a miser; a skinflint.
Pisces: The twelfth sign of the zodiac, marked &pisces_; in almanacs.
Pay dirt: Earth, rock, etc., which yields a profit to the miner.
Pentad: Having the valence of a pentad.
Pantographic: Of or pertaining to a pantograph; relating to pantography.
Patent: To grant by patent; to make the subject of a patent; to secure or protect by patent; as, to patent an invention; to patent public lands.
Pulverable: Capable of being reduced to fine powder; pulverizable.
Patena: A grassy expanse in the hill region of Ceylon.
Pannose: Similar in texture or appearance to felt or woolen cloth.
Poor: A small European codfish (Gadus minutus); -- called also power cod.
Planxty: An Irish or Welsh melody for the harp, sometimes of a mournful character.
Poop: To break over the poop or stern, as a wave.
Pellagra: An affection of the skin, characterized by redness, especially in exposed areas, scaling and shedding of the skin, and accompanied with severe gastrointestinal disturbance and nervous symptoms.  It is due to a deficiency of niacin (vitamin B3; nicotinic acid) and protein in the diet, and may be caused by malnutrition, or, in some cases, by a heavy dependence on maize for food.  It was at one time (ca. 1890) endemic in Northern Italy, and was called Alpine scurvy.  It may also be caused by alcoholism or diease causing an impairment of nutrition.  It is also called St. Ignatius's itch, maidism, mal de la rosa, mal rosso, and psychoneurosis maidica. A variety of pellagra seen in children is called infantile pellagra or kwashiorkor.
Pharyngopneusta: A group of invertebrates including the Tunicata and Enteropneusta.
Pood: A Russian weight, equal to forty Russian pounds or about thirty-six English pounds avoirdupois.
Putlog: One of the short pieces of timber on which the planks forming the floor of a scaffold are laid, -- one end resting on the ledger of the scaffold, and the other in a hole left in the wall temporarily for the purpose.
Plumper: One who, or that which, plumps or swells out something else; hence, something carried in the mouth to distend the cheeks.
Pooh: Pshaw! pish! nonsense! -- an expression of scorn, dislike, or contempt.
Pimaric: Pertaining to, or designating, an acid found in galipot, and isomeric with abietic acid.
Pool: To combine or contribute with others, as for a commercial, speculative, or gambling transaction.
Phyllomorphosis: The succession and variation of leaves during different seasons.
Peremptory: Precluding debate or expostulation; not admitting of question or appeal; positive; absolute; decisive; conclusive; final.
Planet-stricken: Affected by the influence of planets; blasted.
Polymorphous: Having, or assuming, a variety of forms, characters, or styles; as, a polymorphous author.
Presuppose: To suppose beforehand; to imply as antecedent; to take for granted; to assume; as, creation presupposes a creator.
Paramagnetism: A property of materials which are not magnetized in the absence of an external magnetic field, but in which the magnetic moments of their constituents align with and enhance an applied magnetic field; the induced magnetic field of the substance is in direct proportion to the strength of the applied magnetic field; -- opposed to diamagnetic and contrasted with ferromagnetic.
Plentiful: Containing plenty; copious; abundant; ample; as, a plentiful harvest; a plentiful supply of water.
Piciform: Of or pertaining to the Piciformes.
Pregravitate: To descend by gravity; to sink.
Preoccupancy: The act or right of taking possession before another; as, the preoccupancy of wild land.
Prairie: An extensive tract of level or rolling land, destitute of trees, covered with coarse grass, and usually characterized by a deep, fertile soil. They abound throughout the Mississippi valley, between the Alleghanies and the Rocky mountains.
Pissabed: A name locally applied to various wild plants, as dandelion, bluet, oxeye daisy, etc.
Pneumatograph: An instrument for recording the movements of the thorax or chest wall during respiration; -- also called stethograph.
Publisher: One who publishes; as, a publisher of a book or magazine.
Pupillarity: The period before puberty, or from birth to fourteen in males, and twelve in females.
Phylloxera: A small hemipterous insect (Phylloxera vastatrix) allied to the aphids. It attacks the roots and leaves of the grapevine, doing great damage, especially in Europe.
Potash: The hydroxide of potassium hydrate, a hard white brittle substance, KOH, having strong caustic and alkaline properties; -- hence called also caustic potash.
Plasma: A variety of quartz, of a color between grass green and leek green, which is found associated with common chalcedony. It was much esteemed by the ancients for making engraved ornaments.
Poristic: Of or pertaining to a porism; of the nature of a porism.
Phalarope: Any species of Phalaropus and allied genera of small wading birds (Grallæ), having lobate toes. They are often seen far from land, swimming in large flocks. Called also sea goose.
Printer: One who prints; especially, one who prints books, newspapers, engravings, etc., a compositor; a typesetter; a pressman.
Postremote: More remote in subsequent time or order.
Phonotypy: A method of phonetic printing of the English language, as devised by Mr. Pitman, in which nearly all the ordinary letters and many new forms are employed in order to indicate each elementary sound by a separate character.
Punch: To perforate or stamp with an instrument by pressure, or a blow; as, to punch a hole; to punch ticket.
Perfunctorily: In a perfunctory manner; formally; carelessly.
Phonotype: A type or character used in phonotypy.
Planish: To make smooth or plane, as a metallic surface; to condense, toughen, and polish by light blows with a hammer.
Prial: A corruption of pair royal. See under Pair, n.
Ptilop\u00e6dic: Having nearly the whole surface of the skin covered with down; dasypædic; -- said of the young of certain birds.
Pteropoda: A class of Mollusca in which the anterior lobes of the foot are developed in the form of broad, thin, winglike organs, with which they swim at near the surface of the sea.
Prudhomme: A trustworthy citizen; a skilled workman. See Citation under 3d Commune, 1.
Parachordal: Situated on either side of the notochord; -- applied especially to the cartilaginous rudiments of the skull on each side of the anterior part of the notochord.
Pumiced: Affected with a kind of chronic laminitis in which there is a growth of soft spongy horn between the coffin bone and the hoof wall. The disease is called pumiced foot, or pumice foot.
Portmanteau: A bag or case, usually of leather, for carrying wearing apparel, etc., on journeys.
Paraldehyde: A trimer of acetaldehyde (C6H12O3), prepared by polymerization of acetaldehyde with hydrochloric and sulfuric acids.  It has sedative and hypnotic properties.
Paleology: The study or knowledge of antiquities, esp. of prehistoric antiquities; a discourse or treatise on antiquities; archæology .
Pustulate: Covered with pustulelike prominences; pustular; pustulous; as, a pustulate leaf; a pustulate shell or coral.
Portray: To paint or draw the likeness of; as, to portray a king on horseback.
Paguma: Any one of several species of East Indian viverrine mammals of the genus Paguma. They resemble a weasel in form.
Polysyllable: A word of many syllables, or consisting of more syllables than three; -- words of less than four syllables being called monosyllables, dissyllables, and trisyllables.
Pagehood: The state of being a page.
Partiality: The quality or state of being partial; inclination to favor one party, or one side of a question, more than the other; undue bias of mind.
Passover: A feast of the Jews, instituted to commemorate the sparing of the Hebrews in Egypt, when God, smiting the firstborn of the Egyptians, passed over the houses of the Israelites which were marked with the blood of a lamb.
Pygmy: One of a fabulous race of dwarfs who waged war with the cranes, and were destroyed.
pearlescent: Having an iridescent pearl-like surface, giving a play of lustrous rainbowlike colors; nacreous; pearlaceous.
Psychic: Of or pertaining to the human soul, or to the living principle in man.
Percarbureted: Combined with a relatively large amount of carbon.
Purpura: A disease characterized by livid spots on the skin from extravasated blood, with loss of muscular strength, pain in the limbs, and mental dejection; the purples.
Protopodite: The basal portion, or two proximal and more or less consolidated segments, of an appendage of a crustacean.
Purpure: Purple, -- represented in engraving by diagonal lines declining from the right top to the left base of the escutcheon (or from sinister chief to dexter base).
Pelma: The under surface of the foot.
Poleless: Without a pole; as, a poleless chariot.
Philanthropinism: A system of education on so-called natural principles, attempted in Germany in the last century by Basedow, of Dessau.
Philanthropinist: An advocate of, or believer in, philanthropinism.
Perceptive: Of or pertaining to the act or power of perceiving; having the faculty or power of perceiving; used in perception.
Polemarch: In Athens, originally, the military commanderin-chief; but, afterward, a civil magistrate who had jurisdiction in respect of strangers and sojourners. In other Grecian cities, a high military and civil officer.
Pacation: The act of pacifying; a peacemaking.
Primality: The quality or state of being primal.
Producible: Capable of being produced, brought forward, brought forth, generated, made, or extended.
Palmyra: A species of palm (Borassus flabelliformis) having a straight, black, upright trunk, with palmate leaves.  It is found native along the entire northern shores of the Indian Ocean, from the mouth of the Tigris to New Guinea.  More than eight hundred uses to which it is put are enumerated by native writers.  Its wood is largely used for building purposes; its fruit and roots serve for food, its sap for making toddy, and its leaves for thatching huts.
Parethmoid: Near or beside the ethmoid bone or cartilage; -- applied especially to a pair of bones in the nasal region of some fishes, and to the ethmoturbinals in some higher animals.
Pterichthys: A genus of Devonian fossil fishes with winglike appendages. The head and most of the body were covered with large bony plates. See Placodermi.
Philosophism: Spurious philosophy; the love or practice of sophistry.
Plumbous: Of, pertaining to, or containing, lead; -- used specifically to designate those compounds in which it has a lower valence as contrasted with plumbic compounds.
Passeriform: Like or belonging to the Passeres.
Preteritness: The quality or state of being past.
Proposal: That which is proposed, or propounded for consideration or acceptance; a scheme or design; terms or conditions proposed; offer; as, to make proposals for a treaty of peace; to offer proposals for erecting a building; to make proposals of marriage.
Pedicellate: Having a pedicel; supported by a pedicel.
Pali: A dialect descended from Sanskrit, and like that, a dead language, except when used as the sacred language of the Buddhist religion in Farther India, etc.
Personification: The act of personifying; impersonation; embodiment.
Pythonism: The art of predicting events after the manner of the priestess of Apollo at Delphi; equivocal prophesying.
Podophyllin: A brown bitter gum extracted from the rootstalk of the May apple (Podophyllum peltatum). It is a complex mixture of several substances.
Petticoat: A loose under-garment worn by women, and covering the body below the waist.
Prudent: Sagacious in adapting means to ends; circumspect in action, or in determining any line of conduct; practically wise; judicious; careful; discreet; sensible; -- opposed to rash; as, a prudent man; dictated or directed by prudence or wise forethought; evincing prudence; as, prudent behavior.
Pahoehoe: A name given in Hawaii (formerly the Sandwich Islands) to lava having a relatively smooth or billowing surface, in distinction from the rough-surfaced lava, called aa.
Palissy: Designating, or of the nature of, a kind of pottery made by Bernard Palissy, in France, in the 16th centry.
Pericranial: Of or pertaining to the pericranium.
Promoter: One who, or that which, forwards, advances, or promotes; an encourager; as, a promoter of charity or philosophy.
Parrotia: A genus containing one species, the irontree.
Parde: Certainly; surely; truly; verily; -- originally an oath.
Provisional: Of the nature of a provision; serving as a provision for the time being; -- used of partial or temporary arrangements; as, a provisional government; a provisional treaty.
Pardo: A money of account once used in in Goa, India, equivalent to about 2s. 6d. sterling. or 60 cts. (in 1913).
paneling: The act or process of forming in panels or decorating with panels.
Putrid: Tending to decomposition or decay; decomposed; rotten; -- said of animal or vegetable matter; as, putrid flesh. See Putrefaction.
Platonist: One who adheres to the philosophy of Plato; a follower of Plato.
Poult: A young chicken, partridge, grouse, or the like.
Poorliness: The quality or state of being poorly; ill health.
Platonism: The doctrines or philosophy by Plato or of his followers.
Petune: To spray (tobacco) with a liquid intended to produce flavor or aroma.
Primevally: In a primeval manner; in or from the earliest times; originally.
Preconceive: To conceive, or form an opinion of, beforehand; to form a previous notion or idea of.
Paulian: A follower of Paul of Samosata, a bishop of Antioch in the third century, who was deposed for denying the divinity of Christ.
Pockmark: A mark or pit made by smallpox.
Pyrophane: A mineral which is opaque in its natural state, but is said to change its color and become transparent by heat.
Perilymphangial: Around, or at the side of, a lymphatic vessel.
Penumbrala: Of or pertaining to a penumbra; resembling a penumbra; partially illuminated.
Pondfish: Any one of numerous species of American fresh-water fishes belonging to the family Centrarchidæ; -- called also pond perch, and sunfish.
Position: To indicate the position of; to place.
Provenience: Origin; source; place where found or produced; provenance; -- used esp. in the fine arts and in archæology; as, the provenience of a patera.
Plainant: One who makes complaint; the plaintiff.
Phenylic: Pertaining to, derived from, or containing, phenyl.
Porcate: Having grooves or furrows broader than the intervening ridges; furrowed.
Paliform: Resembling a palus; as, the paliform lobes of the septa in corals.
Pacifier: One who or that which pacifies.
Profaner: One who treats sacred things with irreverence, or defiles what is holy; one who uses profane language.
Pritchel: A tool employed by blacksmiths for punching or enlarging the nail holes in a horseshoe.
Pentacrostic: A set of verses so disposed that the name forming the subject of the acrostic occurs five times -- the whole set of verses being divided into five different parts from top to bottom.
pet: Petted; indulged; admired; cherished; as, a pet child; a pet lamb; a pet theory; a pet animal.
Projet: A plan proposed; a draft of a proposed measure; a project.
Punctilio: A nice point of exactness in conduct, ceremony, or proceeding; particularity or exactness in forms; as, the punctilios of a public ceremony.
Pelargonium: A large genus of plants of the order Geraniaceæ, differing from Geranium in having a spurred calyx and an irregular corolla.
Pocoson: Low, wooded grounds or swamps in Eastern Maryland and Virginia.
Psychopannychism: The doctrine that the soul falls asleep at death, and does not wake until the resurrection of the body.
Posthumous: Born after the death of the father, or taken from the dead body of the mother; as, a posthumous son or daughter.
Parochial: Of or pertaining to a parish; restricted to a parish; as, parochial duties; parochial schools.
Pommelion: The cascabel, or hindmost knob, of a cannon.
Peagrit: A coarse pisolitic limestone. See Pisolite.
Patesi: A religious as well as a secular designation applied to rulers of some of the city states of ancient Chaldea, as Lagash or Shirpurla, who were conceived to be direct representatives of the tutelary god of the place.
Phlegmon: Purulent inflammation of the cellular or areolar tissue.
Pantherine: Like a panther, esp. in color; as, the pantherine snake (Ptyas mucosus) of Brazil.
Pandean: Of or relating to the god Pan.
Photo-etch: To engrave, or make an engraving of, by any photomechanical process involving etching of the plate.
Photographometer: An instrument for determining the sensibility of the plates employed in photographic processes to luminous rays.
Painted: Covered or adorned with paint; portrayed in colors.
P\u0153cilopod: One of the Pœcilopoda. Also used adjectively.
Pretemporal: Situated in front of the temporal bone.
Protamin: An amorphous nitrogenous substance found in the spermatic fluid of salmon. It is soluble in water, which an alkaline reaction, and unites with acids and metallic bases.
Phenology: The science of the relations between climate and periodic biological phenomena, as the migrations and breeding of birds, the flowering and fruiting of plants, etc.
Pollenin: A substance found in the pollen of certain plants.
Praline: A confection made of nut kernels, usually of almonds, roasted in boiling sugar until brown and crisp.
Painter: One whose occupation is to paint
Pouched: Having a marsupial pouch; as, the pouched badger, or the wombat.
Plicate: Plaited; folded like a fan; as, a plicate leaf.
Psalm: To extol in psalms; to sing; as, psalming his praises.
Peasantry: Peasants, collectively; the body of rustics.
peppershaker: A shaker with a perforated top for sprinkling ground pepper.
Postrider: One who rides over a post road to carry the mails.
Pair production: The simultaneous creation of a particle and its antiparticle, such as an electron and positron, from a photon; -- usually due to its interaction with the strong field near a nucleus.
Potale: The refuse from a grain distillery, used to fatten swine.
Perhaps: By chance; peradventure; perchance; it may be.
Prism: A solid whose bases or ends are any similar, equal, and parallel plane figures, and whose sides are parallelograms.
Polary: Tending to a pole; having a direction toward a pole.
Prise: See Prize, n., 5. Also Prize, v. t.
Presentation: The act of presenting, or the state of being presented; a setting forth; an offering; bestowal.
Pocket veto: The retention by the President of the United States of a bill unsigned so that it does not become a law, in virtue of the following constitutional provision (Const. Art. I., sec. 7, cl. 2): “If any bill shall not be returned by the President within ten days (Sundays excepted) after it shall have been presented to him, the same shall be a law, in like manner as if he had signed it, unless the Congress by their adjournment prevent its return, in which case it shall not be a law.” Also, an analogous retention of a bill by a State governor.
Periosteum: The membrane of fibrous connective tissue which closely invests all bones except at the articular surfaces.
Petard: A case containing powder to be exploded, esp. a conical or cylindrical case of metal filled with powder and attached to a plank, to be exploded against and break down gates, barricades, drawbridges, etc.  It has been superseded.
Proxy: To act or vote by proxy; to do anything by the agency of another.
Puzzledom: The domain of puzzles; puzzles, collectively.
Polariscope: An instrument consisting essentially of a polarizer and an analyzer, used for polarizing light, and analyzing its properties.
Pipevine: Any climbing species of Aristolochia; esp., the Dutchman's pipe (Aristolochia sipho). See under Dutchman.
Perseus: A Grecian legendary hero, son of Jupiter and Danaë, who slew the Gorgon Medusa.
Planogamete: One of the motile ciliated gametes, or zoögametes, found in isogamous plants, as many green algæ (Chlorophyceæ).
Pettywhin: The needle furze. See under Needle.
Podobranch: One of the branchiæ attached to the bases of the legs in Crustacea.
Polariscopy: The art or rocess of making observations with the polariscope.
Proc\u00e8s verbal: An authentic minute of an official act, or statement of facts.
Polyatomic: Having more than one atom in the molecule; consisting of several atoms.
Pokebag: The European long-tailed titmouse; -- called also poke-pudding.
Palisading: A row of palisades set in the ground.
Pinic: Of or pertaining to the pine; obtained from the pine; formerly, designating an acid which is the chief constituent of common resin, -- now called abietic, or sylvic, acid.
Phyllodium: A petiole dilated into the form of a blade, and usually with vertical edges, as in the Australian acacias.
Phyllosoma: The larva of the spiny lobsters (Palinurus and allied genera). Its body is remarkably thin, flat, and transparent; the legs are very long. Called also glass-crab, and glass-shrimp.
Photoheliograph: A modified kind of telescope adapted to taking photographs of the sun.
Prevenancy: The act of anticipating another's wishes, desires, etc., in the way of favor or courtesy; hence, civility; obligingness.
Perimetry: The art of using the perimeter; measurement of the field of vision.
Prudential: That which relates to or demands the exercise of, discretion or prudence; -- usually in the pl.
Physeter: The genus that includes the sperm whale.
Popedom: The place, office, or dignity of the pope; papal dignity.
Proceres: An order of large birds; the Ratitæ; -- called also Proceri.
Pyroxenite: A rock consisting essentially of pyroxene.
Purse-proud: Affected with purse pride; puffed up with the possession of riches.
Passive: Not active, but acted upon; suffering or receiving impressions or influences; as, they were passive spectators, not actors in the scene.
Prefigure: To show, suggest, or announce, by antecedent types and similitudes; to foreshadow.
Prescapula: The part of the scapula in front of, or above, the spine, or mesoscapula.
Paganism: The state of being pagan; pagan characteristics; esp., the worship of idols or false gods, or the system of religious opinions and worship maintained by pagans; heathenism.
Petaloideous: Having the whole or part of the perianth petaline.
Prol\u00e9taire: One of the common people; a low person; also, the common people as a class or estate in a country.
Palatalize: To modify, as the tones of the voice, by means of the palate;
Polluting: Adapted or tending to pollute; causing defilement or pollution.
Preoccupation: The act of preoccupying, or taking possession of beforehand; the state of being preoccupied; prepossession.
Proscribe: To doom to destruction; to put out of the protection of law; to outlaw; to exile; as, Sylla and Marius proscribed each other's adherents.
Paleobotany: That branch of paleontology which treats of fossil plants.
Provisorily: In a provisory manner; conditionally; subject to a proviso; as, to admit a doctrine provisorily.
Planisher: One who, or that which, planishes.
Pyrargyrite: Ruby silver; dark red silver ore. It is a sulphide of antimony and silver, occurring in rhombohedral crystals or massive, and is of a dark red or black color with a metallic adamantine luster.
Poetship: The state or personality of a poet.
P\u0153cilopoda: Originally, an artificial group including many parasitic Entomostraca, together with the horseshoe crabs (Limuloidea).
Pinacate bug: Any of several clumsy, wingless beetles of the genus Eleodes, found in the Pacific States.
Professor: One who professed, or makes open declaration of, his sentiments or opinions; especially, one who makes a public avowal of his belief in the Scriptures and his faith in Christ, and thus unites himself to the visible church.
Papess: A female pope; i. e., the fictitious pope Joan.
Pentremites: A genus of crinoids belonging to the Blastoidea. They have five petal-like ambulacra.
Peristrephic: Turning around; rotatory; revolving; as, a peristrephic painting (of a panorama).
Palsywort: The cowslip (Primula veris); -- so called from its supposed remedial powers.
Pigsney: A word of endearment for a girl or woman.
Palanquin: An inclosed carriage or litter, commonly about eight feet long, four feet wide, and four feet high, borne on the shoulders of men by means of two projecting poles, -- used in India, China, etc., for the conveyance of a single person from place to place.
Proceeds: That which comes forth or results; effect; yield; issue; product; sum accruing from a sale, etc.
Pleuroperitoneal: Of or pertaining to the pleural and peritoneal membranes or cavities, or to the pleuroperitoneum.
Phenomenal: Relating to, or of the nature of, a phenomenon; hence, extraordinary; wonderful; as, a phenomenal memory.
Parkesine: A compound, originally made from gun cotton and castor oil, but later from different materials, and used as a substitute for vulcanized India rubber and for ivory; -- called also xylotile.
Pythagorize: To speculate after the manner of Pythagoras.
Pomeranian: Of or pertaining to Pomerania, a province of Prussia on the Baltic Sea.
Philosopheme: A philosophical proposition, doctrine, or principle of reasoning.
Pneumophora: A division of holothurians having an internal gill, or respiratory tree.
penny-wise: Thrifty in small matters only.  Used mostly in the phrase penny-wise and pound foolish.
Pitpan: A long, flat-bottomed canoe, used for the navigation of rivers and lagoons in Central America.
Participle: A part of speech partaking of the nature of both verb and adjective; a form of a verb, or verbal adjective, modifying a noun, but taking the adjuncts of the verb from which it is derived. In the sentences: a letter is written; being asleep he did not hear; exhausted by toil he will sleep soundly, -- written, being, and exhaustedare participles.
Pyre: A funeral pile; a combustible heap on which the dead are burned; hence, any pile to be burnt.
parapsychology: The field of study concerned with psychological phenomena not explainable by the laws of physics, especially extrasensory perception, telepathy, psychokinesis, precognition, and clairvoyance.
pedaler: a person who rides a pedal-driven vehicle.
Pneumatology: The doctrine of, or a treatise on, air and other elastic fluids. See Pneumatics, 1.
Period: To come to a period; to conclude. [Obs.] “You may period upon this, that,” etc.
Paludamentum: A military cloak worn by a general and his principal officers.
Parachronism: An error in chronology, by which the date of an event is set later than the time of its occurrence.
parkway: A wide scenic road planted with trees.
Pilidium: The free-swimming, hat-shaped larva of certain nemertean worms. It has no resemblance to its parent, and the young worm develops in its interior.
Polyschematist: Having, or existing in, many different forms or fashions; multiform.
Pis\u00e9: A species of wall made of stiff earth or clay rammed in between molds which are carried up as the wall rises; -- called also pisé work.
Pezizoid: Resembling a fungus of the genus Peziza; having a cuplike form.
Pitchstone: An igneous rock of semiglassy nature, having a luster like pitch.
Polyadelphian: Belonging to the class Polyadelphia; having stamens united in three or more bundles.
Palpiger: That portion of the labium which bears the palpi in insects.
Propulse: To repel; to drive off or away.
Pseudostoma: A group of cells resembling a stoma, but without any true aperture among them.
Pregnant: Affording entrance; receptive; yielding; willing; open; prompt.
Portcullis: To obstruct with, or as with, a portcullis; to shut; to bar.
Polder: A tract of low land reclaimed from the sea by of high embankments.
Piperaceous: Of or pertaining to the order of plants (Piperaceæ) of which the pepper (Piper nigrum) is the type. There are about a dozen genera and a thousand species, mostly tropical plants with pungent and aromatic qualities.
Pablum: A form of cereal for infants.
Pal\u00e6otype: A system of representing all spoken sounds by means of the printing types in common use.
Pyroantimonic: Pertaining to, or designating, an acid of antimony analogous to pyrophosphoric acid.
parity bit: The bit within a data structure which is assigned a value of 1 or 0 so as to make the parity{7} of the data structure odd or even.  Data structures may or may not have parity bits, dpending on whether the system does or does not perform parity checking.  The most commonly used parity bit is the eigth (higher-order) bit of a byte, which is used when data transmission uses only the 7 lower-order bits of each byte as significant data; some memory systems use a ninth bit as a parity bit for each eight bits (one byte) of significant data in memory.
Prerogatived: Endowed with a prerogative, or exclusive privilege.
Plantule: The embryo which has begun its development in the act of germination.
Principia: First principles; fundamental beginnings; elements; as. Newton's Principia.
Pugnacious: Disposed to fight; inclined to fighting; quarrelsome; fighting.
Pulque: An intoxicating Mexican drink. See Agave.
Pricking: The act of piercing or puncturing with a sharp point.
Prosternum: The ventral plate of the prothorax of an insect.
Photobacterium: A genus including certain comma-shaped marine bacteria which emit bluish or greenish phosphorescence. Also, any microörganism of this group.
Parsnip: The aromatic and edible spindle-shaped root of the cultivated form of the Pastinaca sativa, a biennial umbelliferous plant which is very poisonous in its wild state; also, the plant itself.
Pyrenean: Of or pertaining to the Pyrenees, a range of mountains separating France and Spain.
Pulvinar: A prominence on the posterior part of the thalamus of the human brain.
Parapleura: A chitinous piece between the metasternum and the pleuron of certain insects.
Ptenoglossate: Of or pertaining to the Ptenoglossa.
Pathogenic: Of or pertaining to pathogeny; producting disease; as, a pathogenic organism; a pathogenic bacterium.
Phthisical: Of or pertaining to phthisis; affected with phthisis; wasting; consumptive.
Peanism: The song or shout of praise, of battle, or of triumph.
Pressure: The act of pressing, or the condition of being pressed; compression; a squeezing; a crushing; as, a pressure of the hand.
Palladium: A rare metallic element of the light platinum group, found native, and also alloyed with platinum and gold.  It is a silver-white metal resembling platinum, and like it permanent and untarnished in the air, but is more easily fusible, with a melting point of 1555° C.  It can also be prepared as a finely divided black powder.  It is unique in its power of absorbing hydrogen, which it does to the extent of nearly a thousand volumes, forming the alloy Pd2H.  It is used for graduated circles and verniers, for plating certain silver goods, and somewhat in dentistry.  It was so named in 1804 by Wollaston from the asteroid Pallas, which was discovered in 1802.  Symbol Pd.  Atomic number, 46.  Atomic weight, 106.42.  Density 12.0.
Preaxial: Situated in front of any transverse axis in the body of an animal; anterior; cephalic; esp., in front, or on the anterior, or cephalic (that is, radial or tibial) side of the axis of a limb.
Phraseology: Manner of expression; peculiarity of diction; style.
Polycarpellary: Composed of several or numerous carpels; -- said of such fruits as the orange.
Preferential: Giving, indicating, or having a preference or precedence; as, a preferential claim; preferential shares.
Porte: The Ottoman court; the government of the Turkish empire, officially called the Sublime Porte, from the gate (port) of the sultan's palace at which justice was administered.
Porta: The part of the liver or other organ where its vessels and nerves enter; the hilus.
Processional: Of or pertaining to a procession; consisting in a procession.
Pecuniarily: In a pecuniary manner; as regards money.
Petroglyphy: The art or operation of carving figures or inscriptions on rock or stone.
Precordial: Situated in front of the heart; of or pertaining to the præcordia.
Perspirative: Performing the act of perspiration; perspiratory.
Parian: A native or inhabitant of Paros.
Piation: The act of making atonement; expiation.
Previous: Going before in time; being or happening before something else; antecedent; prior; as, previous arrangements; a previous illness.
Plastidule: One of the small particles or organic molecules of protoplasm.
Prink: To prank or dress up; to deck fantastically.
Poisonous: Having the qualities or effects of poison; venomous; baneful; corrupting; noxious.
Print: A mark made by impression; a line, character, figure, or indentation, made by the pressure of one thing on another; as, the print of teeth or nails in flesh; the print of the foot in sand or snow.
Palempore: A superior kind of dimity made in India, -- used for bed coverings.
Perissodactyla: A division of ungulate mammals, including those that have an odd number of toes, as the horse, tapir, and rhinoceros; -- opposed to Artiodactyla.
Puisne: One who is younger, or of inferior rank; a junior; esp., a judge of inferior rank.
Pneumaticity: The state of being pneumatic, or of having a cavity or cavities filled with air; as, the pneumaticity of the bones of birds.
Permission: The act of permitting or allowing; formal consent; authorization; leave; license or liberty granted.
Platitude: The quality or state of being flat, thin, or insipid; flat commonness; triteness; staleness of ideas of language.
pit stop: A stop by one of the competing cars in a pit by the side of the racetrack, to take on gasoline, change tires, or perform other maintenance.
Parbuckle: To hoist or lower by means of a parbuckle.
Pettifogulize: To act as a pettifogger; to use contemptible tricks.
Pyrrhotine: A bronze-colored mineral, of metallic luster.  It is a sulphide of iron, and is remarkable for being attracted by the magnet.  Called also magnetic pyrites.
Poniard: To pierce with a poniard; to stab.
Pyrolusite: Manganese dioxide, a mineral of an iron-black or dark steel-gray color and metallic luster, usually soft.  Pyrolusite parts with its oxygen at a red heat, and is extensively used in discharging the brown and green tints of glass (whence its name).
Perradial: Situated around the radii, or radial tubes, of a radiate.
Pantheon: A temple dedicated to all the gods; especially, the building so called at Rome.
Poundage: Confinement of cattle, or other animals, in a public pound.
Putamen: The shell of a nut; the stone of a drupe fruit. See Endocarp.
Physicking: p. pr. & vb. n. fr. Physic, v. t.
Pickup: Act of picking up, as, in various games, the fielding or hitting of a ball just after it strikes the ground.
Pulpatoon: A kind of delicate confectionery or cake, perhaps made from the pulp of fruit.
Providore: One who makes provision; a purveyor.
Peele: A graceful and swift South African antelope (Pelea capreola).  The hair is woolly, and ash-gray on the back and sides.  The horns are black, long, slender, straight, nearly smooth, and very sharp.  Called also rheeboc, rhebuck, rhebok, and rehboc.
Phrenic: Of or pertaining to the diaphragm; diaphragmatic; as, the phrenic nerve.
Perianth: The leaves of a flower generally, especially when the calyx and corolla are not readily distinguished.
palaeontology: The branch of archeology that studies fossil organisms and related remains.
Penitentiary: One who prescribes the rules and measures of penance.
Plant-cane: A stalk or shoot of sugar cane of the first growth from the cutting. The growth of the second and following years is of inferior quality, and is called rattoon.
Pirameter: A dynamometer for ascertaining the power required to draw carriages over roads.
Plunger: One who, or that which, plunges; a diver.
Peloponnesian: Of or pertaining to the Peloponnesus, or southern peninsula of Greece.
Primitiveness: The quality or state of being primitive; conformity to primitive style or practice.
Pyroboric: Pertaining to derived from, or designating, an acid, H2B4O7 (called also tetraboric acid), which is the acid ingredient of ordinary borax, and is obtained by heating boric acid.
Pound: A certain specified weight; especially, a legal standard consisting of an established number of ounces.
Panurgy: Skill in all kinds of work or business; craft.
Praseodymium: An elementary substance, one of the constituents of didymium; -- so called from the green color of its salts.  Symbol Ps.  Atomic weight 143.6.
Peaty: Composed of peat; abounding in peat; resembling peat.
Paphian: A native or inhabitant of Paphos.
Polygonum: A genus of plants embracing a large number of species, including bistort, knotweed, smartweed, etc.
Puniceous: Of a bright red or purple color.
Par: By; with; -- used frequently in Early English in phrases taken from the French, being sometimes written as a part of the word which it governs; as, par amour, or paramour; par cas, or parcase; par fay, or parfay.
Pas: A pace; a step, as in a dance.
Paw: To pass the paw over; to stroke or handle with the paws; hence, to handle fondly or rudely.
Pax: The kiss of peace; also, the embrace in the sanctuary now substituted for it at High Mass in Roman Catholic churches.
Preaudience: Precedence of rank at the bar among lawyers.
Prevertebral: Situated immediately in front, or on the ventral side, of the vertebral column; prespinal.
Percussion: The act of percussing, or striking one body against another; forcible collision, esp. such as gives a sound or report.
Pac: A kind of moccasin, having the edges of the sole turned up and sewed to the upper.
Pad: To stuff; to furnish with a pad or padding.
Pyrometer: An instrument used for measuring the expansion of solid bodies by heat.
Performance: The act of performing; the carrying into execution or action; execution; achievement; accomplishment; representation by action; as, the performance of an undertaking of a duty.
Pal: A mate; a partner; esp., an accomplice or confederate.
Pam: A form of the female given name Pamela.
Pan: To scan (a movie camera), usu. in a horizontal direction, to obtain a panoramic effect; also, to move the camera so as to keep the subject in view.
Phrenologist: One versed in phrenology; a craniologist.
Pushing: Pressing forward in business; enterprising; driving; energetic; also, forward; officious, intrusive.
Pterocletes: A division of birds including the sand grouse.  They are in some respects intermediate between the pigeons and true grouse.  Called also Pteroclomorphæ.
Piccalilli: A pickle of various vegetables with pungent species, -- originally made in the East Indies.
Porpita: A genus of bright-colored Siphonophora found floating in the warmer parts of the ocean. The individuals are round and disk-shaped, with a large zooid in the center of the under side, surrounded by smaller nutritive and reproductive zooids, and by slender dactylozooids near the margin. The disk contains a central float, or pneumatocyst.
Presumptuousness: The quality or state of being presumptuous.
Pluriliteral: Consisting of more letters than three.
Prepositor: A scholar appointed to inspect other scholars; a monitor.
Pustulous: Resembling, or covered with, pustules; pustulate; pustular.
Planisphere: The representation of the circles of the sphere upon a plane; especially, a representation of the celestial sphere upon a plane with adjustable circles, or other appendages, for showing the position of the heavens, the time of rising and setting of stars, etc., for any given date or hour.
Prosaic: Of or pertaining to prose; resembling prose; in the form of prose; unpoetical; writing or using prose; as, a prosaic composition.
Politics: The science of government; that part of ethics which has to do with the regulation and government of a nation or state, the preservation of its safety, peace, and prosperity, the defense of its existence and rights against foreign control or conquest, the augmentation of its strength and resources, and the protection of its citizens in their rights, with the preservation and improvement of their morals.
Pine-clad: Clad or crowned with pine trees; as, pine-clad hills.
Pharyngeal: A pharyngeal bone or cartilage; especially, one of the lower pharyngeals, which belong to the rudimentary fifth branchial arch in many fishes, or one of the upper pharyngeals, or pharyngobranchials, which are the dorsal elements in the complete branchial arches.
Porcelaneous: Of or pertaining to porcelain; resembling porcelain; as, porcelaneous shells.
Plotinist: A disciple of Plotinus, a celebrated Platonic philosopher of the third century, who taught that the human soul emanates from the divine Being, to whom it reunited at death.
Paragrandine: An instrument to avert the occurrence of hailstorms. See Paragrêle.
peacekeeper: a member of a military force that is assigned (often with international sanction) to preserve peace in a trouble area.
