Pneumo-: A combining form from Gr. &unr_;, &unr_;, a lung; as, pneumogastric, pneumology.
Pitahaya: A cactaceous shrub (Cereus Pitajaya) of tropical America, which yields a delicious fruit.
Pibcorn: A wind instrument or pipe, with a horn at each end, -- used in Wales.
Presbyterianism: That form of church government which invests presbyters with all spiritual power, and admits no prelates over them; also, the faith and polity of the Presbyterian churches, taken collectively.
Polyeidic: Passing through several distinct larval forms; -- having several distinct kinds of young.
Phlebogram: A tracing (with the sphygmograph) of the movements of a vein, or of the venous pulse.
Perchromic: Pertaining to, or designating, a certain one of the highly oxidized compounds of chromium, which has a deep blue color, and is produced by the action of hydrogen peroxide.
Postscutellum: The hindermost dorsal piece of a thoracic somite of an insect; the plate behind the scutellum.
Pestiduct: That which conveys contagion or infection.
Plantigrade: A plantigrade animal, or one that walks or steps on the sole of the foot, as man, and the bears.
Plantigrada: A subdivision of Carnivora having plantigrade feet. It includes the bears, raccoons, and allied species.
Phenocryst: One of the prominent embedded crystals of a porphyry.
Pentane: Any one of the three metameric hydrocarbons, C5H12, of the methane or paraffin series. They are colorless, volatile liquids, two of which occur in petroleum. So called because of the five carbon atoms in the molecule.
Parelectronomic: Of or relating to parelectronomy; as, the parelectronomic part of a muscle.
Pentarchy: A government in the hands of five persons; five joint rulers.
Polygenous: Consisting of, or containing, many kinds; as, a polygenous mountain.
Patagium: In bats, an expansion of the integument uniting the fore limb with the body and extending between the elongated fingers to form the wing; in birds, the similar fold of integument uniting the fore limb with the body.
Playday: A day given to play or diversion; a holiday.
Philosophic: Of or pertaining to philosophy; versed in, or imbued with, the principles of philosophy; hence, characterizing a philosopher; rational; wise; temperate; calm; cool.
Pentine: An unsaturated hydrocarbon, C5H8, of the acetylene series. Same as Valerylene.
Pneumotherapy: The treatment of disease by inhalations of compressed or rarefied air.
pasteurellosis: An acute infectious disease characterized by pneumonia and blood infection.
Pandect: A treatise which comprehends the whole of any science.
Pilot light: a small gas flame kept burning continuously on a stove, water heater, or other gas-burning device, so as to allow immediate ignition of the main flame when the gas flow is turned on.
Psycho-motor: Of or pertaining to movement produced by action of the mind or will.
Passion: To suffer pain or sorrow; to experience a passion; to be extremely agitated.
Pinnacle: To build or furnish with a pinnacle or pinnacles.
pak-choi: An Asiatic plant (Brassica rapa chinensis) grown for its cluster of edible white stalks with dark green leaves.
Ptyxis: The way in which a leaf is sometimes folded in the bud.
Pensileness: State or quality of being pensile; pendulousness.
Preraphaelism: The doctrine or practice of a school of modern painters who profess to be followers of the painters before Raphael. Its adherents advocate careful study from nature, delicacy and minuteness of workmanship, and an exalted and delicate conception of the subject.
Pou sto: A place to stand upon; a locus standi; hence, a foundation or basis for operations.
Pluto: The son of Saturn and Rhea, brother of Jupiter and Neptune; the dark and gloomy god of the Lower World.
Pyroacid: An acid obtained by sybjecting another acid to the action of heat.  Cf. Pyro-.
Powan: A small British lake whitefish (Coregonus clupeoides, or Coregonus ferus); -- called also gwyniad and lake herring.
Protonema: The primary growth from the spore of a moss, usually consisting of branching confervoid filaments, on any part of which stem and leaf buds may be developed.
Pitching: The act of throwing or casting; a cast; a pitch; as, wild pitching in baseball.
P\u0153cilitic: Mottled with various colors; variegated; spotted; -- said of certain rocks.
Populist: A member of the People's party.
Panislamism: A desire or plan for the union of all Muslim nations for the conquest of the world.
Prelector: A reader of lectures or discourses; a lecturer.
paleogeology: The study of geologic features once at the surface of the earth but now buried beneath rocks.
Plasmogen: The important living portion of protoplasm, considered a chemical substance of the highest elaboration.  Germ plasm and idioplasm are forms of plasmogen.
Poke: The act of poking; a thrust; a jog; as, a poke in the ribs.
Pterygium: A superficial growth of vascular tissue radiating in a fanlike manner from the cornea over the surface of the eye.
Panderly: Having the quality of a pander.
Pontlevis: The action of a horse in rearing repeatedly and dangerously.
Participable: Capable of being participated or shared.
Pulvillio: A kind of perfume in the form of a powder, formerly much used, -- often in little bags.
Pizzicato: A direction to violinists to pluck the string with the finger, instead of using the bow. (Abrev. pizz.)
Pedagogism: The system, occupation, character, or manner of pedagogues.
Polarimetry: The art or process of measuring the polarization of light.
Plectospondylous: Of or pertaining to the Plectospondyli.
Preferability: The quality or state of being preferable; preferableness.
Porte-coch\u00e8re: A large doorway allowing vehicles to drive into or through a building. It is common to have the entrance door open upon the passage of the porte-cochère. Also, a porch over a driveway before an entrance door.
Perfectness: The quality or state of being perfect; perfection.
Pigwidgeon: A cant word for anything petty or small. It is used by Drayton as the name of a fairy.
Pre\u00ebmpt: To settle upon (public land) with a right of preemption, as under the laws of the United States; to take by preëmption.
Pr\u00e6cocial: Of or pertaining to the Præcoces.
Premolar: Situated in front of the molar teeth.
Preaching: The act of delivering a religious discourse; the art of sermonizing; also, a sermon; a public religious discourse; serious, earnest advice.
Phainopepla: A small crested passerine bird (Phaïnopepla nitens), native of Mexico and the Southern United States. The adult male is of a uniform glossy blue-black; the female is brownish. Called also black flycatcher.
Pentacrinoid: An immature comatula when it is still attached by a stem, and thus resembles a Pentacrinus.
palladiumize: To cover or coat with palladium.
pantie: A pair of short underpants for women or children (usually used in the plural).
Pornographic: Of or pertaining to pornography; lascivious; licentious; as, pornographic writing.
Phonogram: A letter, character, or mark used to represent a particular sound.
Pygopodous: Of or pertaining to the Pygopodes.
Pedioecetes: A genus of fowl including the sharp-tailed grouse (Pedioecetes phasianellus, also called the prairie chicken).
Poster: One who posts, or travels expeditiously; a courier.
Polypide: One of the ordinary zooids of the Bryozoa.
Pennach: A bunch of feathers; a plume.
Pungy: A small sloop or shallop, or a large boat with sails.
Produce: That which is produced, brought forth, or yielded; product; yield; proceeds; result of labor, especially of agricultural labors
Pendant: Something which hangs or depends; something suspended; a hanging appendage, especially one of an ornamental character, as to a chandelier or an eardrop; also, an appendix or addition, as to a book.
Prejudicative: Forming a judgment without due examination; prejudging.
Paned: Having panes; provided with panes; also, having openings; as, a paned window; paned window sash.
Parallactic: Of or pertaining to a parallax.
Postea: The return of the judge before whom a cause was tried, after a verdict, of what was done in the cause, which is indorsed on the nisi prius record.
Panel: To form in or with panels; as, to panel a wainscot.
Palpitate: To beat rapidly and more strongly than usual; to throb; to bound with emotion or exertion; to pulsate violently; to flutter; -- said specifically of the heart when its action is abnormal, as from excitement.
Phonation: The act or process by which articulate sounds are uttered; the utterance of articulate sounds; articulate speech.
Pulmotor: An apparatus for producing artificial respiration by pumping oxygen or air or a mixture of the two into and out of the lungs, as of a person who has been asphyxiated by drowning, breathing poisonous gases, or the like, or of one who has been stunned by an electrical shock.
Penstock: A close conduit or pipe for conducting water, as, to a water wheel, or for emptying a pond, or for domestic uses.
Pleuronectoid: Pertaining to the Pleuronectidæ, or Flounder family.
Polyspermous: Containing many seeds; as, a polyspermous capsule or berry.
Pyemic: Of or pertaining to pyæmia; of the nature of pyæmia.
Proscriptive: Of or pertaining to proscription; consisting in, or of the nature of, proscription; proscribing.
Purbeck beds: The strata of the Purbeck stone, or Purbeck limestone, belonging to the Oölitic group. See the Chart of Geology.
Perspectograph: An instrument for obtaining, and transferring to a picture, the points and outlines of objects, so as to represent them in their proper geometrical relations as viewed from some one point.
Popularness: The quality or state of being popular; popularity.
Porret: A scallion; a leek or small onion.
Polygram: A figure consisting of many lines.
Polygyn: A plant of the order Polygynia.
Pyromucic: Pertaining to, derived from, or designating, an acid obtained as a white crystalline substance by the distillation of mucic acid, or by the oxidation of furfurol.
Polynemoid: Of or pertaining to the polynemes, or the family Polynemidæ.
Pneumatometer: An instrument for measuring the amount of force exerted by the lungs in respiration.
Pteroceras: A genus of large marine gastropods having the outer border of the lip divided into lobes; -- called also scorpion shell.
Pilgrimage: The journey of a pilgrim; a long journey; especially, a journey to a shrine or other sacred place. Fig., the journey of human life.
Pilot wheel: A wheel, usually with radial handles projecting from the rim, for traversing the saddle of a machine tool, esp. an automatic machine tool, by hand.
Pelecaniformes: Those birds that are related to the pelican; the Totipalmi.
Plumicorn: An ear tuft of feathers, as in the horned owls.
Presentable: Capable or admitting of being presented; suitable to be exhibited, represented, or offered; fit to be brought forward or set forth; hence, fitted to be introduced to another, or to go into society; as, ideas that are presentable in simple language; she is not presentable in such a gown.
Podder: One who collects pods or pulse.
Postmark: To mark with a post-office stamp; as, to postmark a letter or parcel.
Polycotyledonary: Having the villi of the placenta collected into definite patches, or cotyledons.
Portableness: The quality or state of being portable; portability.
Perturbational: Of or pertaining to perturbation, esp. to the perturbations of the planets.
Polly: A woman's name; also, a popular name for a parrot.
Photogalvanography: The art or process of making photo-electrotypes.
Pontificate: To perform the duty of a pontiff.
Pneumogastric: Of or pertaining to the lungs and the stomach.
Pavesade: A canvas screen, formerly sometimes extended along the side of a vessel in a naval engagement, to conceal from the enemy the operations on board.
Plaice: A European food fish (Pleuronectes platessa), allied to the flounder, and growing to the weight of eight or ten pounds or more.
Passim: Here and there; everywhere; as, this word occurs passim in the poem.
Puffball: A kind of ball-shaped fungus (Lycoperdon giganteum, and other species of the same genus) full of dustlike spores when ripe; -- called also bullfist, bullfice, puckfist, puff, and puffin.
Protoplasta: A division of fresh-water rhizopods including those that have a soft body and delicate branched pseudopodia. The genus Gromia is one of the best-known.
Pamphlet: To write a pamphlet or pamphlets.
Puller: One who, or that which, pulls.
Parquetry: A species of joinery or cabinet-work consisting of an inlay of geometric or other patterns, generally of different colors, -- used especially for floors.
Pr\u00e6tores: A division of butterflies including the satyrs.
Persiflage: Frivolous or bantering talk; a frivolous manner of treating any subject, whether serious or otherwise; light raillery.
Potentness: The quality or state of being potent; powerfulness; potency; efficacy.
Pharmacopolist: One who sells medicines; an apothecary.
Public-service corporation: A corporation, such as a railroad company, lighting company, water company, etc., organized or chartered to follow a public calling or to render services more or less essential to the general public convenience or safety.
paternalistic: Benevolent but sometimes intrusive; -- used often of governments and the administration of large organizations.  See paternal government.
Painstaking: The act of taking pains; carefulness and fidelity in performance.
Pygostyle: The plate of bone which forms the posterior end of the vertebral column in most birds; the plowshare bone; the vomer. It is formed by the union of a number of the last caudal vertebræ, and supports the uropigium.
Peritrochium: The wheel which, together with the axle, forms the axis in peritrochio, which see under Axis.
Prededication: A dedication made previously or beforehand.
Pluviometry: That branch of meteorology that treats of the measurement of the precipitation of rain, snow, etc.
Pentecosty: A troop of fifty soldiers in the Spartan army; -- called also pentecostys.
Puissantly: In a puissant manner; powerfully; with great strength.
Preoccupy: To take possession of before another; as, to preoccupy a country not before held.
Podophyllum: A genus of herbs of the Barberry family, having large palmately lobed peltate leaves and solitary flower.  There are two species, the American Podophyllum peltatum, or May apple, the Himalayan Podophyllum Emodi.
Putty: To cement, or stop, with putty.
Phylactol\u00e6ma: An order of fresh-water Bryozoa in which the tentacles are arranged on a horseshoe-shaped lophophore, and the mouth is covered by an epistome.  Called also Lophopoda, and hippocrepians.
Prochronism: The dating of an event before the time it happened; an antedating; -- opposed to metachronism.
Premi\u00e8re: First; chief; as, a première danseuse.
Profess: To take a profession upon one's self by a public declaration; to confess.
Punctiform: Having the form of a point.
Placidness: The quality or state of being placid.
Purslane: An annual plant (Portulaca oleracea), with fleshy, succulent, obovate leaves, sometimes used as a pot herb and for salads, garnishing, and pickling.
parallel-parking: The act or process of parking parallel to the curb; -- contrasted with angle-parking.
Producers goods: Goods that satisfy wants only indirectly as factors in the production of other goods, such as tools and raw material; -- called also instrumental goods, auxiliary goods, intermediate goods, or goods of the second and higher orders, and disting. from consumers' goods.
Pyoid: Of or pertaining to pus; of the nature of, or like, pus.
Privatively: In a privative manner; by the absence of something; negatively.
Psychology: The science of the human soul; specifically, the systematic or scientific knowledge of the powers and functions of the human soul, so far as they are known by consciousness; a treatise on the human soul.
Prenominal: Serving as a prefix in a compound name.
Paramorph: A kind of pseudomorph, in which there has been a change of physical characters, by a change in crystal structure without alteration of chemical composition, as the change of aragonite to calcite; called also allomorph.
Phylactery: Any charm or amulet worn as a preservative from danger or disease.
Putrescible: A substance, usually nitrogenous, which is liable to undergo decomposition when in contact with air and moisture at ordinary temperatures.
Pendentive: The portion of a vault by means of which the square space in the middle of a building is brought to an octagon or circle to receive a cupola.
Phenomenology: A description, history, or explanation of phenomena.
Postscapular: Of or pertaining to the postscapula; infraspinous.
Pachy-: A combining form meaning thick; as, pachyderm, pachydactyl.
Pisolite: A variety of calcite, or calcium carbonate, consisting of aggregated globular concretions about the size of a pea; -- called also peastone, peagrit.
Periastron: That point, in the real or apparent orbit of one star revolving around another, at which the former is nearest to the latter.
Philanthropic: Of or pertaining to philanthropy; characterized by philanthropy; loving or helping mankind; as, a philanthropic enterprise.
Polynesian: Of or pertaining to Polynesia (the islands of the eastern and central Pacific), or to the Polynesians.
Pundle: A short and fat woman; a squab.
Pulverization: The action of reducing to dust or powder.
Profuse: To pour out; to give or spend liberally; to lavish; to squander.
Perpetualty: The state or condition of being perpetual.
Proposer: One who proposes or offers anything for consideration or adoption.
Perfoliate: Having the basal part produced around the stem; -- said of leaves which the stem apparently passes directory through.
Piririgua: A South American bird (Guira guira) allied to the cuckoos.
Penduline: A European titmouse (Parus pendulinus, syn. Ægithalus pendulinus).  It is noted for its elegant pendulous purselike nest, made of the down of willow trees and lined with feathers.
Purseful: All that is, or can be, contained in a purse; enough to fill a purse.
Paynize: To treat or preserve, as wood, by a process resembling kyanizing.
Pilose: Hairy; full of, or made of, hair.
Polygraphy: Much writing; writing of many books.
Prot\u00e9g\u00e9: One under the care and protection of another.
Peucedanin: A tasteless white crystalline substance, extracted from the roots of the sulphurwort (Peucedanum), masterwort (Imperatoria), and other related plants; -- called also imperatorin.
Pantaloonery: The character or performances of a pantaloon; buffoonery.
Percolation: The act or process of percolating, or filtering; filtration; straining. Specifically (Pharm.), the process of exhausting the virtues of a powdered drug by letting a liquid filter slowly through it.
Phasm: An apparition; a phantom; an appearance.
Polypterus: An African genus of ganoid fishes including the bichir.
Phase: To disturb the composure of; to disconcert; to nonplus; -- an older spelling, now replaced by faze.
Puerperal: Of or pertaining to childbirth; as, a puerperal fever.
Pantheism: The doctrine that the universe, taken or conceived of as a whole, is God; the doctrine that there is no God but the combined force and natural laws which are manifested in the existing universe; cosmotheism.  The doctrine denies that God is a rational personality.
Postfix: To annex; specifically (Gram.), to add or annex, as a letter, syllable, or word, to the end of another or principal word; to suffix.
Penologist: One versed in, or a student of, penology.
Panhellenic: Of or pertaining to all Greece, or to Panhellenism; including all Greece, or all the Greeks.
Parturifacient: A medicine tending to cause parturition, or to give relief in childbearing.
Preputial: Of or pertaining to the prepuce.
packinghouse: A place where foodstuffs are processed and packed; as, they came from an apple packinghouse.
Prospect: To make a search; to seek; to explore, as for mines or the like; as, to prospect for gold.
Palliate: To cover with a mantle or cloak; to cover up; to hide.
Phycology: The science of algæ, or seaweeds; algology.
Piperic: Pertaining to, or derived from, or designating, a complex organic acid found in the products of different members of the Pepper family, and extracted as a yellowish crystalline substance.
Private: A secret message; a personal unofficial communication.
Proof-proof: Proof against proofs; obstinate in the wrong.
Palatine Hill: One of the "seven hills" of Rome, situated southeast of the Capitoline and north-northeast of the Aventine.  It borders on the Roman Forum; is the traditional seat of the city founded by Romulus; was the seat of private and later of imperial residences; and contains many antiquities.
Panurgic: Skilled in all kinds of work.
Polygraphic: Pertaining to, or employed in, polygraphy; as, a polygraphic instrument.
Pyruvic: Pertaining to, or designating, an acid (called also pyroracemic acid) obtained, as a liquid having a pungent odor, by the distillation of racemic acid.
Passionless: Void of passion; without anger or emotion; not easily excited; calm.
Preopercular: Situated in front of the operculum; pertaining to the preoperculum.
Pin-tailed: Having a tapered tail, with the middle feathers longest; -- said of birds.
Perpendicle: Something hanging straight down; a plumb line.
Prosimetrical: Consisting both of prose and verse.
Passiflora: A genus of plants, including the passion flower. It is the type of the order Passifloreæ, which includes about nineteen genera and two hundred and fifty species.
Parenchymatous: Of, pertaining to, or connected with, the parenchyma of a tissue or an organ; as, parenchymatous degeneration.
Pomona: The goddess of fruits and fruit trees.
Parage: Equality of condition, blood, or dignity; also, equality in the partition of an inheritance.
patched: Mended, usually clumsily by covering a hole with a patch; as, patched jeans.
Pig-jawed: Having the upper jaw projecting beyond the lower, with the upper incisors in advance of the lower; -- said of dogs.
Piecework: Work done by the piece or job; work paid for at a rate based on the amount of work done, rather than on the time employed.
Personable: Having a well-formed body, or person; graceful; comely; of good appearance; presentable; as, a personable man or woman.
Pronunciatory: Of or pertaining to pronunciation; that pronounces.
Peacebreaker: One who disturbs the public peace.
Pilgrim: To journey; to wander; to ramble.
Polymeniscous: Having numerous facets; -- said of the compound eyes of insects and crustaceans.
Plowfoot: An adjustable staff formerly attached to the plow beam to determine the depth of the furrow.
Presence: The state of being present, or of being within sight or call, or at hand; -- opposed to absence.
Pretypify: To prefigure; to exhibit previously in a type.
Propionyl: The hypothetical radical C3H5O, regarded as the essential residue of propionic acid and certain related compounds.
Praise-meeting: A religious service mainly in song.
Publishable: Capable of being published; suitable for publication.
Petalism: A form of sentence among the ancient Syracusans by which they banished for five years a citizen suspected of having dangerous influence or ambition. It was similar to the ostracism in Athens; but olive leaves were used instead of shells for ballots.
Panton: A horseshoe to correct a narrow, hoofbound heel.
Prytanis: A member of one of the ten sections into which the Athenian senate of five hundred was divided, and to each of which belonged the presidency of the senate for about one tenth of the year.
Ptosis: Drooping of the upper eyelid, produced by paralysis of its levator muscle.
Postfact: A fact that occurs after another.
Pavon: A small triangular flag, esp. one attached to a knight's lance; a pennon.
Pulmonata: An extensive division, or sub-class, of hermaphrodite gastropods, in which the mantle cavity is modified into an air-breathing organ, as in Helix, or land snails, Limax, or garden slugs, and many pond snails, as Limnæa and Planorbis.
Paxillus: One of a peculiar kind of spines covering the surface of certain starfishes.  They are pillarlike, with a flattened summit which is covered with minute spinules or granules. See Illustration in Appendix.
Plucker: One who, or that which, plucks.
Psephism: A proposition adopted by a majority of votes; especially, one adopted by vote of the Athenian people; a statute.
Pleuro-: A combining form denoting relation to a side; specif., connection with, or situation in or near, the pleura; as, pleuroperitoneum.
palimony: a form of alimony paid to a former partner in a romantic relationship after a period of living together, even though the two persons involved were not married to each other.  The absence of a formal marriage distinguishes it from alimony.
Pure: Separate from all heterogeneous or extraneous matter; free from mixture or combination; clean; mere; simple; unmixed; as, pure water; pure clay; pure air; pure compassion.
Persulphide: A sulphide containing more sulphur than some other compound of the same elements; as, iron pyrites is a persulphide; -- formerly called persulphuret.
Polygonaceous: Of or pertaining to a natural order of apetalous plants (Polygonaceæ), of which the knotweeds (species of Polygonum) are the type, and which includes also the docks (Rumex), the buckwheat, rhubarb, sea grape (Coccoloba), and several other genera.
Playbill: A printed programme of a play, with the parts assigned to the actors.
Pibroch: A Highland air, suited to the particular passion which the musician would either excite or assuage; generally applied to those airs that are played on the bagpipe before the Highlanders when they go out to battle.
Parallel sulcus: A sulcus parallel to, but some distance below, the horizontal limb of the fissure of Sylvius.
Paraclete: An advocate; one called to aid or support; hence, the Consoler, Comforter, or Intercessor; -- a term applied to the Holy Spirit.
Piney: A term used in designating an East Indian tree (the Vateria Indica or piney tree, of the order Dipterocarpeæ, which grows in Malabar, etc.) or its products.
Pleuron: One of the sides of an animal.
Pusher: One who, or that which, pushes.
Paction: An agreement; a compact; a bargain.
Pawnees: A tribe of Indians (called also Loups) who formerly occupied the region of the Platte river, but now (1890) live mostly in the Indian Territory (Oklahoma).  The term is often used in a wider sense to include also the related tribes of Rickarees and Wichitas.  Called also Pani.
Paeoniaceae: A natural family of perennial rhizomatous herbs and shrubs, native to temperate Europe and North America.
Petty: Little; trifling; inconsiderable; also, inferior; subordinate; as, a petty fault; a petty prince.
Pyrogallic: Pertaining to, derived from, or designating, an acid called pyrogallol. See Pyrogallol.
Pharmacist: One skilled in pharmacy; a pharmaceutist; a druggist.
Polonium: A radioactive chemical element, discovered by M. and MMe. Curie in pitchblende, and originally called radium F.  It has atomic number 84 and an atomic weight of 210.  It is a very rare natural element, having an abundance in uranium ores only 0.2% that of radium.  It is closely related chemically to bismuth. It emits only alpha rays, and has a half-life of 138 days.  It is thus more unstable than radium, and a milligram of polonium emits as many alpha particles as 5 grams of radium.  Twenty-seven isotopes are known, with atomic masses from 192 to 218. At present a more practical method of preparation than isolation from ores is the preparation by neutron bombardment of bismuth in a nuclear reactor, and it may be obtained commercially by users having an appropriate permit.
Physiologist: One who is versed in the science of physiology; a student of the properties and functions of animal and vegetable organs and tissues.
Paramalic: Pertaining to, or designating, an organic acid metameric with malic acid.
Preternaturalism: The state of being preternatural; a preternatural condition.
Promanation: The act of flowing forth; emanation; efflux.
Prism glass: Glass with one side smooth and the other side formed into sharp-edged ridges so as to reflect the light that passes through, used at windows to throw the light into the interior.
Pustule: A vesicle or an elevation of the cuticle with an inflamed base, containing pus.
Prosphysis: A growing together of parts; specifically, a morbid adhesion of the eyelids to each other or to the eyeball.
Plane-parallel: Having opposite surfaces exactly plane and parallel, as a piece of glass.
pennycress: Any of several plants of the genus Thlaspi; see penny cress.
Pelicosauria: A suborder of Theromorpha, including terrestrial reptiles from the Permian formation.
Proselyte: To convert to some religion, opinion, or system; to bring over.
phony: something or someone that is phony.
Paprika: The dried ripened fruit of Capsicum annuum or various other species of pepper; also, the mildly pungent condiment prepared from it.
Puffery: The act of puffing; bestowment of extravagant commendation.
Perceiver: One who perceives (in any of the senses of the verb).
Pauperism: The state of being a pauper; the state of indigent persons requiring support from the community.
Parthenic: Of or pertaining to the Spartan Partheniæ, or sons of unmarried women.
Painting: The act or employment of laying on, or adorning with, paints or colors.
Portliness: The quality or state of being portly; dignity of mien or of personal appearance; stateliness.
Panada: Bread boiled in water to the consistence of pulp, and sweetened or flavored.
Pelecanidae: A natural family of birds consisting of the pelicans.
Poem: A metrical composition; a composition in verse written in certain measures, whether in blank verse or in rhyme, and characterized by imagination and poetic diction; -- contradistinguished from prose; as, the poems of Homer or of Milton.
Pullus: A chick; a young bird in the downy stage.
paparazzo: A free-lance photographer that specializes in following and photographing celebrities such as movie stars, especially to obtain candid photographs in private situations; as, her dogged pursuit by the paparazzi was believed to be a major factor in Princess Diana's death.
Paschal: Of or pertaining to the passover, or to Easter; as, a paschal lamb; paschal eggs.
Probative: Serving for trial or proof; probationary; as, probative judgments; probative evidence.
Poet: One skilled in making poetry; one who has a particular genius for metrical composition; the author of a poem; an imaginative thinker or writer.
Pianist: A performer, esp. a skilled performer, on the piano.
Plagiarize: To steal or purloin from the writings of another; to appropriate without due acknowledgement (the ideas or expressions of another).
Pseudohalter: One of the rudimentary front wings of certain insects (Stylops).  They resemble the halteres, or rudimentary hind wings, of Diptera.
Pegasean: Of or pertaining to Pegasus, or, figuratively, to poetry.
Pratique: Primarily, liberty of converse; intercourse; hence, a certificate, given after compliance with quarantine regulations, permitting a ship to land passengers and crew; -- a term used particularly in the south of Europe.
Postanal: Situated behind, or posterior to, the anus.
Psychologist: One who is versed in, devoted to, psychology.
Poverty: The quality or state of being poor or indigent; want or scarcity of means of subsistence; indigence; need.
Prophecy: A declaration of something to come; a foretelling; a prediction; esp., an inspired foretelling.
Patrocination: The act of patrocinating or patronizing.
Pyracanth: The evergreen thorn (Cratægus Pyracantha), a shrub native of Europe.
Proximately: In a proximate manner, position, or degree; immediately.
Pustular: Of or pertaining to pustules; as, pustular prominences; pustular eruptions.
Proviso: An article or clause in any statute, agreement, contract, grant, or other writing, by which a condition is introduced, usually beginning with the word provided; a conditional stipulation that affects an agreement, contract, law, grant, or the like; as, the contract was impaired by its proviso.
Polygalaceous: Of or pertaining to a natural order of plants (Polygalaceæ) of which Polygala is the type.
Philo-: A combining form from Gr. fi`los loving, fond of, attached to; as, philosophy, philotechnic.
Polyonym: An object which has a variety of names.
Perspiration: The act or process of perspiring.
Prosecutable: Capable of being prosecuted; liable to prosecution.
Parkeria: A genus of large arenaceous fossil Foraminifera found in the Cretaceous rocks.  The species are globular, or nearly so, and are of all sizes up to that of a tennis ball.
Pilferer: One who pilfers; a petty thief.
Pimpinel: The burnet saxifrage. See under Saxifrage.
Plowboy: A boy that drives or guides a team in plowing; a young rustic.
Piliferous: Bearing a single slender bristle, or hair.
Partisan: A kind of halberd or pike; also, a truncheon; a staff.
Proficient: Well advanced in any branch of knowledge or skill; possessed of considerable acquirements; well-skilled; versed; adept,
Paramere: One of the symmetrical halves of any one of the radii, or spheromeres, of a radiate animal, as a starfish.
Premeditation: The act of meditating or contriving beforehand; previous deliberation; forethought.
Palmar: Pertaining to, or corresponding with, the palm of the hand.
Palmae: A natural family of chiefly tropical trees and shrubs; same as Palmaceae; coextensive with the order Palmales.
Plastron: A piece of leather stuffed or padded, worn by fencers to protect the breast.
Primitial: Being of the first production; primitive; original.
Pleurotoma: Any marine gastropod belonging to Pleurotoma, and ether allied genera of the family Pleurotmidæ. The species are very numerous, especially in tropical seas. The outer lip has usually a posterior notch or slit.
Platypus: The duck mole. See under Duck.
Pantascopic: Viewing all; taking a view of the whole. See under Camera.
Prevenience: The act of going before; anticipation.
Pyrone: An unsaturated cyclic compound, C5H4O2, of which two varieties are known, α and γ. γ-pyrone is the parent substance of several natural yellow dyestuffs.
Plano-horizontal: Having a level horizontal surface or position.
Prorogation: The act of counting in duration; prolongation.
Pimelite: An apple-green mineral having a greasy feel.  It is a hydrous silicate of nickel, magnesia, aluminia, and iron.
Postiler: One who writers marginal notes; one who illustrates the text of a book by notes in the margin.
Palmite: A South African plant (Prionium Palmita) of the Rush family, having long serrated leaves.  The stems have been used for making brushes.
Piddling: Trifling; trivial; frivolous; paltry; -- applied to persons and things.
pan out: To succeed; as, the project didn't pan out.
Psychography: A description of the phenomena of mind.
Porotype: A copy of a print, writing, etc., made by placing it upon a chemically prepared paper which is acted upon by a gas which permeates the paper of the print, writing, etc.
Pitchwork: The work of a coal miner who is paid by a share of his product.
Paladin: A knight-errant; a distinguished champion; as, the paladins of Charlemagne.
Plunge: The act of thrusting into or submerging; a dive, leap, rush, or pitch into, or as into, water; as, to take the water with a plunge.
Pityriasis: A superficial affection of the skin, characterized by irregular patches of thin scales which are shed in branlike particles.
Possibility: The quality or state of being possible; the power of happening, being, or existing.
Psylla: Any leaping plant louse of the genus Psylla, or family Psyllidæ.
Peripatetic: One who walks about; a pedestrian; an itinerant.
Polypoid: Like a polyp; having the nature of a polyp, but lacking the tentacles or other parts.
Permittee: One to whom a permission or permit is given.
Preyer: One who, or that which, preys; a plunderer; a waster; a devourer.
Pharmaceutist: One skilled in pharmacy; a druggist. See the Note under Apothecary.
Phrasing: Method of expression; association of words.
P\u00e9troleur: One who makes use of petroleum for incendiary purposes.
Polyneme: Any one of numerous species of tropical food fishes of the family Polynemidæ. They have several slender filaments, often very long, below the pectoral fin. Some of them yield isinglass of good quality. Called also threadfish.
Pasha: An honorary title given to officers of high rank in Turkey, as to governers of provinces, military commanders, etc. The earlier form was bashaw.
Punt-out: A punt made from the goal line by a player of the side which has made a touchdown to one of his own side for a fair catch, from which an attempt to kick a goal may be made.
Ptomaine: One of a class of animal bases or alkaloids formed in the putrefaction of various kinds of albuminous matter, and closely related to the vegetable alkaloids; a cadaveric poison. The ptomaines, as a class, have their origin in dead matter, by which they are to be distinguished from the leucomaines.
Priorate: The dignity, office, or government, of a prior.
Pectoriloquy: The distinct articulation of the sounds of a patient's voice, heard on applying the ear to the chest in auscultation.  It usually indicates some morbid change in the lungs or pleural cavity.
Placentiform: Having the shape of a placenta, or circular thickened disk somewhat thinner about the middle.
Parlor: A room for business or social conversation, for the reception of guests, etc.
Parseeism: The religion and customs of the Parsees.
Piston: A sliding piece which either is moved by, or moves against, fluid pressure. It usually consists of a short cylinder fitting within a cylindrical vessel along which it moves, back and forth. It is used in steam engines to receive motion from the steam, and in pumps to transmit motion to a fluid; also for other purposes.
Parallelogrammic: Having the properties of a parallelogram.
Peltiform: Shieldlike, with the outline nearly circular; peltate.
Puzzlement: The state of being puzzled; perplexity.
pabulum: The means of nutriment to animals or plants; food; nourishment.
Progressive party: The political party formed, chiefly out of the Republican party, by the adherents of Theodore Roosevelt in the presidential campaign of 1912. The name Progressive party was chosen at the meeting held on Aug. 7, 1912, when the candidates were nominated and the platform adopted.  It was also known as the Bull Moose Party. Among the chief articles in the platform are those demanding direct primaries, preferential primaries for presidential nominations, direct election of United States senators, women's suffrage, and recall of judicial decisions in certain cases.  In 1924 the label was also adopted by the party supporting the presidential campaign of Robert M. La Follette, and in 1948 it was also adopted by the party of Henry Wallace.  The party is no longer (1998) considered a force in U. S. national politics.
Pitcher: A wide-mouthed, deep vessel for holding liquids, with a spout or protruding lip and a handle; a water jug or jar with a large ear or handle.
Pomander: A perfume to be carried with one, often in the form of a ball.
Phloretin: A bitter white crystalline substance obtained by the decomposition of phlorizin, and formerly used to some extent as a substitute for quinine.
Phloretic: Pertaining to, or derived from, or designating, an organic acid obtained by the decomposition of phloretin.
Puritanism: The doctrines, notions, or practice of Puritans.
Physiology: The science which treats of the phenomena of living organisms; the study of the processes incidental to, and characteristic of, life.
Pyromorphite: Native lead phosphate with lead chloride, occurring in bright green and brown hexagonal crystals and also massive; -- so called because a fused globule crystallizes in cooling.
Pancreas: The sweetbread, a gland connected with the intestine of nearly all vertebrates. It is usually elongated and light-colored, and its secretion, called the pancreatic juice, is discharged, often together with the bile, into the upper part of the intestines, and is a powerful aid in digestion. See Illust. of Digestive apparatus.
Peacock: The male of any pheasant of the genus Pavo, of which at least two species are known, native of Southern Asia and the East Indies.
Phosphor-bronze: A variety of bronze possessing great hardness, elasticity, and toughness, obtained by melting copper with tin phosphide. It contains one or two per cent of phosphorus and from five to fifteen per cent of tin.
Pyrocoll: A yellow crystalline substance allied to pyrrol, obtained by the distillation of gelatin.
Premature: Mature or ripe before the proper time; as, the premature fruits of a hotbed.
Patrol: A going of the rounds along the chain of sentinels and between the posts, by a guard, usually consisting of three or four men, to insure greater security from attacks on the outposts.
Pilular: Of or pertaining to pills; resembling a pill or pills; as, a pilular mass.
Pock-pudding: A bag pudding; a name of reproach or ridicule formerly applied by the Scotch to the English.
Precognosce: To examine beforehand, as witnesses or evidence.
Permittance: The act of permitting; allowance; permission; leave.
Pressirostral: Of or pertaining to the pressirosters.
Plano-convex: Plane or flat on one side, and convex on the other; as, a plano-convex lens. See Convex, and Lens.
Psychologic: Of or pertaining to psychology. See Note under Psychic.
Pellibranchiata: A division of Nudibranchiata, in which the mantle itself serves as a gill.
Penwiper: A cloth, or other material, for wiping off or cleaning ink from a pen.
Pellucidity: The quality or state of being pellucid; transparency; translucency; clearness; as, the pellucidity of the air.
p\u00e6dogenesis: Reproduction by young or larval animals.
Photosphere: A sphere of light; esp., the luminous envelope of the sun.
Palindromic: Of, pertaining to, or like, a palindrome.
Presystolic: Preceding the systole or contraction of the heart; as, the presystolic friction sound.
Picot: One of many small loops, as of thread, forming an ornamental border, as on a ribbon.
Pathless: Having no beaten path or way; untrodden; impenetrable; as, pathless woods.
Phosphinic: Pertaining to, or designating, certain acids analogous to the phosphonic acids, but containing two hydrocarbon radicals, and derived from the secondary phosphines by oxidation.
Placenta: The vascular appendage which connects the fetus with the parent, and is cast off in parturition with the afterbirth.
Parasita: An artificial group formerly made for parasitic insects, as lice, ticks, mites, etc.
Priestess: A woman who officiated in sacred rites among pagans.
Paced: Having, or trained in, [such] a pace or gait; trained; -- used in composition; as, slow-paced; a thorough-paced villain.
Presswork: The art of printing from the surface of type, plates, or engravings in relief, by means of a press; the work so done.
Primum mobile: In the Ptolemaic system, the outermost of the revolving concentric spheres constituting the universe, the motion of which was supposed to carry with it all the inclosed spheres with their planets in a daily revolution from east to west. See Crystalline heavens, under Crystalline.
Panoistic: Producing ova only; -- said of the ovaries of certain insects which do not produce vitelligenous cells.
Portcrayon: A metallic handle with a clasp for holding a crayon.
Perichordal: Around the notochord; as, a perichordal column. See Epichordal.
Promisee: The person to whom a promise is made.
Playwriter: A writer of plays; a dramatist; a playwright.
Perpetuable: Capable of being perpetuated or continued.
Passionist: A member of a religious order founded in Italy in 1737, and introduced into the United States in 1852.  The members of the order unite the austerities of the Trappists with the activity and zeal of the Jesuits and Lazarists.  Called also Barefooted Clerks of the Most Holy Cross.
Proctorship: The office or dignity of a proctor; also, the term of his office.
Presbyope: One who has presbyopia; a farsighted person.
Pernyi moth: A silk-producing moth (Attacus Pernyi) which feeds upon the oak. It has been introduced into Europe and America from China.
Populace: The common people; the vulgar; the multitude, -- comprehending all persons not distinguished by rank, office, education, or profession.
Pectoral: A covering or protecting for the breast.
Purgery: The part of a sugarhouse where the molasses is drained off from the sugar.
Prorogue: To protract; to prolong; to extend.
Pronominally: In a pronominal manner&unr_; with the nature or office of a pronoun; as a pronoun.
Postponement: The act of postponing; a deferring, or putting off, to a future time; a temporary delay.
Passegarde: A ridge or projecting edge on a shoulder piece to turn the blow of a lance or other weapon from the joint of the armor.
Passifloraceae: A natural family of tropical woody tendril-climbing vines.
Penetrate: To pass; to make way; to pierce. Also used figuratively.
Polypean: Of or pertaining to a polyp, or polyps.
Palolo: A polystome worm (Palolo viridis) that burrows in the coral reefs of certain of the Pacific Islands.  A little before the last quarter of the moon in October and November, they swarm in vast numbers at the surface of the sea for breeding, and are gathered and highly esteemed as food by the natives.  An allied species inhabits the tropical Atlantic and swarms in June or July.
Perfuncturate: To perform in a perfunctory manner; to do negligently.
Pithecoid: Of or pertaining to the genus Pithecia, or subfamily Pithecinæ, which includes the saki, ouakari, and other allied South American monkeys.
Preoral: Situated in front of, or anterior to, the mouth; as, preoral bands.
Pagan: Of or pertaining to pagans; relating to the worship or the worshipers of false goods; heathen; idolatrous, as, pagan tribes or superstitions.
pacifism: the doctrine that all violence is unjustifiable.
Pseudo-: A combining form or prefix signifying false, counterfeit, pretended, spurious; as, pseudo-apostle, a false apostle; pseudo-clergy, false or spurious clergy; pseudo-episcopacy, pseudo-form, pseudo-martyr, pseudo-philosopher. Also used adjectively.
pacifist: Adhering to pacifism; opposed to war; -- of people.
Previousness: The quality or state of being previous; priority or antecedence in time.
Per: Through; by means of; through the agency of; by; for; for each; as, per annum; per capita, by heads, or according to individuals; per curiam, by the court; per se, by itself, of itself.  Per is also sometimes used with English words.
Pes: The distal segment of the hind limb of vertebrates, including the tarsus and foot.
Pen: A small inclosure; as, a pen for sheep or for pigs.
Paracelsus: Philippus Aureolus Paracelsus (originally Theophrastus Bombastus von Hohenheim, also called Theophrastus Paracelsus and Theophrastus von Hohenheim).  Born at Maria-Einsiedeln, in the Canton of Schwyz, Switzerland, Dec. 17 (or 10 Nov.), 1493: died at Salzburg, Sept. 23 (or 24), 1541.  A celebrated German-Swiss physician, reformer of therapeutics, iatrochemist, and alchemist.  He attended school in a small lead-mining district where his father, William Bombast von Hohenheim, was a physician and teacher of alchemy.  The family originally came from Würtemberg, where the noble family of Bombastus was in possession of the ancestral castle of Hohenheim near Stuttgart until 1409.  He entered the University of Basel at the age of sixteen, where he adopted the name Paracelsus, after Celsius, a noted Roman physician.  But he left without a degree, first going to Wurtzburg to study under Joannes Trithemius, Abbot of Sponheim (1462-1516), a famous astrologer and alchemist, who initiated him into the mysteries of alchemy.  He then spent many years in travel and intercourse with distinguished scholars, studied and practiced medicine and surgery, and at one point attended the Diet of Worms.  He was appointed to the office of city physician of Basel, which also made him a lecturer on medicine at Basel about 1526, where, through the publisher Johan Frobenius he made friends with the scholar Erasmus; and there he fulminated against the medical pseudo-science of his day, and against the blind adherence to ancient medical authorities such as Hippocrates, Galen, and Avicenna, which was still the prevalent philosophy of medicine in the sixteenth century.  But soon, in 1528, he was driven from the city by the medical corporations, whose methods he had severely criticized.  He found refuge with friends, and traveled and practiced medicine, but could not find a publisher willing to print his books.  He preached frequently the need for experimentation in medicine.  He is important in the history of medicine chiefly on account of the impetus which he gave to the development of pharmaceutical chemistry.  He was also the author of a visionary and theosophic system of philosophy.  The first collective edition of his works appeared at Basel in 1589-91.  Among the many legends concerning him is that concerning his long sword, which he obtained while serving as barber-surgeon during the Neapolitan wars.  It was rumored that in the hilt of the sword he kept a familiar or small demon; some thought he carried the elixer of life in the sword.  He is buried in the cemetary of the Hospital of St. Sebastian in Salzburg.  For more detailed information about Paracelsus, there is a special project, the Zurich Paracelsus Project available on the Web.
Ped: A basket; a hammer; a pannier.
Pee: Bill of an anchor. See Peak, 3 (c).
Peg: To work diligently, as one who pegs shoes; -- usually with on, at, or away; as, to peg away at a task.
Pea: A plant, and its fruit, of the genus Pisum, of many varieties, much cultivated for food.  It has a papilionaceous flower, and the pericarp is a legume, popularly called a pod.
Perceive: To obtain knowledge of through the senses; to receive impressions from by means of the bodily organs; to take cognizance of the existence, character, or identity of, by means of the senses; to see, hear, or feel; as, to perceive a distant ship; to perceive a discord.
Palanka: A camp permanently intrenched, attached to Turkish frontier fortresses.
Petitionarily: By way of begging the question; by an assumption.
Perspicacity: The state of being perspicacious; acuteness of sight or of intelligence; acute discernment.
Parvoline: A liquid base, C9H13N, of the pyridine group, found in coal tar; also, any one of the series of isomeric substances of which it is the type.
Parochialize: To render parochial; to form into parishes.
Producers surplus: Any profit above the normal rate of interest and wages accruing to a producer on account of some monopoly (temporary or permanent) of the means or materials of production; -- called also Producer's rent.
Precocious: Ripe or mature before the proper or natural time; early or prematurely ripe or developed; as, precocious trees.
Populism: The political doctrines advocated by the People's party.
Pyrethrine: An alkaloid extracted from the root of the pellitory of Spain (Anacyclus pyrethrum).
Pyrochlore: A niobate of calcium, cerium, and other bases, occurring usually in octahedrons of a yellowish or brownish color and resinous luster; -- so called from its becoming grass-green on being subjected to heat under the blowpipe.
Predigestion: Digestion too soon performed; hasty digestion.
Plexus: A network of vessels, nerves, or fibers.
peacenik: someone who prefers negotiations to armed conflict in the conduct of foreign relations.
Pigmental: Of or pertaining to pigments; furnished with pigments.
participating: Taking part in an activity; as, the participating organizations.
Pretension: The act of pretending, or laying claim; the act of asserting right or title.
Pyrophosphoric: Pertaining to, or designating, an acid, H4P2O7, which is obtained as a white crystalline substance. Its salts are obtained by heating the phosphates.
Pyrovanadic: Pertaining to, or designating, an acid of vanadium, analogous to pyrophosphoric acid.
Penciled: Painted, drawn, sketched, or marked with a pencil.
Pilfer: To take by petty theft; to filch; to steal little by little.
Platyelminthes: A class of helminthes including the cestodes, or tapeworms, the trematodes, and the turbellarians. Called also flatworms.
Publicity: The quality or state of being public, or open to the knowledge of a community; notoriety; publicness.
Puppetman: A master of a puppet show.
Paregoric: A medicine that mitigates pain; an anodyne; specifically, camphorated tincture of opium; -- called also paregoric elexir.
Pungent: Causing a sharp sensation, as of the taste, smell, or feelings; pricking; biting; acrid; as, a pungent spice.
Phosphorus steel: A steel in which the amount of phosphorus exceeds that of carbon.
Postexist: To exist after; to live subsequently.
Papaveraceous: Of, pertaining to, or resembling, a natural family of plants (Papaveraceae) of which the poppy, the celandine, and the bloodroot are well-known examples.
Plong\u00e9e: A slope or sloping toward the front; as, the plongée of a parapet; the plongée of a shell in its course.
Prore: The prow or fore part of a ship.
Peragration: The act or state of passing through any space; as, the peragration of the moon in her monthly revolution.
Picotee: A variety of carnation having petals of a light color variously dotted and spotted at the edges.
Paridigitate: Having an even number of digits on the hands or the feet.
Pinch: A close compression, as with the ends of the fingers, or with an instrument; a nip.
Pseud\u00e6sthesia: False or imaginary feeling or sense perception such as occurs in hypochondriasis, or such as is referred to an organ that has been removed, as an amputated foot.
Providentness: The quality or state of being provident; carefulness; prudence; economy.
pallah: A large South African antelope (Æpyceros melampus).  The male has long lyrate and annulated horns.  The general color is bay, with a black crescent on the croup.  Called also roodebok.
Phenalgin: An ammoniated compound of phenyl and acetamide, used as an analgesic and antipyretic. It resembles phenacetin in its therapeutic action.
Porpoise: Any small cetacean of the genus Phocæna, especially Phocæna communis, or Phocæna phocæna, of Europe, and the closely allied American species (Phocæna Americana).  The color is dusky or blackish above, paler beneath.  They are closely allied to the dolphins, but have a shorter snout.  Called also harbor porpoise, herring hag, puffing pig, and snuffer.
Proscription: The act of proscribing; a dooming to death or exile; outlawry; specifically, among the ancient Romans, the public offer of a reward for the head of a political enemy; as, under the triumvirate, many of the best Roman citizens fell by proscription.
Pissasphalt: Earth pitch; a soft, black bitumen of the consistency of tar, and of a strong smell. It is inflammable, and intermediate between petroleum and asphalt.
Pospolite: A kind of militia in Poland, consisting of the gentry, which, in case of invasion, was summoned to the defense of the country.
Photochromic: Of or pertaining to photochromy; produced by photochromy.
patinate: to coat with a patina; to patinize.
Pouch: To put or take into a pouch.
Pugh: Pshaw! pish! -- a word used in contempt or disdain.
Polypodium: A genus of plants of the order Filices or ferns. The fructifications are in uncovered roundish points, called sori, scattered over the inferior surface of the frond or leaf. There are numerous species.
Prensation: The act of seizing with violence.
Pinnatiped: Any bird which has the toes bordered by membranes.
Papistry: The doctrine and ceremonies of the Church of Rome; popery.
Pinnywinkles: An instrument of torture, consisting of a board with holes into which the fingers were pressed, and fastened with pegs.
Parallelogrammatic: Of or pertaining to a parallelogram; parallelogrammic.
Primogeniture: The state of being the firstborn of the same parents; seniority by birth among children of the same family.
Pliform: In the form of a ply, fold, or doubling.
pathology: The science which treats of diseases, their nature, causes, progress, symptoms, etc.
Predy: Cleared and ready for engagement, as a ship.
Parostosis: Ossification which takes place in purely fibrous tracts; the formation of bone outside of the periosteum.
Paraplegia: Palsy of the lower half of the body on both sides, caused usually by disease of the spinal cord.
Parsimonious: Exhibiting parsimony; sparing in expenditure of money; frugal to excess; penurious; niggardly; stingy.
Polybasite: An iron-black ore of silver, consisting of silver, sulphur, and antimony, with some copper and arsenic.
Poignancy: The quality or state of being poignant; as, the poignancy of satire; the poignancy of grief.
Prestidigital: Nimble-fingered; having fingers fit for prestidigitation, or juggling.
Pottery: The vessels or ware made by potters; earthenware, glazed and baked.
papaya: A tree (Carica Papaya) of tropical America, belonging to the order Passifloreæ; called also papaw and pawpaw.  It has a soft, spongy stem, eighteen or twenty feet high, crowned with a tuft of large, long-stalked, palmately lobed leaves.  The milky juice of the plant is said to have the property of making meat tender.
Pin-fire: Having a firing pin to explode the cartridge; as, a pin-fire rifle.
Plicature: A fold; a doubling; a plication.
Patron: Doing the duty of a patron; giving aid or protection; tutelary.
Petalosticha: An order of Echini, including the irregular sea urchins, as the spatangoids. See Spatangoid.
Pedestrian: A walker; one who journeys on foot; a foot traveler; specif., a professional walker or runner.
Pedestrial: Of or pertaining to the feet; employing the foot or feet.
Prognosticate: To indicate as future; to foretell from signs or symptoms; to prophesy; to foreshow; to predict; as, to prognosticate evil.
Pyromantic: One who pretends to divine by fire.
Perturbable: Liable to be perturbed or agitated; liable to be disturbed or disquieted.
Prima donna: The first or chief female singer in an opera.
Pterotic: Of or pertaining to, or designating, a bone between the proötic and epiotic in the dorsal and outer part of the periotic capsule of many fishes.
Par\u00e1 rubber: The caoutchouc obtained from the South American euphorbiaceous tree Hevea brasiliensis, hence called the Pará rubber tree, from the Brazilian river and seaport named Pará; also, the similar product of other species of Hevea.  It is usually exported in flat round cakes, and is a chief variety of commercial India rubber.
Pinked: Pierced with small holes; worked in eyelets; scalloped on the edge.
Plural: The plural number; that form of a word which expresses or denotes more than one; a word in the plural form.
Persulphate: A sulphate of the peroxide of any base.
Pollenize: To supply with pollen; to impregnate with pollen.
patching: The act of mending a hole in a garment by sewing a patch over it.
Philanthropist: One who practices philanthropy; one who loves mankind, and seeks to promote the good of others.
Paleog\u00e6an: Of or pertaining to the Eastern hemisphere.
Perdu: Lost to view; in concealment or ambush; close.
Pestalozzianism: The system of education introduced by Pestalozzi.
Proxenetism: The action of a go-between or broker in negotiating immoral bargains between the sexes; procuring.
Pagurus: The type genus of the crustacean family Paguridae.
Photologist: One who studies or expounds the laws of light.
Parishioner: One who belongs to, or is connected with, a parish.
Proatlas: A vertebral rudiment in front of the atlas in some reptiles.
Phonolite: A compact, feldspathic, igneous rock containing nephelite, haüynite, etc. Thin slabs give a ringing sound when struck; -- called also clinkstone.
Parakite: A train or series of kites on one string and flying tandem, used for attaining great heights and for sending up instruments for meteorological observations or a man for military reconnaissance; also, a kite of such a train.
Pupation: the act of becoming a pupa.
Paramiographer: A collector or writer of proverbs.
Pedata: An order of holothurians, including those that have ambulacral suckers, or feet, and an internal gill.
Pedate: Palmate, with the lateral lobes cleft into two or more segments; -- said of a leaf.
Phocodontia: A group of extinct carnivorous whales.  Their teeth had compressed and serrated crowns.  It includes Squalodon and allied genera.
Persiennes: Window blinds having movable slats, similar to Venetian blinds.
Pathway: A footpath; a beaten track; any path or course. Also used figuratively.
Panax: A genus of perennial herbs of eastern North America and Asia having aromatic tuberous roots: ginseng.
Pookoo: A red African antelope (Kobus Vardoni) allied to the water buck.
Preventability: The quality or state of being preventable.
Pentamethylene: A hypothetical hydrocarbon, C5H10, metameric with the amylenes, and the nucleus of a large number of derivatives; -- so named because regarded as composed of five methylene residues.  Cf. Trimethylene, and Tetramethylene.
Pinguefaction: A making of, or turning into, fat.
Punka: A machine for fanning a room, usually a movable fanlike frame covered with canvas, and suspended from the ceiling. It is kept in motion by pulling a cord.
Penurious: Excessively sparing in the use of money; sordid; stingy; miserly.
Pelota: A Basque, Spanish, and Spanish-American game played in a court, in which a ball is struck with a wickerwork racket.
PBS: Phosphate-buffered saline, a normal saline solution containing a phosphate buffer.
Paraglossa: One of a pair of small appendages of the lingua or labium of certain insects. See Illust. under Hymenoptera.
Perfidiousness: The quality of being perfidious; perfidy.
Polarity: That quality or condition of a body in virtue of which it exhibits opposite, or contrasted, properties or powers, in opposite, or contrasted, parts or directions; or a condition giving rise to a contrast of properties corresponding to a contrast of positions, as, for example, attraction and repulsion in the opposite parts of a magnet, the dissimilar phenomena corresponding to the different sides of a polarized ray of light, etc.
Principally: In a principal manner; primarily; above all; chiefly; mainly.
Phylarchy: The office of a phylarch; government of a class or tribe.
Physiolatry: The worship of the powers or agencies of nature; materialism in religion; nature worship.
Prurience: The quality or state of being prurient.
Pencel: A small, narrow flag or streamer borne at the top of a lance; -- called also pennoncel.
Provided: On condition; by stipulation; with the understanding; if; -- usually followed by that; as, provided that nothing in this act shall prejudice the rights of any person whatever.
puzzle: To perplex; to confuse; to embarrass; to put to a stand; to nonplus.
Psoas: An internal muscle arising from the lumbar vertebræ and inserted into the femur. In man there are usually two on each side, and the larger one, or great psoas, forms a part of the iliopsoas.
Papaverous: Of or pertaining to the poppy; of the nature of the poppy.
Provider: One who provides, furnishes, or supplies; one who procures what is wanted.
Pneumonophora: The division of Siphonophora which includes the Physalia and allied genera; -- called also Pneumatophoræ.
Patchy: Full of, or covered with, patches; abounding in patches.
Pinole: An aromatic powder used in Italy in the manufacture of chocolate.
Pentateuch: The first five books of the Old Testament, collectively; -- called also the Law of Moses, Book of the Law of Moses, etc.
Proximate: Nearest; next immediately preceding or following.
Presentive: Bringing a conception or notion directly before the mind; presenting an object to the memory of imagination; -- distinguished from symbolic.
Peplum: A peplos. Hence: An overskirt hanging like an ancient peplos; also, a short fitted skirt attached to a waist or coat.
Pernicious: Having the quality of injuring or killing; destructive; very mischievous; baleful; malicious; wicked.
Peplus: An upper garment worn by Grecian and Roman women.
Protosomite: One of the primitive segments, or metameres, of an animal.
Pyrgom: A variety of pyroxene; -- called also fassaite.
Pandurate: Obovate, with a concavity in each side, like the body of a violin; fiddle-shaped; as, a panduriform leaf; panduriform color markings of an animal.
Phenomenon: An appearance; anything visible; whatever, in matter or spirit, is apparent to, or is apprehended by, observation; as, the phenomena of heat, light, or electricity; phenomena of imagination or memory.
Petro-: A combining form from Gr. pe`tra a rock, pe`tros a stone; as, petrology, petroglyphic.
Pessimism: The opinion or doctrine that everything in nature is ordered for or tends to the worst, or that the world is wholly evil; -- opposed to optimism.
Pessimist: Of or pertaining to pessimism; characterized by pessimism; gloomy; foreboding.
panicky: Same as panic-stricken; as, the travellers became panicky as the snow deepened.
Persulphocyanic: Pertaining to, or designating, a yellow crystalline substance (called also perthiocyanic acid), analogous to sulphocyanic acid, but containing more sulphur.
Polygenist: One who maintains that animals of the same species have sprung from more than one original pair; -- opposed to monogenist.
Pergolo: A continuous colonnade or arcade; -- applied to the decorative groups of windows, as in Venetian palazzi.
Passionateness: The state or quality of being passionate.
Polygenism: The doctrine that animals of the same species have sprung from more than one original pair.
Pedipalpous: Pertaining to, or resembling, the pedipalps.
Polysynthesis: The act or process of combining many separate elements into a whole.
Primly: In a prim or precise manner.
Pistil: The seed-bearing organ of a flower. It consists of an ovary, containing the ovules or rudimentary seeds, and a stigma, which is commonly raised on an elongated portion called a style. When composed of one carpel a pistil is simple; when composed of several, it is compound. See Illust. of Flower, and Ovary.
Polymathic: Pertaining to polymathy; acquainted with many branches of learning.
Palewise: In the manner of a pale or pales; by perpendicular lines or divisions; as, to divide an escutcheon palewise.
Plummy: Of the nature of a plum; desirable; profitable; advantageous.
Procris: Any species of small moths of the genus Procris. The larvæ of some species injure the grapevine by feeding in groups upon the leaves.
Philatelist: One versed in philately; one who collects postage stamps, as a hobby or for investment; a stamp collector.
papers: Documents providing information, esp. of an official nature about a person, vehicle, business, etc.  See paper{9}, n.
Punitive: Of or pertaining to punishment; involving, awarding, or inflicting punishment; as, punitive law or justice.
Penuchle: A game at cards, played with forty-eight cards, being all the cards above the eight spots in two packs.
Protogine: A kind of granite or gneiss containing a silvery talcose mineral.
papery: Like paper; having the thinness or consistency of paper.
Precipitantness: The quality or state of being precipitant; precipitation.
Philately: The collection of postage stamps of various issues.
Preparator: One who prepares beforehand, as subjects for dissection, specimens for preservation in collections, etc.
Perpotation: The act of drinking excessively; a drinking bout.
Pyroscope: An instrument for measuring the intensity of heat radiating from a fire, or the cooling influence of bodies. It is a differential thermometer, having one bulb coated with gold or silver leaf.
pyrrol: A nitrogenous heterocyclic base found in coal tar, bone oil, and other distillates of organic substances, and also produced synthetically as a colorless liquid, C4H5N, having on odor like that of chloroform.  It is the nucleus and origin of a large number of derivatives.  So called because it colors a splinter of wood moistened with hydrochloric acid a deep red.
Pannier: A bread basket; also, a wicker basket (used commonly in pairs) for carrying fruit or other things on a horse or an ass
pedophilia: A sexual perversion in which children rather than adults most strongly excite sexual desire, and are used as sexual partners.
Presidial: Of or pertaining to a garrison; having a garrison.
Pericope: A selection or extract from a book; especially (Theol.), a selection from the Bible, appointed to be read in the churches or used as a text for a sermon.
Pawnee: One or two whom a pledge is delivered as security; one who takes anything in pawn.
Panomphean: Uttering ominous or prophetic voices; divining.
Pawner: One who pawns or pledges anything as security for the payment of borrowed money or of a debt.
Patronization: The act of patronizing; patronage; support.
Pelusiac: Of or pertaining to Pelusium, an ancient city of Egypt; as, the Pelusiac (or former eastern) outlet of the Nile.
Proverbialist: One who makes much use of proverbs in speech or writing; one who composes, collects, or studies proverbs.
Proteles: A South Africa genus of Carnivora, allied to the hyenas, but smaller and having weaker jaws and teeth. It includes the aard-wolf.
Proface: Much good may it do you! -- a familiar salutation or welcome.
Podoscaph: A canoe-shaped float attached to the foot, for walking on water.
Plenipotentiary: Containing or conferring full power; invested with full power; as, plenipotentiary license; plenipotentiary ministers.
Pritch: A sharp-pointed instrument; also, an eelspear.
Postsphenoid: Of or pertaining to the posterior part of the sphenoid bone.
Pelvimeter: An instrument for measuring the dimensions of the pelvis.
Panhellenium: An assembly or association of Greeks from all the states of Greece.
Predicament: A class or kind described by any definite marks; hence, condition; particular situation or state; especially, an unfortunate or trying position or condition.
Postclavicle: A bone in the pectoral girdle of many fishes projecting backward from the clavicle.
Prehension: The act of taking hold, seizing, or grasping, as with the hand or other member.
Pleurodynia: A painful affection of the side, simulating pleurisy, usually due to rheumatism.
Psycho-: A combining form from Gr. psychh` the soul, the mind, the understanding; as, psychology.
Polyhedron: A body or solid contained by many sides or planes.
Phryganeides: A tribe of neuropterous insects which includes the caddice flies; -- called also Trichoptera. See Trichoptera.
Pertusion: The act of punching or piercing with a pointed instrument; as, pertusion of a vein.
Paraphysis: A minute jointed filament growing among the archegonia and antheridia of mosses, or with the spore cases, etc., of other flowerless plants.
Prelection: A lecture or discourse read in public or to a select company.
Prawn: Any one of numerous species of large shrimplike Crustacea having slender legs and long antennæ. They mostly belong to the genera Pandalus, Palæmon, Palæmonetes, and Peneus, and are much used as food. The common English prawn is Palæmon serratus.
Purely: In a pure manner (in any sense of the adjective).
Patronomatology: That branch of knowledge which deals with personal names and their origin; the study of patronymics.
Posteriority: The state of being later or subsequent; as, posteriority of time, or of an event; -- opposed to priority.
Phellogen: The tissue of young cells which produces cork cells.
Protoplasm: The viscid and more or less granular material of vegetable and animal cells, possessed of vital properties by which the processes of nutrition, secretion, and growth go forward; the so-called “ physical basis of life;” the original cell substance, cytoplasm, cytoblastema, bioplasm sarcode, etc.
Perimeter: The outer boundary of a body or figure, or the sum of all the sides.
Parabola: A kind of curve; one of the conic sections formed by the intersection of the surface of a cone with a plane parallel to one of its sides.  It is a curve, any point of which is equally distant from a fixed point, called the focus, and a fixed straight line, called the directrix.  See Focus.
-plastic: A combining form signifying developing, forming, growing; as, heteroplastic, monoplastic, polyplastic.
Pluck: The act of plucking; a pull; a twitch.
Public: The general body of mankind, or of a nation, state, or community; the people, indefinitely; as, the American public; also, a particular body or aggregation of people; as, an author's public.
Protovertebral: Of or pertaining to the protovertebræ.
Psalmodist: One who sings sacred songs; a psalmist.
Petaled: Having petals; as, a petaled flower; -- opposed to apetalous, and much used in compounds; as, one-petaled, three-petaled, etc.
Pertness: The quality or state of being pert.
Puissant: Powerful; strong; mighty; forcible; as, a puissant prince or empire.
Premorse: Terminated abruptly, or as it bitten off.
Peso: A Spanish dollar; also, an Argentine, Chilian, Colombian, etc., coin, equal to from 75 cents to a dollar; also, a pound weight.
Pest: A fatal epidemic disease; a pestilence; specif., the plague.
Polypous: Of the nature of a polypus; having many feet or roots, like the polypus; affected with polypus.
Prosit: Lit., may it do (you) good; -- a salutation used in well wishing, esp. among Germans, as in drinking healths; -- also used in the contracted form prost.
Periscian: Having the shadow moving all around.
Planarida: A division of Turbellaria; the Dendrocœla.
Punish: To impose a penalty upon; to afflict with pain, loss, or suffering for a crime or fault, either with or without a view to the offender's amendment; to cause to suffer in retribution; to chasten; as, to punish traitors with death; a father punishes his child for willful disobedience.
Poonah painting: A style of painting, popular in England in the 19th century, in which a thick opaque color is applied without background and with scarcely any shading, to thin paper, producing flowers, birds, etc., in imitation of Oriental work.
Peptotoxine: A toxic alkaloid found occasionally associated with the peptones formed from fibrin by pepsinhydrochloric acid.
Prolificness: The quality or state of being prolific; fruitfulness; prolificacy.
Physico-: A combining form, denoting relation to, or dependence upon, natural causes, or the science of physics.
Partridge: Any one of numerous species of small gallinaceous birds of the genus Perdix and several related genera of the family Perdicidæ, of the Old World.  The partridge is noted as a game bird.
Preventative: That which prevents; -- incorrectly used instead of preventive.
Presentee: One to whom something is presented; also, one who is presented; specifically (Eccl.), one presented to benefice.
Parricidal: Of or pertaining to parricide; guilty of parricide.
Phylloxanthin: A yellow coloring matter extracted from chlorophyll.
Pickpocket: One who steals purses or other articles from pockets.
Pr\u00e6cognita: This previously known, or which should be known in order to understand something else.
Photomagnetism: The branch of science which treats of the relation of magnetism to light.
Push: A crowd; a company or clique of associates; a gang.
Pseudo-monocotyledonous: Having two coalescent cotyledons, as the live oak and the horse-chestnut.
Procedure: The act or manner of proceeding or moving forward; progress; process; operation; conduct.
Postaxial: Situated behind any transverse axis in the body of an animal; caudal; posterior; especially, behind, or on the caudal or posterior (that is, ulnar or fibular) side of, the axis of a vertebrate limb.
Pneumatic: Consisting of, or resembling, air; having the properties of an elastic fluid; gaseous; opposed to dense or solid.
Porite: Any coral of the genus Porites, or family Poritidæ.
Peribranchial: Around the bronchi or bronchial tubes; as, the peribronchial lymphatics.
Pernickety: Finical or fussy; full of petty details.
Props: A game of chance, in which four sea shells, each called a prop, are used instead of dice.
Prosopop\u0153ia: A figure by which things are represented as persons, or by which things inanimate are spoken of as animated beings; also, a figure by which an absent person is introduced as speaking, or a deceased person is represented as alive and present. It includes personification, but is more extensive in its signification.
Photolithographic: Of or pertaining to photolithography; produced by photolithography.
Politicalism: Zeal or party spirit in politics.
Presumer: One who presumes; also, an arrogant person.
Parallelly: In a parallel manner; with parallelism.
Polytheism: The doctrine of, or belief in, a plurality of gods.
Pediculus: A genus of wingless parasitic Hemiptera, including the common lice of man. See Louse.
Pulverous: Consisting of dust or powder; like powder.
Parfleche: A kind of rawhide consisting of hide, esp. of the buffalo, which has been soaked in crude wood-ash lye to remove the hairs, and then dried.
Panshon: An earthen vessel wider at the top than at the bottom, -- used for holding milk and for various other purposes.
Precession: The act of going before, or forward.
Pantheology: A system of theology embracing all religions; a complete system of theology.
Pulverate: To beat or reduce to powder or dust; to pulverize.
Pelecoid: A figure, somewhat hatched-shaped, bounded by a semicircle and two inverted quadrants, and equal in area to the square ABCD inclosed by the chords of the four quadrants.
Portland vase: A celebrated cinerary urn or vase found in the tomb of the Emperor Alexander Severus. It is owned by the Duke of Portland, and kept in the British Museum.
Polianite: Manganese dioxide, occurring in tetragonal crystals nearly as hard as quartz.
Presumptive: Based on presumption or probability; grounded on probable evidence; probable; as, presumptive proof.
Pseudo-metallic: Falsely or imperfectly metallic; -- said of a kind of luster, as in minerals.
Pictorial: Of or pertaining to pictures; illustrated by pictures; forming pictures; representing with the clearness of a picture; as, a pictorial dictionary; a pictorial imagination.
Pinax: A tablet; a register; hence, a list or scheme inscribed on a tablet.
Pharmacop\u0153ia: A book or treatise describing the drugs, preparations, etc., used in medicine; especially, one that is issued by official authority and considered as an authoritative standard.
Phase meter: A device for measuring the difference in phase of two alternating currents of electromotive forces.
passivism: The doctrine that all violence is unjustifiable; hence, the principle of passive resistance.
Prodigiousness: The quality or state of being prodigious; the state of having qualities that excite wonder or astonishment; enormousness; vastness.
Purchase: The act of seeking, getting, or obtaining anything.
Planticle: A young plant, or plant in embryo.
Peroxidize: To oxidize to the utmost degree, so as to form a peroxide.
Pterostigma: A thickened opaque spot on the wings of certain insects.
Paradisaic: Of or pertaining to, or resembling, paradise; paradisiacal; as, paradisaical innocence; an age of paradisaical happiness.
Pillorize: To set in, or punish with, the pillory; to pillory.
Predomination: The act or state of predominating; ascendency; predominance.
Polycyttaria: A division of Radiolaria. It includes those having one more central capsules.
Puccoon: Any one of several plants yielding a red pigment which is used by the North American Indians, as the bloodroot and two species of Lithospermum (Lithospermum hirtum, and Lithospermum canescens); also, the pigment itself.
Pseudomorphism: The state of having, or the property of taking, a crystalline form unlike that which belongs to the species.
Preventable: Capable of being prevented or hindered; as, preventable diseases.
