Powdermill: A mill in which gunpowder is made.
Preponderance: The quality or state of being preponderant; superiority or excess of weight, influence, or power, etc.; an outweighing.
Pediment: Originally, in classical architecture, the triangular space forming the gable of a simple roof; hence, a similar form used as a decoration over porticoes, doors, windows, etc.; also, a rounded or broken frontal having a similar position and use. See Temple.
Preferableness: The quality or state of being preferable.
Permistion: The act of mixing; the state of being mingled; mixture.
Pertinacious: Holding or adhering to any opinion, purpose, or design, with obstinacy; perversely persistent; obstinate; as, pertinacious plotters; a pertinacious beggar.
pyroxylin: A substance resembling gun cotton in composition and properties, but distinct in that it is more highly nitrified and is soluble in alcohol, ether, etc.; -- called also pyroxyle.
Portoir: One who, or that which, bears; hence, one who, or that which, produces.
Paramastoid: Situated beside, or near, the mastoid portion of the temporal bone; paroccipital; -- applied especially to a process of the skull in some animals.
Patent-hammered: Having a surface dressed by cutting with a hammer the head of which consists of broad thin chisels clamped together.
paper over: To ignore or conceal (a disagreement or dispute) so as to continue friendly or productive relations; as, to paper over differences.
Psilop\u00e6des: birds whose young at first have down on the pterylæ only; -- called also Gymnopædes.
Practicability: The quality or state of being practicable; practicableness; feasibility.
Periotic: Surrounding, or pertaining to the region surrounding, the internal ear; as, the periotic capsule.
Platonic: A follower of Plato; a Platonist.
Press proof: The last proof for correction before sending to press.
Pedobaptist: One who advocates or practices infant baptism.
Pedobaptism: The baptism of infants or of small children.
Pornography: Licentious painting or literature; especially, the painting anciently employed to decorate the walls of rooms devoted to bacchanalian orgies.
Pound-breach: The breaking of a public pound for releasing impounded animals.
Polybromide: A bromide containing more than one atom of bromine in the molecule.
Pastorium: A parsonage; -- so called in some Baptist churches.
Pettifoggery: The practice or arts of a pettifogger; disreputable tricks; quibbles.
Poak: Waste matter from the preparation of skins, consisting of hair, lime, oil, etc.
Placable: Capable of being appeased or pacified; ready or willing to be pacified; willing to forgive or condone.
Plebeian: One of the plebs, or common people of ancient Rome, in distinction from patrician.
Phacellus: One of the filaments on the inner surface of the gastric cavity of certain jellyfishes.
paperknife: A dull knife used to cut open the envelopes in which letters are mailed or to slit uncut pages of books.
Pilpul: Among the Jews, penetrating investigation, disputation, and drawing of conclusions, esp. in Talmudic study.
Porcelainized: Baked like potter's lay; -- applied to clay shales that have been converted by heat into a substance resembling porcelain.
Palmaceous: Of or pertaining to palms; of the nature of, or resembling, palms.
Pulchritude: That quality of appearance which pleases the eye; beauty; comeliness; grace; loveliness.
Pedometric: Pertaining to, or measured by, a pedometer.
Parity: The quality or condition of being equal or equivalent; a like state or degree; equality; equivalence; close correspondence; analogy; as, parity of reasoning.
Prosiphon: A minute tube found in the protoconch of ammonites, and not connected with the true siphon.
Pillory: To set in, or punish with, the pillory.
Prospection: The act of looking forward, or of providing for future wants; foresight.
Pearlfish: Any fish whose scales yield a pearl-like pigment used in manufacturing artificial pearls, as the bleak, and whitebait.
Pistole: The name of certain gold coins of various values formerly coined in some countries of Europe. In Spain it was equivalent to a quarter doubloon, or about $3.90, and in Germany and Italy nearly the same. There was an old Italian pistole worth about $5.40.
pensionable: Entitled to receive a pension; as, a pensionable employee.
Post-it note: A small sheet of paper having the back part partly covered with a non-permanent gum which allows the note to be attached temporarily to another object, and easily removed without leaving any trace of glue on the object to which it was affixed.  Such note papers are sold in pads of varying sizes.
Pollicitation: A voluntary engagement, or a paper containing it; a promise.
paradiddle: The sound of a drum (especially a snare drum) beaten rapidly and continuously.
Privileged: Invested with a privilege; enjoying a peculiar right, advantage, or immunity.
Positivism: A system of philosophy originated by M. Auguste Comte, which deals only with positives. It excludes from philosophy everything but the natural phenomena or properties of knowable things, together with their invariable relations of coexistence and succession, as occurring in time and space. Such relations are denominated laws, which are to be discovered by observation, experiment, and comparison. This philosophy holds all inquiry into causes, both efficient and final, to be useless and unprofitable.
Palmer: A wandering religious votary; especially, one who bore a branch of palm as a token that he had visited the Holy Land and its sacred places.
plastic: A substance composed predominantly of a synthetic organic high polymer capable of being cast or molded; many varieties of plastic are used to produce articles of commerce (after 1900). [MW10 gives origin of word as 1905]
Probate: To obtain the official approval of, as of an instrument purporting to be the last will and testament; as, the executor has probated the will.
Palmed: Having or bearing a palm or palms.
Psaltery: A stringed instrument of music used by the Hebrews, the form of which is not known.
Piculet: Any species of very small woodpeckers of the genus Picumnus and allied genera. Their tail feathers are not stiff and sharp at the tips, as in ordinary woodpeckers.
pacifiable: Capable of being pacified or appeased; placable.
Postoral: Situated behind, or posterior to, the mouth.
Portability: The quality or state of being portable; fitness to be carried.
Pearlins: A kind of lace of silk or thread.
Procrastinatory: Of or pertaining to procrastination; dilatory.
Prosector: One who makes dissections for anatomical illustration; usually, the assistant of a professional anatomist.
Percoid: Belonging to, or resembling, the perches, or family Percidæ.
Propithecus: A genus including the long-tailed, or diadem, indris. See Indris.
Phlegethon: One of the principal rivers of Hades, in the channel of which fire flowed instead of water.
Polygamist: One who practices polygamy, or maintains its lawfulness.
Periphrastic: Expressing, or expressed, in more words than are necessary; characterized by periphrase; circumlocutory.
Persalt: A term formerly given to the salts supposed to be formed respectively by neutralizing acids with certain peroxides.
Pseudo-hyperthophic: Falsely hypertrophic; as, pseudo-hypertrophic paralysis, a variety of paralysis in which the muscles are apparently enlarged, but are really degenerated and replaced by fat.
Prussic: designating the acid now called hydrocyanic acid, but formerly called prussic acid, because Prussian blue is derived from it or its compounds. See Hydrocyanic.
pastime: To sport; to amuse one's self.
Protuberate: To swell, or be prominent, beyond the adjacent surface; to bulge out.
Pernot furnace: A reverberatory furnace with a circular revolving hearth, -- used in making steel.
Phthalyl: The hypothetical radical of phthalic acid.
Presupposition: The act of presupposing; an antecedent implication; presumption.
Pesage: A fee, or toll, paid for the weighing of merchandise.
Prostate: Standing before; -- applied to a gland which is found in the males of most mammals, and is situated at the neck of the bladder where this joins the urethra.
Prepossessor: One who possesses, or occupies, previously.
Polyporus: A genus of fungi having the under surface full of minute pores; also, any fungus of this genus.
Pralltriller: A melodic embellishment consisting of the quick alternation of a principal tone with an auxiliary tone above it, usually the next of the scale; -- called also the inverted mordente.
Polisher: One who, or that which, polishes; also, that which is used in polishing.
Priming: The powder or other combustible used to communicate fire to a charge of gunpowder, as in a firearm.
Pounce: To fall suddenly and seize with the claws; -- with on or upon; as, a hawk pounces upon a chicken. Also used figuratively.
Podalgia: pain in the foot, due to gout, rheumatism, etc.
Psychian: Any small moth of the genus Psyche and allied genera (family Psychidæ). The larvæ are called basket worms. See Basket worm, under Basket.
Perpendicular: A line at right angles to the plane of the horizon; a vertical line or direction.
Pulvinic: Pertaining to, or designating, an acid obtained by the decomposition of vulpinic acid, as a white crystalline substance.
Plaything: A thing to play with; a toy; anything that serves to amuse.
Physostigmine: An alkaloid found in the Calabar bean (the seed of Physostigma venenosum), and extracted as a white, tasteless, substance, amorphous or crystalline; -- formerly called eserine, with which it was regarded as identical.
Parigenin: A curdy white substance, obtained by the decomposition of parillin.
Pharos: A lighthouse or beacon for the guidance of seamen.
Pipestem: The hollow stem or tube of a pipe used for smoking tobacco, etc.
Pegasus: A winged horse fabled to have sprung from the body of Medusa when she was slain.  He is noted for causing, with a blow of his hoof, Hippocrene, the inspiring fountain of the Muses, to spring from Mount Helicon.  On this account he is, in modern times, associated with the Muses, and with ideas of poetic inspiration.
patch up: To mend by patching; to patch; -- also used figuratively; as, to patch up frayed relations bewteen parties.
Plea: That which is alleged by a party in support of his cause; in a stricter sense, an allegation of fact in a cause, as distinguished from a demurrer; in a still more limited sense, and in modern practice, the defendant's answer to the plaintiff's declaration and demand. That which the plaintiff alleges in his declaration is answered and repelled or justified by the defendant's plea. In chancery practice, a plea is a special answer showing or relying upon one or more things as a cause why the suit should be either dismissed, delayed, or barred. In criminal practice, the plea is the defendant's formal answer to the indictment or information presented against him.
partake: To partake of; to have a part or share in; to share.
Pointingstock: An object of ridicule or scorn; a laughingstock.
Peracute: Very sharp; very violent; as, a peracute fever.
Pung: A kind of plain sleigh drawn by one horse; originally, a rude oblong box on runners.
Piazza: An open square in a European town, especially an Italian town; hence (Arch.), an arcaded and roofed gallery; a portico. In the United States the word is popularly applied to a veranda.
Puna: A cold arid table-land, as in the Andes of Peru.
Punk: Wood so decayed as to be dry, crumbly, and useful for tinder; touchwood.
Paralgesia: Disordered sensibility to pain, including absence of sensibility to pain, excessive sensibility to pain, and abnormal painful results of stimuli.
Piciformes: A group of birds including the woodpeckers, toucans, barbets, colies, kingfishes, hornbills, and some other related groups.
Polyzonal: Consisting of many zones or rings.
Pactitious: Setted by a pact, or agreement.
Plasterwork: Plastering used to finish architectural constructions, exterior or interior, especially that used for the lining of rooms. Ordinarly, mortar is used for the greater part of the work, and pure plaster of Paris for the moldings and ornaments.
Prayerful: Given to prayer; praying much or often; devotional.
Propositional: Pertaining to, or in the nature of, a proposition; considered as a proposition; as, a propositional sense.
Powder-posted: Affected with dry rot; reduced to dust by rot. See Dry rot, under Dry.
Pigfoot: A marine fish (Scorpæna porcus), native of Europe. It is reddish brown, mottled with dark brown and black.
Plesiosaurus: A genus of large extinct marine reptiles, having a very long neck, a small head, and paddles for swimming. It lived in the Mesozoic age.
Phoronis: A remarkable genus of marine worms having tentacles around the mouth. It is usually classed with the gephyreans.  Its larva (Actinotrocha) undergoes a peculiar metamorphosis.
Pardonable: Admitting of pardon; not requiring the excution of penalty; venial; excusable; -- applied to the offense or to the offender; as, a pardonable fault, or culprit.
Polygrooved: Having many grooves; as, a polygrooved rifle or gun (referring to the rifling).
Putrescin: A nontoxic diamine, C4H12N2, formed in the putrefaction of the flesh of mammals and some other animals.
parking: The act of maneuvering a vehicle into a location where it can be left temporarily.
Peafowl: The peacock or peahen; any species of Pavo.
Pardonably: In a manner admitting of pardon; excusably.
Peptone: The soluble polypeptides produced by hydrolysis of protein; specifically the soluble peptides into which food is transformed by the action of the gastric and pancreatic juices. Peptones are also formed from protein matter by the action of boiling water and boiling dilute acids.
Pendicle: An appendage; something dependent on another; an appurtenance; a pendant.
Portico: A colonnade or covered ambulatory, especially in classical styles of architecture; usually, a colonnade at the entrance of a building.
Pyroarsenic: Pertaining to or designating, an acid of arsenic analogous to pyrophosphoric acid.
parrotlike: Mechanically imitated or repeated without thought or understanding; as, a mere parrotlike word-calling process; a voice quality sounding parrotlike.
Puppyhood: The time or state of being a puppy; the time of being young and undisciplined.
Panhellenism: A scheme to unite all the Greeks in one political body.
Pyretology: A discourse or treatise on fevers; the doctrine of fevers.
Podocephalous: Having a head of flowers on a long peduncle, or footstalk.
Prothesis: A credence table; -- so called by the Eastern or Greek Church.
Pharyngognathi: A division of fishes in which the lower pharyngeal bones are united. It includes the scaroid, labroid, and embioticoid fishes.
Pseudotetramera: A division of beetles having the fifth tarsal joint minute and obscure, so that there appear to be but four joints.
Philhellenist: A friend of Greece; one who supports the cause of the Greeks; particularly, one who supported them in their struggle for independence against the Turks; a philhellene.
Punctually: In a punctual manner; promptly; exactly.
Phassachate: The lead-colored agate; -- so called in reference to its color.
Punctuator: One who punctuates, as in writing; specifically, a punctator.
Proceeding: The act of one who proceeds, or who prosecutes a design or transaction; progress or movement from one thing to another; a measure or step taken in a course of business; a transaction; as, an illegal proceeding; a cautious or a violent proceeding.
Phonographically: In a phonographic manner; by means of phonograph.
Polytechnics: The science of the mechanic arts.
Pricket: A buck in his second year. See Note under 3d Buck.
Peridotite: An eruptive rock characterized by the presence of chrysolite (peridot). It also usually contains pyroxene, enstatite, chromite, etc. It is often altered to serpentine.
Pricker: One who, or that which, pricks; a pointed instrument; a sharp point; a prickle.
Potamology: A scientific account or discussion of rivers; a treatise on rivers; potamography.
Procellarian: One of a family of oceanic birds (Procellaridæ) including the petrels, fulmars, and shearwaters.  They are often seen in great abundance in stormy weather.
Poets Corner: An angle in the south transept of Westminster Abbey, London; -- so called because it contains the tombs of Chaucer, Spenser, Dryden, Ben Jonson, Gray, Tennyson, Browning, and other English poets, and memorials to many buried elsewhere.
Propiolic: Pertaining to, or designating, an organic acid (called also propargylic acid) of the acetylene or tetrolic series, analogous to propionic acid, and obtained as a white crystalline substance.
Pitchblende: A pitch-black mineral consisting chiefly of the oxide of uranium; uraninite. See Uraninite.
Placentation: The mode of formation of the placenta in different animals; as, the placentation of mammals.
Pactolian: Pertaining to the Pactolus, a river in ancient Lydia famous for its golden sands.
paying: yielding material gain or profit; as, paying investments.
Paroccipital: Situated near or beside the occipital condyle or the occipital bone; paramastoid; -- applied especially to a process of the skull in some animals.
Potential: Anything that may be possible; a possibility; potentially.
Preparatory: Preparing the way for anything by previous measures of adaptation; antecedent and adapted to what follows; introductory; preparative; as, a preparatory school; a preparatory condition.
Perdition: Entire loss; utter destruction; ruin; esp., the utter loss of the soul, or of final happiness in a future state; future misery or eternal death.
parse: To resolve into its elements, as a sentence, pointing out the several parts of speech, and their relation to each other by government or agreement; to analyze and describe grammatically.
Proctorage: Management by a proctor, or as by a proctor; hence, control; superintendence; -- in contempt.
Perspicuous: Capable of being through; transparent; translucent; not opaque.
Petroleum: Rock oil, mineral oil, or natural oil, a dark brown or greenish inflammable liquid, which, at certain points, exists in the upper strata of the earth, from whence it is pumped, or forced by pressure of the gas attending it. It consists of a complex mixture of various hydrocarbons, largely of the methane series, but may vary much in appearance, composition, and properties. It is refined by distillation, and the products include kerosene, benzine, gasoline, paraffin, etc.
Predominant: Having the ascendency over others; superior in strength, influence, or authority; prevailing; as, a predominant color; predominant excellence.
Pardoning: Relating to pardon; having or exercising the right to pardon; willing to pardon; merciful; as, the pardoning power; a pardoning God.
Pneumato-: A combining form from Gr. pney^ma, pney`matos, wind, air, breath, respiration; as, pneumatograph, pneumatology.
Puddler: One who converts cast iron into wrought iron by the process of puddling.
Pancake: A thin cake of batter fried in a pan or on a griddle; a griddlecake; a flapjack.
Persecution: The act or practice of persecuting; especially, the infliction of loss, pain, or death for adherence to a particular creed or mode of worship.
Probationership: The state of being a probationer; novitiate.
Phosgenite: A rare mineral occurring in tetragonal crystals of a white, yellow, or grayish color and adamantine luster.  It is a chlorocarbonate of lead.
Pliable: Capable of being plied, turned, or bent; easy to be bent; flexible; pliant; supple; limber; yielding; as, willow is a pliable plant.
Periblem: Nascent cortex, or immature cellular bark.
Proventriulus: The glandular stomach of birds, situated just above the crop.
Parabolically: By way of parable; in a parabolic manner.
Pocketknife: A knife with one or more blades, which fold into the handle so as to admit of being carried in the pocket.
Purport: To intend to show; to intend; to mean; to signify; to import; -- often with an object clause or infinitive.
Pothole: A circular hole formed in the rocky beds of rivers by the grinding action of stones or gravel whirled round by the water in what was at first a natural depression of the rock.
Polythalamous: Many-chambered; -- applied to shells of Foraminifera and cephalopods. See Illust. of Nautilus.
Priestism: The influence, doctrines, principles, etc., of priests or the priesthood.
Pigmented: Colored; specifically (Biol.), filled or imbued with pigment; as, pigmented epithelial cells; pigmented granules.
Physical: Of or pertaining to nature (as including all created existences); in accordance with the laws of nature; also, of or relating to natural or material things, or to the bodily structure, as opposed to things mental, moral, spiritual, or imaginary; material; natural; as, armies and navies are the physical force of a nation; the body is the physical part of man.
Pink: Resembling the garden pink in color; of the color called pink (see 6th Pink, 2); as, a pink dress; pink ribbons.
Palatopterygoid: Pertaining to the palatine and pterygoid region of the skull; as, the palatopterygoid cartilage, or rod, from which the palatine and pterygoid bones are developed.
Pavis: A large heavy oblong shield covering the whole body, carried by a pavisor, who sometimes also screened an archer with it.  It was originally carried but sometimes set up in permanent position
Prelusive: Of the nature of a prelude; introductory; indicating that something of a like kind is to follow.
Pina: A cone of silver amalgam prepared for retorting; also, the residuary cone of spongy silver left after the retorting.
Ping: To make the sound called ping.
Pine: Any tree of the coniferous genus Pinus. See Pinus.
pastureland: A field covered with grass or herbage and suitable for grazing by livestock; pasture.
Pantamorph: That which assumes, or exists in, all forms.
Priestcraft: Priestly policy; the policy of a priesthood; esp., in an ill sense, fraud or imposition in religious concerns; management by priests to gain wealth and power by working upon the religious motives or credulity of others.
Presbyopia: A defect of vision consequent upon advancing age. It is due to rigidity of the crystalline lens, which produces difficulty of accommodation and recession of the near point of vision, so that objects very near the eyes can not be seen distinctly without the use of convex glasses. Called also presbytia.
Presbyopic: Affected by presbyopia; also, remedying presbyopia; farsighted.
Primariness: The quality or state of being primary, or first in time, in act, or in intention.
Pigment: Any material from which a dye, a paint, or the like, may be prepared; particularly, the refined and purified coloring matter ready for mixing with an appropriate vehicle.
pallet: A small and mean bed; a bed of straw.
Pedipalpi: A division of Arachnida, including the whip scorpions (Thelyphonus) and allied forms.  Sometimes used in a wider sense to include also the true scorpions.
Pinchcock: A clamp on a flexible pipe to regulate the flow of a fluid through the pipe.
Papyrography: The process of multiplying copies of writings, etc., by means of the papyrograph.
paranormal: Of or pertaining to parapsychology; pertaining to forces or mental processes, such as extrasensory perception or psychokinesis, outside the possibilities defined by natural or scientific laws; as, paranormal phenomena.
Powerful: Full of power; capable of producing great effects of any kind; potent; mighty; efficacious; intense; as, a powerful man or beast; a powerful engine; a powerful argument; a powerful light; a powerful vessel.
Pin: To fasten with, or as with, a pin; to join; as, to pin a garment; to pin boards together.
Pic: A Turkish cloth measure, varying from 18 to 28 inches.
Pig: To bring forth (pigs); to bring forth in the manner of pigs; to farrow.
Pip: To cry or chirp, as a chicken; to peep.
Poledavy: A sort of coarse canvas; poldway.
Peccancy: The quality or state of being peccant.
Per diem: By the day; substantively (chiefly U. S.), an allowance or amount of so much by the day.  Also used adjectivally; as, a per diem allowance.
Pot-au-feu: A dish of broth, meat, and vegetables prepared by boiling in a pot, -- a dish esp. common among the French.
Peachblow: Of the delicate purplish pink color likened to that of peach blooms; -- applied esp. to a Chinese porcelain, small specimens of which bring great prices in the Western countries.
Palmetto State: South Carolina; -- a nickname alluding to the State Arms, which contain a representation of a palmetto tree.
Polishment: The act of polishing, or the state of being polished.
pacific: Of or pertaining to peace; of a peaceful character; not warlike; not quarrelsome; as, a pacific nature or condition.
Patolli: An American Indian game analogous to dice, probably originally a method of divination.
Peshito: The earliest Syriac version of the Old Testament, translated from Hebrew; also, the incomplete Syriac version of the New Testament.
Pyrogallol: A phenol metameric with phloroglucin, obtained by the distillation of gallic acid as a poisonous white crystalline substance having acid properties, and hence called also pyrogallic acid. It is a strong reducer, and is used as a developer in photography and in the production of certain dyes.
Portentous: Of the nature of a portent; containing portents; foreshadowing, esp. foreshadowing ill; ominous.
Printery: A place where cloth is printed; print works; also, a printing office.
Paddy: Unhusked rice; -- commonly so called in the East Indies.
Pleadings: The mutual pleas and replies of the plaintiff and defendant, or written statements of the parties in support of their claims, proceeding from the declaration of the plaintiff, until issue is joined, and the question made to rest on some single point.
Parthenon: A celebrated marble temple of Athena, on the Acropolis at Athens. It was of the pure Doric order, and has had an important influence on art.
Pumiceous: Of or pertaining to pumice; resembling pumice.
Pulsate: To throb, as a pulse; to beat, as the heart.
Porkwood: The coarse-grained brownish yellow wood of a small tree (Pisonia obtusata) of Florida and the West Indies. Also called pigeon wood, beefwood, and corkwood.
penny-pinching: Scrimping; reluctant to spend money; stingy; miserly; same as cheesparing.
Panegyric: Containing praise or eulogy; encomiastic; laudatory.
Planary: Of or pertaining to a plane.
Prudentialist: One who is governed by, or acts from, prudential motives.
Putanism: Habitual lewdness or prostitution of a woman; harlotry.
Peoples bank: A form of coöperative bank, such as those of Germany; -- a term loosely used for various forms of coöperative financial institutions.
Planking: The act of laying planks; also, planks, collectively; a series of planks in place, as the wooden covering of the frame of a vessel.
Portly: Having a dignified port or mien; of a noble appearance; imposing.
Preceptorial: Of or pertaining to a preceptor.
Pi\u00f9: A little more; as, più allegro, a little more briskly.
Pretervection: The act of carrying past or beyond.
Prayer: The act of praying, or of asking a favor; earnest request or entreaty; hence, a petition or memorial addressed to a court or a legislative body.
Particularity: The state or quality of being particular; distinctiveness; circumstantiality; minuteness in detail.
Pyrometry: The art of measuring degrees of heat, or the expansion of bodies by heat.
Pittance: An allowance of food bestowed in charity; a mess of victuals; hence, a small charity gift; a dole.
Poco: A little; -- used chiefly in phrases indicating the time or movement; as, poco più allegro, a little faster; poco largo, rather slow.
Poicile: The frescoed porch or gallery in Athens where Zeno taught.
Pock: A pustule raised on the surface of the body in variolous and vaccine diseases.
Pelorus: An instrument similar to a mariner's compass, but without magnetic needles, and having two sight vanes by which bearings are taken, esp. such as cannot be taken by the compass.
Postmaster: One who has charge of a station for the accommodation of travelers; one who supplies post horses.
Propulsive: Tending, or having power, to propel; driving on; urging.
Pianograph: A form of melodiograph applied to a piano.
Paraffin: A white waxy substance, resembling spermaceti, tasteless and odorless, and obtained from coal tar, wood tar, petroleum, etc., by distillation.  It is used in candles, as a sealing agent (such as in canning of preserves), as a waterproofing agent, as an illuminant and as a lubricant.  It is very inert, not being acted upon by most of the strong chemical reagents.  It was formerly regarded as a definite compound, but is now known to be a complex mixture of several higher hydrocarbons of the methane or marsh-gas series; hence, by extension, any substance, whether solid, liquid, or gaseous, of the same chemical series; thus gasoline, coal gas and kerosene consist largely of paraffins.
Paragr\u00eale: A lightning conductor erected, as in a vineyard, for drawing off the electricity in the atmosphere in order to prevent hailstorms.
Pipe-line: To convey by a pipe line; to furnish with a pipe line or pipe lines.
Pentagonally: In the form of a pentagon; with five angles.
Post-obit: A bond in which the obligor, in consideration of having received a certain sum of money, binds himself to pay a larger sum, on unusual interest, on the death of some specified individual from whom he has expectations.
Purger: One who, or that which, purges or cleanses; especially, a cathartic medicine.
Permit: A large pompano (Trachinotus goodei) of the West Indies, Florida, etc. It becomes about three feet long.
Pediculate: Of or pertaining to the Pediculati.
Protractile: Capable of being protracted, or protruded; protrusile.
Pampas: Vast grass-covered plains in the central and southern part of the Argentine Republic in South America.  The term is sometimes used in a wider sense for the plains east of the Andes extending from Bolivia to Southern Patagonia.
Pot shot: Lit., a shot fired simply to fill the pot; hence, a shot fired at an animal or person when at rest or within easy range, or fired simply to kill, without reference to the rules of sport; a shot needling no special skill.
Permanganic: Pertaining to, or designating, one of the higher acids of manganese, HMnO4, which forms salts called permanganates.
Protestantly: Like a Protestant; in conformity with Protestantism.
Patronymic: A modification of the father's name borne by the son; a name derived from that of a parent or ancestor; as, Pelides, the son of Peleus; Johnson, the son of John; Macdonald, the son of Donald; Paulowitz, the son of Paul; also, the surname of a family; the family name.
Parishional: Of or pertaining to a parish; parochial.
Palpiform: Having the form of a palpus.
Psilanthropy: The doctrine of the merely human existence of Christ.
Protectionist: One who favors protection. See Protection, 4.
Prediction: The act of foretelling; also, that which is foretold; prophecy.
Pivotal: Of or pertaining to a pivot or turning point; belonging to, or constituting, a pivot; of the nature of a pivot; as, the pivotalopportunity of a career; the pivotal position in a battle.
Protester: One who protests; one who utters a solemn declaration.
Pimola: An olive stuffed with a kind of sweet red pepper, or pimiento.
Perpendicularity: The quality or state of being perpendicular.
Pertuse: Punched; pierced with, or having, holes.
Pontoon: A wooden flat-bottomed boat, a metallic cylinder, or a frame covered with canvas, India rubber, etc., forming a portable float, used in building bridges quickly for the passage of troops.
Physicism: The tendency of the mind toward, or its preoccupation with, physical phenomena; materialism in philosophy and religion.
Paynes process: A process for preserving timber and rendering it incombustible by impregnating it successively with solutions of sulphate of iron and calcium chloride in vacuo.
Peccadillo: A slight trespass or offense; a petty crime; a trifling fault.
Picking: Done or made as with a pointed tool; as, a picking sound.
Premunite: To fortify beforehand; to guard against objection.
Polyandry: The possession by a woman of more than one husband at the same time; -- contrasted with monandry.
Pauxi: A curassow (Ourax pauxi), which, in South America, is often domesticated.
Packman: One who bears a pack; a peddler.
Perron: An out-of-door flight of steps, as in a garden, leading to a terrace or to an upper story; -- usually applied to mediævel or later structures of some architectural pretensions.
Phosphatic: Pertaining to, or containing, phosphorus, phosphoric acid, or phosphates; as, phosphatic nodules.
Procerite: The segment next to the flagellum of the antennæ of Crustacea.
Plattdeutsch: The modern dialects spoken in the north of Germany, taken collectively; modern Low German. See Low German, under German.
philosophize: To reason like a philosopher; to search into the reason and nature of things; to investigate phenomena, and assign rational causes for their existence.
Phylogenesis: The history of genealogical development; the race history of an animal or vegetable type; the historic exolution of the phylon or tribe, in distinction from ontogeny, or the development of the individual organism, and from biogenesis, or life development generally.
Primarily: In a primary manner; in the first place; in the first place; in the first intention; originally.
Pahi: A large war canoe of the Society Islands.
Photogen: A light hydrocarbon oil resembling kerosene. It is obtained by distilling coal, paraffin, etc., and is used as a lubricant, illuminant, etc.
Pretermit: To pass by; to omit; to disregard.
Picrotoxin: A bitter white crystalline substance found in the cocculus indicus. It is a peculiar poisonous neurotic and intoxicant, and consists of a mixture of several neutral substances.
Plagioclase: A general term used of any triclinic feldspar. See the Note under Feldspar.
Pinenchyma: Tabular parenchyma, a form of cellular tissue in which the cells are broad and flat, as in some kinds of epidermis.
Princeliness: The quality of being princely; the state, manner, or dignity of a prince.
Persevere: To persist in any business or enterprise undertaken; to pursue steadily any project or course begun; to maintain a purpose in spite of counter influences, opposition, or discouragement; not to give or abandon what is undertaken.
Posterior: Later in time; hence, later in the order of proceeding or moving; coming after; -- opposed to prior.
Podosperm: The stalk of a seed or ovule.
Potts disease: Caries of the vertebræ, frequently resulting in curvature of the spine and paralysis of the lower extremities; -- so named from Percival Pott, an English surgeon.
Phlorizin: A bitter white crystalline glucoside extracted from the root bark of the apple, pear, cherry, plum, etc.
Pyrology: That branch of physical science which treats of the properties, phenomena, or effects of heat; also, a treatise on heat.
Pyroelectricity: Electricity developed by means of heat; the science which treats of electricity thus developed.
Preocular: Placed just in front of the eyes, as the antennæ of certain insects.
Plowhead: The clevis or draught iron of a plow.
Psyche: A lovely maiden, daughter of a king and mistress of Eros, or Cupid. She is regarded as the personification of the soul.
Patriarchism: Government by a patriarch, or the head of a family.
Pichurim bean: The seed of a Brazilian lauraceous tree (Nectandra Puchury) of a taste and smell between those of nutmeg and of sassafras, -- sometimes used medicinally.  Called also sassafras nut.
Porringer: A porridge dish; esp., a bowl or cup from which children eat or are fed; as, a silver porringer.
Predestinate: To predetermine or foreordain; to appoint or ordain beforehand by an unchangeable purpose or decree; to preëlect.
Parley: To speak with another; to confer on some point of mutual concern; to discuss orally; hence, specifically, to confer orally with an enemy; to treat with him by words, as on an exchange of prisoners, an armistice, or terms of peace.
Pubic: Of or pertaining to the pubes; in the region of the pubes; as, the pubic bone; the pubic region, or the lower part of the hypogastric region. See Pubes.
Pulse: To drive by a pulsation; to cause to pulsate.
Proselytism: The act or practice of proselyting; the making of converts to a religion or a religious sect, or to any opinion, system, or party.
Phthisicky: Having phthisis, or some symptom of it, as difficulty in breathing.
Plenteous: Containing plenty; abundant; copious; plentiful; sufficient for every purpose; as, a plenteous supply.
Puttyroot: An American orchidaceous plant (Aplectrum hyemale) which flowers in early summer. Its slender naked rootstock produces each year a solid corm, filled with exceedingly glutinous matter, which sends up later a single large oval evergreen plaited leaf. Called also Adam-and-Eve.
Pseudo-china: The false china root, a plant of the genus Smilax (Smilax Pseudo-china), found in America.
Pshaw: To express disgust or contemptuous disapprobation, as by the exclamation “ Pshaw!”
Palsgravine: The consort or widow of a palsgrave.
Pistillaceous: Growing on, or having nature of, the pistil; of or pertaining to a pistil.
Pull: The act of pulling or drawing with force; an effort to move something by drawing toward one.
Philippize: To support or advocate the cause of Philip of Macedon.
Prude: A woman of affected modesty, reserve, or coyness; one who is overscrupulous or sensitive; one who affects extraordinary prudence in conduct and speech.
Pulu: A vegetable substance consisting of soft, elastic, yellowish brown chaff, gathered in the Hawaiian Islands from the young fronds of free ferns of the genus Cibotium, chiefly Cibotium Menziesii; -- used for stuffing mattresses, cushions, etc., and as an absorbent.
Pommel: To beat soundly, as with the pommel of a sword, or with something knoblike; hence, to beat with the fists.
Perspicuity: The quality or state of being transparent or translucent.
Preferential voting: A system of voting, as at primaries, in which the voters are allowed to indicate on their ballots their preference (usually their first and second choices) between two or more candidates for an office, so that if no candidate receives a majority of first choices the one receiving the greatest number of first and second choices together in nominated or elected.
Phasing current: The momentary current between two alternating-current generators when juxtaposed in parallel and not agreeing exactly in phase or period.
Plaiter: One who, or that which, plaits.
Pleurobranch: Any one of the gills of a crustacean that is attached to the side of the thorax.
Parvati: The wife of Siva and a benevolent aspect of Devi; the goddess of plenty.
Phlo\u00ebm: That portion of fibrovascular bundles which corresponds to the inner bark; the liber tissue; -- distinguished from xylem.
Providence: The act of providing or preparing for future use or application; a making ready; preparation.
Plaited: Folded; doubled over; braided; figuratively, involved; intricate; artful.
Protocercal: Having a caudal fin extending around the end of the vertebral column, like that which is first formed in the embryo of fishes; diphycercal.
Polygon: A plane figure having many angles, and consequently many sides; esp., one whose perimeter consists of more than four sides; any figure having many angles.
Polygraph: An instrument for multiplying copies of a writing; a manifold writer; a copying machine.
Pumpernickel: A sort of bread, made of unbolted rye, which forms the chief food of the Westphalian peasants. It is acid but nourishing.
Pipefish: Any lophobranch fish of the genus Siphostoma, or Syngnathus, and allied genera, having a long and very slender angular body, covered with bony plates. The mouth is small, at the end of a long, tubular snout. The male has a pouch on his belly, in which the incubation of the eggs takes place.
Picea: A genus of coniferous trees of the northen hemisphere, including the Norway spruce and the American black and white spruces. These trees have pendent cones, which do not readily fall to pieces, in this and other respects differing from the firs.
Polyphore: A receptacle which bears many ovaries.
Primordialism: Devotion to, or persistence in, conditions of the primordial state.
Panpresbyterian: Belonging to, or representative of, those who hold Presbyterian views in all parts of the world; as, a Panpresbyterian council.
Pedestrianize: To practice walking; to travel on foot.
paddy wagon: An enclosed truck used by police to transport prisoners.
Pleurenchyma: A tissue consisting of long and slender tubular cells, of which wood is mainly composed.
Phrenology: The science of the special functions of the several parts of the brain, or of the supposed connection between the various faculties of the mind and particular organs in the brain.
Promisor: One who engages or undertakes; a promiser.
pectin: One of a series of carbohydrates, commonly called vegetable jelly, found very widely distributed in the vegetable kingdom, especially in ripe fleshy fruits, as apples, cranberries, etc.  It is extracted as variously colored, translucent substances, which are soluble in hot water but become viscous on cooling.  It is commonly used in making fruit jelllies.
Primateship: The office, dignity, or position of a primate; primacy.
Prickliness: The quality of being prickly, or of having many prickles.
pectic: Of or pertaining to pectin; specifically, designating an acid obtained from ordinary vegetable jelly (pectin) as an amorphous substance, tough and horny when dry, but gelatinous when moist.
Penury: Absence of resources; want; privation; indigence; extreme poverty; destitution.
Paraconic: Pertaining to, or designating, an organic acid obtained as a deliquescent white crystalline substance, and isomeric with itaconic, citraconic, and mesaconic acids.
Particularly: In a particular manner; expressly; with a specific reference or interest; in particular; distinctly.
Paramylum: A substance resembling starch, found in the green frothy scum formed on the surface of stagnant water.
Parvolin: A nonoxygenous ptomaine, formed in the putrefaction of albuminous matters, especially of horseflesh and mackerel.
Prase: A variety of cryptocrystalline of a leek-green color.
Polemics: The art or practice of disputation or controversy, especially on religious subjects; that branch of theological science which pertains to the history or conduct of ecclesiastical controversy.
Photoscope: Anything employed for the observation of light or luminous effects.
Pollage: A head or poll tax; hence, extortion.
Phantom: Being, or of the nature of, a phantom.
Purpleheart: A strong, durable, and elastic wood of a purplish color, obtained from several tropical American leguminous trees of the genus Copaifera (Copaifera pubiflora, Copaifera bracteata, and Copaifera officinalis). Used for decorative veneering. See Copaiba.
Pouparts ligament: A ligament, of fascia, extending, in most mammals, from the ventral side of the ilium to near the symphysis of the pubic bones.
Parliament: A parleying; a discussion; a conference.
Priceite: A hydrous borate of lime, from Oregon.
Pyrologist: One who is versed in, or makes a study of, pyrology.
Pneumococcus: A form of micrococcus found in the sputum (and elsewhere) of persons suffering with pneumonia, and thought to be the cause of this disease.
Plumbism: A diseased condition, produced by the absorption of lead, common among workers in this metal or in its compounds, as among painters, typesetters, etc. It is characterized by various symptoms, as lead colic, lead line, and wrist drop. See under Colic, Lead, and Wrist.
Prevalent: Gaining advantage or superiority; having superior force, influence, or efficacy; prevailing; predominant; successful; victorious.
Pithecanthropus: A hypothetical genus of primates intermediate between man and the anthropoid apes.
Perceptible: Capable of being perceived; cognizable; discernible; perceivable.
Patonce: Having the arms growing broader and floriated toward the end; -- said of a cross. See Illust. 9 of Cross.
Plagose: Fond of flogging; as, a plagose master.
Peon: A foot soldier; a policeman; also, an office attendant; a messenger.
Physostomi: An order of fishes in which the air bladder is provided with a duct, and the ventral fins, when present, are abdominal. It includes the salmons, herrings, carps, catfishes, and others.
Polychrome: Executed in the manner of polychromy; as, polychrome printing.
Player: One who plays, or amuses himself; one without serious aims; an idler; a trifler.
Polychromy: The art or practice of combining different colors, especially brilliant ones, in an artistic way.
Pantography: A general description; entire view of an object.
Pug nose: A short, thick nose; a snubnose.
Passible: Susceptible of feeling or suffering, or of impressions from external agents.
Preoblongata: The anterior part of the medulla oblongata.
Pheon: A bearing representing the head of a dart or javelin, with long barbs which are engrailed on the inner edge.
Patriarchal: Of or pertaining to a patriarch or to patriarchs; possessed by, or subject to, patriarchs; as, patriarchal authority or jurisdiction; a patriarchal see; a patriarchal church.
Pettifog: To advocate like a pettifogger; to argue trickily; as, to pettifog a claim.
Papyraceous: Made of papyrus; of the consistency of paper; papery.
Pulmograde: Swimming by the expansion and contraction, or lunglike movement, of the body, or of the disk, as do the medusæ.
pademelon: Any of several small reddish-brown wallabies of scrubby areas of Australia and New Guinea, especially those belonging to the genus Thylogale; a paddymelon.  See Wallaby
Pliers: A kind of small pinchers with long jaws, -- used for bending or cutting metal rods or wire, for handling small objects such as the parts of a watch, etc.
Parapherna: The property of a woman which, on her marriage, was not made a part of her dower, but remained her own.
Physiognomy: The art and science of discovering the predominant temper, and other characteristic qualities of the mind, by the outward appearance, especially by the features of the face.
Physograde: Any siphonophore which has an air sac for a float, as the Physalia.
panning: The act or process in which heavier ores are concentrated by agitating a sample of crushed ore under water in a shallow pan, thus washing away the lighter particles from the sample; as, panning for gold.  See pan{1}, v. t. and pan{1}, v. i.
Pleasure: To take pleasure; to seek pursue pleasure; as, to go pleasuring.
Properispomenon: A word which has the circumflex accent on the penult.
Pudendum: The external organs of generation, especially of the female; the vulva.
Piddle: To deal in trifles; to concern one's self with trivial matters rather than with those that are important.
Palliobranchiate: Having the pallium, or mantle, acting as a gill, as in brachiopods.
Petal: One of the leaves of the corolla, or the colored leaves of a flower. See Corolla, and Illust. of Flower.
Propagandism: The art or practice of propagating tenets or principles; zeal in propagating one's opinions.
Propagandist: A person who devotes himself to the spread of any system of principles.
Positively: In a positive manner; absolutely; really; expressly; with certainty; indubitably; peremptorily; dogmatically; -- opposed to negatively.
Plight: To pledge; to give as a pledge for the performance of some act; as, to plight faith, honor, word; -- never applied to property or goods.
Pleasantry: That which denotes or promotes pleasure or good humor; cheerfulness; gayety; merriment; especially, an agreeable playfulness in conversation; a jocose or humorous remark; badinage.
Parnassus: A mountain in Greece, sacred to Apollo and the Muses, and famous for a temple of Apollo and for the Castalian spring.
Polyandrous: Belonging to the class Polyandria; having many stamens, or any number above twenty, inserted in the receptacle.
Pocketful: As much as a pocket will hold; enough to fill a pocket; as, pocketfuls of chestnuts.
Proteaceous: Of or pertaining to the Proteaceæ, an order of apetalous evergreen shrubs, mostly natives of the Cape of Good Hope or of Australia.
Picador: A horseman armed with a lance, who in a bullfight receives the first attack of the bull, and excites him by picking him without attempting to kill him.
Pile: To lay or throw into a pile or heap; to heap up; to collect into a mass; to accumulate; to amass; -- often with up; as, to pile up wood.
Passport: Permission to pass; a document given by the competent officer of a state, permitting the person therein named to pass or travel from place to place, without molestation, by land or by water.
Photolithographer: One who practices, or one who employs, photolithography.
Pill: A medicine in the form of a little ball, or small round mass, to be swallowed whole.
Plebs: The commonalty of ancient Rome who were citizens without the usual political rights; the plebeians; -- distinguished from the patricians.
Puncturation: The act or process of puncturing. See Acupuncture.
Peseta: A Spanish silver coin, and money of account, equal to about nineteen cents, and divided into 100 centesimos.
Pasteurizer: One that Pasteurizes, specif. an apparatus for heating and agitating, fluid.
Pneumatocele: A distention of the scrotum by air; also, hernia of the lungs.
Perennial: A perennial plant; a plant which lives or continues more than two years, whether it retains its leaves in winter or not.
Pastorale: A composition in a soft, rural style, generally in 6-8 or 12-8 time.
Pinkroot: The root of Spigelia Marilandica, used as a powerful vermifuge; also, that of Spigelia Anthelmia.  See definition 2 (below).
Protocanonical: Of or pertaining to the first canon, or that which contains the authorized collection of the books of Scripture; -- opposed to deutero-canonical.
p\u00e6on: A foot of four syllables, one long and three short, admitting of four combinations, according to the place of the long syllable.
Papua: A Pacific island north of Australia; governed by Australia and Indonesia.
Pistachio: The nut of the Pistacia vera, a tree of the order Anacardiaceæ, containing a kernel of a pale greenish color, which has a pleasant taste, resembling that of the almond, and yields an oil of agreeable taste and odor; -- called also pistachio nut. It is wholesome and nutritive. The tree grows in Arabia, Persia, Syria, and Sicily.
Potboiler: A term applied derisively to any literary or artistic work, and esp. a painting, done simply for money and the means of living.
Pilchard: A small European food fish (Clupea pilchardus) resembling the herring, but thicker and rounder. It is sometimes taken in great numbers on the coast of England.
People: To stock with people or inhabitants; to fill as with people; to populate.
Pentachord: An ancient instrument of music with five strings.
Polyscope: A glass which makes a single object appear as many; a multiplying glass.
Pedograph: An instrument carried by a pedestrian for automatically making a topographical record of the ground covered during a journey.
Past: By; beyond; as, he ran past.
Palely: In a pale manner; dimly; wanly; not freshly or ruddily.
Pass: An opening, road, or track, available for passing; especially, one through or over some dangerous or otherwise impracticable barrier; a passageway; a defile; a ford; as, a mountain pass.
Perverseness: The quality or state of being perverse.
Ponder: To think; to deliberate; to muse; -- usually followed by on or over.
Penitence: The quality or condition of being penitent; the disposition of a penitent; sorrow for sins or faults; repentance; contrition.
Paleocrinoidea: A suborder of Crinoidea found chiefly in the Paleozoic rocks.
pestle: To pound, pulverize, bray, or mix with a pestle, or as with a pestle; to use a pestle.
Picamar: An oily liquid hydrocarbon extracted from the creosote of beechwood tar. It consists essentially of certain derivatives of pyrogallol.
Pocky: Full of pocks; affected with smallpox or other eruptive disease.
Photoluminescent: Luminescent due to exposure to light waves.
Ponderable: Capable of being weighed; having appreciable weight.
Pleasant: A wit; a humorist; a buffoon.
Psalterium: The third stomach of ruminants. See Manyplies.
Pouncet box: A box with a perforated lid, for sprinkling pounce, or for holding perfumes.
Paolo: An old Italian silver coin, worth about ten cents.
Priestly: Of or pertaining to a priest or the priesthood; sacerdotal; befitting or becoming a priest; as, the priestly office; a priestly farewell.
Propione: The ketone of propionic acid, obtained as a colorless fragrant liquid.
Phenacite: A glassy colorless mineral occurring in rhombohedral crystals, sometimes used as a gem.  It is a silicate of glucina, and receives its name from its deceptive similarity to quartz.
Petroline: A paraffin obtained from petroleum from Rangoon in India, and practically identical with ordinary paraffin.
Plumbing: The art of casting and working in lead, and applying it to building purposes; especially, the business of furnishing, fitting, and repairing pipes for conducting water, sewage, etc.
Precel: To surpass; to excel; to exceed.
Piet\u00e0: A representation of the dead Christ, attended by the Virgin Mary or by holy women and angels.
Pulldevil: A number of fishhooks rigidly fastened back to be pulled through the water to catch fish.
peepul: A sacred tree (Ficus religiosa) of the Buddhists, a kind of fig tree which attains great size and venerable age; it lacks the prop roots of the banyan.  See Bo tree.
Paragnathus: One of the two lobes which form the lower lip, or metastome, of Crustacea.
Post-disseizor: A person who disseizes another of lands which the disseizee had before recovered of the same disseizor.
Phenacetin: A white, crystalline compound, C10H13O2N, once used in medicine principally as an antipyretic.  It is now seldom used because of serious side effects.
Prophesy: To foretell; to predict; to prognosticate.
Preterimperfect: Old name of the tense also called imperfect.
Pucherite: Vanadate of bismuth, occurring in minute reddish brown crystals.
Pennoncel: A small pennon borne on a lance.  See Pencel.
Pantologist: One versed in pantology; a writer of pantology.
Pre\u00ebminent: Eminent above others; prominent among those who are eminent; superior in excellence; surpassing, or taking precedence of, others; rarely, surpassing others in evil, or in bad qualities; as, preëminent in guilt.
Pipette: A small glass tube, often with an enlargement or bulb in the middle, and usually graduated, -- used for transferring or delivering measured quantities.
Pluviometer: An instrument for ascertaining the amount of rainfall at any place in a given time; a rain gauge.
Proconsul: An officer who discharged the duties of a consul without being himself consul; a governor of, or a military commander in, a province. He was usually one who had previously been consul.
Pentahedral: Having five sides; as, a pentahedral figure.
Pock-broken: Broken out, or marked, with smallpox; pock-fretten.
Pseudoscorpiones: An order of Arachnoidea having the palpi terminated by large claws, as in the scorpions, but destitute of a caudal sting; the false scorpions. Called also Pseudoscorpii, and Pseudoscorpionina. See Illust. of Book scorpion, under Book.
Puteal: An inclosure surrounding a well to prevent persons from falling into it; a well curb.
Piety: Veneration or reverence of the Supreme Being, and love of his character; loving obedience to the will of God, and earnest devotion to his service.
Pageantry: Scenic shows or spectacles, taken collectively; spectacular quality; splendor.
palpate: To examine for medical purposes by touching, as of body parts; as, the nurse palpated the patient's stomach.
Pepper dulse: A variety of edible seaweed (Laurencia pinnatifida) distinguished for its pungency.
Pachisi: A game, somewhat resembling backgammon, originating in India.
Plenariness: Quality or state of being plenary.
patterned: Having describable patterns, especially patterns of colors.
Phleum: A genus of grasses, including the timothy (Phleum pratense), which is highly valued for hay; cat's-tail grass.
Pterophore: Any moth of the genus Pterophorus and allied genera; a plume moth. See Plume moth, under Plume.
Preservative: That which preserves, or has the power of preserving; a presevative agent.
Perfect: To make perfect; to finish or complete, so as to leave nothing wanting; to give to anything all that is requisite to its nature and kind.
Pelagian: Of or pertaining to Pelagius, or to his doctrines.
Prestimony: A fund for the support of a priest, without the title of a benefice. The patron in the collator.
Palmin: A white waxy or fatty substance obtained from castor oil.
Profit: To gain advantage; to make improvement; to improve; to gain; to advance.
Pourpoint: A quilted military doublet or gambeson worn in the 14th and 15th centuries; also, a name for the doublet of the 16th and 17th centuries worn by civilians.
Protoconch: The embryonic shell, or first chamber, of ammonites and other cephalopods.
Palmic: Of, pertaining to, or derived from, the castor-oil plant (Ricinus communis, or Palma Christi) and other species of the family Euphorbiaceae; -- formerly used to designate an acid now called ricinoleic acid (d-12-hydroxyoleic acid, C18H34O3).
Poetic: Of or pertaining to poetry; suitable for poetry, or for writing poetry; as, poetic talent, theme, work, sentiments.
Pyrophoric: Light-producing; of or pertaining to pyrophorus.
Paulician: One of a sect of Christian dualists originating in Armenia in the seventh century.  They rejected the Old Testament and the part of the New.
painfulness: Emotional distress; a fundamental feeling that people try to avoid.
Pederast: One guilty of pederasty; a sodomite.
Poenamu: A variety of jade or nephrite, -- used in New Zealand for the manufacture of axes and weapons.
Proterosaurus: An extinct genus of reptiles of the Permian period.  Called also Protosaurus.
Phlegm: One of the four humors of which the ancients supposed the blood to be composed. See Humor.
Pectous: Of, pertaining to, or consisting of, pectose.
Pinnipedia: A suborder of aquatic carnivorous mammals including the seals and walruses; -- opposed to Fissipedia.
Pan-: Combining forms signifying all, every; as, panorama, pantheism, pantagraph, pantograph. Pan- becomes pam- before b or p, as pamprodactylous.
Proctorial: Of or pertaining to a proctor, esp. an academic proctor; magisterial.
Preterist: One whose chief interest is in the past; one who regards the past with most pleasure or favor.
Pyretic: Of or pertaining to fever; febrile.
Purposeless: Having no purpose or result; objectless.
Pressure cooker: a pot with a lid which may be tightly bound to the bottom part, forming a vessel  which can withstand some gas pressure from within.  It is used to heat foods in water or steam to a temperature somewhat above the boiling point of water, allowing the cooking process to be accomplished more quickly than otherwise.
Paraphimosis: A condition in which the prepuce, after being retracted behind the glans penis, is constricted there, and can not be brought forward into place again.
partitionist: An advocate of partitioning a country.
Peridrome: The space between the columns and the wall of the cella, in a Greek or a Roman temple.
Platinoid: An alloy of German silver containing tungsten; -- used for forming electrical resistance coils and standards.
Perpetual calendar: A calendar that can be used perpetually or over a wide range of years. That of Capt. Herschel covers, as given below, dates from 1750 to 1961 only, but is capable of indefinite extension.
Pang: To torture; to cause to have great pain or suffering; to torment.
Pane: A division; a distinct piece, limited part, or compartment of any surface; a patch; hence, a square of a checkered or plaided pattern.
Preorbital: Situated in front or the orbit.
Pruning: The act of trimming, or removing what is superfluous.
Pumpage: That which is raised by pumps, or the work done by pumps.
Pedanty: An assembly or clique of pedants.
Playa: A beach; a strand; in the plains and deserts of Texas, New Mexico, and Arizona, a broad, level spot, on which subsequently becomes dry by evaporation.
Paseng: The wild or bezoar goat. See Goat.
Pleader: One who pleads; one who argues for or against; an advotate.
Protocatechuic: Pertaining to, derived from, or designating, an organic acid which is obtained as a white crystalline substance from catechin, asafetida, oil of cloves, etc., and by distillation itself yields pyrocatechin.
Pectoriloquial: Pertaining to, or of the nature of, pectoriloquy.
Processionary: Pertaining to a procession; consisting in processions; as, processionary service.
Patchery: Botchery; covering of defects; bungling; hypocrisy.
Petrel: Any one of numerous species of longwinged sea birds belonging to the family Procellaridæ. The small petrels, or Mother Carey's chickens, belong to Oceanites, Oceanodroma, Procellaria, and several allied genera.
Pantisocratic: Of or pertaining to a pantisocracy.
Paralysis: Abolition of function, whether complete or partial; esp., the loss of the power of voluntary motion, with or without that of sensation, in any part of the body; palsy. See Hemiplegia, and Paraplegia.  Also used figuratively; as, paralysis of the will.
Palus: One of several upright slender calcareous processes which surround the central part of the calicle of certain corals.
Pelerine: A woman's cape; especially, a fur cape that is longer in front than behind.
Pudding: A species of food of a soft or moderately hard consistence, variously made, but often a compound of flour or meal, with milk and eggs, etc.
Preconcert: Something concerted or arranged beforehand; a previous agreement.
Propidene: The unsymmetrical hypothetical hydrocarbon radical, CH3.CH2.CH, analogous to ethylidene, and regarded as the type of certain derivatives of propane; -- called also propylidene.
Propugn: To contend for; to defend; to vindicate.
Procatarxis: The kindling of a disease into action; also, the procatarctic cause.
Ph\u0153nicopterus: A genus of birds which includes the flamingoes.
Postponence: The act of postponing, in sense 2.
Preacher: One who preaches; one who discourses publicly on religious subjects.
Patency: The condition of being open, enlarged, or spread.
Proteolysis: The digestion or dissolving of proteid matter by proteolytic ferments.
Petechial: Characterized by, or pertaining to, petechiæ; spotted.
Poonac: A kind of oil cake prepared from the cocoanut. See Oil cake, under Cake.
Proterandrous: Having the stamens come to maturity before the pistil; -- opposed to proterogynous.
Percomorphi: A division of fishes including the perches and related kinds.
Parapophysis: The ventral transverse, or capitular, process of a vertebra. See Vertebra.
Pileous: Consisting of, or covered with, hair; hairy; pilose.
Polemoscope: An opera glass or field glass with an oblique mirror arranged for seeing objects that do not lie directly before the eye; -- called also diagonal opera glass, or side opera glass.
Pupillometer: An instrument for measuring the size of the pupil of the pupil of the eye.
Papain: A proteolytic ferment, like trypsin, present in the juice of the green fruit of the papaw (Carica Papaya) of tropical America.
Peritricha: A division of ciliated Infusoria having a circle of cilia around the oral disk and sometimes another around the body. It includes the vorticellas. See Vorticella.
Propertied: Possessing property; holding real estate, or other investments of money.
Plat: The flat or broad side of a sword.
Pentose: Any of a group of sugars of the formula C5H10O5, such as as arabinose or ribose; -- so called from the five carbon atoms in the molecule. They are not fermented by yeast.
pe: the 17th letter of the Hebrew alphabet.
Possess: To occupy in person; to hold or actually have in one's own keeping; to have and to hold.
Postpaid: Having the postage prepaid, as a letter.
Pteridologist: One who is versed in pteridology.
Plutocrat: One whose wealth gives him power or influence; one of the plutocracy.
Periople: The external smooth horny layer of the hoof of the horse and allied animals.
Pedicel: A stalk which supports one flower or fruit, whether solitary or one of many ultimate divisions of a common peduncle. See Peduncle, and Illust. of Flower.
Physianthropy: The philosophy of human life, or the doctrine of the constitution and diseases of man, and their remedies.
Pneumometry: Measurement of the capacity of the lungs for air.
parachuter: One who descends from a high altitude to the ground by means of a parachute, especially one who does so for sport or in a military operation.
Polyclinic: A clinic in which diseases of many sorts are treated; especially, an institution in which clinical instruction is given in all kinds of disease.
Perispore: The outer covering of a spore.
pachyderma: An abnormal thickening of the skin (usually unilateral on an extremity) caused by congenital enlargement of lymph vessel and lymph vessel obstruction.
Piqu\u00e9: A cotton fabric, figured in the loom, -- used as a dress goods for women and children, and for vestings, etc.
Positiveness: The quality or state of being positive; reality; actualness; certainty; confidence; peremptoriness; dogmatism. See Positive, a.
Pteridomania: A madness, craze, or strong fancy, for ferns.
Periwinkle: A trailing herb of the genus Vinca.
Paleographer: One skilled in paleography; a paleographist.
Premonition: Previous warning, notice, or information; forewarning; as, a premonition of danger.
Pantomime: Representing only in mute actions; pantomimic; as, a pantomime dance.
Perforate: Pierced with a hole or holes, or with pores; having transparent dots resembling holes.
Pipestone: A kind of clay slate, carved by the Indians into tobacco pipes.  Cf. Catlinite.
Purling: The motion of a small stream running among obstructions; also, the murmur it makes in so doing.
Predisponency: The state of being predisposed; predisposition.
Port-royalist: One of the dwellers in the Cistercian convent of Port Royal des Champs, near Paris, when it was the home of the Jansenists in the 17th century, among them being Arnauld, Pascal, and other famous scholars.  Cf. Jansenist.
Premonitor: One who, or that which, gives premonition.
Penetralia: The recesses, or innermost parts, of any thing or place, especially of a temple or palace.
Promethea: A large American bombycid moth (Callosamia promethea). Its larva feeds on the sassafras, wild cherry, and other trees, and suspends its cocoon from a branch by a silken band.
Perimysium: The connective tissue sheath which surrounds a muscle, and sends partitions inwards between the bundles of muscular fibers.
Pineapple: A tropical plant (Ananassa sativa); also, its fruit; -- so called from the resemblance of the latter, in shape and external appearance, to the cone of the pine tree. Its origin is unknown, though conjectured to be American.
Photometry: That branch of science which treats of the measurement of the intensity of light.
Protestation: The act of making a protest; a public avowal; a solemn declaration, especially of dissent.
Pupilage: The state of being a pupil.
Populares: The people or the people's party, in ancient Rome, as opposed to the optimates.
Percaline: A fine kind of cotton goods, usually of one color, and with a glossy surface, -- much use for linings.
Phototypic: Of or pertaining to a phototype or phototypy.
Pinworm: A small nematoid worm (Oxyurus vermicularis), which is parasitic chiefly in the rectum of man. It is most common in children and aged persons.
Planter: One who, or that which, plants or sows; as, a planterof corn; a machine planter.
Planted: Fixed in place, as a projecting member wrought on a separate piece of stuff; as, a planted molding.
Playground: A piece of ground used for recreation; as, the playground of a school.
Principiation: Analysis into primary or elemental parts.
Platiniridium: A natural alloy of platinum and iridium occurring in grayish metallic rounded or cubical grains with platinum.
Preterpluperfect: Old name of the tense also called pluperfect.
Pennyweight: A troy weight containing twenty-four grains, or the twentieth part of a troy ounce; 1.555 grams; as, a pennyweight of gold or of arsenic.  It is abbreviated dwt or pwt.  It was anciently the weight of a silver penny, whence the name.
Pompano: Any one of several species of marine fishes of the genus Trachynotus, of which four species are found on the Atlantic coast of the United States; -- called also palometa.
Podium: A low wall, serving as a foundation, a substructure, or a terrace wall.
Porism: A proposition affirming the possibility of finding such conditions as will render a certain determinate problem indeterminate or capable of innumerable solutions.
Phototropism: The tendency of growing plant organs to move or curve under the influence of light. In ordinary use the term is practically synonymous with heliotropism.
Predeterminate: Determined beforehand; as, the predeterminate counsel of God.
Postfurca: One of the internal thoracic processes of the sternum of an insect.
Promorphological: Relating to promorphology; as, a promorphological conception.
Primeval: Belonging to the first ages; pristine; original; primitive; primary; as, the primeval innocence of man.
Pakistan: A country in South Asia formerly part of British India.
Ph\u00e6nogamia: The class of flowering plants including all which have true flowers with distinct floral organs; phanerogamia.
Paradigmatic: A writer of memoirs of religious persons, as examples of Christian excellence.
Pycnodont: Any fossil fish belonging to the Pycnodontini. They have numerous round, flat teeth, adapted for crushing.
Pseudo-cumene: A hydrocarbon of the aromatic series, metameric with mesitylene and cumene, found in coal tar, and obtained as a colorless liquid.
Pintail: A northern duck (Dafila acuta), native of both continents. The adult male has a long, tapering tail. Called also gray duck, piketail, piket-tail, spike-tail, split-tail, springtail, sea pheasant, and gray widgeon.
Purulent: Consisting of pus, or matter; partaking of the nature of pus; attended with suppuration; as, purulent inflammation.
Penteconter: A Grecian vessel with fifty oars.
Paramo: A high, bleak plateau or district, with stunted trees, and cold, damp atmosphere, as in the Andes, in South America.
Photolithograph: To produce (a picture, a copy) by the process of photolithography.
Putrefactive: Of or pertaining to putrefaction; as, the putrefactive smell or process.
Pigeonhole: To place in the pigeonhole of a case or cabinet; hence, to put away; to lay aside indefinitely; as, to pigeonhole a letter or a report.
Pleaseman: An officious person who courts favor servilely; a pickthank.
Phragmocone: The thin chambered shell attached to the anterior end of a belemnite.
Prelatic: Of or pertaining to prelates or prelacy; as, prelatical authority.
Phenic: Of, pertaining to, derived from, or resembling, phenyl or phenol.
pedaller: a person who rides a pedal-driven vehicle; a pedaler.
Prosecutor: One who prosecutes or carries on any purpose, plan, or business.
Prodromal: Of or pertaining to prodromes; as, the prodromal stage of a disease.
Priestliness: The quality or state of being priestly.
Pluralist: A clerk or clergyman who holds more than one ecclesiastical benefice.
Parvenu: An upstart; a man newly risen into notice.
Pluralism: The quality or state of being plural, or in the plural number.
Paleolith: A relic of the Paleolithic era.
Papaverine: An alkaloid found in opium.  It has a weaker therapeutic action than morphine.
Perthite: A kind of feldspar consisting of a laminated intertexture of albite and orthoclase, usually of different colors.
Particle: A minute part or portion of matter; a morsel; a little bit; an atom; a jot; as, a particle of sand, of wood, of dust.
Polynesians: The race of men native in Polynesia.
Powdering: a. & n. from Powder, v. t.
Presbytership: The office or station of a presbyter; presbyterate.
Parsonage: A certain portion of lands, tithes, and offerings, for the maintenance of the parson of a parish.
pipeline: A line of pipe with pumping machinery and apparatus for conveying liquids, gases, or finely divided solids, such as petroleum or natural gas, between distant points.
Picnic: To go on a picnic, or pleasure excursion; to eat in public fashion.
Parraqua: A curassow of the genus Ortalida, allied to the guan.
Pawnbroker: One who makes a business of lending money on the security of personal property pledged or deposited in his keeping.
Pickax: A pick with a point at one end, a transverse edge or blade at the other, and a handle inserted at the middle; a hammer with a flattened end for driving wedges and a pointed end for piercing as it strikes.
Plaided: Of the material of which plaids are made; tartan.
Paver: One who paves; one who lays a pavement.
Picaroon: One who plunders; especially, a plunderer of wrecks; a pirate; a corsair; a marauder; a sharper.
Piecener: One who supplies rolls of wool to the slubbing machine in woolen mills.
Photics: The science of light; -- a general term sometimes employed when optics is restricted to light as a producing vision.
Paterfamilias: The head of a family; in a large sense, the proprietor of an estate; one who is his own master.
Polite: To polish; to refine; to render polite.
Polity: The form or constitution of the civil government of a nation or state; the framework or organization by which the various departments of government are combined into a systematic whole.
Pentahedron: A solid figure having five sides.
Perjurer: One who is guilty of perjury; one who perjures or forswears, in any sense.
Prehistoric: Of or pertaining to a period before written history begins; as, the prehistoric ages; prehistoric man.
Postglenoid: Situated behind the glenoid fossa of the temporal bone.
Pitapat: A light, repeated sound; a pattering, as of the rain.
Panorpid: Any neuropterous insect of the genus Panorpa, and allied genera.  The larvæ feed on plant lice.
Proc\u0153lian: A reptile having procœlian vertebræ; one of the Procœlia.
parity checking: The process of performing a parity check.
Parabanic: Pertaining to, or designating, a nitrogenous acid which is obtained by the oxidation of uric acid, as a white crystalline substance (C3N2H2O3); -- also called oxalyl urea.
pro-life: Same as antiabortion; -- used by those opposed to voluntary abortion, to emphasize their view of a fetus as already living, and to avoid the negative tone of a word beginning with “anti-”.
partitioning: An analysis into mutually exclusive categories.
Piccolo: A small, shrill flute, the pitch of which is an octave higher than the ordinary flute; an octave flute.
Preordain: To ordain or appoint beforehand: to predetermine: to foreordain.
Propagative: Producing by propagation, or by a process of growth.
Potpie: A meat pie which is boiled instead of being baked.
Pullicate: A kind of checked cotton or silk handkerchief.
Pillwort: Any plant of the genus Pilularia; minute aquatic cryptograms, with small pill-shaped fruit; -- sometimes called peppergrass.
Pimiento: The Spanish sweet pepper, the fruit of which is used as a vegetable, to stuff olives, etc.; also the fruit itself.  Also called pimento.
Proclive: Having a tendency by nature; prone; proclivous.
Pleuropericardial: Of or pertaining to the pleura and pericardium.
Particulate: Having the form of a particle.
Patamar: A vessel resembling a grab, used in the coasting trade of Bombay and Ceylon.
Parascenium: One of two apartments adjoining the stage, probably used as robing rooms.
Prosecution: The act or process of prosecuting, or of endeavoring to gain or accomplish something; pursuit by efforts of body or mind; as, the prosecution of a scheme, plan, design, or undertaking; the prosecution of war.
Proctotomy: An incision into the rectum, as for the division of a stricture.
Politely: In a polished manner; so as to be smooth or glossy.
Prefecture: The office, position, or jurisdiction of a prefect; also, his official residence.
Polypteroidei: A suborder of existing ganoid fishes having numerous fins along the back. The bichir, or Polypterus, is the type. See Illust. under Crossopterygian.
Polyorama: A view of many objects; also, a sort of panorama with dissolving views.
Psilomelane: A hydrous oxide of manganese, occurring in smooth, botryoidal forms, and massive, and having an iron-black or steel-gray color.
Parquet circle: That part of the lower floor of a theater with seats at the rear of the parquet and beneath the galleries; -- called also, esp. in U. S., orchestra circle or parterre.
Piscicapture: Capture of fishes, as by angling.
Phosphoric: Of or pertaining to phosphorus; resembling, or containing, from us; specifically, designating those compounds in which phosphorus has a higher valence as contrasted with the phosphorous compounds.
Post-disseizin: A subsequent disseizin committed by one of lands which the disseizee had before recovered of the same disseizor; a writ founded on such subsequent disseizin, now abolished.
Postnatal: After birth; subsequent to birth; as, postnatal infanticide; postnatal diseases.
Pander: To act the part of a pander.
Pathfinder: One who discovers a way or path; one who explores untraversed regions.
Prefiguration: The act of prefiguring, or the state of being prefigured.
Pomiculture: The culture of fruit; pomology as an art.
Proscript: A proscription; a prohibition; an interdict.
Purlieu: Originally, the ground near a royal forest, which, having been unlawfully added to the forest, was afterwards severed from it, and disafforested so as to remit to the former owners their rights.
Pavonine: Like, or pertaining to, the genus Pavo.
Plicidentine: A form of dentine which shows sinuous lines of structure in a transverse section of the tooth.
Pullulate: To germinate; to bud; to multiply abundantly.
Plug board: A switchboard in which connections are made by means of plugs.
Postcornu: The posterior horn of each lateral ventricle of the brain.
Picturable: Capable of being pictured, or represented by a picture.
Paring: The act of cutting off the surface or extremites of anything.
Popelote: A word variously explained as “a little puppet,” “a little doll,” or “a young butterfly.”  Cf. Popet.
Peregrinator: One who peregrinates; one who travels about.
Polypode: An animal having many feet; a myriapod.
Perineurium: The connective tissue sheath which surrounds a bundle of nerve fibers. See Epineurium, and Neurilemma.
Process plate: A plate prepared by a mechanical process, esp. a photomechanical process.
Perinuclear: Of or pertaining to a nucleus; situated around a nucleus; as, the perinuclear protoplasm.
Pityroid: Having the form of, or resembling, bran.
Praseolite: A variety of altered iolite of a green color and greasy luster.
Pyla: The passage between the iter and optocœle in the brain.
Picard: One of a sect of Adamites in the fifteenth century; -- so called from one Picard of Flanders. See Adamite.
Prefectship: The office or jurisdiction of a prefect.
Probang: A slender elastic rod, as of whalebone, with a sponge on the end, for removing obstructions from the esophagus, etc.
Pin-eyed: Having the stigma visible at the throad of a gamopetalous corolla, while the stamens are concealed in the tube; -- said of dimorphous flowers. The opposite of thrum-eyed.
Polatouche: A flying squirrel (Sciuropterus volans) native of Northern Europe and Siberia; -- called also minene.
Pugil: As much as is taken up between the thumb and two first fingers.
