Panic: A sudden, overpowering fright; esp., a sudden and groundless fright; terror inspired by a trifling cause or a misapprehension of danger; as, the troops were seized with a panic; they fled in a panic.
Peccable: Liable to sin; subject to transgress the divine law.
Panderism: The employment, arts, or practices of a pander.
Pantograph: An instrument for copying plans, maps, and other drawings, on the same, or on a reduced or an enlarged, scale.
Pluri-: A combining form from L. plus, pluris, more, many; as pluriliteral.
Pulmocutaneous: Of or pertaining to the lungs and the akin; as, the pulmocutaneous arteries of the frog.
Phytologist: One skilled in phytology; a writer on plants; a botanist.
Paly: Divided into four or more equal parts by perpendicular lines, and of two different tinctures disposed alternately.
Pall-mall: A game formerly common in England, in which a wooden ball was driven with a mallet through an elevated hoop or ring of iron.  The name was also given to the mallet used, to the place where the game was played, and to the street, in London, still called Pall Mall.
Palp: To have a distinct touch or feeling of; to feel.
Pericarpial: Of or pertaining to a pericarp.
Papilloma: A tumor formed by hypertrophy of the papillæ of the skin or mucous membrane, as a corn or a wart.
Philistinism: The condition, character, aims, and habits of the class called Philistines. See Philistine, 3.
Palo: A pole or timber of any kind; -- in the names of trees.
Pale: To inclose with pales, or as with pales; to encircle; to encompass; to fence off.
Pachycephala: A genus of arborial insectivorous birds.
Pairing: The act or process of uniting or arranging in pairs or couples.
Pomfret: One of two or more species of marine food fishes of the genus Stromateus (Stromateus niger, Stromateus argenteus) native of Southern Europe and Asia.
Pleading: The act of advocating, defending, or supporting, a cause by arguments.
Pikestaff: The staff, or shaft, of a pike.
Prosoc\u0153le: The entire cavity of the prosencephalon.
Pulsion: The act of driving forward; propulsion; -- opposed to suction or traction.
Prairial: The ninth month of the French Republican calendar, which dated from September 22, 1792. It began May, 20, and ended June 18. See Vendemiaire.
Paramaleic: Pertaining to, or designating, an acid obtained from malic acid, and now called fumaric acid.
Pre\u00ebminence: The quality or state of being preëminent; superiority in prominence or in excellence; distinction above others in quality, rank, etc.; rarely, in a bad sense, superiority or notoriety in evil; as, preëminence in honor.
Pyroxylic: Derived from wood by distillation; -- formerly used in designating crude wood spirit.
Presspack: To pack, or prepare for packing, by means of a press.
Parkinsonia: A small genus of spiny shrubs or small trees.
Pyridic: Related to, or formed from, pyridin or its homologues; as, the pyridic bases.
Periwig: To dress with a periwig, or with false hair.
Panic-stricken: Struck with a panic, or sudden fear; thrown into a state of intense fear; as, trying to keep back the panic-stricken crowd.
-phore: Combining form meaning bearer of the element preceding; as, ionophore; semaphore.
Padder: One who, or that which, pads.
Poon: A name for several East Indian, or their wood, used for the masts and spars of vessels, as Calophyllum angustifolium, Calophyllum inophullum, and Sterculia fœtida; -- called also peon.
Parauque: A bird (Nyctidromus albicollis) ranging from Texas to South America.  It is allied to the night hawk and goatsucker.
Pseudonymous: Bearing a false or fictitious name; as, a pseudonymous work.
Prostitute: A woman giver to indiscriminate lewdness; a strumpet; a harlot.
Palliation: The act of palliating, or state of being palliated; extenuation; excuse; as, the palliation of faults, offenses, vices.
Pinner: One who pins or impounds cattle. See Pin, v. t.
Pioneer: To go before, and prepare or open a way for; to act as pioneer.
Pyrothonide: A kind of empyreumatic oil produced by the combustion of textures of hemp, linen, or cotton in a copper vessel, -- formerly used as a remedial agent.
Pearly: Containing pearls; abounding with, or yielding, pearls; as, pearly shells.
Pharmacolite: A hydrous arsenate of lime, usually occurring in silky fibers of a white or grayish color.
Pebrine: An epidemic disease of the silkworm, characterized by the presence of minute vibratory corpuscles in the blood.
Perditionable: Capable of being ruined; worthy of perdition.
Paduasoy: A rich and heavy silk stuff.
Pilocarpine: An alkaloid extracted from jaborandi (Pilocarpus pennatifolius) as a white amorphous or crystalline substance which has a peculiar effect on the vasomotor system.
Pterygoquadrate: Of, pertaining to, or representing the pterygoid and quadrate bones or cartilages.
Phosgene: Producing, or produced by, the action of light; -- used specifically to designate a gas also called carbonyl chloride. See Carbonyl.
Purpresture: Wrongful encroachment upon another's property; esp., any encroachment upon, or inclosure of, that which should be common or public, as highways, rivers, harbors, forts, etc.
Pruner: One who prunes, or removes, what is superfluous.
Preglacial: Prior to the glacial or drift period.
Pinus: A large genus of evergreen coniferous trees, mostly found in the northern hemisphere. The genus formerly included the firs, spruces, larches, and hemlocks, but is now limited to those trees which have the primary leaves of the branchlets reduced to mere scales, and the secondary ones (pine needles) acicular, and usually in fascicles of two to seven. See Pine.
Philatory: A kind of transparent reliquary with an ornamental top.
Patriarchy: The jurisdiction of a patriarch; patriarchship.
Puritanic: Of or pertaining to the Puritans, or to their doctrines and practice.
Pyrocitric: Pertaining to, or designating, any one of three acids obtained by the distillation of citric acid, and called respectively citraconic, itaconic, and mesaconic acid.
Predial: Consisting of land or farms; landed; as, predial estate; that is, real estate.
Puckery: Producing, or tending to produce, a pucker; as, a puckery taste.
Plumosity: The quality or state of being plumose.
Parcenary: The holding or occupation of an inheritable estate which descends from the ancestor to two or more persons; coheirship.
Porthole: An embrasure in a ship's side. See 3d Port.
Pewterer: One whose occupation is to make utensils of pewter; a pewtersmith.
Phase rule: A generalization with regard to systems of chemical equilibrium, discovered by Prof. J. Willard Gibbs. It may be stated thus: The degree of variableness (number of degrees of freedom) of a system is equal to the number of components minus the number of phases, plus two. Thus, if the components be salt and water, and the phases salt, ice, saturated solution, and vapor, the system is invariant, that is, there is only one set of conditions under which these four phases can exist in equilibrium. If only three phases be considered, the system is univariant, that is, the fixing of one condition, as temperature, determines the others.
Paddlefish: A large ganoid fish (Polyodon spathula) found in the rivers of the Mississippi Valley.  It has a long spatula-shaped snout.  Called also duck-billed cat, and spoonbill sturgeon.
Pantechnicon: A depository or place where all sorts of manufactured articles are collected for sale.
Pinule: One of the sights of an astrolabe.
Psilanthropist: One who believes that Christ was a mere man.
Phototonus: A motile condition in plants resulting from exposure to light.
Perdix: A genus of birds including the common European partridge. Formerly the word was used in a much wider sense to include many allied genera.
Pelton wheel: A form of impulse turbine or water wheel, consisting of a row of double cup-shaped buckets arranged round the rim of a wheel and actuated by one or more jets of water playing into the cups at high velocity.
Percipient: Having the faculty of perception; perceiving; as, a percipient being.
Plowbote: Wood or timber allowed to a tenant for the repair of instruments of husbandry. See Bote.
Pyroacetic: Pertaining to, and designating, a substance (acetone) obtained by the distillation of the acetates. It is now called also pyroacetic ether, and formerly was called pyroacetic spirit.
Prolifical: Producing young or fruit abundantly; fruitful; prolific.
Pollack: A marine gadoid food fish of Europe (Pollachius virens). Called also greenfish, greenling, lait, leet, lob, lythe, and whiting pollack.
Phyllocladium: A flattened stem or branch which more or less resembles a leaf, and performs the function of a leaf as regards respiration and assimilation.
Pnyx: The place at Athens where the meetings of the people were held for making decrees, etc.
paraformaldehyde: A polymer of formaldehyde obtained as a white crystalline substance by concentration of a formaldehyde solution.  Formula (CH20)n.  It dissolves in hot water with the release of formaldehyde, and is used as a disinfectant.
Pactional: Of the nature of, or by means of, a paction.
Pro: For, on, or in behalf of, the affirmative side; -- in contrast with con.
Prudish: Like a prude; very formal, precise, or reserved; affectedly severe in virtue; as, a prudish woman; prudish manners.
Perlid: Any insect of the genus Perla, or family Perlidæ. See Stone fly, under Stone.
Poldway: A kind of coarse bagging, -- used for coal sacks.
Polychrest: A medicine that serves for many uses, or that cures many diseases.
Politize: To play the politician; to dispute as politicians do.
Pyrogallate: A salt of pyrogallic acid; an ether of pyrogallol.
Pantomimist: An actor in pantomime; also, a composer of pantomimes.
Penitencer: A priest who heard confession and enjoined penance in extraordinary cases.
Partisanship: The state of being a partisan, or adherent to a party; feelings or conduct characteristic of a partisan.
Parameter: A constant number which is part of a theory, function, or calculation, whose value is not determined by the form of the theory or equation itself, and may in some cases be arbitrary assigned.
Paracorolla: A secondary or inner corolla; a corona, as of the Narcissus.
Predicamental: Of or pertaining to a predicament.
pitprop: A wooden prop used to support the roof of a mine temporarily.
Palmcrist: The palma Christi. (Jonah iv. 6, margin, and Douay version, note.)
Peliom: A variety of iolite, of a smoky blue color; pelioma.
Pulpy: Like pulp; consisting of pulp; soft; fleshy; succulent; as, the pulpy covering of a nut; the pulpy substance of a peach or a cherry.
Plucky: Having pluck or courage; characterized by pluck; displaying pluck; courageous; spirited; as, a plucky race.
Prosal: Of or pertaining to prose; prosaic.
Pyroligneous: Pertaining to, or designating, the acid liquid obtained in the distillation of wood, consisting essentially of impure acetic acid.
Plagiotropic: Having the longer axis inclined away from the vertical line.
Pickaback: On the back or shoulders; as, to ride pickback.
Postoblongata: The posterior part of the medulla oblongata.
Paganic: Of or pertaining to pagans or paganism; heathenish; paganish.
pancreatin: One of the digestive enzymes of the pancreatic juice.
Procreative: Having the power to beget; generative.
Palestrian: Of or pertaining to the palestra, or to wrestling.
Protrude: To shoot out or forth; to be thrust forward; to extend beyond a limit; to project.
-pod: A combining form or suffix from Gr. poy`s, podo`s, foot; as, decapod, an animal having ten feet; phyllopod, an animal having leaflike feet; myriapod, hexapod.
Pearlash: A white amorphous or granular substance which consists principally of potassium carbonate, and has a strong alkaline reaction.  It is obtained by lixiviating wood ashes, and evaporating the lye, and has been an important source of potassium compounds.  It is used in making soap, glass, etc.
Predetermination: The act of previous determination; a purpose formed beforehand; as, the predetermination of God's will.
Push button: A simple device, resembling a button in form, so arranged that pushing it closes an electric circuit, as of an electric bell; -- called also button.
Phenol: A white or pinkish crystalline substance, C6H5OH, produced by the destructive distillation of many organic bodies, as wood, coal, etc., and obtained from the heavy oil from coal tar.
Phyllopodous: Of or pertaining to the Phyllopoda.
Pseudo-dipteral: Falsely or imperfectly dipteral, as a temple with the inner range of columns surrounding the cella omitted, so that the space between the cella wall and the columns is very great, being equal to two intercolumns and one column.
Pyrus: A genus of rosaceous trees and shrubs having pomes for fruit. It includes the apple, crab apple, pear, chokeberry, sorb, and mountain ash.
Pantomimic: Of or pertaining to the pantomime; representing by dumb show.
Proleptics: The art and science of predicting in medicine.
Phrenics: That branch of science which relates to the mind; mental philosophy.
Pellicular: Of or pertaining to a pellicle.
Prismatically: In the form or manner of a prism; by means of a prism.
Pretzel: A kind of German biscuit or cake in the form of a twisted ring, salted on the outside.
Prunella: A smooth woolen stuff, generally black, used for making shoes; a kind of lasting; -- formerly used also for clergymen's gowns.
Prunelle: A kind of small and very acid French plum; -- applied especially to the stoned and dried fruit.
Pitots tube: A bent tube used to determine the velocity of running water, by placing the curved end under water, and observing the height to which the fluid rises in the tube; a kind of current meter.
Picromel: A colorless viscous substance having a bitter-sweet taste.
Prunello: A species of dried plum; prunelle.
Pharaonic: Of or pertaining to the Pharaohs, or kings of ancient Egypt.
Pterobranchia: An order of marine Bryozoa, having a bilobed lophophore and an axial cord. The genus Rhabdopleura is the type.  Called also Podostomata.  See Rhabdopleura.
Preservation: The act or process of preserving, or keeping safe; the state of being preserved, or kept from injury, destruction, or decay; security; safety; as, preservation of life, fruit, game, etc.; a picture in good preservation.
Protectorship: The office of a protector or regent; protectorate.
Plastography: The art of forming figures in any plastic material.
Peter: To become exhausted; to run out; to fail; -- used generally with out; as, that mine has petered out.
Precursorship: The position or condition of a precursor.
Postprandial: Happening, or done, after dinner; after-dinner; as, postprandial speeches.
Pleurobrachia: A genus of ctenophores having an ovate body and two long plumose tentacles.
Pravity: Deterioration; degeneracy; corruption; especially, moral crookedness; moral perversion; perverseness; depravity; as, the pravity of human nature.
Phal\u00e6nid: Any moth of the family Phalænidæ, of which the cankerworms are examples; a geometrid.
pallor: Paleness; want of color; pallidity; as, pallor of the complexion.
Poonga oil: A kind of oil used in India for lamps, and for boiling with dammar for pitching vessels. It is pressed from the seeds of a leguminous tree (Pongamia glabra).
Pachydermatous: Of or pertaining to the pachyderms.
Porismatic: Of or pertaining to a porism; poristic.
Persuasive: That which persuades; an inducement; an incitement; an exhortation.
Preantenultimate: Being or indicating the fourth syllable from the end of a word, or that before the antepenult.
Patronate: The right or duty of a patron; patronage.
Pimpillo: A West Indian name for the prickly pear (Opuntia); -- called also pimploes.
Purging: The act of cleansing; excessive evacuations; especially, diarrhea.
Periodicalist: One who publishes, or writes for, a periodical.
Pachyglossal: Having a thick tongue; -- applied to a group of lizards (Pachyglossæ), including the iguanas and agamas.
Patois: A dialect peculiar to the illiterate classes; a provincial form of speech.
Pawl: To stop with a pawl; to drop the pawls off.
Pawn: To give or deposit in pledge, or as security for the payment of money borrowed; to put in pawn; to pledge; as, to pawn one's watch.
Poy: A support; -- used in composition; as, teapoy.
Pontific: Relating to, or consisting of, pontiffs or priests.
Preoperculum: The anterior opercular bone in fishes.
Poh: An exclamation expressing contempt or disgust; bah !
Poi: A national food of the Hawaiians, made by baking and pounding the kalo (or taro) root, and reducing it to a thin paste, which is allowed to ferment.
Pyromalic: Pertaining to, or designating, an acid now called maleic acid.
Pod: To swell; to fill; also, to produce pods.
Poa: A genus of grasses, including a great number of species, as the kinds called meadow grass, Kentucky blue grass, June grass, and spear grass (which see).
Pythoness: The priestess who gave oracular answers at Delphi in Greece.
Paradoxides: A genus of large trilobites characteristic of the primordial formations.
Periscopic: Viewing all around, or on all sides.
Plonge: To cleanse, as open drains which are entered by the tide, by stirring up the sediment when the tide ebbs.
Preventingly: So as to prevent or hinder.
Preadamitic: Existing or occurring before Adam; preadamic; as, preadamitic periods.
Pepperer: A grocer; -- formerly so called because he sold pepper.
Polyautography: The act or practice of multiplying copies of one's own handwriting, or of manuscripts, by printing from stone, -- a species of lithography.
Prediastolic: Preceding the diastole of the heart; as, a prediastolic friction sound.
Proto-: A combining form prefix signifying first, primary, primordial; as, protomartyr, the first martyr; protomorphic, primitive in form; protoplast, a primordial organism; prototype, protozoan.
Pasteurization: A process devised by Pasteur for preventing or checking fermentation in fluids, such as wines, milk, etc., by exposure to a temperature of 140° F., thus destroying the vitality of the contained microorganisms.
Propylon: The porch, vestibule, or entrance of an edifice.
Prettiness: The quality or state of being pretty; -- used sometimes in a disparaging sense.
Primitia: The first fruit; the first year's whole profit of an ecclesiastical preferment.
Piarist: One of a religious order who are the regular clerks of the Scuole Pie (religious schools), an institute of secondary education, founded at Rome in the last years of the 16th century.
Paragraph: Originally, a marginal mark or note, set in the margin to call attention to something in the text, e. g., a change of subject; now, the character ¶, commonly used in the text as a reference mark to a footnote, or to indicate the place of a division into sections.
Paraxanthin: A crystalline substance closely related to xanthin, present in small quantity in urine.
Puncticular: Comprised in, or like, a point; exact.
Periproctitis: Inflammation of the tissues about the rectum.
Postal: Belonging to the post office or mail service; as, postal arrangements; postal authorities.
Pregnable: Capable of being entered, taken, or captured; expugnable; as, a pregnable fort.
Provision: To supply with food; to victual; as, to provision a garrison.
Penny: Worth or costing one penny; as, penny candy.
Pickthank: One who strives to put another under obligation; an officious person; hence, a flatterer. Used also adjectively.
Plethysmography: The study, by means of the plethysmograph, of the variations in size of a limb, and hence of its blood supply.
Prehensory: Adapted to seize or grasp; prehensile.
Pitter: To make a pattering sound; to murmur; as, pittering streams.
Painstaker: One who takes pains; one careful and faithful in all work.
Palmaceae: A natural family of chiefly tropical trees and shrubs and vines usually having a tall columnar trunk bearing a crown of very large leaves; coextensive with the order Palmales.
Pitted: Marked with little pits, as in smallpox. See Pit, v. t., 2.
Palatable: Agreeable to the palate or taste; savory; hence, acceptable; pleasing; as, palatable food; palatable advice.  Opposite of unpalatable.
Pyrope: A variety of garnet, of a poppy or blood-red color, frequently with a tinge of orange. It is used as a gem. See the Note under Garnet.
Pesthouse: A house or hospital for persons who are infected with any pestilential disease.
Pedal: A lever or key acted on by the foot, as in the pianoforte to raise the dampers, or in the organ to open and close certain pipes; a treadle, as in a lathe or a bicycle.
Protactinium: The radioactive chemical element, of atomic number 91;  Atomic symbol Pa;  at. wt. of longest-lived isotope, 231 (T1/2 = 32,500 yrs.)  Also called brevium, Uranium X2 and UX2.
pants: A garment extending from the waist to the knee or ankle, covering each leg separately.
Parentation: Something done or said in honor of the dead; obsequies.
Playgoer: One who frequents playhouses, or attends dramatic performances.
Punctator: One who marks with points. specifically, one who writes Hebrew with points; -- applied to a Masorite.
Podurid: Any species of Podura or allied genera.
Pubescence: The quality or state of being pubescent, or of having arrived at puberty.
Pycnometer: A specific gravity bottle; a standard flask for measuring and comparing the densities of liquids.
Phosphoroscope: An apparatus for observing the phosphorescence produced in different bodies by the action of light, and for measuring its duration.
Placket: A petticoat, esp. an under petticoat; hence, a cant term for a woman.
Precedent: Something done or said that may serve as an example to authorize a subsequent act of the same kind; an authoritative example.
Psora: A cutaneous disease; especially, the itch.
Propensity: The quality or state of being propense; natural inclination; disposition to do good or evil; bias; bent; tendency.
paracentric: Deviating from circularity; changing the distance from a center.
Prevalence: The quality or condition of being prevalent; superior strength, force, or influence; general existence, reception, or practice; wide extension; as, the prevalence of virtue, of a fashion, or of a disease; the prevalence of a rumor.
Pipelaying: The laying of conducting pipes underground, as for water, gas, etc.
Pudgy: Short and fat or sturdy; dumpy; podgy; as, a short, pudgy little man; a pudgy little hand.
Pardonableness: The quality or state of being pardonable; as, the pardonableness of sin.
Pricklouse: A tailor; -- so called in contempt.
Preternatural: Beyond of different from what is natural, or according to the regular course of things, but not clearly supernatural or miraculous; strange; inexplicable; extraordinary; uncommon; irregular; abnormal; as, a preternatural appearance; a preternatural stillness; a preternatural presentation (in childbirth) or labor.
Pearlaceous: Resembling pearl or mother-of-pearl; pearly in quality or appearance.
Penicillinase: An enzyme which destroys the antibacterial activity of penicillin by hydrolyzing the amide bond in the beta-lactam ring.  Many penicillinases are known, and are produced by a wide variety of bacteria.  The production of penicillinase is one of the mechanisms by which bacteria may become resistant to penicillins.  Penicillinase production in various bacterial species may be induced, i.e., it may occur only when stimulated by the presence of penicillin in the culture medium, or it may be constitutive, i.e., it may occur whenever the cells are producing protein.  Molecular weights of the various penicillinases tend to cluster near 50,000.
Pharisean: Following the practice of Pharisees; Pharisaic.
Parclose: A screen separating a chapel from the body of the church.
Pluviometrical: Of or pertaining to a pluviometer; determined by a pluviometer.
Pipe clay: A plastic, unctuous clay of a grayish white color, -- used in making tobacco pipes and various kinds of earthenware, in scouring cloth, and in cleansing soldiers' equipments.
Preserve: That which is preserved; fruit, etc., seasoned and kept by suitable preparation; esp., fruit cooked with sugar; -- commonly in the plural.
Pectinibranch: One of the Pectinibranchiata.  Also used adjectively.
Plasmodium: A jellylike mass of free protoplasm, without any union of amœboid cells, and endowed with life and power of motion.
Poachard: A common European duck (Aythya ferina); -- called also goldhead, poker, and fresh-water widgeon, or red-headed widgeon.
Pimpernel: A plant of the genus Anagallis, of which one species (Anagallis arvensis) has small flowers, usually scarlet, but sometimes purple, blue, or white, which speedily close at the approach of bad weather.
Pecan: A species of hickory (Carya olivæformis), growing in North America, chiefly in the Mississippi valley and in Texas, where it is one of the largest of forest trees; also, its fruit, a smooth, oblong nut, an inch or an inch and a half long, with a thin shell and well-flavored meat.
Preordination: The act of foreordaining: previous determination.
Pediculati: An order of fishes including the anglers. See Illust. of Angler and Batfish.
Preventer: One who goes before; one who forestalls or anticipates another.
Purpurogenous: Having the power to produce a purple color; as, the purpurogenous membrane, or choroidal epithelium, of the eye. See Visual purple, under Visual.
Perineoplasty: The act or process of restoring an injured perineum.
passenger pigeon: A once common wild pigeon of North America (Ectopistes migratorius), now extinct.  It was so called on account of its extensive migrations.
Pott: A size of paper. See under Paper.
Pewtery: Belonging to, or resembling, pewter; as, a pewtery taste.
Punctual: Consisting in a point; limited to a point; unextended.
Purificative: Having power to purify; tending to cleanse.
Platinous: Of, pertaining to, or containing, platinum; -- used specifically to designate those compounds in which the element has a lower valence, as contrasted with the platinic compounds; as, platinous chloride (PtCl2).
Prestation: A payment of money; a toll or duty; also, the rendering of a service.
Polyphase: Having or producing two or more phases; multiphase; as, a polyphase machine, a machine producing two or more pressure waves of electro-motive force, differing in phase; a polyphase current.
Pinnatilobate: Having lobes arranged in a pinnate manner.
Pamprodactylous: Having all the toes turned forward, as the colies.
Plantation: The act or practice of planting, or setting in the earth for growth.
Pre\u00ebmption: The act or right of purchasing before others.
Priesthood: The office or character of a priest; the priestly function.
Pasty: A pie consisting usually of meat wholly surrounded with a crust made of a sheet of paste, and often baked without a dish; a meat pie.
Post-captain: A captain of a war vessel whose name appeared, or was “posted,” in the seniority list of the British navy, as distinguished from a commander whose name was not so posted. The term was also used in the United States navy; but no such commission as post-captain was ever recognized in either service, and the term has fallen into disuse.
Pulpitical: Of or pertaining to the pulpit; suited to the pulpit.
Paste: To unite with paste; to fasten or join by means of paste.
Postpalatine: Situated behind the palate, or behind the palatine bones.
Promorphology: Crystallography of organic forms; -- a division of morphology created by Haeckel. It is essentially stereometric, and relates to a mathematical conception of organic forms. See Tectology.
Protopope: One of the clergy of first rank in the lower order of secular clergy; an archpriest; -- called also protopapas.
panzer: Equipped with armored vehicles; armored; as, a panzer division.
Pronuncial: Of or pertaining to pronunciation; pronunciative.
Pterygomaxillary: Of or pertaining to the inner pterygoid plate, or pterygoid bone, and the lower jaw.
pabular: Of, pertaining to, or fit for, pabulum or food; affording food.
Presumption: The act of presuming, or believing upon probable evidence; the act of assuming or taking for granted; belief upon incomplete proof.
Percarbide: A compound containing a relatively large amount of carbon.
Peirameter: A dynamometer for measuring the force required to draw wheel carriages on roads of different constructions.
Postliminium: The return to his own country, and his former privileges, of a person who had gone to sojourn in a foreign country, or had been banished, or taken by an enemy.
Prehend: To lay hold of; to seize.
Premunition: The act of fortifying or guarding against objections.
Pettiness: The quality or state of being petty or paltry; littleness; meanness.
Pyxidium: A pod which divides circularly into an upper and lower half, of which the former acts as a kind of lid, as in the pimpernel and purslane.
Precondition: A previous or antecedent condition; a preliminary condition.
Polyembryonate: Consisting of, or having, several embryos; polyembryonic.
Periodoscope: A table or other means for calculating the periodical functions of women.
Pozzuolana: Volcanic ashes from Pozzuoli, in Italy, used in the manufacture of a kind of mortar which hardens under water.
Peritoneum: The smooth serous membrane which lines the cavity of the abdomen, or the whole body cavity when there is no diaphragm, and, turning back, surrounds the viscera, forming a closed, or nearly closed, sac.
Politzerization: The act of inflating the middle ear by blowing air up the nose during the act of swallowing; -- so called from Prof. Politzer of Vienna, who first practiced it.
Permians: A tribe belonging to the Finnic race, and inhabiting a portion of Russia.
Proverbial: Mentioned or comprised in a proverb; used as a proverb; hence, commonly known; as, a proverbial expression; his meanness was proverbial.
Pickedness: The state of being sharpened; pointedness.
Pierre-perdu: Blocks of stone or concrete heaped loosely in the water to make a foundation (as for a sea wall), a breakwater, a mole, etc.
pasties: A pair of adhesive patches worn to cover the nipples of exotic dancers and striptease performers.
Parliamentarian: One who adhered to the Parliament, in opposition to King Charles I.
Provant: Provided for common or general use, as in an army; hence, common in quality; inferior.
Pillworm: Any myriapod of the genus Iulus and allied genera which rolls up spirally; a galleyworm. See Illust. under Myriapod.
Pining: Languishing; drooping; wasting away, as with longing.
Promorphologist: One versed in the science of promorphology.
Platinichloric: Of, pertaining to, or designating, an acid consisting of platinic chloride and hydrochloric acid, and obtained as a brownish red crystalline substance, called platinichloric, or chloroplatinic, acid.
Promiscuousness: The quality or state of being promiscuous.
Phlebology: A branch of anatomy which treats of the veins.
Panification: The act or process of making bread.
Pincushion: A small cushion, in which pins may be stuck for use.
Palmidactyles: A group of wading birds having the toes webbed, as the avocet.
Pillar: Having a support in the form of a pillar, instead of legs; as, a pillar drill.
Papilla: Any minute nipplelike projection; as, the papillæ of the tongue.
Population: The act or process of populating; multiplication of inhabitants.
Ptolemaic: Of or pertaining to Ptolemy, the geographer and astronomer.
Passenger mile: A unit of measurement of the passenger transportation performed by a railroad during a given period, usually a year, the total of which consists of the sum of the miles traversed by all the passengers on the road in the period in question.
Podarthrum: The foot joint; in birds, the joint between the metatarsus and the toes.
pasta: Any of a variety of edible unleavened doughey preparations made from flour, eggs and water, originating in Italy, and shaped into various forms, such as solid strings (as spaghetti), hollow tubes, or layered squares (ravioli).  They may be mixed with various sauces, often having a tomato base, or filled with meat or cheese fillings.
Pestiferous: Pest-bearing; pestilential; noxious to health; malignant; infectious; contagious; as, pestiferous bodies.
Paintless: Not capable of being painted or described.
Permeate: To pass through the pores or interstices of; to penetrate and pass through without causing rupture or displacement; -- applied especially to fluids which pass through substances of loose texture; as, water permeates sand.
Patriotism: Love of country; devotion to the welfare of one's country; the virtues and actions of a patriot; the passion which inspires one to serve one's country.
Populin: A glycoside, related to salicin, found in the bark of certain species of the poplar (Populus), and extracted as a sweet white crystalline substance.
Pointed: Sharp; having a sharp point; as, a pointed rock.
Plutocratic: Of or pertaining to plutocracy; as, plutocratic ideas.
peeing: Urination; -- an informal term; as, he doesn't like peeing out of doors.
Parumbilical: Near the umbilicus; -- applied especially to one or more small veins which, in man, connect the portal vein with the epigastric veins in the front wall of the abdomen.
Pointer: One who, or that which, points.
Powerable: Capable of being effected or accomplished by the application of power; possible.
Palmigrade: Putting the whole foot upon the ground in walking, as some mammals.
Plantar: Of or pertaining to the sole of the foot; as, the plantar arteries.
Pliohippus: An extinct genus of horses from the Pliocene deposits. Each foot had a single toe (or hoof), as in the common horse.
Perspire: To emit or evacuate through the pores of the skin; to sweat; to excrete through pores.
Patristic: Of or pertaining to the Fathers of the Christian church.
Plantal: Belonging to plants; as, plantal life.
Peephole: A hole, or crevice, through which one may peep without being discovered.
Penman: One who uses the pen; a writer; esp., one skilled in the use of the pen; a calligrapher; a writing master.
Puseyite: One who holds the principles of Puseyism; -- often used opprobriously.
Phascolome: A marsupial of the genus Phascolomys; a wombat.
Pi\u00f1on: The edible seed of several species of pine; also, the tree producing such seeds, as Pinus Pinea of Southern Europe, and Pinus Parryana, cembroides, edulis, and monophylla, the nut pines of Western North America.
Phallism: The worship of the generative principle in nature, symbolized by the phallus.
Parovarium: A group of tubules, a remnant of the Wolffian body, often found near the ovary or oviduct; the epoöphoron.
Pedantize: To play the pedant; to use pedantic expressions.
Picayune: A small coin of the value of six and a quarter cents. See Fippenny bit.
Placodermal: Of or pertaining to the placoderms; like the placoderms.
Paymaster-general: In the United States army, an officer of the rank of brigadier general, who commands the pay department, which is charged with the payment of the officers and men.
Peregrination: A traveling from one country to another; a wandering; sojourn in foreign countries.
Plagueful: Abounding, or infecting, with plagues; pestilential; as, plagueful exhalations.
Pseudopupa: A stage intermediate between the larva and pupa of bees and certain other hymenopterous insects.
Plagueless: Free from plagues or the plague.
Propodium: The anterior portion of the foot of a mollusk.
Pulsation: A beating or throbbing, especially of the heart or of an artery, or in an inflamed part; a beat of the pulse.
Phyma: A tubercle on any external part of the body.
Pr\u00e6munire: To subject to the penalties of præmunire.
Priestcap: A form of redan, so named from its shape; -- called also swallowtail.
Paramitome: The fluid portion of the protoplasm of a cell.
Proteose: One of a class of soluble products formed in the digestion of proteids with gastric and pancreatic juice, and also by the hydrolytic action of boiling dilute acids on proteids. Proteoses are divided into the two groups, the primary and secondary proteoses.
Plumage: The entire clothing of a bird.
Pr\u00e6cornu: The anterior horn of each lateral ventricle of the brain.
Punctuality: The quality or state of being punctual; especially, adherence to the exact time of an engagement; exactness.
Preconization: A publishing by proclamation; a public proclamation.
Patera: A saucerlike vessel of earthenware or metal, used by the Greeks and Romans in libations and sacrifices.
Patronize: To act as patron toward; to support; to countenance; to favor; to aid.
Periclinium: The involucre which surrounds the common receptacle in composite flowers.
Percesoces: An order of fishes including the gray mullets (Mugil), the barracudas, the silversides, and other related fishes.  So called from their relation both to perches and to pikes.
Plating: The art or process of covering anything with a plate or plates, or with metal, particularly of overlaying a base or dull metal with a thin plate of precious or bright metal, as by mechanical means or by electro-magnetic deposition.
pachonta: A substance resembling gutta-percha, and used to adulterate it, obtained from the East Indian tree Isonandra acuminata.
Platinic: Of, pertaining to, or containing, platinum; -- used specifically to designate those compounds in which the element has a higher valence, as contrasted with the platinous compounds; as, platinic chloride (PtCl4).
Potance: The stud in which the bearing for the lower pivot of the verge is made.
Paracentesis: The perforation of a cavity of the body with a trocar, aspirator, or other suitable instrument, for the evacuation of effused fluid, pus, or gas; tapping.
Pass-key: A key for opening more locks than one; a master key.
Pilotage: The pilot's skill or knowledge, as of coasts, rocks, bars, and channels.
Parastichy: A secondary spiral in phyllotaxy, as one of the evident spirals in a pine cone.
parthenogenesis: The production of new individuals from virgin females by means of ova which have the power of developing without the intervention of the male element; the production, without fertilization, of cells capable of germination.  It is one of the phenomena of alternate generation.  Cf. Heterogamy, and Metagenesis.
P\u00e6an: An ancient Greek hymn in honor of Apollo as a healing deity, and, later, a song addressed to other deities.
Pronominal: Belonging to, or partaking of the nature of, a pronoun.
Peleus: A king of the Myrmidons and father of Achilles; he was the son of Aeachus.
Picker: One who, or that which, picks, in any sense, -- as, one who uses a pick; one who gathers; a thief; a pick; a pickax; as, a cotton picker.
Pre\u00ebngagement: Prior engagement, obligation, or attachment, as by contract, promise, or affection.
Paling: Pales, in general; a fence formed with pales or pickets; a limit; an inclosure.
